column2: Phil Mickelson’s improbable nine-stroke victory over Tiger Woods has to test the thinking that Woods’s career swoon is only temporary.
Six men damaged Buddhist figures they believed were idols, officials said as worry increases that extremists are gaining a foothold in the Sunni Muslim nation.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Iran for the bombs on Monday aimed at Israeli Embassy personnel in New Delhi and Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia.
An Indonesian court on Monday indicted Umar Patek on charges including premeditated murder for his alleged role in the 2002 terrorist bombings on the resort island of Bali.
President Obama proposed an $8 billion program with the goal of training two million workers for well-paying jobs in high-demand industries.
Navi Pillay publicly castigated Syria’s leaders, accusing them of intensifying their deadly crackdown after the Security Council failed to reach a solution.
Pakistan’s highest court indicted Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on charges of contempt of court on Monday, escalating a confrontation that could cost Mr. Gilani his job.
“Though she’d never talked to MacGregor, everything she’d learned about the seventy-three-year-old recluse had turned MacGregor into Madeleine’s favorite biologist.”
“Tell them about the pheromones,” Madeleine said.
Tarsiers, five-inch-tall creatures found in Southeast Asia, produce calls that are entirely in ultrasound, above the range of human hearing, researchers find.

In the past, researchers had guessed that the new continent, often called Amasia, would form either over the Atlantic Ocean near present-day Africa, or 180 degrees away, on the other side of the world.
Articles in this series are exploring the struggle to shape the culture of authoritarian China.

FOLLENDER--Irma R. (nee Haibloom), 80, of Boca Raton, Florida and formerly of Teaneck and Fort Lee New Jersey died on February 12, 2012, surrounded by her loving family after a courageous 36-year battle with breast cancer. Mrs. Follender was born in New York City on May 20, 1931, the daughter of Pauline and Abraham Haibloom. She is survived by her loving husband of 58 years, Judge David B. Follender, and her three children Jonathan Follender of Big Indian, New York, Mark Follender and his wife Caryn of Ridgewood, New Jersey and Nancy Follender and her husband Curt Buckler, of Edgewater New Jersey and by her three grandchildren Hannah, Alecsa and Emma Follender. Mrs. Follender held a B.A. from Cornell University, an M.A. from New York University and was a doctoral candidate at the Bernard Revel School of Yeshiva University. She taught both in the New York City and New Jersey school systems and lectured and wrote about American-Jewish history. She was also a licensed interior decorator and member of the Allied Board of Trade. A native of New York City, Mrs. Follender and her husband raised their family in Teaneck, New Jersey, a community in which they became an integral part, helping to found B'Nai Yeshurun synagogue, the Jewish Center of Teaneck, and the Moriah School of Englewood. In 1980, she received the United Jewish Community award for "Distinguished Service in Community Leadership." In 1994, both she and her husband received the "Gates of Jerusalem" medal from Israel Bonds. Mrs. Follender was a life member of Hadassah, a proud Lion of Judah, a charter life member of the Moriah School of Englewood, and a charter member of the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC. Irma and her husband David participated in numerous missions to Europe and Israel to save the remnant of Jewish Holocaust survivors, and accompany them by plane or ship to Israel. A talented pianist, she studied with Moritz Rosenthal (himself a pupil of Franz Liszt), before entering the High School of Music and Art in New York City, and played cello with the now defunct Tenafly Orchestra. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in her memory be made to Boys Town Jerusalem or Friends of the Israeli Defense Forces. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, February 15, 2012 at 11am at Gutterman-Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Interment to be at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday strongly defended his administration's decision to ban churches from holding services in public schools, pushing back against criticism from some religious leaders and elected officials. Sunday was the last day that several dozen churches were allowed to hold worship services there, after federal courts allowed the city to eject them. Some lawmakers want to require the city to permit the services -- the State Senate passed a bill that would allow churches to continue worshiping in schools -- but the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has expressed concerns about the legislation, saying it is too broad. Advocates for the churches plan to return to court on Tuesday to seek a preliminary injunction against the city.

AARON--Roger S. AJC is profoundly saddened by the death of Roger Aaron, a devoted leader and cherished friend. Roger served AJC with distinction as an Honorary Vice President, and a member of our Board of Trustees and National Leadership Council. In 2000, we were proud to honor him with our Judge Learned Hand Award. His wise counsel and dedication will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Ginny, his children, grandchildren, and the entire family. Robert H. Elman, Pres. David Harris, Exec. Dir.
International VANDALISM OF TREASURES

A piece of Mars fell on Morocco in July. But that was just the start of its travels on Earth. The biggest chunk of the meteorite flew from Morocco to Paris to New York, where the collector who bought it bicycled around town with it in his backpack. Finally, this week, it flew to London.

The Emerson String Quartet, a dominant force on the chamber music scene in America in recent decades, will announce a change in its membership on Tuesday for the first time in 34 years. David Finckel, who joined the ensemble as cellist in 1979 when it was three years old, plans to leave at the end of the 2012-13 season, to be replaced by Paul Watkins. Mr. Finckel, 60, who has been multitasking of late in ventures with his wife, the pianist Wu Han - as co-artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with a current contract running through the 2012-13 season, and Music@Menlo in California, and as co-producer of the record label ArtistLed - is leaving to pursue ''his personal artistic endeavors,'' the quartet says in a statement. Mr. Finckel amplified in a telephone interview, saying that he wanted to broaden himself musically, in the cello literature and beyond; broaden himself intellectually, with a chance to read more widely; and broaden his involvement in education.

AARON--Roger. It is with great sadness that we have learned of the loss of our long-time Teach For America-New York Advisory Board member, Roger Aaron. Over his seven years on the board, Roger served as co-chair, and also as head of the Governance Committee. He was a true believer in, and ambassador for, our work to ensure all children have the opportunity to attain an excellent education and, in the many ways Roger served, he set a standard of professionalism that will be his permanent legacy to our board and organization. In honor of Roger's leadership and engagement, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP has supported our efforts, for which we are immensely grateful. We send our condolences to Ginny and the entire Aaron family. We will miss Roger's wisdom, guidance and gentle manner very much. Bob Scully and Scott Nuttall, NY Advisory Board Co-Chairs Jeff Li, NY Executive Director Walter Isaacson, National Board of Directors Chair Wendy Kopp, Founder & CEO

LEWIS--Robert, founding partner of the labor and employment law firm Jackson Lewis, LLP, died peacefully Sunday morning in Los Angeles, following complications from pneumonia at the age of 88. Born in Brooklyn, New York, even his earliest baby pictures reveal Bob's quintessential grin. He met his wife Ethel Padnick as a teenager, and after several years of courtship, from which the family still holds his elegant letters, the couple embarked on what would become nearly 65 years of marriage. He enlisted in the Army shortly after graduating from Brooklyn Technical High School. It was his time stationed in Italy during WWII as a secretary for the Office of the Staff Judge Advocate that sparked two of his lifelong interests: law and archaeology. He enrolled in Brooklyn Law School on the G.I. bill and married Ethel in 1947. In the years to follow, his career and family grew. Alongside Louis Jackson, he formed the firm now known as Jackson Lewis, one of the nation's leading firms specializing in labor and employment law. In his career Bob was known for his scholarly interest, his mentorship of younger attorneys, and his firm's commitment to ethical practice. He co-authored the book "Winning NLRB Elections," now in its fourth printing, and argued before the Supreme Court in Food Employees Union v. Logan Valley Plaza (1968). In addition to an illustrious law career, Bob pursued many passions throughout his life. He was an avid tennis player. A lifetime of travel took Bob and Ethel around the world, including trips to Israel, Tunisia, China, Morocco, and Cuba. His family and friends remember him best for his lifelong commitment to reading The New York Times; his endearing love for Chinese food and ice cream (eaten separately); his passion for Civil War history and presidential biographies; and his unending good humor and dedication to his family. He is survived by his wife Ethel, his brother, Warren, his daughters, Eileen and Nancy, and his grandchildren, Carolyn and Alison Silveira and Matthew Lewis.

FOLLENDER--Irma R. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a valued member of its extended family. Irma, together with her partner in life and philanthropy, Judge David B. Follender, provided generous support to numerous charitable causes. She was an ardent Zionist and because of the Follenders' key leadership roles in Israel-based causes, they were received by, and developed close friendships with high level government officials during their frequent visits to Israel. The Follenders established the Judge David B. and Irma R. Follender Scholarship Endowment Fund at BTJ as an expression of their commitment to the school's mission of turning young boys from limitless backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. They also dedicated the Dean's Office of BTJ's 18 acre campus with a message on the inscription reflecting their personal connection to the students: "Young men of Boys Town, seize the opportunity, reach higher, even beyond your grasp." We extend heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Board member, Judge David B. Follender, Irma's soul mate for almost 58 years, and to the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman L. Robert Kaswell, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP

PEELEN--Fred G. Family and friends are deeply saddened to announce the untimely passing of Fred G. Peelen. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue at 81st street on Wednesday, February 15 from 5:00pm to 8:00pm. A Solemn Requiem Mass will be held at Saint Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street on Thursday, February 16 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Organ Fund of Saint Thomas Church.

AARON--Roger Shaw, on February 11, 2011 Age 69. Beloved husband of Ginny, devoted father of Peter and Todd, loving father-in-law of Jessica, adoring grandfather of Nate and Will, most loving son of the indomitable Phyllis; dearly loved brother/brother-in-law of Carolyn and Elliot Ross and Pat and Ed Falkenberg. Roger grew up in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He attended Dartmouth College where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa and Magna Cum Laude, then went on to earn his MBA at Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, graduating with High Distinction and winning the Walter A. Jacobs Memorial Award for intellectual curiosity and sound judgment. He earned his LLB from Yale Law School in 1968. He was devoted to all his schools throughout his life and reveled in the fact that both his sons chose to attend Dartmouth. For his first job as a lawyer Roger chose a small New York firm, becoming the 19th lawyer at Skadden Arps. The firm currently numbers over 1800 lawyers. An integral part of the firm's growth and management over the last 40 years, he took great pride and pleasure in the institution that Skadden has become. He loved his work, the Skadden family and his close relationship with his mentor Joe Flom. Over the decades Roger rose as a consummate dealmaker while also serving for more than 20 years as the firm's global Corporate Practice Partner, overseeing Skadden's corporate, M&A, Governance, Finance and Restructuring practices. He was a senior member of the firm's Policy Committee as well as a frequent lecturer and panelist. Throughout his career he served on a number of non-profit boards, including Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, The Legal Aid Society, the New York branches of Teach for America and The American Jewish Committee, and was a co-chair of Mt Sinai Hospital's Crystal Ball. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was an original member of Dartmouth's President's Leadership Council. He loved skiing, fishing, biking in Aspen and sharing all these activities with his family and friends. Roger Aaron lived his life fully and with great dedication to the things he believed in. He fought his battle with cancer bravely and privately with the help of talented and extremely caring doctors and nurses. Roger was a source of wise counsel and support for a vast network of family, friends and acquaintances. His tremendous generosity, sharp intellect and thoughtful leadership will be dearly missed. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 14 at 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine (www.mssm.edu).

KAMSKY--Leonard. Our heartfelt sympathy on the passing of Leonard, wonderful and caring husband, father and grandfather. We extend condolences to the Kamsky family. Liz, Jonathan, Chelsea, Grant and Eyan Goldman

McCORMICK--Patrick J.,of New York and East Hampton, New York, died peacefully on February 8, 2012 at his home in East Hampton. Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on May 21, 1921. He came to the U.S. in the 1950s and founded McCormick Trading Co. in 1959. He is survived by Elena Bosch McCormick, his loving wife of 51 years, and his sons Patrick McCormick (Tracey) and Michael McCormick (Maria) and four grandchildren: Patrick, Amanda, Carolina and Christopher.

GOLDIN--Bernice, of West Hempstead, NY and Lake Worth, FL, died on February 9, 2012 at age 86. Beloved wife of the late Paul Goldin, devoted mother of Steven (Marjorie) and Shelley, loving grandmother to Russell (Angela) and Brian, doting great-grandmother to Kaleb and Micah, and a wonderful friend to many. She was greatly loved and will be sorely missed by her family and many friends.

Several years ago, my friend Jeffrey Zaslow sent me a chapter from a book he was writing about lifelong friendships among a group of women from Ames, Iowa. It was a powerful story about love and loss that moved me to tears. With the draft pages still in my hands, I sat down with my daughter, a second-grader at the time, to talk about the importance of friendship. We talked about her girlfriends, why occasional fights didn't matter and why she should always treasure her friends. It was a sweet moment, and I was grateful to Jeff for inspiring the conversation through his writing.

''Presidents and senators don't have men killed,'' Michael Corleone was told in ''The Godfather.'' They do, however, give out prizes. On Monday, President Obama presented Al Pacino, the ''Godfather'' star and Academy and Tony Award-winner, with a medal recognizing his contributions to film and theater as the 2011 National Medals of Arts and National Humanities Medals were awarded. At a ceremony held in the East Room of the White House, Mr. Pacino received a National Medal of Arts, a distinction managed by the National Endowment for the Arts that recognizes individuals and organizations for ''their contributions to the creation, growth, and support of the arts in the United States,'' according to a statement from its organizers. In a citation read as he was given his medal, Mr. Pacino was honored for, among other things, his ''signature intensity.'' Arts medals were also awarded to the artist Will Barnet; Rita Dove, a former poet laureate of the United States; the philanthropist Emily Rauh Pulitzer; the sculptor Martin Puryear; Mel Tillis, the country musician; the classical pianist Andre Watts; and the United Service Organizations. Winners of the National Humanities Medal, which is managed by the National Endowment for the Humanities, included Kwame Anthony Appiah, Robert Darnton, John Ashbery and Amartya Sen. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LIFF--Seena, on February 10, 2012, age 57. After a brave battle with cancer. Beloved daughter of Eleanor and the late Alvin Liff. Loving sister of Daniel and (Joanne) Liff. Cherished aunt of Laina, Jenna, Brandon, Ally, Nicholas and Mia. Seena was a dear friend to many.

WEIGHING A BID Vodafone confirmed on Monday that it was considering an all-cash takeover bid for Cable & Wireless Worldwide, an embattled British telecommunications service provider. Vodafone's brief statement came after a report by The Sunday Times of London that the cellphone services giant, run by Vittorio Colao, left, was weighing a bid worth £700 million ($1.1 billion). The newspaper reported that the private equity firm Apax Partners had also expressed interest in a potential deal.

Mikhail Baryshnikov has been awarded the Vilcek Prize for the Arts. The award, which honors the contributions of foreign-born artists and scientists in the United States and is given by the the Vilcek Foundation, includes a cash prize of $100,000. Mr. Baryshnikov, born in Latvia to Russian parents, is being honored for his ''body of distinguished work and his legacy of advancing the field of dance,'' according to a statement. Michel Kouakou, a choreographer from the Ivory Coast, received the 2012 Vilcek Prize for Creative Promise, which includes a cash award of $25,000.The Vilcek Prize honors immigrants who have played a significant role in the vibrancy of culture in the United States. The American Dance Festival has awarded the choreographer William Forsythe the 2012 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award for Lifetime Achievement. The award, which includes a $50,000 prize, will be presented to Mr. Forsythe in a ceremony on June 30 before a performance by Hubbard Street Dance Chicago at the Durham Performing Arts Center in North Carolina. The performance will include Mr. Forsythe's 1993 work ''Quintett.'' The award, which was established in 1981 by the arts patron Samuel H. Scripps and the ADF, honors choreographers who have dedicated their lives and talent to the creation of modern dance. Past recipients include Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Hanya Holm, Alwin Nikolais, Katherine Dunham, Alvin Ailey, Twyla Tharp and others.
SCHLANG--David. Dear longtime friend, he will be greatly missed. Kind, loving, generous. Our hearts go out to his adored Matti, Julie, Lisa, Matt, Eric and grandchildren. Diane and Jim Parver

The National Review Online called on Monday for Newt Gingrich to quit the Republican presidential contest and endorse Rick Santorum. The editors of the conservative magazine said it would be a mistake for Republican voters to nominate someone with ''such poor judgment and persistent unpopularity'' to be the party's standard bearer.

GOLDSMITH--Juliet Kittenplan, beloved wife, sister, aunt, mother and grandmother passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 12 surrounded by her loving family. She was 75. Juliet was born and raised in Scarsdale, NY where she attended Fox Meadow Elementary School and graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1954. Juliet was a graduate of Smith College in 1958. She worked for 25 years as the Director of Public Relations at Weill Cornell Hospital - White Plains Campus. Juliet served as a board member of the Scarsdale Adult School for over 35 years. The lifelong friendships she enjoyed, and her love of the arts and travel which she shared with everyone will be a blessed memory. Juliet is survived by her loving husband of 50 years Bobby, brother Stephen Kittenplan (Gail), son Richard (Linda) and daughter Gillian Rittmaster (Peter) and cherished grandchildren Davis, William, Holly, Samantha and Graham. Funeral service on Tuesday, February 14 at 12:00 Noon, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.
BERK--Chuck. September 3, 1947- February 14, 2008. Always on our minds. Always in our hearts. Loving you. Missing you. Love, Joan and Samantha

The recent disclosure of the Sierra Club's secret acceptance of $26 million in donations from people associated with a natural gas company has revived an uncomfortable debate among environmental groups about corporate donations and transparency. The gifts from the company, Chesapeake Energy, have drawn criticism from some environmentalists. ''Sleeping with the enemy'' was a comment much forwarded on Twitter posts about the undisclosed arrangement.
THE FACTS Flying in economy class may be easier on your wallet. But can it put a greater strain on your legs, raising risks of blood clots?

AARON--Roger S. A brilliant lawyer, a wonderful traveling companion, a true gentleman, but most of all a true friend. We will miss him sorely. Our prayers and condolences go to Ginny, Peter, Todd, Jessica, Phyllis, Carolyn, Nate and Will. Bill and Marilyn Frank
OSMOND--Barbro K.,passed February 11, 2012. Beloved by family and friends in the U.S. and her native Sweden, her optimistic spirit and selfless love will be forever cherished.

ARONSON--Audrey Shampan, 95, of New York City died peacefully at the Poster's home. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Bernard Aronson, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange and past President of The Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was the mother of Dr. Joan Poster (Dennis) of Westport, CT and Ronney Berinstein (Henry) of New York City and the grandmother of Meredith Poster Bukzin, Cynthia Eigen both of Westport, CT and DJ Nordquist of Alexandria, VA and nine wonderful great-grandchildren. Audrey was most generous with her time for many charities following in the footsteps of her husband's philanthropy and was the founder of The Aronson Family Foundation. She was also a volunteer at Hospital for Special Surgery for over 25 years receiving several awards for her service. Funeral service will be private. Please make donations in her memory to the charity of your choice.

AARON--Roger. We extend our deepest condolences to the family of Roger Aaron. Roger was the epitome of honor, charisma and elegance. His generosity extended to all within his reach, and I am profoundly grateful to him for giving me my first opportunity. Without his willingness to take a chance on me and his invaluable support and guidance, my career would have been very different. We join with the countless others whose life Roger touched in wishing his family peace and comfort during this difficult time. David Fox and Caryn Schacht

The About New York column on Feb. 1, about Steve Mandl, the coach of the George Washington High School baseball team in Washington Heights who had been suspended after a complaint by a rival coach, misstated the number of city championships the team had won. In 27 years, the team won three city championships -- twice with Mr. Mandl as coach -- not 26. (The team won 26 division titles under Mr. Mandl.)
An obituary on Feb. 5 about the composer, arranger, conductor and keyboardist Clare Fischer misstated the given name of his wife, who survives him. She is Donna, not Susan.

5 A.M. (TCM) 8 1/2 (1963) In this dazzling Freudian mosaic from Fellini, Marcello Mastroianni plays an Italian film director who retreats from the demands of moviemaking by reminiscing about his life and loves, and in the process finds inspiration for his next project. Fellini received Oscar nominations for best director and, with his colleagues Ennio Flaiano, Tullio Pinelli and Brunello Rondi, best screenplay. The movie won for best foreign-language film and Piero Gherardi for best costume design. In ''The Bicycle Thief'' (1948), at 7:30, a laborer (Lamberto Maggiorani) and his young son (Enzo Staiola, above right, with Mr. Maggiorani) search for the stolen bicycle that the man desperately needs back to keep his new job. Vittorio De Sica directed this classic neo-realist study of poverty in postwar Rome. 1 P.M. (HBO2) VALENTINE'S DAY (2010) Ashton Kutcher, playing a Los Angeles florist privy to any number of botched romantic situations, leads a cast in this comedy from Garry Marshall, which includes Jessica Alba, Kathy Bates, Jessica Biel , Bradley Cooper, Eric Dane, Patrick Dempsey, Hector Elizondo, Jamie Foxx, Jennifer Garner, Anne Hathaway, Julia Roberts and others. Writing for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said the best thing about the film ''is that it makes you appreciate and long for the breeziness, acting and basic competency -- the decent lighting, focused cameras and choreographed action -- of 'Love Actually,' the ingratiating British movie it transparently and ineptly rips off.''

9:10 p.m. | Updated to add more details throughout. Responding to a growing outcry over conditions at its overseas factories, Apple said Monday that an outside organization had begun to audit working conditions at the plants where the bulk of iPhones, iPads and other Apple products are built, and that the group would make its finding public.

RODIN--Sylvia, died February 9, 2012, wife of late Eugene, daughter of Jacob and Florence Denenfeld, mother of Patricia and Bruce, grandmother of Jesse, Alison, and Avi, and great-grandmother of Harry. An interior decorator, artist and sculptor with business acumen who served as Gene's navigator and partner. The penultimate green thumb who knew the ropes.

DIX--Robert Knight (Bob), January 16 in Redding, CT. Born in Gallatin MO in 1917, he held a Chem. Eng. doctorate from M.I.T. He retired as Sr. Vice President of Exxon Chemical Co. in 1977 to devote time to musical composition. After the death of his wife Mary Murphy Dix he married Marie S. Goff. He is survived by Marie S. Dix, by his children, grand-children and greatgrand-children. A musical celebration will be held in spring. Contact via: www.rkdixmusic.com

The show's most famous competitor arrived long after the canine masses had begun their procession across Seventh Avenue - some carried in crates or cradled between biceps, others trudging delicately in bejeweled coats and miniature boots to protect against the cool of the sidewalk. As these visitors formed a line near the freight elevator in a cavernous hallway of Madison Square Garden, their owners grumbling about the wait, the cherished guest slipped in through an employee entrance around 8 a.m.

Associate Justice Stephen Breyer of the United States Supreme Court was robbed by a man armed with a machete while vacationing on the island of Nevis in the West Indies last Thursday, The Associated Press reported on Monday, quoting a spokeswoman for the Supreme Court. Justice Breyer was in his vacation home with his wife, Joanna, and guests when the robber entered the home around 9 p.m. on Thursday. The assailant took approximately $1,000 in cash and fled, the spokeswoman said. No injuries were reported.

KAMSKY--Leonard, 93, a proud son of Richmond, Virginia and a graduate of the University of Richmond, passed away peacefully surrounded by his family on Monday, February 13, 2012. Mr. Kamsky had a distinguished military and business career. As a young man, he enlisted as a private in the Army during the Second World War, and was selected for Officer Candidate School at Harvard for a specialized program taught by Robert McNamara, future Secretary of Defense. Upon graduating, he joined General Eisenhower's staff at Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force, based in England. Mr. Kamsky was awarded the Bronze Star, and was honored by the British with an M.B.E. (Mily) and by the French with the Croix de Guerre, for his role in planning the invasion of Normandy. Major Kamsky, while on General Eisenhower's staff, took the call that the Germans were surrendering. He went on to become a pioneer in the field of business economics, spending thirty years at W.R. Grace & Co., retiring in 1985 as Chief Economist and Senior Vice President. He served President John F. Kennedy in the creation of the Latin American Economic Development Project and The Alliance for Progress; and also served President Ronald Reagan on The President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years, Sonya Levien; three daughters, Katherine Adler, Susan Sussman, Virginia Kamsky; and four grandchildren, David, Rebecca, Zachary and Michael. He also leaves his loving sister, Sylvia, aged 97. A private graveside service will be held on Tuesday, February 14, 2012. The family will be receiving friends at the home of Sonya Kamsky, 150 East 69th Street, on Tuesday from 5pm to 8pm and on Wednesday from 4pm to 8pm.

To work for Success Academy Charter Schools is to be both target and instigator of the ever-churning battle in New York over the direction of the public schools. Jim Manly has been in the line of fire the longest of any Success principal since Eva S. Moskowitz, the hard-charging former city councilwoman, founded the network in 2006. Ms. Moskowitz has become a lightning rod in the charter school controversy in New York, with her effort to expand the network to 40 schools. Each new opening has unleashed opposition. Earlier this month, a lawsuit was filed to try to stop the Success network from opening a school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, which would be the network's 12th.
It is hard to disagree with Paul A Volcker. But I will.

A longstanding debate about the perceived insensitivities of a popular comic-book adventurer -- call it Detractors versus Tintin -- has reached a Belgian court, which has ruled for now that one of Tintin's more contentious exploits is not racist and does not need to be banned. Of the two-dozen Tintin volumes written and illustrated by Herge, the pen name of the Belgian artist Georges Remi, the 1931 installment ''Tintin in the Congo'' has been one of the more problematic tales to feature that intrepid young cartoon reporter. The book, which was reissued in 1946, has been criticized for its presentation of Congolese people, who are drawn with dark skin and large lips and depicted as childlike, and bookstores have sold it with protective warnings or pulled it entirely.

Wall Street made its broadest assault yet against new regulation on Monday, taking aim at a rule that has come to define the battle over how to police banks in the aftermath of the financial crisis. Regulators in charge of writing the Volcker Rule, which would ban banks from trading with their own money, were inundated with complaints and suggestions on Monday, the deadline to comment on a draft proposal. More than 200 letters were expected to be filed by the midnight deadline on the rule, which regulators outlined in October.

When my mother asked what I wanted for my 16th birthday, I said, ''A new bicycle.'' From her response - ''How much longer are you going to be riding a bicycle?'' - I knew I wasn't going to get one. I muddled through on my aging Schwinn (bought secondhand when I was 10) for two more years, and then for my 18th birthday I bought myself a new bike. I am now 70, and I've never gone a year without a bike - not one that collects dust or serves as a clothes hanger, but a bike that is ridden nearly every day. I use my bike for daily exercise and transport to class, work, shopping, tennis, swimming - most everywhere I need to go, as long as the weather, distance and dress code do not make riding impractical.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a portrait believed to be of Mary Todd Lincoln that hung in the governor's mansion in Springfield, Ill., and has now been deemed a hoax misidentified the position that Barry Bauman, an independent conservator who discovered the fraud, held when he was at the Art Institute of Chicago. He was an assistant conservator, not an assistant curator.

It doesn't have a particularly snappy title, but the Summary Report of the Expert Panel on Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents makes for surprisingly accessible and interesting reading. For one thing, it's well written, especially for a scientific report and a set of clinical guidelines. For another, the report, published in late 2011 in the journal Pediatrics, takes on a question at once basic and profound: What do we know about how the hearts of children become the hearts of adults?

AARON--Roger. Peerless mentor and tremendous friend who inspired me in countless ways for over three decades. You were and always will be special to me. There is no way to replace the irreplaceable and I will miss you always. My deepest condolences to Ginny, Peter, Todd, Jessica, Nate, Will, Phyllis and Caroline. Nancy A. Lieberman

Between the Grammys, Whitney Houston and Jeremy Lin, the Bagger is nearly overwhelmed by blogworthy topics. (And realtalk: we're still trying to get over Madge and world peace, not to mention Metta World Peace.) Let's look to the British to set us straight: the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars, were handed out on Sunday, and they could be a preview of our own big movie night. ''The Artist'' swept, winning seven awards, including best picture, director, screenplay, composer, costumes and best actor for Jean Dujardin. (Best screenplay is especially notable for a film with almost no dialogue.)
GOLDSMITH--Juliet K.,our family has lost an expectional member who showed us ever lasting courage by the way she lived her life. We will miss our Jules. With love, Jane & Paul

AARON--Roger. With broken hearts, we mourn the passing of our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. Dear friend since college, font of wisdom, pillar of strength and integrity, brilliant attorney, generous contributor to the community, and steadfast champion of our family. "Uncle Rog" was always there to share our joyous times, extend support wherever needed. How we will miss his greeting, "How are the Falkies?" Our love and open arms to Ginny, whose loss is infinite, his adoring wife of 45 years and tirelessly devoted companion during his courageous battle with illness; to Peter, Todd and Jessica, Nate and Will, Phyllis, Carolyn and Elliot. He touched and inspired so many. His like will not be seen again soon. He will be sorely missed by so many who loved him and especially by us. Rest in peace. The Falkenberg and Mahan family

The robots are coming! The robots are coming! In ''Samuel & Alasdair: A Personal History of the Robot War,'' an imaginative riff on atomic age fears (have they ever gone away?), robots wiped out the United States in 1959, killing its people and leaving it unfit for habitation. But sometime in the middle of the 21st century a small outpost of Soviet Free Radio in Irkutsk keeps bits of American culture alive, broadcasting a play about two Iowa brothers, Samuel and Alasdair, and their lives before the robot holocaust.

Dorothy and Thomas Evans hosted out-of-town guests and celebrated Thanksgiving and Christmas there with their son. Lindsay Bilisoly regularly shared meals there with his parents, Frank and Indie.

McGUIRK--Helen Aspden, of Bronxville, beloved daughter of Reverend Donald Minto Aspden and Helen Knight Aspden, and the cherished wife of the late LTJG George Joseph McGuirk, passed away on February 12, 2012. She was born on December 26, 1921 in Glen Ridge, New Jersey and died at her family home in Chester, Vermont. She is survived by her seven loving children, Scott, Cheryl, Bruce, Dwight, Rosemary, Melanie and Amy, and fifteen grandchildren. She was a graduate of Montclair High School and Stoneleigh Junior College. She was a WWII Navy Veteran, serving as a WAVE, Petty Officer 2nd Class, and was stationed at NAS Lakehurst as an air traffic controller. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and the New England Society. Visitation will be at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4, and 7 to 9pm on Wednesday. There will be a Mass of Christian Burial held at St Joseph's Church on Thursday, February 16 at 11am. The burial will be in Chester, Vermont on a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations are asked to be made to the Springfield Hospital Foundation, PO Box 2003, Springfield, VT 05156.

An article on Saturday about the stringent precautions many business and government officials are taking when traveling abroad with mobile devices referred imprecisely to a panel on which Tom Kellermann, chief technology officer of the wireless security company AirPatrol, served. It was a commission established by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a policy research organization, to advise the incoming President Obama on cybersecurity. It was not a presidential commission.

The game of musical chairs that is conference realignment has now produced what might be called a superconference, just by its sheer span alone. Reeling from defections of its highest-profile teams, Conference USA and the Mountain West have announced their remaining members will form one big association. This creates a league -- which will get a new name -- that will create a set of strange bedfellows: Hawaii in the same conference as East Carolina, Wyoming sharing a kinship with Southern Miss. Yes, it is a bunch of schools jumping into a lifeboat, but this is one ludicrously long lifeboat.

An article on the Small Business page on Thursday about the reaction of business owners to new patent laws defined the term ''prior art'' incorrectly. Prior art is used to challenge a patent -- not to establish it. The term refers to items in the public domain, like books, patent applications and academic papers, that predate a patent claim; it does not refer to private documentation from the patent claimant. (Private documentation from the patent claimant, like dated sketches, notebooks, drafts of academic papers and models, can be used to defend a patent against a challenge.)

The On Soccer column on Thursday, about Fabio Capello's resignation as coach of the English national team, included several errors. England was eliminated from the 2010 World Cup by a 4-1 loss to Germany in the Round of 16, not in the quarter finals. England plays the Netherlands on Feb. 29, not Feb. 26, and England's two preparatory matches before the European championships are in late May and early June; they are not both in May.

The Grammy Awards telecast on CBS smashed every recent ratings record Sunday night, not just for the music awards show but for any awards broadcast, fueled by keen interest in how the show would pay tribute to Whitney Houston, who had died the day before. For its full duration - the show ended out of prime time at 11:33 p.m. in the East - the Grammys attracted 39.9 million viewers, making it the most-watched nonsports program of the television season.

VERMYLEN--Nancy Barr, of Saddle River, NJ and Shoreham, NY died peacefully on Saturday, February 11, 2012 at age 91. She is survived by her beloved husband of 66 years, Paul Anthony Vermylen; their seven children: Paul Jr. (Robin), Jay, Peter (Cathleen), David (Stacy), Jessica Vermylen Fiddes (John), Robert (Mary), and Mark (Barbara); twenty-one grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Nancy was a loyal alumna of The Ursuline School, New Rochelle, NY (1938) and Trinity College (now Trinity Washington University, 1942). She was a Past President of the Board of Cerebral Palsy Center of Bergen County, a volunteer in the Valley Hospital Auxiliary and at The Forum School of Waldwick, NJ. Nancy was a long-time parishioner of St. Gabriel's Church in Saddle River where she was a Eucharistic Minister. Funeral arrangements are being made through Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. www.feeneyfuneralhome.com. Visiting hours 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday, February 14 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. Funeral Mass 10:00am Wednesday, February 15 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Children's Therapy Center in Fairlawn, NJ would be appreciated. www.thechildrenstherapycenter.org/donate.html

AARON--Roger. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the death of our partner Roger S. Aaron, who passed away on Saturday, February 11, 2012 following an illness. Mr. Aaron was 69 years old. He joined Skadden as a summer associate in 1967 and returned as a full-time associate in 1968. Mr. Aaron was promoted to partner in 1975 and rapidly became one of the proteges groomed by Joe Flom to succeed him in leading the firm. He served as the head of the firm's corporate practice for more than two decades and played a leading role on many of the firm's management committees. Mr. Aaron not only preserved the legacy with which he was entrusted, but also played a vital role in the global development of the firm. Skadden would not have become the firm that it is today without Roger Aaron. He helped shape our firm culture and was dedicated not only to his clients and the work, but equally to the firm. Over the years, Mr. Aaron led many of the most significant corporate transactions for the world's largest corporations, including XTO Energy, Compaq Computer, General Motors, Mobil Oil, Univision, U.S. Steel, Pfizer, Time Warner, Daimler and Alcatel. Mr. Aaron graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1964 and received an MBA with high distinction from Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration in 1965. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1968. He has been recognized as a top attorney by such publications as Chambers Global, Chambers USA, The Best Lawyers in America and International Financial Law Review 1000. Who's Who Legal called Mr. Aaron the "dean of the Bar." In addition to his leadership role at the firm and in his field, Mr. Aaron was an active supporter, fundraiser and contributor to his alma maters Dartmouth College and Yale Law School. He served on the boards of directors of the American Jewish Committee, the Burke Rehabilitation Center, the Legal Aid Society, the Rockefeller Center at Dartmouth College, and Teach for America. Mr. Aaron is survived by his wife Virginia (Ginny), sons Peter and Todd, mother Phyllis, sister Caroline, daughter-in-law Jessica and grandsons Nate and Will.

McGUIRK--Helen Aspden, of Bronxville, beloved daughter of Reverend Donald Minto Aspden and Helen Knight Aspden, and the cherished wife of the late LTJG George Joseph McGuirk, passed away on February 12, 2012. She was born on December 26, 1921 in Glen Ridge, New Jersey and died at her family home in Chester, Vermont. She is survived by her seven loving children, Scott, Cheryl, Bruce, Dwight, Rosemary, Melanie and Amy, and fifteen grandchildren. She was a graduate of Montclair High School and Stoneleigh Junior College. She was a WWII Navy Veteran, serving as a WAVE, Petty Officer 2nd Class, and was stationed at NAS Lakehurst as an air traffic controller. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and the New England Society. Visitation will be at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4, and 7 to 9pm on Wednesday. There will be a Mass of Christian Burial held at St Joseph's Church on Thursday, February 16 at 11am. The burial will be in Chester, Vermont on a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations are asked to be made to the Springfield Hospital Foundation, PO Box 2003, Springfield, VT 05156.

MARCUS--Alan. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the sudden passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Alan Marcus, principal in the law firm of Federman & Marcus. Working for many years with the staff of the hospital's Social Work Department, Alan worked tirelessly to protect and defend the rights of our patients and their families, particularly in difficult and challenging guardianship cases. His humor, kindness and warm and engaging demeanor will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him. To his wife, Barbara, his children Simon and Nomi, his parents William and Sylvia, the entire Marcus family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD President Fran Silverman, MSW Director of Social Work Robin Blumenthal, LCSW, ACSW Asst. Director of Social Work

PEELEN--Fred G. The Netherland-America Foundation is deeply saddened by untimely passing of Fred G. Peelen, member of its Board, Executive Committee and Chair of the Peter Stuyvesant Ball Organizing Committee. Fred, after graduating from The Hague Hotel School in 1962, came to the U.S. as trainee, sponsored by the Netherland-America Foundation. Upon completion of his traineeship and graduate work at the Cornell School of Hotel Administration, he joined InterContinental Hotels where, after a stellar career over 35 years, he retired in 2000 as President for the Americas of InterContinental Hotels and Resorts and Crowne Plaza Hotels and Resorts. Those who had the privilege to know and work with Fred will remember his personal loyalty, generosity and operating manager's attention to detail. With his passing, the Netherland-America Foundation has lost one of its most supportive members, and many have lost a good friend. The visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City, on Wednesday, February 15, 2012 from 5:00-8:00pm. A solemn Requiem Mass will be held at Saint Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street on Thursday, February 16 at 11:00am. The funeral service and interment will take place in The Hague, The Netherlands, early next week.

For almost five months, one of the busiest intersections in New York City has been transformed -- by the unlikely medium of 800 used paper coffee cups hung from fishing line -- into an enchanted cleft in the canyons, a place of visual delight and surprising tranquillity. The cups, on which the artist Gwyneth Leech has drawn or painted vibrant graphic patterns and imagery, fill the glass-enclosed ''prow'' at the base of the Flatiron Building, on 23rd Street, between Broadway and Fifth Avenue. Suspended in space, they move gently, too, as heat currents rise from the floor registers. It's a public art installation for which no invitation is needed. Passers-by simply stop -- amused, astonished, perplexed, engaged. Or they come by, as Michael Munguia did the other day from Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, because their friends have told them they must see the lady who draws on coffee cups.

Radiohead, Red Hot Chili Peppers and the reunited Beach Boys will headline this year's Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, organizers said Tuesday. The sprawling four-day festival that starts on June 7 will have 125 bands on 13 stages, covering a wide range of genres and styles. It will be the first time the Red Hot Chili Peppers, who are being inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame this year, will play the 11-year-old festival, which is held annually on a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn.

Over the past five theater seasons Asian-American actors were cast in 2 percent of the roles in Broadway and major Off Broadway productions, while 80 percent of the roles went to white performers, 13 percent to black actors, and 4 percent to Hispanic artists, according to data compiled by an advocacy group for Asian-American performers. Over those seasons, 2006-07 to 2010-11, Asian-Americans were found to be the only minority group whose share of New York acting roles declined slightly, and they were also the least likely to be chosen for characters that would traditionally be played by white actors. The data, culled from Broadway credits and 16 major Off Broadway theater companies, were the focus of a roundtable discussion on Monday night at Fordham College at Lincoln Center that included 19 actors, directors, playwrights, producers, and talent agents, including the Tony Award winners David Henry Hwang (''Chinglish,'' ''M. Butterfly'') and Bartlett Sher (the director of the 2008 revival of ''South Pacific'').

AARON--Roger. Peerless mentor and tremendous friend who inspired me in countless ways for over three decades. You were and always will be special to me. HAMMOND--R. Philip, a chemical and nuclear engineer who helped usher in the age of nuclear power, died on December 22 in Laguna Hills, California. He was 95. As a graduate student during WWII at the University of Chicago, Dr. Hammond helped Enrico Fermi prepare the uranium for the world's first nuclear reactor. A few years later at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, he proposed and co-led the Nuclear Reactor Division, designing and building several advanced reactors and helping to work out processes for the back end of the nuclear fuel cycle. Later at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory he led efforts on nuclear-powered desalinization. He was among the first to advocate the concept of monitored retrievable storage for nuclear waste. Dr. Hammond served on the U.S. delegation to the international conference on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy over nearly a decade. He was a prolific investor, awarded more than 20 patents, a charter member of the American Nuclear Society, and the author of more than 100 technical articles on nuclear power and other energy topics. In his later career, he headed the energy division of R&D Associates in California, developed an extremely high efficiency desalinization unit for the Los Angeles Division of Water and Power, and consulted widely in the U.S. and overseas. In addition to his professional work, he was an amateur painter, an enthusiastic dancer, and a lifelong sailor. Dr. Hammond is survived by his four children, Allen L. Hammond; David M. Hammond; Jean P. Hammond; and Stanley W. Hammond.

A bountiful array of glatt kosher prepared foods, traditional and innovative, is the star attraction at Prime Butcher Baker, an elaborate new market created by Joey Allaham, who owns the Manhattan kosher restaurants Prime Grill, Prime KO and Solo. But there is also plenty for those who prefer to do the cooking. At the entrance of the Upper East Side shop, which opens on Wednesday, is a temperature- and humidity-controlled glass case for aging steaks like rib-eyes. Beyond are a bakery and counters for fish, groceries and meat, including kosher wagyu and organic beef. Lining one wall are freezers filled with Lebanese stuffed vine leaves, flatbreads, kibbe and meat pies, along with soups, quiches, knishes, kugel, ready-to-cook sliders with various seasonings, and scores of other dishes.

KAPLAN--Shirley, (nee Polsky) died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on February 13. Born June 7, 1918, daughter of Bertha and Abraham, sister to Murray and Lawrence. Beloved wife for 55 years of the late Michael. Loving mother of Jim, Gail, Shelley and Steve, Happy grandmother of Brett, Lindsi, Lindsay, Lucy and Clara. She was a "fighter" to the end, in the best sense of the word and without hesitation wanted all good things for her family. Elegantly dressed, there was always a restaurant to enjoy, a time at the theatre to celebrate and a laugh to be had. She will be dearly missed. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Michael and Shirley Kaplan Memorial Scholarship at FIT would be appreciated, 227 West 27th St, Rm C204, New York, NY 10001.

In 2008, Blue Bottle Coffee turned heads in San Francisco when it unveiled a halogen-powered siphon bar. On Saturday, Blue Bottle will introduce New York to the theatrical coffeemaker when it opens its newest shop in a former loading dock on the ground floor of Milk Studios in Chelsea. This will be Blue Bottle's seventh location nationwide, and the first in Manhattan. (A Blue Bottle coffee stand operates on the High Line from April to November.) The new shop is divided into two parts: In front is a coffee bar equipped with all the gear New Yorkers have come to expect in this era of obsessively crafted coffee: a Strada (for cappuccinos, Gibraltars and other espresso drinks, plus single origin espresso), filter cones (where coffee will be brewed one cup at a time) and cold-brewers (for iced coffee). A glass case will hold pastries baked at Blue Bottle's roaster and coffee bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

The new musical ''Far From Heaven,'' based on the 2002 film starring Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid as a 1950s housewife and her sexually conflicted husband, will be among the six productions that Playwrights Horizons will mount during its 2012-13 season, that Off Broadway theater company announced on Tuesday. The adaptation, which will open in late spring 2013, has music by Scott Frankel and lyrics by Michael Korie, the team behind ''Grey Gardens,'' and a book by the Tony winner Richard Greenberg (''Take Me Out''). Michael Greif (''Rent'') will direct the show at Playwrights as well as for a tryout this summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival. A spokesman for Playwrights Horizons said the Williamstown mounting, for which no casting has been announced, would not necessarily be transferred intact for the Off Broadway run.

SAN DIEGO -- As Newt Gingrich looks to reboot his struggling campaign, he has turned to an ally who has always been there but in an almost entirely mute and, to the public, mysterious role: his wife, Callista. Mrs. Gingrich delivered a three-minute introduction of her husband at a conservative conference in Washington last week, including humanizing details about the contents of his Kindle (''an entire library'') and his golf game (''he gets in and out of more sand traps than anyone I have ever seen'').

An article on Tuesday about a debate regarding corporate donations to environmental groups misidentified a source of donations to the Environmental Working Group for research on asbestos litigation. It is the American Trial Lawyers Association, not Travelers Insurance. The article also referred imprecisely to the Environmental Defense Fund's partnerships with McDonald's and FedEx. While it worked with both companies on environmental issues, the fund's leadership said it did not receive donations from either one as part of those collaborations.

A brief article with a picture essay in some editions on Monday about the Musical Connections program, part of the Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall, erroneously included two venues among those that the program focuses on in trying to reach a wider audience. While it goes to health care settings, prisons, homeless shelters and senior service organizations, it does not go to schools or bars.

Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass Friday 10am at St Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave at 84 St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Roberts name to Sloan Kettering Brain Cancer Program.
The question to William Shatner was fairly conventional. The answer wasn't. What are people who come to your new Broadway show going to see and, just as important, what are they not going to see?

AARON--Roger Shaw, on February 11, 2011 Age 69. Beloved husband of Ginny, devoted father of Peter and Todd, loving father-in-law of Jessica, adoring grandfather of Nate and Will, most loving son of the indomitable Phyllis; dearly loved brother/brother-in-law of Carolyn and Elliot Ross and Pat and Ed Falkenberg. Roger grew up in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He attended Dartmouth College where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa and Magna Cum Laude, then went on to earn his MBA at Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, graduating with High Distinction and winning the Walter A. Jacobs Memorial Award for intellectual curiosity and sound judgment. He earned his LLB from Yale Law School in 1968. He was devoted to all his schools throughout his life and reveled in the fact that both his sons chose to attend Dartmouth. For his first job as a lawyer Roger chose a small New York firm, becoming the 19th lawyer at Skadden Arps. The firm currently numbers over 1800 lawyers. An integral part of the firm's growth and management over the last 40 years, he took great pride and pleasure in the institution that Skadden has become. He loved his work, the Skadden family and his close relationship with his mentor Joe Flom. Over the decades Roger rose as a consummate dealmaker while also serving for more than 20 years as the firm's global Corporate Practice Partner, overseeing Skadden's corporate, M&A, Governance, Finance and Restructuring practices. He was a senior member of the firm's Policy Committee as well as a frequent lecturer and panelist. Throughout his career he served on a number of non-profit boards, including Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, The Legal Aid Society, the New York branches of Teach for America and The American Jewish Committee, and was a co-chair of Mt Sinai Hospital's Crystal Ball. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was an original member of Dartmouth's President's Leadership Council. He loved skiing, fishing, biking in Aspen and sharing all these activities with his family and friends. Roger Aaron lived his life fully and with great dedication to the things he believed in. He fought his battle with cancer bravely and privately with the help of talented and extremely caring doctors and nurses. Roger was a source of wise counsel and support for a vast network of family, friends and acquaintances. His tremendous generosity, sharp intellect and thoughtful leadership will be dearly missed. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 14 at 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine (www.mssm.edu).

The ''Popular Demand'' listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday about the top nonfiction books of 2011 misstated the publication date of a biography of Steve Jobs of Apple. The book, ''Steve Jobs, '' by Walter Isaacson, was published on Oct. 24, not four days before Mr. Jobs's death. (He died on Oct. 5.)

PRESSING FOR A SALE Carl C. Icahn, below, the activist investor, wrote in a regulatory filing on Tuesday that CVR Energy, an independent oil refiner, should sell itself to generate the highest return for its shareholders. CVR announced on Monday that it planned to pay shareholders a special dividend, to be financed in part by selling a part of CVR Partners, a subsidiary that produces nitrogen fertilizer. But Mr. Icahn, who owns a 14.5 percent stake in the company, expressed his dissatisfaction with that strategy.

An obituary on Saturday about the author Jeffrey Zaslow contained several errors. The bookstore where Mr. Zaslow appeared on Thursday, the night before he was killed in an automobile accident, was in Petoskey, Mich., not in Elmira, Mich. Randy Pausch, the subject and co-author of Mr. Zaslow's book ''The Last Lecture,'' delivered the talk that gave the book its title when he learned he was dying of pancreatic cancer, not ''an ailment similar to Lou Gehrig's disease.'' And the plane that the pilot Chesley B. Sullenberger III, whose book ''Highest Duty'' Mr. Zaslow co-wrote, landed in the Hudson River in 2009 was an Airbus A320 with about 150 passengers, not a commuter plane.

Do Michael Bay and Veena Sud have more in common than meets the eye? Mr. Bay makes movies about robots that transform into vehicles and technological devices; Ms. Sud produces a television series about a murder mystery that transforms into a much longer commitment than audiences realize. Both have complicated relationships with their fan bases, to say the least, and now both are preparing new film projects that hope to move things forward while starting them over. Mr. Bay, the whiz-bang-kaboom director, has announced on his Web site that he would make a new ''Transformers'' movie for Paramount Pictures as part of a two-film deal for that studio. Based on the popular toy series, ''Transformers'' and its two sequels, ''Revenge of the Fallen'' and ''Dark of the Moon,'' have been among the most critically derided movies of recent years but have also sold more than $2.6 billion in tickets worldwide. A statement on Mr. Bay's site said the next ''Transformers'' movie would be ''a new take'' on the story and would be released on June 29, 2014. (Mr. Bay's other movie in the Paramount deal will be called ''Pain and Gain,'' but it's about criminal bodybuilders, not skyscraper-size action figures.)

After more than two years of temporary leadership, the J. Paul Getty Museum has chosen Timothy Potts, a specialist in ancient art and a veteran museum hand, to be its new director. Mr. Potts has been the director of the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge, England, since 2008 and before that he ran the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Tex., for almost a decade, making a mark there with ambitious acquisitions and several well-regarded exhibitions. Born and raised in Australia, he began his career as director of the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne.

KAMSKY--Leonard, 93, a proud son of Richmond, Virginia and a graduate of the University of Richmond, passed away peacefully surrounded by his family on Monday, February 13, 2012. Mr. Kamsky had a distinguished military and business career. As a young man, he enlisted as a private in the Army during the Second World War, and was selected for Officer Candidate School at Harvard for a specialized program taught by Robert McNamara, future Secretary of Defense. Upon graduating, he joined General Eisenhower's staff at Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force, based in England. Mr. Kamsky was awarded the Bronze Star, and was honored by the British with an M.B.E. (Mily) and by the French with the Croix de Guerre, for his role in planning the invasion of Normandy. Major Kamsky, while on General Eisenhower's staff, took the call that the Germans were surrendering. He went on to become a pioneer in the field of business economics, spending thirty years at W.R. Grace & Co., retiring in 1985 as Chief Economist and Senior Vice President. He served President John F. Kennedy in the creation of the Latin American Economic Development Project and The Alliance for Progress; and also served President Ronald Reagan on The President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years, Sonya Levien; three daughters, Katherine Adler, Susan Sussman, Virginia Kamsky; and four grandchildren, David, Rebecca, Zachary and Michael. He also leaves his loving sister, Sylvia, aged 97. A private graveside service will be held on Tuesday, February 14, 2012. The family will be receiving friends at the home of Sonya Kamsky on Wednesday from 4pm to 8pm.

ZORN--Norma, of Scarsdale, NY, beloved mother of Amy and Steven, cherished grandmother of Jonah, loving sister of Bobbi and loving aunt to Susan and Barry, Robert and Michael, Hilary and David, Jason and Regina, Howard and Melissa and Becky and Jon, passed away suddenly on February 11th after celebrating a joyous 82nd birthday on February 5th. 'Grandma' as she so happily came to be known, was always happiest when she was with friends and family; they were her heart as were her beloveds Milton and Janet. Norma was the winner of the 1949 Philadelphia Voice of Tomorrow contest and she will be our beautiful voice always and for eternity. Services on Wednesday 12:00pm Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale 10583. Interment following at Sharon Gardens. The family will receive friends on Wednesday in Scarsdale following Interment and Thursday 6:30-9:00 in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to JDRF, 432 Park Ave S, 15th Fl, NYC 10016.

President Obama did not forget the National Endowment for the Arts when he released the details of his proposed budget on Monday. The budget would raise the agency's annual spending to $154.255 million, an increase of more than $8 million over the current level. Both the president and the chairman of the endowment, Rocco Landesman, emphasized the economic benefits of spending money on the arts. ''A dollar invested directly through the NEA is matched by $8 of additional investment and generates $26 of economic activity in the community,'' Mr. Landesman said in a statement. ''In short, art works.''

On the surface, comparisons between Jeremy Lin, the Knicks sensation, and Tim Tebow, the N.F.L. quarterback, are ridiculous, regardless of their religious devotion. Tebow won the Heisman Trophy and two national championships while playing at the University of Florida, a college football powerhouse. TAUBER--Erika (nee Graf). Beloved wife of 51 years of Stephen, mother of Andrew, Sharon, and Elizabeth, grandmother of three, and twin sister of Eva, died peacefully on February 14 at the age of 79. Born August 31, 1932 in Vienna, Erika reached the U.S. in 1941 after a three year odyssey. A graduate of Forest Hills High School and Barnard College, with an M.A. from Middlebury College, Erika lived in New York, Chevy Chase, MD, and Lexington, MA. A warm and cultured woman with a radiant smile, Erika will be sorely missed. Contributions may be made to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum.

ROME - Cardinal-designate Timothy M. Dolan is not shy about championing his adopted hometown. On Tuesday morning, he welcomed visitors to the roof of the Pontifical North American College near the Vatican, wearing a New York Police Department windbreaker and a New York Giants Super Bowl victory cap. But the affection is not merely symbolic. Archbishop Dolan, who has been drafting an address about evangelization that he plans to deliver to Pope Benedict XVI and the College of Cardinals on Friday, said he saw part of his job as defending New York to a Vatican that views it warily.

FOLLENDER--Irma R. (nee Haibloom), 80, of Boca Raton, Florida and formerly of Teaneck and Fort Lee New Jersey died on February 12, 2012, surrounded by her loving family after a courageous 36-year battle with breast cancer. Mrs. Follender was born in New York City on May 20, 1931, the daughter of Pauline and Abraham Haibloom. She is survived by her loving husband of 58 years, Judge David B. Follender, and her three children Jonathan Follender of Big Indian, New York, Mark Follender and his wife Caryn of Ridgewood, New Jersey and Nancy Follender and her husband Curt Buckler, of Edgewater New Jersey and by her three grandchildren Hannah, Alecsa and Emma Follender. Mrs. Follender held a B.A. from Cornell University, an M.A. from New York University and was a doctoral candidate at the Bernard Revel School of Yeshiva University. She taught both in the New York City and New Jersey school systems and lectured and wrote about American-Jewish history. She was also a licensed interior decorator and member of the Allied Board of Trade. A native of New York City, Mrs. Follender and her husband raised their family in Teaneck, New Jersey, a community in which they became an integral part, helping to found B'Nai Yeshurun synagogue, the Jewish Center of Teaneck, and the Moriah School of Englewood. In 1980, she received the United Jewish Community award for "Distinguished Service in Community Leadership." In 1994, both she and her husband received the "Gates of Jerusalem" medal from Israel Bonds. Mrs. Follender was a life member of Hadassah, a proud Lion of Judah, a charter life member of the Moriah School of Englewood, and a charter member of the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC. Irma and her husband David participated in numerous missions to Europe and Israel to save the remnant of Jewish Holocaust survivors, and accompany them by plane or ship to Israel. A talented pianist, she studied with Moritz Rosenthal (himself a pupil of Franz Liszt), before entering the High School of Music and Art in New York City, and played cello with the now defunct Tenafly Orchestra. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in her memory be made to Boys Town Jerusalem or Friends of the Israeli Defense Forces. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, February 15, 2012 at 11am at Gutterman-Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Interment to be at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey.

ALBANY -- A federal judge on Tuesday named a panel to consider whether to take New York State's redistricting process out of the hands of lawmakers and appoint a special master to remake the political map. The action, by Dennis G. Jacobs, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, is the latest twist in the slowly evolving effort by the state to redraw its Assembly, Senate and Congressional districts, as required by law, to reflect population shifts identified by the 2010 census.

Mitt Romney may have a new constituency to worry about: dogs and dog lovers. The group ''Dogs Against Romney'' held a protest outside the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York on Tuesday afternoon to bring attention to the story of how 25 years ago, Mr. Romney drove from Boston to Canada on vacation with his dog, Seamus, in a carrier strapped to the roof of the family station wagon -- a tale that political commentators and opponents have seized on it as a window into Mr. Romney's character. About a dozen people stood outside Madison Square Garden with signs reading ''Mitt is Mean.''

YOUNER--Kenneth D. M.D.,age 64, died peacefully at home in Englewood, NJ after a long battle with kidney cancer, diagnosed in 2003. He also fought valiantly from a spinal injury in October 2010 which occurred during a training bicycle ride to raise money for a Cancer foundation which he led. Beloved husband, father, brother, papa, uncle, friend and member of the Jewish community. Following his successful gastroenterology practice, he channeled his passions into many areas including back country skiing, world travel, photography, music and creating a Japanese Garden. A strong believer in fitness, Ken ran in two marathons and swam hundreds of miles before discovering his love of bicycle riding. His relationship with his wife Cecile and the profound love that they shared changed him deeply. A remarkable man who loved life to its fullest, he will be sorely missed by all he touched. Donations in his honor can be made to Action to Cure Kidney Cancer and to Congregation Ahavath Torah (contact for shiva).

New York City police officers stopped people and questioned them 684,330 times in 2011, the highest number since the department started collecting the data in 2002, according to the New York Civil Liberties Union. The number represents a 14 percent increase over the 2010 figure and a roughly 600 percent increase from the first year of theBloomberg administration, a decade ago. Many, but not all, of those stopped were frisked.

Yahoo's drive to revive its business hit major roadblocks on Tuesday, as the company's talks to sell back most of its stakes in its Asian partners collapsed and a big investor unveiled plans to mount a board fight. The developments raised questions about whether Yahoo would be able to reverse years of missteps and make itself relevant in an Internet landscape now dominated by Google and Facebook. They also put additional pressure on the company's new chief executive, Scott Thompson, to provide a clear vision of what the new Yahoo will look like.

NOON (Sundance) THE POOL (2008) Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious home in which no one seems to swim. Eventually he approaches the property's owner (Nana Patekar, above right, with Mr. Chavan) and becomes his assistant; the rich man, in turn, promises to become Venkatesh's benefactor if he will move from Goa to Mumbai and go to school. ''At first 'The Pool' suggests an inspirational fable in which a selfless older man rescues a youth from the streets,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film by Chris Smith, adapted from a short story by Randy Russell. ''But just when you expect the film to turn into a predictable, rose-colored valentine to opportunity and hope, it goes to a deeper, more ambiguous place. Contemplating poverty from Venkatesh's perspective, it understands that his pursuit of upward mobility will require a terrifying leap of faith.'' The film was chosen as a New York Times Critics' Pick. In ''Summer Hours'' (2009), a movie from Olivier Assayas, at 1:45 p.m., Charles Berling and Juliette Binoche play Frédéric and Adrienne, siblings who must decide what to do with their mother's charming country house and cherished art collection after her death. Frédéric wants to keep everything the way it is for the enjoyment of the next generation. Adrienne and another brother (Jérémie Renier) want to sell the house and most of its contents, donating the best paintings and furnishings to the Musée d'Orsay. ''That, in a nutshell, is the dramatic arc of this extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. 10:55 A.M. (HBO2) SOMEWHERE (2010) In the first entry in a double bill from Sofia Coppola, Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff) is a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood. He finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves their 11-year-old daughter (Elle Fanning, right, with Mr. Dorff) in his care. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott described the movie as ''exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious.'' What happens, he added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies.'' ''Lost in Translation'' (2003), for which Ms. Coppola won an Oscar for best original screenplay, follows at 12:40 p.m.

The Kellogg Company said on Wednesday that it would buy Pringles for about $2.7 billion in cash, swooping in on the snack company after an earlier agreement with Diamond Foods fell apart. The deal will add a prominent brand to existing Kellogg snack offerings Keebler and Cheez-It, helping the company increase its presence in snacks. Beginning with its $4.5 billion purchase of Keebler in 2000, Kellogg has tried to reduce its reliance on its mainstay cereal business, which includes Corn Flakes and Rice Krispies.

ANTHONY--Charles. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our beloved colleague, tenor Charles Anthony. Charlie holds the record for having sung more performances than any solo singer in Met history, an astounding 2928. From his company debut in 1954 to his final performance in 2010, he sang 111 roles in 69 operas. In the half-century that he was a constant presence at the Met, he gained a reputation for artistic excellence and absolute professionalism. Charlie was also one of the most popular, respected, and loved figures in the opera house. He was a sympathetic and helpful colleague, a cool head under pressure, and a warm, cheerful team player who simply loved his job. His record number of performances is an amazing feat, but the deep affection and admiration that he inspired in his colleagues is an even greater legacy. We offer our sincerest condolences to his wife Eleanor, his children Anna Beth, Barbara, and Tony, his seven grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and all his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

PRINCETON, N.J. -- Princeton University might have borrowed the rubric the Bard Music Festival uses for its composer explorations and called the musicological conference it held last weekend ''Taruskin and His World.'' True, Richard Taruskin is a music historian, not a composer, but his world is capacious, and this event traveled it widely. Mr. Taruskin, 66, has written books on Russian music, including the magisterial two-volume ''Stravinsky and the Russian Traditions.'' He has also produced compilations of essays originally published in The New York Times and elsewhere on all manner of musical subjects, and his writings on early music in particular have been influential, showing that current notions of historically ''authentic'' performance owe as much to modernist impulses and predilections as they do to any firm understanding of ancient practice.

COMAYAGUA, Honduras -- The bodies of the inmates, shirtless and blackened by soot, lay on the ground in neat rows, belying the chaos from which they emerged. Outside the fence, hundreds of relatives rushed the gates of the burned-out prison on Wednesday, anguished and anxious for any word, clashing with soldiers and the police when they could not get in. As a prison officer stood on a balcony, reading out a roll call of the dead and survivors from a handwritten list, faces in the crowd turned away in tears.

For years, people looking for a real browsing experience on Android phones and tablets have been left pecking through something Google called ''Browser'' - an open-source-based browser that wasn't quite horrible but wasn't quite great, either. Now, for a certain lucky few, Google's own browser, Chrome, is available on Android devices and it's a very nice upgrade. First, the good news: Google Chrome is a considerable improvement over the old browser and features a ''stack'' system for collecting and sorting Web pages. It supports tabbed browsing on larger screens and the stacks let you organize pages on a phone or minitablet.

Having directed big-budget action thrillers like ''The Bourne Identity'' and ''Mr. & Mrs. Smith,'' Doug Liman is taking a grassroots approach to a new project meant to raise awareness about real-life violence, politics and torture. The American Civil Liberties Union and the PEN American Center are expected to announce on Thursday a collaboration with Mr. Liman called ''Reckoning With Torture: Memos and Testimonies From the War on Terror.'' For this project Mr. Liman will create a feature-length film whose script is compiled from various documents on prisoner abuse and torture, some of which were obtained through Freedom of Information Act requests, and whose footage will consist of user-submitted videos of their readings of these documents.
