Jeremy Lin's drawing power - even in losses - is helping the MSG Network set ratings records. The loss to the New Orleans Hornets last Friday generated a 7.32 rating (which equals 540,788 local households). Then, Monday night's game against the Nets led to an even higher rating, 7.34. Those are the highest regular-season ratings for Knicks games since the 1988-89 season, when MSG began measuring its audience.

MOSHER--Sally. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Paul Mosher. Loving mother of Joan Weill (Sandy) and Michael Van Scoy-Mosher (Claudia), adored grandmother of Jessica Bibliowicz (Natan), Marc Weill, Oriana Van Scoy-Mosher and Lauren Watstein, and fun loving "Gigi" to Tommy Bibliowicz (Megan), David Bibliowicz, Laurel Weill and Matt Weill. Devoted big sister to baby brother, Max Desfor, and adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sally celebrated her 100th birthday in June in great spirits and made a speech thanking everyone there. Sally was a very talented sculptor, working with stone until her 94th year. Sally was, and will always be, an inspiration to all of us never giving up, never complaining and Sally always kept her wicked sense of humor. Because you have been with us over 100 years, it is hard for me to believe you won't be on the phone with me every day, asking about all of us, including Angel. We all love you very much Mother you will be in our hearts forever. Rest in peace next to Daddy. Your devoted children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and all who knew you.

EISENPRESS--Alta, of White Plains, NY, on February 19, 2012 at age 87. Cherished wife of Harry for 54 years. Survived by beloved sons Aron and his wife Dorothy, Eli and his wife Angela, and Samuel. Delighted grandmother of Ben, Sasha, and Pooja. Alta loved to share her knowledge of books and her Jewish heritage with everyone from 1 to 120. Her smile was like the sun breaking out and her effervescence and indomitable spirit created a legacy that continues to be a blessing. Services were on Monday. UMIN--Steven M. 73, died peacefully February 19, at his home in Washington, D.C. after a long fight with Frontal Temporal Degeneration (FTD). Born January 28, 1939, he was raised in the Bronx (NYC). Valedictorian of New Rochelle High School, NY; graduate of Yale University (Summa Cum Laude, Valedictorian, 1959), Rhodes Scholar, Oxford University (1959-1961), Yale Law School (1961-1964), Law Clerk to Chief Justice Roger Traynor, California Supreme Court (1964-1965), Law Clerk to Potter Stewart, Associate Justice, Supreme Court of the United States (1965-1966), Attorney at Williams & Connolly, Washington, D.C. (1966 2004), Deputy Counsel, United States Senate Subcommittee on the Judiciary, Member - Central & Eastern Europe Legal Institute, Member Advisory Committee, United States Court of Appeals, Public Member United States Delegation Vienna Conference on Helsinki Treaty, Board Multiple Sclerosis International Federation, and Adjunct Professor of Law, Georgetown Law Center. Steven Umin will be remembered as a lawyer of exceptional talent whose bold intellectual curiosity, humor and incisiveness underpinned his numerous academic and professional achievements. He was a warm, compassionate, and loving person whose loyalty to his family, friends, and colleagues, to Camp Mooween, Yale, and the New York Giants, touched all and will never be forgotten. Steve's support of the New York Giants was instilled by his father, who took him to his first game when he was four-years-old. Despite living in Washington, D.C. for 42 years, and working daily with Edward Bennett Williams of Williams & Connolly, owner of the Washington Redskins, Steve's dedication to his home team never wavered. He is survived by his loving wife, Candace R. Umin, and loving family, his daughter, Courtney of Washington, D.C., his sister, Gail Massot of Arlington, Va., and his niece and nephew, Randa Massot of Paris, France, and Olivier Massot of Arlington, Va. The Family will receive visitors at Gawler's Funeral Home, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue, Washington, D.C. 6:30 9:00pm, Thursday, February 23, 2012. A Memorial Service will be held at Washington Hebrew Congregation, at 2:00pm, Friday, February 24, 2012. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Steven's name to The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration (AFTD) in support of research.

For Sean Nevins, as for most serious beer drinkers, freshness is crucial to the quality of the brew. Too often, beer suffers as it is shipped from brewery to warehouse to retailer, sitting for days or weeks along the way. Mr. Nevins, who had a career starting new businesses for large companies, decided to do something about the problem and spent a year and a half putting his expertise to the test. The result is Beerjobber, a Web site where consumers can order beer by the case, shipped in a week to 10 days directly from each brewery. So far, the site features several dozen American craft breweries, including Blue Point, on Long Island; Twisted Pine, of Boulder, Colo.; Appalachian, in Harrisburg, Pa.; Mad River, of Blue Lake, Calif.; and Philadelphia Brewing (above). Mr. Nevins, based in Conshohocken, Pa., said he could deliver beer to 38 states, as well as the District of Columbia. ''Whenever a new consumer registers, we check the ZIP code to make sure we can legally ship to them,'' he said. Most of the brands are small and local. ''We don't want to specialize in the beers like Sierra Nevada and Sam Adams that you can buy everywhere,'' Mr. Nevins said.

The architect Abraham J. Simberg has finally received what he was looking for all along: professional respect and appreciation for the vibrant Jazz Age tower he inscribed on the downtown Brooklyn skyline in 1928 - the 30-story Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce Building, now a residential co-op, at 75 Livingston Street. It is the crown jewel in the new Borough Hall Skyscraper Historic District [PDF] along Court Street, created last year by the Landmarks Preservation Commission and sustained Feb. 1 by the City Council. In describing 75 Livingston Street, developed by Jacob Adelman, the commission said it was a work of ''considerable elegance and sophistication,'' with ''projecting pavilions, chamfered corners and secondary setbacks that give the building visual interest well beyond what was required by the zoning regulations and equal to that of any skyscraper in greater New York.''

GUTTENBERG--William S. (Bill) was born on October 9, 1922, at Barnert Hospital, Paterson, NJ. He graduated from Paterson School No. 13, and then Eastside High in 1940. Bill's activities included being Editor-in-Chief of the Senior Mirror and Editor-inChief of the newspaper, Criterion, as well as being an active member of the Math Club, band, orchestra and various other clubs. He also wrote a weekly column about high school for the Paterson Evening News. Bill graduated from Newark College of Engineering (now known as New Jersey Institute of Technology-NJIT) in 1944 with a BS degree in electrical engineering. There, his activities included being Editor-in-Chief of the Technician and Associate Editor of the Nucleus. He was also on the Honors Option. Bill served in France and Germany with the Ninth Division, US Army, from 1944 to 1945. Prior to crossing the Rhine River in March 1945, he was wounded twice, for which he was awarded a Purple Heart with Oak Leaf Cluster. Bill was employed by Bogue Electric Company from 1944 to 1972, except for the period when he was in the Armed Forces, rising from Test Engineer to President in 1964. In the early 1970's, Guttenberg led a team to design motors and controls for an all-electric car with a range comparable to its gas engine counterpart. It soon became apparent that it was not possible with the state-of-the art batteries available then and still today. As the shortage of gasoline and the lines at the stations disappeared, interest in electric vehicles waned. During his time at Bogue, Bill was noted for designing and developing high-frequency generators for both the US Navy and the Army Corps of Engineers. He left Bogue in August 1972 to form his own company, Wilco Electric Inc., which he ran until his recent retirement. Bill established a Scholarship fund to permanently endow some twenty scholarships at NJIT for the disabled, for the Honors College, and for students from Paterson and other New Jersey inner-cities. In 1990, NJIT recognized Bill's contributions to the school and his advocacy for the physically and developmentally disabled population by naming its five-story, 150,000 square foot building the WILLIAM S. GUTTENBERG INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CENTER. Then, in 2000, Bill was named OUTSTANDING ALUMNUS, and in 2008, he received an honorary DOCTOR of SCIENCE degree. Bill was among the group of five parents who, in 1978, established SPECTRUM for LIVING, an organization that devoted itself to the care of the developmentally-disabled population. Today SPECTRUM serves over 700 clients, an ICF, 14 Group Homes, five Apartments and six Adult Training Centers. Bill expanded the special-service activities of the JCC on the PALISADES with generous donations. The JCC responded by naming those services the GUTTENBERG CENTER for SPECIAL SERVICES. Bill was married to Adele Rita Basch, daughter of Fred and Natalie Basch of Teaneck for 58 years. They had two children, Frances Robin and Charles Gary. His wife and children predeceased him. In 2009, he married Aden Maza Marbratu of Addis Ababa. He is survived by his wife and two stepsons, Hennock and Simon. Funeral Services were handled by Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ and interment took place in the New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Spectrum for Living, 210 River Vale Road, River Vale, NJ 07675.

GREENBERG--Steven A. The Scharf Family mourns the passing of their dear friend Steven Greenberg. He has been an important part of our lives since 1972. He led a uniquely interesting life characterized by both business success and helping those in need. His generosity was ever present and boundless. Steven's uncanny resemblance to Benjamin Franklin extended to more than appearance. He also had Franklin's integrity, imagination, creativity, brilliance, warmth and humor. In many respects Steven was a creative genius. Recently, his creative juices went into overdrive as he created "230 Fifth Avenue", which quickly became the most successful bar in New York and a "must see" attraction for visiting international travelers. Steven was a true "mensch" who performed good deeds every day of his life, and we will miss him every day of our lives. Rest in peace "Best Friend" and dear "Uncle Steven." Michael and Fiona Scharf Andrew and William Scharf

Alison Klayman's documentary ''Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry,'' an award-winning chronicle of that provocative Chinese artist who was detained by his country's government for three months last year, has been acquired for North American distribution by Sundance Selects and will receive a theatrical release this summer, the distributor said on Tuesday. Ms. Klayman, a journalist and filmmaker, began meeting with Mr. Ai in 2008. Last year, his studio in Shanghai was demolished and the artist himself was detained by Chinese authorities for 81 days, from Aprilthrough June. Though Chinese officials said they were investigating him for tax evasion, Mr. Ai is an outspoken critic of that nation's government and has used his blog and other online outlets to call attention to its human rights violations.

Last month, the British historian Simon Schama took aim at ''Downton Abbey,'' denouncing it in Newsweek as an exercise in ''cultural necrophilia,'' a ''servile soap opera'' and a ''steaming, silvered tureen of snobbery.'' (To which millions of American television viewers apparently replied, ''Yes, and ?'') Now, the British poet James Fenton has piled on, if more gently, in the generally Anglophilic pages of The New York Review of Books. In an essay titled ''The Abbey That Jumped the Shark,'' Mr. Fenton accuses the show not just of absurd plot twists, geographical inconsistencies and excessively buried gay subplots, but of brazenly promoting the class interests of its creator, Julian Fellowes, ''aka Julian Kitchener-Fellowes, a k a the Conservative peer the Baron Fellowes of West Stafford, Lord of the Manor of Tattershall.''

Following through on a pledge to carry more minority-owned cable channels, Comcast on Tuesday indicated its support for four such channels, including one from the music mogul Sean Combs and another from the former basketball star, Magic Johnson. The first of the four is called BabyFirst Americas, a commercial-free channel owned and operated by Hispanic-Americans. The channel, which begins April 1, will include content for children under age 3. The second one, led by Mr. Johnson, is called Aspire and will start this summer. Aspire is described as an uplifting, entertaining channel for African-American families.

12:25 p.m. | Updated It has adorned everything from mugs and t-shirts to key chains, anti-George Bush campaign buttons, inflatable dolls and iPad covers. Now a version of Edvard Munch's celebrated painting ''The Scream'' will be up for sale at Sotheby's in New York on May 2nd, the auction house announced on Tuesday morning. Officials there estimate it could bring more than $80 million. Munch made four versions of the composition, which has become the embodiment of angst and existential dread. Three are in Norwegian museums and this one, pastel on board, from 1895, is the only ''Scream'' still in private hands. It is being sold by Petter Olsen, a Norwegian businessman and shipping heir whose father, Thomas, was a friend, neighbor and patron of the artist.

Who says you have to journey to the deserts of Indio, Calif., or the farm country of Manchester, Tenn., to enjoy top musical acts while risking dehydration and exposure to the summer sun? If you're a New York-area resident (or even if you're not) you can do all that right here at Randalls Island Park, where the organizers of the Governors Ball Music Festival said that event's second annual outing will take place this year. The festival (which was held for the first time last year at Governors Island) will take place on June 23 and 24, and promises performances on two stages with no overlapping sets, the festival's producers, Founders Entertainment, said Tuesday in news release.

The critically acclaimed Off Broadway production of ''The Lyons,'' Nicky Silver's black comedy starring Linda Lavin as an acid-tongued family matriarch, will transfer to Broadway this April in time to qualify for eligibility for the 2012 Tony Awards, the play's lead producer announced on Tuesday - adding another high-profile new play and more notable performances to the Tonys horse race this spring. Ms. Lavin and Dick Latessa, both Tony winners, will return with the production to the Cort Theater, where the play ''Stick Fly'' will close on Sunday. Mr. Latessa played the patriarch in ''The Lyons'' last fall in the Vineyard Theater production; the other cast members there -- Michael Esper, Kate Jennings Grant, Brenda Pressley and Gregory Wooddell - are expected to return for Broadway as well, a spokesman for the production said.

9 P.M. (13) DON GIOVANNI Mariusz Kwiecien makes his Metropolitan Opera debut as Mozart's promiscuous nobleman in this new production from Michael Grandage, originally broadcast in theaters on Oct. 29 and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' Marina Rebeka and Mojca Erdmann sing the roles of Donna Anna and Zerlina, two of Giovanni's conquests; Barbara Frittoli (above, with Mr. Kwiecien) is the fiery Donna Elvira, his spurned lover out for revenge; Ramón Vargas is Donna Anna's fiancé, Don Ottavio; and Luca Pisaroni is Giovanni's hapless manservant, Leporello. Mr. Kwiecien, who injured himself at a dress rehearsal and was replaced for opening night and two other performances, ''looked nimble on his feet, sang robustly and threw himself into the title role,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times. ''Whatever one's take on Mr. Kwiecien's portrayal of a role he considers his calling card, his performance was a triumph of physical rehabilitation and artistic determination.'' Mr. Tommasini called the orchestra's performance under Fabio Luisi, the Met's principal conductor, ''a fleet, clear-textured and wonderfully natural account of this multilayered, ingenious score.'' 7 A.M. (Cinemax) BIG FISH (2003) Albert Finney plays Edward Bloom (Ewan McGregor is his youthful version), a traveling salesman from Alabama who has spent a lifetime shading and embellishing the truth in this fantasy from Tim Burton, adapted from the novel by Daniel Wallace. Billy Crudup is Bloom's estranged son, Will, a reporter in Paris who has been summoned home for a deathbed reconciliation, during which Edward elaborates on his biography. Edward's doctor asks: Wouldn't Will prefer to believe that on the day of his birth his father was subduing a legendary catfish rather than selling household gadgets in Wichita? ''The movie insists that the only possible answer is yes, and thus chooses maudlin moonshine over engagement with the difficulties of real life, which is exactly the choice Edward has made,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''In their eagerness to celebrate Edward's grand spirit, the filmmakers wind up diminishing it, declining to explore the causes or the costs of his addiction to fantasy.'' Danny Elfman received an Oscar nomination for best original score.

SWEETER and less overbred than leopard spots, more cuddly than those Givenchy Rottweiler tees, cat prints are having a moment. Last seen prominently on Miu Miu's spring 2010 runway -- be glad if you own one of those -- the feline popped up as an origami-like print on silk p.j. separates at Piamita; on flirty smock dresses in Victoria Beckham's new secondary line; and, at Fashion Week, on kitty-face sweaters worn by bloggers like Susie Bubble and Hanneli Mustaparta, courtesy of an Opening Ceremony collaboration with Glamour magazine. The most charming cat moment of the week, however, came on the Miguel Adrover runway. For his fall collection, the contrarian designer showed a sweater dress with stuffed knit cats mischievously crawling around it (above). Not for everyone, but seriously cute. Above right, Piamita silk cat-print pants, $260 at Barneys New York; silk charmeuse shirt, $250 at shopbop.com. Top, Opening Ceremony x Glamour limited-edition

LONDON -- Britons sometimes celebrate sports as a metaphor for life itself, from the possibly apocryphal assertion by the Duke of Wellington that the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton to the pepperings of cricket in political analysis: a politician ''on the back foot'' is, usually, deemed to be on the defensive; the front foot denotes muscular attack. But, if those comparisons bear scrutiny, then events on the nation's soccer pitches in recent times offer a more painful conclusion, conjuring questions of race and identity many decades after Britain embarked on a long and tortured transformation from a largely white society to one in which ethnic diversity has come to claim an ambiguous position, somewhere between a commonplace and a stubborn source of contention, hatred and even violence.

Occasionally in the coming weeks and months, The Agenda will introduce you to small-business owners who are wrestling with how to provide health insurance to their employees. Over time, we hope to delve into all aspects of a crucial decision - not just managing the costs but sorting out benefit packages, weighing alternatives, and dealing with insurers and brokers. Along the way, we hope to get a better understanding of how the 2010 health-care legislation will, or won't, affect small businesses. Today we meet Ann Gish, who designs high-end bed linens from offices in Manhattan. As we proceed with this series, we'd like to hear from you. What questions would you like us to ask of the business owners we profile? Do you have an interesting health insurance story to tell? Please drop us a line.

Last week, we published a case study recounting a dilemma faced by Action Ambulance, a provider of ambulance and transportation services to hospitals, nursing homes, rehabilitation facilities and special-education programs within school systems. The 260-employee company, which is based in Wilmington, Mass., 17 miles north of Boston, was facing increasing competition. Its chief executive, Mike Woronka, believed a more aggressive approach to sales might lure business from his seven direct competitors and also expand Action's territory. But targeted sales, Mr. Woronka said, are unusual in his industry, where account managers generally push gently and gradually for new business. He needed to decide whether he could train his existing account managers to be more proactive or whether he would need to hire a full-time sales representative to pursue new accounts. He also considered hiring a sales manager to oversee the team.

Federal regulators are narrowing a list of possible new safeguards for customers at futures firms, a response to the collapse of MF Global and the disappearance of more than $1 billion in client cash. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will hold a public roundtable next week to discuss policy changes, including a plan that would allow customers to trade through futures brokerage firms without keeping their excess cash there, according to a copy of the agenda provided to The New York Times.

Mitt Romney, seeking to kick-start his presidential campaign among recalcitrant conservatives, on Wednesday proposed cutting the top income tax for individuals to 28 percent while holding out the prospect of limiting tax deductions. Mr. Romney's earlier economic plan called only for preserving the current top tax rate of 35 percent, while holding out the promise of lower rates later in an overhaul of the tax code. But facing a major challenge from the upstart Republican rival Rick Santorum, he chose to outline such an overhaul in Arizona before critical primaries here and in Michigan next Tuesday - and before a televised debate Wednesday night in Mesa, Ariz.

ENERGY ACQUISITION Royal Dutch Shell agreed on Wednesday to buy the oil exploration company Cove Energy for £992 million ($1.6 billion) as it looks to expand into East Africa in search of new energy reserves. Shell, the British-Dutch energy giant, said it would pay Cove Energy's shareholders 195 pence apiece for their shares, 29 percent above Cove's closing share price on Tuesday. MARK SCOTTCHEAP GREEK DEBT Despite their previous losses from investing in Greek debt, a number of hedge funds are said to be considering another round of bets. This time, the funds are looking at the cheapest Greek bonds on the street: long-term, local-law bonds that currently trade at 19 cents on the euro -- a knock-down price that reflects Greece's ailing condition. By buying these bonds and then swapping them for new longer-term Greek securities when a debt restructuring takes place next month, the funds hope to make a quick profit. Traders and analysts expect the new bonds to have a market value of 26 to 30 cents. LANDON THOMAS Jr.

Last week, it finally became clear that the Volcker Rule was as good as dead. The Volcker Rule, named after Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is meant to bar financial institutions that are protected and subsidized by the federal government from trading for their own accounts. That is, it's pretty simple: Traders shouldn't speculate for their own personal gain using the money you and I pay in taxes.

FARRELLY--Peter Joseph, age 77, of St. Augustine, FL, passed away February 18, 2012, at his home. Born and raised in Dublin, Ireland, he spent most of his adult life in the Chicago area as Cargo Sales Manager for Air New Zealand and Proprietor of "All Things Irish." He relocated to St. Augustine in 2009. A loving husband and father, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by his beloved wife, Etta, of St. Augustine; sons, Joseph of Washington, D.C. and Donald of Delray Beach, FL; sisters, Mary Carmel and Philomena of Dublin; brothers, John of New York, Desmond, Henry, and Martin of Dublin, and Tiarnach (Phil) of London. Funeral Mass will be held Friday, February 24, at the Cathedral Basilica of St. Augustine. Interment will follow at 4:30pm on Friday at Calvary Cemetery in Clearwater, FL. A visitation will be held this evening at St. Johns Family Funeral Home, 385 State Road 207, St. Augustine, FL, 32084. St Johns (tel. 1-904-824-1672) is in charge of arrangements. LONDON -- James Whitaker, considered by many of his peers to be the dean of the tight-knit pack of reporters who specialize in covering the British royal family, had the good fortune that comes to those in all walks of life who fall into jobs to which they are innately suited. Mr. Whitaker, who died last week at the age of 71 after a year's battle with cancer, had chronicled the lives of Queen Elizabeth II and her family for 45 years, a career that had its genesis, he said, in the late 1960s, when, as a junior reporter, he was assigned to cover a polo match in which Prince Charles was playing, and to write a diary column about it.

Gordon--Sally. The Board of Directors and staff of the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation express their sadness at the loss of Sally Gordon, wife of Board member, Michael Gordon. She inspired us with her courage and strength, as well as her warmth and kindness. She was deeply committed to supporting research to end all suffering from cancer. In her memory, we will rededicate ourselves to this goal. Our hearts go out to her family.

MATORIN--Esther, nee Ginsburg. On February 20. Beloved mother of Sue Ellen Appleman (Warren) and the late Carl (Helene) Matorin. Loving sister to the late Rose Levine and sister-in-law B. Matorin. Adored grandmother of David, Sarah, Neal and Rebecca. Cherished great-grandmother of Nathan. Devoted aunt to Hirschel, Deanna, Carol and Janet. Dear friend of Rhoda. Services will be private.

ZUCKERMAN--Jack, 88 years. The Council of School Supervisors and Administrators mourns the passing of one of its founders and former president. Jack, a veteran of World War II, was a devoted educator who began his career as a teacher in the NYC public school system in 1948. Deeply grounded in the ideals and beliefs of the labor movement since childhood, he turned his attention to organizing school supervisors in 1959, giving them a unified voice. With several of his brothers and sisters in the labor movement, he succeeded in getting a charter from the AFL-CIO to form a national union which today is AFSA (American Federation of School Administrators). Jack was the Vice President of CSA when Governor Hugh Carey was persuaded to recognize it as a union shop and he stood beside the Governor when legislation was signed making that a fact. After retirement, Jack became AFSA and CSA's official historian and remained until his death the keeper of the flame that illuminates our 50-year history as a union. We salute Jack and extend our heartfelt sympathy to Estelle, his beloved wife of 62 years, and their cherished children Lois and Marc Zuckerman and granddaughters Nora and Hannah.

JERUSALEM -- The Israeli Supreme Court has invalidated a law that exempted from military service ultra-Orthodox Jews engaged in religious studies, adding a new urgency to the government's negotiations with religious parties over a more equitable distribution of the burdens of citizenship. The 6-to-3 decision, handed down late Tuesday, declared the so-called Tal Law unconstitutional at a time of growing tension in Israel over the place of the ultra-Orthodox. The law, in effect since 2002, granted exemptions to tens of thousands of religious academy students. It was widely viewed as a failure, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had already said it would not be renewed when it expired this summer.

UMIN--Steven M. 73, died peacefully February 19, at his home in Washington, D.C. after a long fight with Frontal Temporal Degeneration (FTD). Born January 28, 1939, he was raised in the Bronx (NYC). Valedictorian of New Rochelle High School, NY; graduate of Yale University (Summa Cum Laude, Valedictorian, 1959), Rhodes Scholar, Oxford University (1959-1961), Yale Law School (1961-1964), Law Clerk to Chief Justice Roger Traynor, California Supreme Court (1964-1965), Law Clerk to Potter Stewart, Associate Justice, Supreme Court of the United States (1965-1966), Attorney at Williams & Connolly, Washington, D.C. (1966 2004), Deputy Counsel, United States Senate Subcommittee on the Judiciary, Member - Central & Eastern Europe Legal Institute, Member Advisory Committee, United States Court of Appeals, Public Member United States Delegation Vienna Conference on Helsinki Treaty, Board Multiple Sclerosis International Federation, and Adjunct Professor of Law, Georgetown Law Center. Steven Umin will be remembered as a lawyer of exceptional talent whose bold intellectual curiosity, humor and incisiveness underpinned his numerous academic and professional achievements. He was a warm, compassionate, and loving person whose loyalty to his family, friends, and colleagues, to Camp Mooween, Yale, and the New York Giants, touched all and will never be forgotten. Steve's support of the New York Giants was instilled by his father, who took him to his first game when he was four-years-old. Despite living in Washington, D.C. for 42 years, and working daily with Edward Bennett Williams of Williams & Connolly, owner of the Washington Redskins, Steve's dedication to his home team never wavered. He is survived by his loving wife, Candace R. Umin, and loving family, his daughter, Courtney of Washington, D.C., his sister, Gail Massot of Arlington, Va., and his niece and nephew, Randa Massot of Paris, France, and Olivier Massot of Arlington, Va. The Family will receive visitors at Gawler's Funeral Home, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue, Washington, D.C. 6:30 9:00pm, Thursday, February 23, 2012. A Memorial Service will be held at Washington Hebrew Congregation, at 2:00pm, Friday, February 24, 2012. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Steven's name to The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration (AFTD) in support of research.

Amazon.com removed more than 4,000 e-books from its site this week after it tried and failed to get them more cheaply, a muscle-flexing move that is likely to have significant repercussions for the digital book market. Amazon is under pressure from Wall Street to improve its anemic margins. At the same time, it is committed to selling e-books as cheaply as possible as a way to preserve the dominance of its Kindle devices.

ONEIDA, N.Y. -- The trucks lumber past cornfields and dilapidated farm houses, pull up to a onetime bingo hall and unload their cargo: boxes of tobacco imported from the Carolinas. Inside, employees of the Oneida Indian Nation dump the shredded tobacco leaves into rolling machines and fashion them into cigarettes to be sold at a dozen tribal convenience stores midway between Syracuse and Utica.

WEIDNER--Frederick III, 83, a four-year resident of Kent, CT, formerly of Upper Montclair, NJ, died Sunday, February 19, 2012, at a local nursing home. Mr. Weidner owned and operated Fred Weidner & Son Printers, Inc., in Manhattan from 1963 to 1999. Born on July 12, 1928, in Brooklyn, he was the son of the late Frederick Weidner, Jr., and Dorothea Albert Weidner. On March 9, 1963, he married Nancy Marian Guild who survives at home. After graduating in 1950 from Bowdoin College in Brunswick, ME, he won a Fulbright Scholarship to Germany. Blessed with a beautiful tenor voice, he sang professionally in Germany during the 1950's and upon his return to the United States he maintained numerous affiliations with organizations such as the Blue Hill Troupe, Canterbury Choral Society, The Players and the Episcopal Actors' Guild, all based in New York City, and with the American Institute of Musical Studies, based in Texas. All would benefit greatly by a memorial donation in his name. He is also survived by two daughters, Alyson Harkins of Hutto, TX, and Cynthia Weidner of New City, NY; a sister, Norma Weidner of Kent; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, February 25, 2012, at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 1 North Main Street in Kent.

An article in some editions on Friday about Joe Nesci, the men's basketball coach at New York University who this season set the school record for career wins with his 410th, misidentified the site where former N.Y.U. coach Howard Cann gained his 409th career victory, on March 4, 1958. That milestone came with a win over City College at Fordham, not at Madison Square Garden.

SCHNUR--Leon, of Warren, Ohio died February 21, 2012. A graduate of City College of New York and the New York University College of Dentistry, he passed away peacefully in the presence of his devoted daughter, Dr. Nancy Schnur. He is survived by his loving children, Susan of Warren and Dr. Gary Schnur of Shaker Heights, Ohio. He is also survived by his son-in-law, Dr. Peter Sherman of Scarsdale, New York and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife of 45 years, Lorre Schnur. He lived his last few years comfortably at The Osborn in Rye, New York. He is also survived by his wife, Rose Schnur of Boca Raton, Florida. Leon was a kind, gentle person who loved to travel, especially while riding his bicycle. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched.

The Grammy Awards helped push Adele to two new sales milestones last week: The 730,000 sales of her album ''21'' (XL/Columbia) last week represent the biggest ''Grammy bump'' in two decades, and also become the first to sell 2 million copies on iTunes. Whitney Houston, who died the day before the Grammys and was given several tributes on the show, was up four spots to No. 2 on this week's chart, with 175,000 sales of ''Whitney: The Greatest Hits'' (Arista), a 174 percent weekly gain.

Millions of television and Web viewers spent time Saturday afternoon watching the funeral service for Whitney Houston, the pop music icon who died a week earlier. CNN was the biggest beneficiary of the viewer vigil, according to Nielsen ratings. The cable news channel had an average of five million viewers between 12:15 and 3:45 p.m., the hours that it and other channels carried the funeral service without commercial interruption.

RUBIN--Donald S. February 20, 2012 -- The McGraw-Hill family fondly remembers the life of Donald S. Rubin, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. He will be profoundly missed by thousands of colleagues for his wisdom, integrity and wit during his exceptional 52-year career with the corporation. Don personified all that is best in human nature and in McGraw-Hill; he was selfless in his support for others, unswerving in seeking truth, and original, genuine and inspiring. Don began his career as a sports writer, reporter and magazine editor before serving in executive positions at McGraw-Hill. At home, he and wife Nancy treasured the cultural scene in New York City and enjoyed playing tennis. His McGraw-Hill colleagues in the U.S. and around the world express their deepest sympathy to Nancy and his family, including children Alexander (Karolann) and Laura, and grandchildren James, Logan and Isabella. A private family service will be held in Stamford, CT and a memorial will be held at a later date. Donations in Don's memory can be made to the New York Public Library.

Fredo Corleone was memorably warned by his brother Michael, ''Don't ever take sides with anyone against the family again.'' But now it looks as if a judge will have to come down on one side of the media empire that has grown up around the Corleone clan and the ''Godfather'' novels that spawned them, in a lawsuit that pits Paramount Pictures, the studio that released the ''Godfather'' movies, against Anthony Puzo, the executor of the estate of Mario Puzo, the author of the books. Paramount has sued Anthony Puzo, a son of the novelist, seeking to stop publication of a new ''Godfather'' novel called ''The Family Corleone,''Reuters reported. The studio says that it gave permission for a 2004 sequel, ''The Godfather Returns,'' written by Mark Winegardner and published by Random House, but not for a 2006 follow-up, ''The Godfather's Revenge,'' also by Mr. Winegardner and published by Putnam.

MAE SOT, THAILAND -- Pity the Burmese dissident in exile. For more than two decades they were symbols of defiance against Myanmar's military dictatorship, campaigning tirelessly in foreign countries for regime change. Now that the Myanmar government is earning plaudits for its program of reforms, hundreds of dissidents living abroad may need career counseling.

A new musical adaptation of ''Kinky Boots,'' the 2005 British film about a drag queen named Lola who helps save a family shoe factory, will have a pre-Broadway tryout run in Chicago this October, the producers Daryl Roth and Hal Luftig announced on Wednesday. No dates were given for a Broadway production, but Ms. Roth has said she is aiming for the 2012-13 season. ''Kinky Boots'' would be the Broadway debut of the pop musician Cyndi Lauper as a composer and lyricist; the show's book is by Harvey Fierstein (''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''Newsies'') and the director and choreographer is Jerry Mitchell (''Legally Blonde'''). In recent readings the actor Billy Porter (the Off Broadway revival of ''Angels in America'') has played Lola, while the Tony Award nominee Stark Sands (''Journey's End,'' ''American Idiot'') has played the shoe business scion Charlie Price. No casting has been confirmed for Chicago or Broadway, but the creative team was said to be happy with the work of the two actors.

LAURA VELA introduced her handbag line a year ago at Fashion Week. Parsons-educated by way of business school, Ms. Vela had taken inspiration from a trip to Argentina, where she studied with renowned leather craftsmen, and her debut collection had the worn-yet-sturdy look of a world traveler's baggage. Since then, she has begun to play with color and texture. A small chain-strap bag, good for evening, is trimmed with turquoise embossed-croc leather and gold piping. A briefcase shape, which recalled her father, José, a doctor in Spain, comes in black and off-white and in this navy and rust combination. Sensible prices -- between $300 and $500 -- are refreshing, too. Laura Vela suede-and-leather handbag, $370 at lauravela.com.

The e-mail from the Obama campaign found the right target: Dave Hunt, lifelong Democrat from Upper Manhattan and owner of an Irish saloon, had contributed to President Obama's 2008 victory drive. Now, just in time for St. Patrick's Day, barackobama.com was peddling ''O'Bama'' T-shirts, playing on the president's wee trace of Irish blood and his joke on a visit to Ireland last year that he had ''come home to find the apostrophe that we lost somewhere along the way.''

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Marie Colvin recognized the significant story unfolding in the rebellious Syrian city of Homs. The problem was how to get at it. She had been hoping for an official visa to visit Syria's capital, Damascus, but with none forthcoming, she decided to sneak over the border despite strong misgivings about her safety in Homs, which is suffering a constant battering from government tanks and heavy artillery.

MOSHER--Sally. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Paul Mosher. Loving mother of Joan Weill (Sandy) and Michael Van Scoy-Mosher (Claudia), adored grandmother of Jessica Bibliowicz (Natan), Marc Weill, Oriana Van Scoy-Mosher and Lauren Watstein, and fun loving "Gigi" to Tommy Bibliowicz (Megan), David Bibliowicz, Laurel Weill and Matt Weill. Devoted big sister to baby brother, Max Desfor, and adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sally celebrated her 100th birthday in June in great spirits and made a speech thanking everyone there. Sally was a very talented sculptor, working with stone until her 94th year. Sally was, and will always be, an inspiration to all of us never giving up, never complaining and Sally always kept her wicked sense of humor. Because you have been with us over 100 years, it is hard for me to believe you won't be on the phone with me every day, asking about all of us, including Angel. We all love you very much Mother you will be in our hearts forever. Rest in peace next to Daddy. Your devoted children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and all who knew you.

AT the Berlin Film Festival earlier this month, Diane Kruger accessorized her Giambattista Valli couture gown with a black gold and diamond cuff around one ear. The Repossi ear cuff was surely a statement piece, if, at more than $10,000, not an accessible one. The earpieces that the Norwegian designer Bjorg creates are within reach, and kind of fabulous: a bit surreal, strangely sexy. One gold style wraps the ear with multiple hanging chains; another doubles as a bracelet. If you think of yourself as a fashion risk-taker, pull back your hair and accessorize with this horsehair pair. There's a statement, even a mesmerizing one. Bjorg horsehair ear cuffs, $175 each at Henrik Vibskov, 456 Broome Street; (212) 219-3950.

Listening to audiobooks and podcasts on an iPhone or an iPod Touch can help make a commute or workout go faster, but unexpected interruptions can make you miss some of those spoken words. If this happens to you, just tap the iPhone or iPod Touch to bring up the Now Playing screen with your current audio selection. Tap the screen again to call up a layer of controls. Find the icon in the center of the screen that looks like an arrow encircling the number 30, and tap it to jump back 30 seconds in the audiobook or podcast. You can also increase or decrease the narrator's reading speed by tapping the 1X, 2X or 1/2X button on the right side of the screen. Podcasts have other screen icons as well, including an envelope button to send the show's link to a friend, and separate buttons to ''like'' or comment about the episode on Apple's Ping social network.

The cable channel TBS announced on Wednesday that it had extended its contract with Conan O'Brien to star in the late-night series he began on the network in November 2010. The new agreement, which amounted to picking up an existing option, will guarantee that Mr. O'Brien will remain on TBS through April 2014.

An article on Wednesday about the anticipated sale of a version of Edvard Munch's celebrated work ''The Scream'' described it incorrectly in one instance. As the article initially noted, it is a work of pastel on board; it is not a ''painting'' or a prized ''canvas.''

A gender gap for Rick Santorum has surfaced in the most recent set of polls released before next week's primaries, with women in Arizona supporting Mitt Romney over Mr. Santorum by nearly 2 to 1. This is the first time in the campaign that polling in various states, as well as exit polls, has shown that the support for Mr. Santorum has become noticeably uneven between men and women.

LONDON -- Martin Abbott, chief executive of the London Metal Exchange, has a lot on his plate. Along with running the world's largest metal futures exchange, Mr. Abbott also is overseeing a bidding process that could lead to the 1 billion ($1.6 billion) takeover of the 135-year-old L.M.E.

The last Broadway production of ''Death of a Salesman'' was only 13 years ago, starring Brian Dennehy in a Tony-winning performance as Willy Loman, yet audience interest in Arthur Miller's landmark drama appears higher than ever. A new ''Salesman'' arrived on Broadway last week, starring Oscar winner Philip Seymour Hoffman (''Capote'') as Willy and the movie star Andrew Garfield (''The Amazing Spider-Man'') as his son Biff, and grossed $613,569 for its first six preview performances - more money per performance than the early previews for either the Dennehy production in 1999 or its predecessor, the Dustin Hoffman-led ''Salesman'' in 1984. In its first week at the box office, this new ''Salesman'' beat every other play on Broadway except for the hit ''War Horse,'' which won the 2011 Tony for best play and grossed $926,111 for its full eight performances last week. The maximum possible gross for the six performances of ''Salesman'' last week was $731,760; the production took in 84 percent of that amount, an extremely high share for a play.

Like many people, I downloaded a new to-do list app that came out on Thursday, Clear ($1 on the App Store), and started messing around with it.(Others have done that too; it's already No. 1 on Apple's App Store) A few initial thoughts: Clear's interface is elegant and clever. The app avoids using any simulacra of physical controls - there are no ''buttons,'' no ''switches'' (well, except for a pop-up keyboard, but you kind of need that).

Small companies in America do not tend to expand employment as much over long periods as large ones, according to new statistics from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. But employment levels have been more stable at smaller companies during economic downturns, particularly during the recession beginning in 2000.

Carlos Soria, 73, is on course to become the oldest man to ascend the 14 mountains in the world of more than 8,000 meters, or 26,250 feet, having already reached the summit of 10. In early March, he is leaving his village of Moralzarzal, 50 kilometers, or 31 miles, outside Madrid, for Nepal, where he will climb in the Annapurna section of the Himalayas. Soria said his goal had never been to set records. Instead, he wants to help rewrite the guidelines for what older people should aim for. Read more»

DARMER--Mary Katherine Baird, of Newport Beach, California, died February 17, 2012. She was born on October 31, 1964 in Atlanta, Georgia. She leaves behind her husband of twelve years, Roman Ernest Darmer, and their two children, Lelia Jane Darmer, 11, and Matthew Locke Darmer, 8. Katherine is also survived by her parents, Robert M. and Alice Baird of Waco, Texas; her brother, Robert D. Baird of St. Louis, Missouri; her sister, Susan Baird, and brother-in-law, Scott Gaynor, and nephews Malcolm and Dawson of Portage, Michigan; many loving aunts, uncles, cousins, and a great-uncle, R. Matthew Dawson of Waco. Also surviving Katherine is her beloved mother-in-law, Marie Darmer, of Tucson, Arizona. Katherine graduated from Princeton University, where she received her A.B. degree with high honors in 1986. She received her Juris Doctor degree in 1989 from Columbia University School of Law, where she was a Harlan Fiske Stone scholar and served as Articles Editor of the Columbia Journal of Environmental Law. Katherine served as a law clerk to the Honorable Kimba Wood of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, and to the Honorable William Timbers of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. She joined the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York city in 1991 as a litigation associate and left in 1995 to become an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. In 2000, she joined the faculty of Chapman University School of Law and was later promoted to Professor of Law. On a later sabbatical, she served as a senior fellow in the Gender and Sexuality Law Program at Columbia University School of Law. She was elected to be Chair of the Criminal Justice Section of the American Association of Law Schools in 2010. She will be remembered fondly by her family, friends, colleagues and students for her energy, keen intellect, and remarkable eloquence. A voracious reader and avid runner, she loved New York City and competed in the New York City Marathon several times. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark Presbyterian Church, 2200 San Joaquin Hills Road, Newport Beach, California, on February 25, 2012 at 11am. Remembrances may be made to The Riverside Church of New York City; Princeton University; or the Orange County Equality Coalition.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about a plan for theater companies to contribute five cents from every ticket sale to help bolster Off Off Broadway misstated the potential surcharge as a percent of the cost of the average Broadway ticket. It is .057 percent, not .0057.

Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a judge to impose a 23-year prison sentence on Christopher M. Coke, who has been described as one of the most powerful and brutal drug lords in Jamaica and whose arrest in 2010 came after a monthlong manhunt that left more than 70 people dead. Mr. Coke, 42, pleaded guilty in August to charges including racketeering conspiracy and is scheduled to be sentenced on Tuesday in Federal District Court.

Ryan Braun, the reigning most valuable player in the National League and one of baseball's brightest young stars, has become the sport's first player to successfully appeal a positive drug test and, as a result, escape a 50-game suspension. In a 2-1 vote, the panel that heard Braun's appeal agreed that valid questions had been raised about the manner in which the test sample was handled. Braun was tested on Saturday, Oct. 1, as his Milwaukee Brewers team was making its first appearance in the postseason in three years and, according to two people in baseball with knowledge of the case, the test collector first took the urine sample home and stored it in his refrigerator for two days before having it shipped to a laboratory in Montreal.

New York City's Education Department has called for investigations into nine high schools for irregularities in the way the schools scored examinations or awarded credits, and has identified hundreds of students in the city who were allowed to graduate without meeting basic requirements. Officials found problems at 55 of the 60 high schools reviewed in a special audit, including the improper grading of Regents exams, the graduation of students who did not meet credit and testing requirements, the awarding of credits for work not performed, and gaps in reporting about students who supposedly switched to other schools.

Because of an editing error, a theater review on Wednesday about ''Bad Kid'' -- David Crabb's solo show about being a gay, goth youth in Texas -- misidentified what the reviewer described as ''the most famous ancestor of the goth movement.'' It was Victor Frankenstein's monster, not Frankenstein.

McELROY--Robert R. The Pace Gallery mourns the passing of Robert R. McElroy and sends its deepest sympathy to his wife Evelyn McElroy. His lasting legacy is his photographic record of the New York art scene during the late 1950s and 1960s, specifically his documentation of the "Happenings" of Jim Dine, Allan Kaprow, Claes Oldenburg and Robert Whitman. His works of that period are currently on exhibition at The Pace Gallery.

BRONSTEIN--Norman, ended a rich and full life on February 16, 2012. A loving husband and father he leaves three children Sheila Schooler, Martin Bronstein, and Fern (Howard) Zlotoff; seven cherished grandchildren Marla (Sam) Kupersmith and Kim (Bradley) Peters, Barrett and Jordan (Leslie) Zlotoff and Lindsay (Adam) Sigrist, Hannah and Taylor Camfield Bronstein; and seven adored great-grandchildren Morgan and Brady Kupersmith and Emma, Molly and Lily Peters, Eli Zlotoff and Jackson Sigrist.

MOSHER--Sally. The Board and staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels send heartfelt condolences to past Board President Joan Weill on the loss of her mother, Sally Mosher. Joan's caring devotion to her mother is reflected in her deep commitment and compassion for New York's frail homebound elderly. Gael Greene Co-Founder & Chair Marcia Stein Founding Executive Director

Strauss--Florence. Loving mother to William Strauss of Bethesda, MD and Diane Zamecki of Pueblo, CO passed away on February 22. A memorial service will be held at Noon on February 26th Hines-Rinaldi Funeral Home, Silver Spring, MD.

10 P.M. (MSNBC) SEMPER FI: ALWAYS FAITHFUL (2011) In 1985 9-year-old Janey Ensminger died of acute lymphocytic leukemia, a disease she had been battling for more than two years. As her grief-stricken father, Master Sgt. Jerry Ensminger, above, a Marine Corps drill instructor, searched for answers, he made a shocking discovery: The drinking water at Camp Lejeune, the North Carolina base where he and his family had lived for years, was highly contaminated by toxic chemicals. Now, 25 years after the wells were closed, it is estimated that nearly one million Marines and their families may have been exposed to high levels of carcinogens through the water, and only a fraction of the base's former residents are aware of the danger. Lawrence O'Donnell hosts this presentation of a documentary by Rachel Libert and Tony Hardmon that was shown at the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival. 8:30 A.M. (USA) FROST/NIXON (2008) In May 1977 the British television personality David Frost (played by Michael Sheen, below) faced off against Richard M. Nixon (Frank Langella), three years after Nixon left the presidency in disgrace. Mr. Frost was gambling with his money and future; Nixon, with public perception (though he received $600,000 and 10 percent of the program's profits). The result was blockbuster ratings to rival those of ''Happy Days,'' starring Ron Howard, who directed this adaptation of Peter Morgan's play. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis described the film as ''a soothing, agreeably amusing experience, more palliative than purgative,'' adding that Mr. Langella and Mr. Sheen, who originated their roles on the London stage and later repeated them on Broadway, were first rate.

SCHNUR--Leon, of Warren, Ohio died February 21, 2012. A graduate of City College of New York and the New York University College of Dentistry, he passed away peacefully in the presence of his devoted daughter, Dr. Nancy Schnur. He is survived by his loving children, Susan of Warren and Dr. Gary Schnur of Shaker Heights, Ohio. He is also survived by his son-in-law, Dr. Peter Sherman of Scarsdale, New York and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife of 45 years, Lorre Schnur. He lived his last few years comfortably at The Osborn in Rye, New York. He is also survived by his wife, Rose Schnur of Boca Raton, Florida. Leon was a kind, gentle person who loved to travel, especially while riding his bicycle. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched.

Newt Gingrich used campaign cash to reimburse himself for more than $88,000 in travel expenses in January, despite repeated warnings from the Federal Election Commission about how his campaign has accounted for such expenses, according to documents filed with the commission this week. Those amounts come on top of more than $200,000 in lump-sum payments Mr. Gingrich drew from his campaign account during the last three months of 2011, according to the year-end filing he made at the end of last month. Those payments were all marked ''travel.''

A federal judge has released from prison a stock research analyst accused of insider trading, rejecting an appeal from prosecutors that he posed a danger to the community because of harassing voice messages he had left for government officials. The analyst, John Kinnucan, founder of Broadband Research in Portland, Ore., was charged earlier this week in New York with leaking secret information about technology companies to his hedge fund clients. He has proclaimed his innocence.

-Broadway divas were forever immortalized in Woody Allen's 1994 film ''Bullets Over Broadway'' by Dianne Wiest's Oscar-winning performance as Helen Sinclair, an aging grande dame who silenced sweet nothings from her amorous playwright by repeating theatrically, ''don't speak!'' Now Mr. Allen wants to have another go with Helen and ''Bullets'' - and Broadway: He is adapting his original screenplay, written with Douglas McGrath, into a stage musical that producers are aiming to open on Broadway in 2013. The producers, Julian Schlossberg and Letty Aronson, said on Thursday that the show would feature existing music from the period - Prohibition-era 1920s - in addition to the book by Mr. Allen. Like the movie, which was nominated for six other Academy Awards, the musical centers on an aspiring playwright (played by John Cusack in the film) forced to cast a mobster's no-talent girlfriend (Jennifer Tilly) in his show to find financing to produce it. The creative team, casting and performance schedule will be announced later.

MARILIA, Brazil - Atomico went off the beaten path for its first investment in Brazil, and not just in terms of geography. Last year, Haroldo Korte, a partner at the venture capital firm, drove 300 miles from Sao Paulo deep into the southern rural interior to meet with Paulo Biancalana, a self-made entrepreneur with no university education who had turned a local auto accessories dealer into a fast-growing Internet business. Working out of a ramshackle building, he had become the country's top seller on a leading e-commerce site, MercadoLibre, and started Connectparts - which together gave him annual sales of $10 million.

J.K. Rowling, the British author whose ''Harry Potter'' fantasy series ignited a passion for reading for millions of children around the world, has emerged from a five-year publishing hiatus with a new book: this time for adults. Little, Brown and Company, part of the Hachette Book Group, said on Thursday it had acquired the rights to publish the book, whose title and publication date was not named. ''Although I've enjoyed writing it every bit as much, my next book will be very different to the Harry Potter series, which has been published so brilliantly by Bloomsbury and my other publishers around the world,'' Ms. Rowling said in a statement. ''The freedom to explore new territory is a gift that Harry's success has brought me, and with that new territory it seemed a logical progression to have a new publisher. I am delighted to have a second publishing home in Little, Brown, and a publishing team that will be a great partner in this new phase of my writing life.''

FOX--Marcia. February 23, after a long illness. Wife of Emanuel, mother of Jonathan, Becky, Eben. A lover of all fine things who could not resist one more rose. Services February 26, 1pm, Menorah Chapels Union, NJ.

An article in some editions on Feb. 13 about criticism of a New York Police Department program that includes photographing the irises of people who are arrested misspelled the name of a lawyer who said some clients had been held longer than usual after refusing to allow their irises to be photographed. She is Meghan Maurus, not Megan Morris. The article also misspelled the surname of a man who agreed to a photograph because he did not want to be held longer. He is Keegan Stephan, not Stefan.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about a bilingual marketing campaign for milk featuring the actress Salma Hayek, misstated the day that television commercials will begin. They will start on Monday, not today. (The campaign is to be announced formally today.)
FRIEDMAN--Samuel. 1/12/20 - 2/24/1985. Think of you everyday. We miss you. Love, Eleanor and son Arthur

BROWN--Aurelia Clifton, 87, "Thistle" died peacefully February 21st, New York City. Born 1925, Ardmore, Pennsylvania, daughter of James Crosby Brown and Gladys Pomeroy Jenkins. Exuberant aunt to dozens of Jenkins and Brown nieces and nephews, beloved mentor and helper to flocks of friends, who remember Thistle as both devoted and daring in her life and in her spirituality. She was an accomplished artist, and heart and soul and owner of Wingspread Gallery, Northeast Harbor, Maine 1969-2009. Memorial Services: New York, April 20th, 4pm, St. James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street; summer date in Northeast Harbor, Maine to be announced. In lieu of flowers gifts in her honor may be made to "The Organ Fund", St. Andrews' Church, 1231 Washington Blvd., Stamford, CT 06902 or to "Friends of Music", The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10025.

Updated, 4:15 p.m. | A school aide in Queens was arrested Thursday on charges of sexually abusing six 9- and 10-year-old girls at the school, becoming the fifth city school worker charged in the last few weeks with sexual crimes against children. The aide, Brett Picou, 30, of Public School 52 in Springfield Gardens, is awaiting arraignment on seven felony counts of sexual abuse, one felony count of repeated sexual abuse of a child and seven misdemeanor counts of forcible touching, the Queens district attorney's office said.

Sears Holdings moved on Thursday to allay fears that it could run low on cash this year, announcing plans to sell stores in transactions that the company says could raise nearly $800 million. But the deals also highlight the major challenges that Sears faces as it tries to stop a multiyear slump in its operations, analysts said.

The numbers do not lie: After a decade on top, ''American Idol'' is no longer the most popular show on television. That became clearer Wednesday when the former powerhouse took another sharp drop in the ratings, falling to a mark where, in the weekly rankings, it will be almost a full ratings point behind a newer singing sensation, ''The Voice,'' on NBC.

ROBERTS--Helen Shaw. On February 15, 2012, age 95, from Alzheimer's. Born in Pittsburgh, PA on December 14, 1916. Predeceased in 2007 by her husband, Joseph L. Roberts, Jr., a Pittsburgh jeweler, whom she married in 1948. Survived by her three daughters Melinda, Jean and Kyoki Christine and by Kyoki's son and grandsons, Joseph, David and Tristan Eliason. Graduated from the Westover School (Middlebury, CT) in 1934. Bred fox-hunters on her farm, Glimmer Glen, in Sewickley Heights, PA and rode for many years with the Sewickley Hunt. Also bred and showed Irish Wolfhounds. Memorial Service: In Sewickley, Saturday, February 25, 1:30pm, at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. Family can be contacted through kyoki@deepspringzen.org. or c/o Gladmore Farm, 879 Blackburn Road, Sewickley Heights, PA 15143.

Once upon a time, New York subway announcements were an unintelligible mishmash of growl and static. They've come a long way. Today, the mellifluous voice of Bernie Wagenblast, a transportation-voice-over specialist, is heard on many platforms, perpetually chipper and pausing mechanically with the insertion of appropriate train line numbers or letters. ''There is ... an uptown local ... 1 train ... to Van Cortlandt Park-242nd Street.'' Mr. Wagenblast's official repertory is relatively limited, however. City Room asked readers what announcements they would like to hear over subway speakers and brought in Mr. Wagenblast to record the requests in a studio at The New York Times. The results, including a two-minute rap, ''The Voice of Supreme Articulation / Spittin' mad 4-1-1 in the subway station,'' can be heard at nytimes.com/cityroom.

Stanley Brezenoff, President & CEO Continuum Health Partners Harris M. Nagler MD, President Beth Israel

DERIVATIVES RULES The big banks and traders that dominate the $600 trillion derivatives industry will face new oversight under a plan approved Thursday by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which is led by Gary Gensler, left. The final rules, passed on a 3-to-2 vote, spell out numerous requirements to bolster internal business standards. Firms must, for example, manage the risks posed by derivatives trading, prevent conflicts of interest and empower a chief compliance officer to prepare an annual report detailing a firm's internal controls. BEN PROTESS

1:08 p.m. | Updated The conductor Kurt Masur, 84 and increasingly frail, has withdrawn from performances of Beethoven's ''Missa Solemnis'' with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Thursday, Friday and Saturday in Boston and on March 6 at Carnegie Hall because of his ''current physical condition,'' the orchestra said in a statement without elaborating. Mr. Masur's assistant, Stefana Atlas, said a combination of vision problems and the toll of age had led him to cancel. ''His condition is not any different than it's been before,'' Ms. Atlas said in a telephone interview. ''But obviously he realized it was not good enough to meet the demands for the 'Missa Solemnis.' It's a very difficult piece. For him he says it's a mountain of a work. He felt he was not physically fit to attack this piece.'' It is the second consecutive year that the Boston Symphony has lost a marquee conductor for Carnegie appearances. Last season, James Levine, its music director at the time, pulled out of three concerts because of failing health. The statement said that Mr. Masur, a former music director of the New York Philharmonic, would go forward with performances with various orchestras in Israel, Germany, China and France in March and April. John Oliver, who conducts the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, which will also participate, will lead the Boston performances, and Mr. Masur's replacement for Carnegie has yet to be determined, the orchestra said.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- The potential scope of the fallout from the burning of several copies of the Koran by American military personnel this week became chillingly clear on Thursday as a man in an Afghan Army uniform shot and killed two American soldiers, while a crowd nearby protested the desecration of the Muslim holy book. In the third successive day of deadly violence over the Koran burning, seven Afghans were killed in three provinces on Thursday and many more were injured, most in skirmishes with Afghan security forces. The Afghan government, which had responded slowly on the first day of protests, was in high gear on Thursday as officials tried to tamp down emotions ahead of the Friday day of prayer. Western and Afghan authorities feared that there could be emotional demonstrations after the prayer that the Taliban and extremist elements would try to exploit.

An article on Wednesday about the detention of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, by French authorities investigating a prostitution case misstated the length of time a person can be detained without charge in France. It is 48 hours, with a possible extension to another 48 in serious cases -- not 24 hours with a possible extension of another 24.

Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. defended the Justice Department's record on financial fraud Thursday evening, asserting that the administration's ''record of success has been nothing less than historic.'' In a speech at Columbia University, Mr. Holder said, ''From securities, bank and investment fraud to mortgage, consumer and health care fraud - we've found that these schemes are as diverse as the imaginations of those who perpetrate them, and as sophisticated as modern technology will permit.''

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about some American Indian tribes in New York State that manufacture and sell their own cigarettes, which they say are exempt from the state's excise tax, misidentified the location of the Native Pride smoke shop and gas station, where some such cigarettes are manufactured and packaged. It is on the Cattaraugus Reservation, which is Seneca land, not in Cattaraugus, N.Y.

FRANKFURT - Several of Europe's largest banks provided a reminder Thursday of how much work remains to overcome the effects of the financial crisis that began in 2008 and the sovereign debt crisis that quickly followed. Burdened by their exposure to Greek government debt and other damaged assets, Royal Bank of Scotland, Credit Agricole in France and Dexia, a French-Belgian bank, all reported quarterly losses.

While the second season of the British import ''Downton Abbey'' may have drawn some criticism on its native shores, American audiences continue to find themselves entranced by the series. The PBS presentation of the Season 2 finale on Sunday averaged 5.4 million total viewers, according to Nielsen, the highest rating for a PBS program since the premiere of the Ken Burns documentary ''The National Parks: America's Best Idea'' in September 2009. The second season frequently doubled the average prime-time rating for PBS and, speaking to the strongly favorable word of mouth the show has generated, exceeded the average overnight metered market rating for the first season by 25 percent. Season 3 -- which will feature the addition of Shirley MacLaine to the cast as the American mother of Elizabeth McGovern's Countess of Grantham -- is being filmed. (Ms. MacLaine is now on the set, and according to Vulture, is ''already tweeting Dowager Countess-worthy observations,'' including the news that ''I have Internet but this hotel has no phone service or TV. I feel I am on another planet.'') New episodes are scheduled to be broadcast in September in Britain, with the United States premiere to follow early next year.

A Memo From Jerusalem article on Wednesday, about the complexities of Israelis' views of the conflict in Syria, omitted part of a quotation by Hussein Sweiti, a journalist with an Israeli Arab newspaper, Al Sinara. When he commented on the forces arrayed against the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, he included Ayman al-Zawahri, the leader of Al Qaeda. Mr. Sweiti said in full: ''Our community is in a difficult situation. We cannot be in the same line with Zawahri, Netanyahu and Obama against Assad. And no matter who rules in Syria they will want the Golan back.''

No soup for you, Mitt Romney. At Wednesday's Republican presidential debate, Mr. Romney made a humorous attempt at brandishing his man-of-the-people bona fides by referring to a catchphrase from ''Seinfeld.''

The Lebanese director Nadine Labaki's feature ''Where Do We Go Now?,'' a top prize-winner at last year's Toronto International Film Festival, will be the opening-night presentation of the 41st New Directors/New Films series, the annual program organized by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. The lineup also includes Stanley Kubrick's feature-length debut as well as the first 3-D feature to be shown at New Directors/New Films, its organizers said on Thursday. ''Where Do We Go Now?,'' which won the Cadillac People's Choice Award in Toronto, tells a story of Muslim and Christian women in a remote village in Lebanon who band together to prevent its men from starting a religious war. The film, which was Lebanon's submission for the best foreign-language Oscar this year (but did not receive a nomination), will be shown at MoMA on March 21 and is to get a theatrical release from Sony Pictures Classics.

GRIER--Claudine Helene-Louise, born on April 26, 1964 in New York City, passed away on February 5th, 2012 in Los Angeles, CA. She was laid to rest on February 17th at The Saint Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx, NY. Claudine grew up in The Bronx, NY, attended St. Joseph's Montessori School in New Rochelle, NY, and The Academy of Mount Saint Ursula in The Bronx, NY. She graduated from Boston University earning a B.S. in Electrical Engineering and later an MBA from Columbia University. Claudine combined her skills as an engineer with her strong business acumen and applied them to a wide range of businesses, from start-ups to global powerhouses. Throughout her career, she held positions at Raytheon, IBM, Microsoft and Sage Metrics, among others. Most recently, Claudine co-founded Big Man Bakes, the gourmet cupcake bakery in Los Angeles. Claudine could light up a room with her ready smile and infectious laughter. She had boundless energy which drew people to her from all corners of the globe. Claudine is survived by her mother, Ruby Grier and her family. She is remembered by countless friends who all mourn the loss of a woman who was truly one-of-a-kind. Please join us this Saturday, February 25th, from 2-5pm to celebrate the life of Claudine at The Farmers & Merchants Bank, 401 Main Street in downtown Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, we request that a contribution be sent to Ms. Ruby Grier c/o WCG 650 Fifth Ave 11th Floor New York, NY 10019.

When I last wrote about Betterment, an online investment adviser that doesn't mind if you don't have a lot of money, I noted its promise but fretted over its relatively high prices, lack of international investments and lack of Individual Retirement Accounts. Since then, it has added international funds to the menu of exchange-traded funds it puts its customers in. And on Wednesday, it added regular, Roth and rollover I.R.A.'s to the mix.

4:25 p.m. | Updated For 12 weeks starting in the spring and summer of 2013, several hundred of New York City's water tanks will be wrapped with artist-designed creations. The project is the brainchild of Word Above the Street, a nonprofit organization whose mission is to raise awareness about the global water supply, and was first reported online in the Art Newspaper. ''We're hoping this project inspires New York to become more sustainable,'' said Mary Jordan, the organization's founder, adding that other objectives include ''to promote New York City tap water and lower our consumption of plastic waste.''

A map on Monday with the continuation of an article about the complex logistics Israel would face if it decided to strike Iran showed an incorrect starting point in some copies for one of three flight paths Israeli jets might use. An airstrike following a southern route would originate in Israel, as would the other two routes. It would not begin on Egypt's Sinai peninsula. The map also omitted the source of information. It was from the Center for Strategic and International Studies. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/world.

It was too bad to be true. The lute, said the composer Peter Schickele in his guise as perpetrator of the music of P.D.Q. Bach, is so quiet that you can't hear it if there is even another instrument in the same room with it. So when the lutenist Hank Heijink was listed in an announcement of Bach in the Subways Day, on March 21, Bach's 327th birthday, you could only imagine Mr. Heijink plinking away in some subway station against the roar of the trains. But it turns out that Mr. Heijink, more often heard playing the deeper-voiced theorbo in early-music performances in New York and elsewhere, will appear only in the followup concert, ''Happy Birthday Bach!,'' at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, on West 69th Street, on March 25. The musicians actually performing in the subways will be mainly cellists. The event is being organized by Dale Henderson, a cellist whose own underground performances have evolved into a standing program, Bach in the Subways. Donations will not be solicited, in line with Mr. Henderson's belief that ''the experience is infinitely more valuable when money is removed from the equation.''

LONDON -- The Lloyds Banking Group, partly owned by the British government, reported on Friday a loss for 2011 after it had to compensate some customers who were wrongly sold insurance. Lloyds, based in London, said its net loss for last year was 2.8 billion ($4.4 billion), compared with a 320 million loss for 2010. The loss resulted from a 3.2 billion provision the bank made last August after it inappropriately sold payment protection insurance, which covered customers if they were laid off or became ill. Other British banks, including Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, also have had to pay similar charges.

SZU-TU--Anthony. Anthony Y.S. Szu-Tu passed away peacefully surrounded by loved ones on February 18, 2012 after a brief illness. He was the beloved husband of his late wife, Marilyn. He is survived by his children: Arthur Szu-Tu and his wife, Carol; Vivien and her husband, Daniel Bean. He is also survived by his three grandchildren: Laura, Derek, and Ariane. Born 1923, in Beijing, China, Anthony obtained advanced degrees in International Law and Finance; he was also a published/produced playwright. He was on diplomatic assignment to the U.S. with his bride when the Communist Party took over China. Anthony spent the remainder of his professional career in life insurance and financial planning. His efforts garnered a Man of the Year Award in 1990 from Mutual of New York. Anthony will be remembered for his constant smile, his generosity, and the way he embraced life. Two weeks past his 89th birthday, Anthony was sporting a pink t-shirt and his characteristic smile as he crossed the finish line for the South Florida Race for the Cure. Funeral Services will be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, March 3, 2012 at the Quattlebaum Funeral Home 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, with Rev. Paul R. Manning, officiating. Friends may visit with the family from 12:30pm until service time. Entombment will be private for the family.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, ''The Behavior Gap,'' was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. It's hard to imagine just sitting on a pile of cash that ought to be invested, but the situation comes up more often than you might think. And such a situation can be intimidating, as there are natural fears that arise from deciding to invest a large sum. To cope, individuals may turn to a strategy called dollar-cost averaging, which can make sense in specific situations but cause problems in others.

10 P.M. (Showtime) THE TEMPEST (2010) Prospera (Helen Mirren, above), a vengeful sorceress, unleashes her powers against shipwrecked enemies in this adaptation of Shakespeare's drama by Julie Taymor, the director of the ''The Lion King'' on Broadway and the former director of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.'' Felicity Jones plays Miranda, Prospera's doted-on daughter; Djimon Hounsou is the slave Caliban; and Ben Whishaw is Ariel, the puckish spirit. Alan Cumming, as the treacherous Sebastian, and Chris Cooper, as Antonio, round out the ensemble; Tom Conti is the kindly Gonzalo; David Strathairn is King Alonso; and Russell Brand and Alfred Molina are servants driven by drink and idleness to absurd visions of sovereignty. ''In this noisy, stormy adaptation, an energetic and for the most part excellent cast marshals considerable resources of wit, discipline and timing in a struggle against the hectic inventiveness that is, characteristically for Ms. Taymor, either the vehicle for interesting theatrical ideas or a sign of their absence,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But rather than cohere into a compellingly new -- or satisfyingly traditional -- rendering of the play, they slosh around, generating glimmers of insight, slivers of feeling and spasms of sensation, as well as empty dazzle and frustration.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Hendrik Hertzberg, a senior editor and staff writer at The New Yorker, concludes his discussion of the 2012 campaign by suggesting that the United States elect its president by popular vote.
