SCHULHOF--Hannelore Buck. "Art is almost like a religion. It is what I believe in. It is what gives my life dimension beyond the material world." Such were the words of Mrs. Hannelore Buck Schulhof, devoted widow of Rudolph Schulhof and noteworthy patron of the arts, who peacefully passed away on February 23, 2012 at the age of 90. Hannelore was born in Berlin and raised in a home filled with art and music, subjects she continued to study throughout her life. She met her only true love, Czech born Rudolph, when she was a teenager in Vienna, with Europe on the brink of World War II. Hannelore and Rudolph escaped Nazi occupation to marry in Brussels in 1940. They soon settled in the United States, where they lived in love for the remainder of their lives. There they proudly raised a family of four children: Michael, Ronald (deceased), Thomas, and Wendy. American and European post war and contemporary art became a central interest in Hannelore's life. She was a collector, patron, museum trustee and great friend to artists, dealers and curators. She served on the Boards of the Guggenheim, Whitney, Brooklyn Museum, National Gallery of Art in Washington, The Israel Museum in Jerusalem, and the American Federation of Arts. Hannelore lived a life of passion and love for family and the arts. She travelled extensively. She was an avid music lover who played viola, and who attended countless performances of the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic. She was a gracious host who welcomed family and friends to visit the beauty of her home, and share in the many stories of her vast experience. Hannelore is survived by three children, as well as ten grandchildren and eighteen-great grandchildren, who all brought great joy to her life. Services will be held Monday, February 27 at 11:00am at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, followed by a private family burial service at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Westchester County.

The street artist Shepard Fairey, whose ''Hope'' campaign poster of Barack Obama became an enduring symbol of his last presidential campaign, pleaded guilty Friday to a charge stemming from his misconduct in trying to bolster claims in a lawsuit over which photograph had been used as a basis for the poster. Mr. Fairey, 42, sued The Associated Press in 2009 after it contended he had infringed on the copyright of one of its photographs in creating the poster. Mr. Fairey had claimed in his suit that he had used a different photograph of Mr. Obama, but later admitted that he had been mistaken and had tried to conceal his mistake, by destroying documents and fabricating others.

In the first political rebuke of one of the four Republican state senators who voted for same-sex marriage, the Erie County Conservative Party has endorsed a Democrat who is challenging Mark J. Grisanti's re-election bid. The county party's chairman, Ralph C. Lorigo, said Senator Grisanti had lost its trust after twice telling party executives, in 2008 and 2010, that he was not in favor of same-sex marriage, and then voting last year to legalize it.

An article on Friday about a NATO review of screening procedures for recruits in the Afghan security forces described incorrectly an order by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan that is to take effect next month. The order requires that as of March 20, the new Afghan Personal Protection Force, which is under control of the Afghan government, replace all private security contractors for development projects, convoys and commercial businesses in Afghanistan. The order does not require that as of March there be no more American private security contractors in Afghanistan. (Under a waiver, the Afghan Personal Protection Force will not replace private security contractors at NATO and American military bases in Afghanistan until March 20, 2013.) The article also misstated the middle initial of the commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan. He is Gen. John R. Allen, not John V.

The Opera Orchestra of New York announced on Friday that it had canceled its concert performance of Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra'' scheduled for March 7 at Avery Fisher Hall because of a ''loss of funding.'' The performance's novelty, of sorts, was that the tenor Placido Domingo was to have sung the baritone title role, though Mr. Domingo has already sung it in full productions at the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere. There are no plans to reschedule the concert, and ticketholders may request refunds. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHULHOF--Hannelore B. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of Hannelore B. Schulhof, Honorary Trustee. Hannelore and her late husband Rudolph Schulhof collected postwar European and American art with a remarkable passion and discernment over the course of a half century, and an important part of their collection will permanently reside at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice as the Hannelore B. and Rudolph B. Schulhof Collection. Rudolph was a Trustee of the Foundation from 1994 until his death in 1999. Hannelore was an invaluable supporter of the Guggenheim Museum. She helped nurture the institution over several decades and was a Charter Member and later lifetime Emeritus Member of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection Advisory Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Hannelore's son Michael, also a Trustee of the Foundation, and to all her family. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; Jennifer Blei Stockman, President; Richard Armstrong, Director; Nancy Spector, Deputy Director and Chief Curator, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Philip Rylands, Director, Peggy Guggenheim Collection

As part of an effort to educate consumers about overdraft fees, the new federal consumer watchdog agency is proposing a ''fee penalty'' box to be included on checking account statements. Banks charge overdraft fees when customers spend more than is available in their checking account. The form is the latest in a series of ''plain language'' financial disclosures proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

MILAN THE comings and goings of designers don't seem dramatic anymore, the tumults of the fashion world miniaturized by events of more consequence or just more noise and scandal. On Sunday, millions will be watching the Oscars and judging dresses. That many designers and accessory makers now earn their way onto the carpet by paying stars to wear their stuff probably doesn't shock people. One thing about the fashion world is that it's not full of innocence.

JEFF CHIEN-HSING LIAO loved documentary and street photography, but an internship at the cooperative photo agency Magnum led him to a sobering conclusion. ''You go through their contact sheets and it strikes you,'' he admitted. ''I was never going to be better.''

An article last Sunday about budget problems in San Jose, Calif., misspelled the surname of a resident who lost her job last spring and is using local coffee shops as virtual offices. She is Christine Velasquez, not Velazquez. The article also misspelled the name of one of the coffee shops she visits. It is Caffe Frascati, not Caffe Frescati.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the funeral of Whitney Houston referred imprecisely to a public housing project in Newark, across the street from New Hope Baptist Church, where the funeral was held. While the James M. Baxter Terrace housing project used to be there, it has been torn down and is being replaced with another public housing complex.

ISLAMABAD -- The Pakistani authorities moved on Saturday to demolish the house where Osama bin Laden died at the hands of Navy SEALs last May, erasing a three-story building that had acquired a painful symbolism for Pakistan's powerful military, which was badly embarrassed by the American raid. Working by floodlight, heavy machinery operators broke through the tall perimeter wall of the 3,000 square-meter compound in Abbottabad, 35 miles north of Islamabad, after dark on Saturday. Hours later, they started to knock down the main house where Bin Laden had lived with his family and three smaller buildings.

Dan Nainan, a comedian, who said he would be open to checking out new programs, like one offered by KLM, allowing ticket holders to upload details from other airline passengers' online profiles and use the data to choose seatmates for flights. WHEN the actress Da'Vine Joy Randolph first heard that the 1990 movie ''Ghost'' was being turned into a musical, she was more than a little skeptical that the special effects in the supernatural romance -- Patrick Swayze walking through solid objects, a penny floating toward Demi Moore -- would work onstage. '' 'I don't know about that,' '' she recalled saying in a sassy tone last fall as she read an audition notice for a Broadway production of the musical, which opened in London in July. Still, Ms. Randolph had a freshly minted master's degree from the Yale School of Drama and no acting credits in New York -- so why not aim for a small part as one of the sisters of Oda Mae Brown, the sometime psychic that Whoopi Goldberg won an Academy Award playing in the film? The stakes went up when Ms. Randolph, who was ''far from a die-hard fan of the movie,'' was invited to try out as the understudy for the actress playing Oda Mae -- an actress who had yet to be chosen, but who Ms. Randolph assumed would be ''a big name, a star'' or else Sharon D. Clarke, who played the part in London. For the audition she memorized 20 pages of dialogue and sang two numbers, all the while feeling underprepared. She left certain that she would not be called back.

A caption on Feb. 12 with readers' pictures of their favorite travel destinations described Signal Hill in Cape Town incorrectly. It is not on the southernmost point of Africa. (It is about 140 miles northwest of the tip.)

JOSH YOUNG was 17 when a drama teacher told him that his yearning baritone lent itself to playing romantic leading men in musical theater. But there was one obvious hitch: Mr. Young, then 5 feet 8 inches tall, weighed 250 pounds. ''I was completely unhealthy, obese, so I committed to running three miles every morning for six months and following a strict diet,'' he recalled. ''And 100 pounds came off.'' Now trim and lantern-jawed at 31, Mr. Young is set to make his Broadway debut next month as an unlikely heartthrob -- Judas Iscariot -- in the Stratford Shakespeare Festival's production of ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' the 1971 rock opera by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice.

KAYLE--Milton P. age 89, one of the last surviving members of President Harry S. Truman's White House staff, died February 19, 2012 in Glenview, IL. A Phi Beta Kappa in his junior year at Hamilton College, he graduated in 1943, saw armed combat in the European Theater during WWII, graduated from Harvard Law School in 1948, and was Special Assistant to President Truman. After moving to New York, Kayle pioneered merchandise-licensing law in entertainment and sports, was "of counsel" to Gilbert, Segall & Young, served as Trustee to Hamilton College, was on the Board of Temple Israel in New Rochelle, NY, and was a Board Member, Officer and Trustee of the Truman Library Institute. He also belonged to the Judson Welliver Society, an organization for presidential speechwriters. Kayle was the beloved husband for 68 years of Dorothy, nee Slater; loving father to Jennifer Kayle (Jeffrey) Posner and Hilary Kayle (Dr. Peter) Crist; proud grandfather of Emily Kayle (Josh) Sobel, Risa Posner (Joey) Wiener and Scott (Ali) Posner; adoring great-grandfather of Max and Zoe Sobel; dear brother of the late Leonard Kayle and Esther Harr. Remembrances may be sent to The Truman Library Institute or Hamilton College.

LOPEZ--Jacqueline, PhD Dr. Jaqueline Lopez, born on March 4, 1922 in Hartford, Connecticut, passed on in her home on February 7, 2012 after a long battle with myeloma. Her parents, Sydney and Hilda Lopez were Jamaican immigrants. Dr. Lopez attended NYU as a student and obtained both her undergraduate degree and her doctorate at NYU in psychology. She became a staff psychologist with the NYU University Counseling Service and was an Adjunct Associate Professor from l975 to l998. Dr. Lopez completed training at the NYU Postdoctoral Program in Psychoanalysis and Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy and was a current member of the Psychoanalytic Society of the Postdoctoral Program. She was a uniquely distinguished contributor to the field of inter-racial issues in applied psychology and also had a private practice from her home. She was fascinated by patient motivations and behaviors and loved her work as a therapist. Dr. Lopez was a woman ahead of her time. Very independent, with intense intellectual curiosity and many cultural and political interests, she became an accomplished photographer after her retirement from New York University. She is survived by her brother Dr. Edward Lopez and his four children, Maria Lopez, Andrea O'Brien, Gregory Lopez and Christopher Lopez. She is predeceased by her sister, Betty Lopez Brewer and is survived by Betty's children, Diane Brewer, Charles Brewer, and Lynne Brewer. A memorial will be announced.

SCHULHOF--Hannelore B. The trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts are deeply saddened by the loss of our wonderful friend and long-time trustee Hannelore Schulhof. We will be forever grateful for her generosity and leadership during her 30 years on our board. She was a woman of great grace, intellect and passion and she will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her children and their families. Tom L. Freudenheim, Chairman Jason N. R. Herrick, President Pauline Willis, Director

A T 33 Patricia McGregor is taking, in her own words, a ''big leap'' as the director of Katori Hall's ''Hurt Village,'' part of the inaugural season at the new Signature Theater complex. Ms. McGregor lives in Harlem with her 86-year-old father, Oscar, who is battling cancer, and her older sister, Paloma, a choreographer with whom she founded Angela's Pulse, an artists' collective. While she has done work across the city, from the Brooklyn Academy of Music to Lincoln Center Institute, many of her shows in recent years have been mounted uptown, at Harlem Stage and at the Apollo, where she wrote and directed a theatrical concert called ''Burnt Sugar Freaks the James Brown Songbook.'' Her highest-profile show in the theater district was ''Fela!'': she served as associate director during the end of its Broadway run.

BROWN--Aurelia Clifton, 87, "Thistle" died peacefully February 21st, New York City. Born 1925, Ardmore, Pennsylvania, daughter of James Crosby Brown and Gladys Pomeroy Jenkins. Exuberant aunt to dozens of Jenkins and Brown nieces and nephews, beloved mentor and helper to flocks of friends, who remember Thistle as both devoted and daring in her life and in her spirituality. She was an accomplished artist, and heart and soul and owner of Wingspread Gallery, Northeast Harbor, Maine 1969-2009. Memorial Services: New York, April 20th, 4pm, St. James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street; summer date in Northeast Harbor, Maine to be announced. In lieu of flowers gifts in her honor may be made to "The Organ Fund", St. Andrews' Church, 1231 Washington Blvd., Stamford, CT 06902 or to "Friends of Music", The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10025.

An article on Friday about Edward Blum, the head of a legal defense fund, the Project on Fair Representation, that has contested race-based laws, misidentified the court that ruled in 1996 that the University of Texas' affirmative action policy was unconstitutional. It was the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, not the Texas Supreme Court.

HOLCOMB--Edward Stewart, MD, passed away peacefully on February 12th in Charleston, SC at the age of 92. He is survived by his son Cary (Heather) and grandchildren Taylor and Ben of Darien, CT and son Richard (Jacquie) of Christchurch, NZ. Ed was born May 11, 1919 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Cornell University in 1939 and Cornell Medical School in 1943. During WWII he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps-63rd Field Hospital. In 1947 he married Nancy May Eggleston. They were married for 61 years. Ed moved to Gloversville, NY where he practiced medicine for over 48 years. He was Chief of Medicine and Chief of Staff during his tenure at Nathan Littauer Hospital in Gloversville. Ed was an avid sailor and former member of the Mayfield, NY and Charleston, SC Yacht Clubs. At he time of his death, Ed was the oldest active fencer with the United States Fencing Association. He was a former Captain of the Cornell University Fencing Team and recently served as a volunteer coach with the East of the Cooper Fencing Program. He was a kind, intelligent, generous man of integrity, wit and wisdom -- a true gentleman. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

A number of hotels are offering leap year deals. A sampling: Alexandria, Va.: Book on Feb. 29 and save 29 percent on a spring trip to Old Town Alexandria at the Hotel Monaco Alexandria, Morrison House or Lorien Hotel & Spa. Rates start at $113; stays must take place from March 1 to April 15.

WORLD WAR I has long offered fertile ground to filmmakers to comment on military horrors and absurdities. Jean Renoir used it in ''The Grand Illusion,'' as did Steven Spielberg in ''War Horse.'' Few have done so as effectively as Stanley Kubrick, who visited the scorched French trenches in ''PATHS OF GLORY.'' Part of BAM Cinématek's two-part series Jim Thompson: A Hell of a Writer -- Thompson wrote the taut screenplay for this 1957 film with Kubrick and Calder Willingham -- the movie (at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday) displays Kubrick's technical wizardry while evincing a warmth elusive in his later work. Kirk Douglas portrays Colonel Dax, a man assigned to lead his troops on a suicidal mission so that his general will be promoted. When his unit is defeated -- in a stunningly raw battlefield tableau that puts ''Full Metal Jacket'' to shame -- three of his men are court-martialed, and Dax must defend them. Kubrick's wide angles, ''Shining''-style tracking shots and high-contrast interiors abound. But infusing the whole is a gritty, articulate compassion for the soldier in the field. Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100; schedule and prices: bam.org.

SINGER--June C. June C. Singer, New York City painter and interior designer, died February 16, in Springfield MA, at 91. Born June 21, 1920 in Manhattan, Mrs. Singer spent most of her life there. She was proud to be a "native New Yorker" and deeply loved the city's spellbinding mixture of creativity, culture and history. She married noted New York pediatrician Dr. Milton Singer in 1941. Dr. Singer had a practice in Manhattan, was on the staff at Babies Hospital, and was Director of the Pediatric Cerebral Palsy Clinic. Mrs. Singer studied painting under Czechoslovakian artist Riko Mikeska and maintained a studio on 17th Street. She traveled and painted extensively in Europe in the 1970's and 1980's. After Dr. Singer died in 1972, Mrs. Singer started an interior design company, June C. Singer Interiors. She pursued that career intensely and successfully, attracting such well known clients as Vincent Sardi and Audrey Hepburn. She continued working well into her eighties. Mrs. Singer spent her summers in Sorrento, Maine, where the spectacular coastal scenery and slow pace offered a welcome contrast to her Manhattan lifestyle, and she cherished her time there. Mrs. Singer was widely known and admired for her charm, grace, elegance, dignity and unfailing humor. She is survived by her son John and daughter-in-law Ruth, four grandchildren Mary, David, Rachel and Patrick Kennedy, and great-granddaughter Morgan Mary Kennedy. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched.

THE year 1998 was a significant one for East Nashville, an area that comprises several small neighborhoods directly across the Cumberland River from the Tennessee capital's downtown. The locale, which had already fallen on tough times, got even shoddier when a tornado ripped through the community, wreaking havoc on its infrastructure. Yet, in hindsight, the disaster also brought opportunity. After an influx of insurance money, creative types began flocking to the area thanks to cheap rents; young entrepreneurs followed, slowly transforming it into a hub for Nashville's culturally savvy. Although East Nashville was also hit hard by the 2010 flood that inundated the city (though not as badly as downtown), its rebound has continued. Perhaps thanks to all these misfortunes, it has also developed a strong sense of solidarity. ''I've lived all over the country,'' said Roderick Bailey, the owner and chef of the Silly Goose restaurant, ''and I've never experienced a community that's more supportive of its neighborhood and businesses.'' ERIC BEEN

SZU-TU--Anthony. Anthony Y.S. Szu-Tu passed away peacefully surrounded by loved ones on February 18, 2012 after a brief illness. He was the beloved husband of his late wife, Marilyn. He is survived by his children: Arthur Szu-Tu and his wife, Carol; Vivien and her husband, Daniel Bean. He is also survived by his three grandchildren: Laura, Derek, and Ariane. Born 1923, in Beijing, China, Anthony obtained advanced degrees in International Law and Finance; he was also a published/produced playwright. He was on diplomatic assignment to the U.S. with his bride when the Communist Party took over China. Anthony spent the remainder of his professional career in life insurance and financial planning. His efforts garnered a Man of the Year Award in 1990 from Mutual of New York. Anthony will be remembered for his constant smile, his generosity, and the way he embraced life. Two weeks past his 89th birthday, Anthony was sporting a pink t-shirt and his characteristic smile as he crossed the finish line for the South Florida Race for the Cure. Funeral Services will be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, March 3, 2012 at the Quattlebaum Funeral Home 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, with Rev. Paul R. Manning, officiating. Friends may visit with the family from 12:30pm until service time. Entombment will be private for the family.

KIRKHAM--Robert (Bob), 81, of Pittsburgh, PA, passed away on February 20 at home. Bob leaves his wife of 49 years, Barbara Wilson Kirkham; three sons: Robert, David and Gregory; two daughters: Gloria Sullivan and Cynthia Kirkham. Also, five grandchildren. Bob had a successful career in the lumber industry retiring as president of Seaboard International in New York. His passion was owning racehorses. He won the 1983 Belmont Stakes with Caveat. Bob felt he had a full and lucky life and will be greatly missed. Memorial donations may be made to: Exceller Fund (Kentucky) and Family Hospice Care of Mt. Lebanon, PA.

IT has already been a huge crowd pleaser in San Francisco and Paris, and now ''THE STEINS COLLECT: MATISSE, PICASSO AND THE PARISIAN AVANT-GARDE'' is coming to New York, where it opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday. The exhibition focuses on Gertrude Stein and her brothers, Leo and Michael (as well as Michael's wife Sarah), who settled in Paris in the early years of the 20th century and befriended artists like Matisse and Picasso. Their home became a famous gathering place where they held weekly salons for artists and collectors, scholars, dealers and aristocrats to see the latest examples of what was being produced during those years. And over time the family amassed a formidable collection of paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures that offers a snapshot of a seminal era in the history of art. The exhibition showcases the Steins' collection, with both well-known and obscure images that total around 200 paintings, sculpture and works on paper. The show begins with the art Leo Stein collected when he moved to Paris in 1903 -- paintings and prints by Cézanne, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Manet and Renoir -- and goes on to chronicle the family's acquisitions in subsequent years, examining the close relationships they formed with many of the artists they encountered. Through June 3, (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org.

SCHULHOF--Hannelore Buck. "Art is almost like a religion. It is what I believe in. It is what gives my life dimension beyond the material world." Such were the words of Mrs. Hannelore Buck Schulhof, devoted widow of Rudolph Schulhof and noteworthy patron of the arts, who peacefully passed away on February 23, 2012 at the age of 90. Hannelore was born in Berlin and raised in a home filled with art and music, subjects she continued to study throughout her life. She met her only true love, Czech born Rudolph, when she was a teenager in Vienna, with Europe on the brink of World War II. Hannelore and Rudolph escaped Nazi occupation to marry in Brussels in 1940. They soon settled in the United States, where they lived in love for the remainder of their lives. There they proudly raised a family of four children: Michael, Ronald (deceased), Thomas, and Wendy. American and European post war and contemporary art became a central interest in Hannelore's life. She was a collector, patron, museum trustee and great friend to artists, dealers and curators. She served on the Boards of the Guggenheim, Whitney, Brooklyn Museum, National Gallery of Art in Washington, The Israel Museum in Jerusalem, and the American Federation of Arts. Hannelore lived a life of passion and love for family and the arts. She travelled extensively. She was an avid music lover who played viola, and who attended countless performances of the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic. She was a gracious host who welcomed family and friends to visit the beauty of her home, and share in the many stories of her vast experience. Hannelore is survived by three children, as well as ten grandchildren and eighteen-great grandchildren, who all brought great joy to her life. Services will be held Monday, February 27 at 11:00am at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, followed by a private family burial service at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Westchester County.

ROSEN--Albert I.,M.D., a psychiatrist, died as a result of a fire in his home in Port Washington, NY, on Tuesday, February 21, 2012. He was 73. Dr. Rosen was retired from the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in the Bronx and from Einstein's Soundview Throgs Neck Community Mental Health Center, where he had been medical director of the adult outpatient program. Before he retired, he was an officer of the Bronx District Branch of the American Psychiatric Association, and he remained an active member of Drugs and Society, Columbia University Seminars. Dr. Rosen, an Army veteran, became an advocate for the health and well-being of returning Iraqi and Afghan war veterans, many of whom he met through his work. He is survived by his wife, Jan Morgan Rosen, of Port Washington; his four brothers, Norman Rosen of Concord, CA; Dr. David M. Rosen of San Francisco; Lester Rosen of the Bronx, and Philip Rosen and his wife, of Marie Orsini Rosen of Stamford, CT, as well as their adult children, Jessica Rosen of Brooklyn, and Matthew Rosen of New Orleans; and his sister-in-law and brother-in-law Sally Morgan McCarren and Joseph F. McCarren of Tarrytown, NY. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 26, 2012, at 1pm, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Burial at the Long Ridge Union Cemetery, Erskine Road, Stamford. After the burial, a consolation meal will be offered and family and friends will sit Shiva until 5pm at the Fellowship for Jewish Learning, 572 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Soldiers Project: thesoldiersproject.org, Military Family: militaryfamily.org or the Fellowship for Jewish Learning, P.O. Box 17291, Stamford, CT 06907. fellowshipforjewish learning.org.

MIHO--Tomoko Kawakami. September 2, 1931-February 10, 2012. Tomoko passed away peaceably on Friday, February 10, 2012. A long-time resident of New York City, she established her firm in 1974, and renamed it Tomoko Miho Design in 1982. Over her long and distinguished career as a graphic designer, Ms. Miho received many awards, including the AIGA Gold Medal in 1993. She served on the AIGA Board of Directors and was a long-time member of the Alliance Graphique Internationale (AGI). Her work has been exhibited in both the United States and Europe, and is in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress, the Smithsonian Institution, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London and the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Tomoko spent her early years in Los Angeles, three years in Gila River, Arizona during WWII, and finished high school in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Her inspiration and appreciation for the art world began when she enrolled at the Art Center College of Design in Los Angeles. She is survived by her brother Paul Kawakami of Los Angeles, and her nieces and nephews.

DUBE--Daniel L.,died February 23, 2012 at the age of 103. Son of Newman and Jennie. Brother of Judith Seakwood, Joseph, Irving, Lillian and Herbert Dube. Uncle Dan was the uncle to scores of family members and friends. Dan and his father founded Park Surgical Company of Brooklyn, NY where he worked until the end of his life. He was at the first meeting of Israel Zion Hospital (as a child) which became Maimonides Medical Center of Brooklyn. His father was the founding president. Counselor at Camp Winadu in its inaugural year, trustee of Temple Emanu-el of Boro Park and president of the Boro Park YM-YWHA. Truly the end of an era. He will be sorely missed by everyone who ever met him. Dan was absolutely one of a kind. Funeral is graveside only on Sunday, February 26, 11am at Mount. Carmel Cemetery 83-45 Cypress Hills Street Glendale, NY 11385. (718) 366-5900.

Nov. 27, 2011, New DelhiI attended this Sikh wedding as a guest of the cousin of the bride. Here, the bride's family is awaiting the groom, who is dressed in a traditional headpiece. In addition to being enamored with the richness of sounds and colors of Sikh traditions, I was thinking about how, in Western cultures, the bride is the one that is doted on and receives her own procession into an adoring crowd. I quite enjoyed the reversal, and the absence of any ''bridezillas.'' FATIMA REYNOLDS, Freehold, N.J.

LEON--Andrew C.,Ph.D. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Andy Leon, who passed away Saturday, February 18, 2012 at his home near the Poconos in Pennsylvania. Dr. Leon was a professor of biostatistics in psychiatry and professor of public health at Weill Cornell Medical College. A member of the Weill Cornell faculty for nearly twenty-five years, Dr. Leon was a unique leader in the field of psychiatry with international recognition for his expertise in novel and advanced clinical trial design and analysis for psychiatric treatments. He used his expertise in applied biostatistics to translate research findings into clinical meaningful information invaluable to clinicians, researchers, and policy makers. He contributed to the field through his many publications and presentations and served as a consultant to the pharmaceutical industry and governmental agencies including the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Dr. Leon's intelligence and truly gracious spirit made him respected and beloved by his many friends and colleagues across the nation and abroad. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Leon's family including his wife Yuki Okuma, daughter Angelica, sister Sally, brothers Hap and Peter, and nephew Milan Aviles. Jack D. Barchas, MD Chair and Psychiatrist-in-Chief NY-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center Philip J. Wilner, MD, MBA Executive Vice Chair and Medical Director NY-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center

ROTHENBERG--Michael. With great sadness we announce the passing of Michael Rothenberg, a wonderful father and husband, devoted colleague and exceptional Executive Director of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. Upon graduation from NYU, Michael worked as a litigator in the housing unit of Brooklyn Legal Services. After receiving a fellowship from the Rockefeller Family Foundation, he worked on jury reform issues at the Vera Institute. Drawn to institution-building, Michael joined New York Lawyers for the Public Interest and was named Executive Director in 2001. In addition to his work at NYLPI, in 2010 Michael was appointed by Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman to serve on his Task Force to expand access to civil legal services in New York. A man with an enormous heart, Michael Rothenberg is survived by his wife, Zerline Goodman; their children, Brice, Garon and Zaya Rothenberg; his mother, Eleanor; and his brothers, David and Seth. His funeral service will be held Sunday at 3:00pm at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, a historic site in Brooklyn Heights. The family's rabbi will be officiating. Board and Staff, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest

SCHULHOF--Hannelore B. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of Hannelore B. Schulhof, Honorary Trustee. Hannelore and her late husband Rudolph Schulhof collected postwar European and American art with a remarkable passion and discernment over the course of a half century, and an important part of their collection will permanently reside at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice as the Hannelore B. and Rudolph B. Schulhof Collection. Rudolph was a Trustee of the Foundation from 1994 until his death in 1999. Hannelore was an invaluable supporter of the Guggenheim Museum. She helped nurture the institution over several decades and was a Charter Member and later lifetime Emeritus Member of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection Advisory Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Hannelore's son Michael, also a Trustee of the Foundation, and to all her family. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; Jennifer Blei Stockman, President; Richard Armstrong, Director; Nancy Spector, Deputy Director and Chief Curator, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Philip Rylands, Director, Peggy Guggenheim Collection

DOUG ELKINS will deconstruct one of his dances before viewers' very eyes. That happens when his company, DOUG ELKINS CHOREOGRAPHY, ETC., appears during Stripped/Dressed, this year's 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival. Doug Varone, the festival's curator, has invited choreographers to take a dance, strip it of its costumes, lighting and theatrical effects, and expose its conceptual bare bones. Then it gets put back together to be performed ''dressed'' in its complete form. Mr. Elkins may be ideally suited for such a process, for he is a choreographic collagist fond of juxtaposing many source materials. Take ''Mo(or)town Redux,'' the piece he's deconstructing at the Y. A new version of a dance he created in 1990, it's inspired, in part, by José Limón's ''Moor's Pavane,'' a modern-dance classic of 1949 based on ''Othello.'' Mr. Elkins's dance also celebrates the passionate American pop music of Motown. There's certainly much to dismantle and reassemble here. 8 p.m. Friday and next Saturday, 3 p.m. next Sunday, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500, 92y.org; $15.

AN apartment with 4,000 square feet of space on the 68th floor of the Time Warner Center that sold for $19.453 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The apartment has all the amenities prized by people who are able to play at this level of the real estate market, including a Bulthaup eat-in kitchen and a fully automated home designed by Crestron, according to the listing by Prudential Douglas Elliman. For the uninitiated, a Crestron system allows control of all the settings in the apartment -- from audio speakers to lights to window blinds -- with the touch of button. The new owners will be able to set any mood in the great room, the media room, and each of the five bedrooms and five and a half bathrooms -- all without getting out of bed.

BLOOM--Jules (Julieoe) of Roosevelt Island/d, NY, died Tuesday, February 21, 2012, at 91. The beloved son of Ruben and Leah Bloom, he was adored by his family and many friends. Jules was predeceased by his devoted and much-loved wife of 55 years, Florence (Liz). He will be deeply missed by his daughters Janet and Amy; brother Sam and sister Adele; son-in-law Terry; grandchildren Lauren and Mara; sisters-in-law Donna and Malvina; nieces Debby and Rona; nephews Matt, Harry, David, Ron, Paul, Warren, William, and Edward; as well as many great-nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends. A lifelong New Yorker, Julie was a WWII Army Air Force veteran of the Italian Campaign, and a brilliant and engaging history teacher and administrator for more than 30 years. An early and indefatigable fighter for social justice, he was passionate about every aspect of life, and believed in individual responsibility and the power of collective activism. An avid and accomplished tennis player, classical music lover, movie maven, and voracious reader with encyclopedic knowledge of history and political science, he was a true Renaissance man. Jules was a loyal and devoted friend, a charismatic personality with an unquenchable joie-de-vivre and a rich, contagious laugh who relished good conversation. He will long be remembered for his humor, intelligence, and energy. Services will be held at 11:30am, on Sunday, February 26 at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, LI. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Rosenberg Fund for Children or Amnesty International.

CLOSE--Elizabeth Butler Betty Close, 95, passed away peacefully in her sleep on February 1, 2012 of natural causes. She was born on October 13th, 1916 in Chicago Illinois to Charles A. Butler and Daisy Pugh Butler. Betty grew up in New Rochelle, New York and graduated from New Rochelle High School. She then attended Connecticut College and graduated in 1939. In 1941, she married Walter Harvey Close Jr. and they were happily married for 50 years until his passing in1991. They lived in Scarsdale after WWII, a place where she had deep roots and many friends. Later in life, she moved to Dallas to live near her daughter. Betty Close was active in The Junior League of Scarsdale, The Scarsdale Women's Club, The Greenville Community Church and White Plains Hospital. She and Walter spent some very happy times playing golf at the Scarsdale Golf Club and on many courses around the country. She is preceded in death by her daughter Valerie Bowen, and survived by two of her daughters, Cynthia Larkin of Dallas and Roxane Hays of Cardiff-By-The-Sea, California: also by six grandchildren, Eric Hays, Trevor Hays (Melissa), Stephen Bowen (Carolyn), Daniel Bowen, Kathleen Larkin Nadelson (Adam) and Daniel Larkin. Her life will be celebrated in a memorial service, date to be determined, in April at Preston Hollow Presbyterian Church, Dallas, Texas. Expressions of sympathy in memory of Betty Close may be sent to Cancer Care (cancercare.org) or the American Cancer Society (cancer.org).

A front-page article last Sunday reported on the deaths of contractors in Afghanistan who work for American companies, noting that most die uncounted and that sometimes their survivors are uncompensated. The family of one contractor who was killed, Qais Mansoori, an Afghan interpreter, criticized Mr. Mansoori's employer, Mission Essential Personnel, saying that while the company promptly made a lump sum payment, it never mentioned a lifetime annuity to which the family was entitled. The article quoted a spokesman for Mission Essential who disputed that, saying the company had been making biweekly payments to the family and would continue to do so for 29 years. After the article was published, the Mission Essential spokesman, Sean Ruston, contacted The Times to say that in addition to his initial rebuttal he could also provide documentation of the payments. When The Times contacted the family about the documents, a family member confirmed that Mission Essential Personnel had indeed been paying the family the annuity. ''We are satisfied with the company,'' the family member said.

THIS is a big week for STEVEN STUCKY, who has no fewer than three works being performed in New York. A widely respected composer who won the Pulitzer Prize in 2005, Mr. Stucky is a familiar face in the city, having hosted the New York Philharmonic's fondly remembered Hear & Now new-music concert series for several seasons. Mr. Stucky's busy run begins on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, where Manfred Honeck conducts the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra in the local premiere of ''Silent Spring.'' Introduced in Pittsburgh this month, this symphonic poem commemorates the 50th anniversary of Rachel Carson's book of the same title -- and, by extension, the birth of modern environmentalism. 3 p.m., Sunday, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $77.

ROSS--Eric S.,passed away at his home in New York City on February 23, 2012 at the age of 73. Loving father to Matthew and his wife Judith; doting grandfather to Chloe, Sofia, and Ella; dearest brother of Mark. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W. 76th St., on February 26 at 3pm.

SCHULHOF--Hannelore. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the death of Hanne Schulhof one of its founding directors. For four decades Hanne and her husband Ruda have enriched its contemporary art collection. We extend condolences to Mickey, Tom, Wendy and the entire family. Stephen Lash & Judy Steinhardt, Board co-chairs, AFIM Ninah Lynne, President, AFIM James Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Monique Birenbaum, Exec Dir, AFIM

STOBER--Lori, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL passed away on February 24 at the age of 53. Lori had a big and fun personality that matched her loving heart. She was a successful pioneer in the hedge fund industry and held a BS and MBA from NYU Stern College. She was raised in Great Neck, NY and is mourned by her family: Her parents, Dr. Gerald and Ruth Stober, her sister Jill and brother-in-law Barry Lafer, her brother Clifford and sister-in-law Wendy Stober, her nephews, Josh Lafer (Marissa) and Peter Lafer and nieces, Casey Lafer, and Haley and Sara Stober. She will also be missed by her extended family and many dear friends and colleagues. Funeral on Monday at 1:30pm at Beth David Memorial, Hollywood, FL.

LEINWOLL--Stanley, 85. Loving husband of Miriam for 60 years. Adoring father of Laura and Bobby Shapiro and Joanie Leinwoll. Generous, caring grandfather to Ellice, Alexandra, Jesse and Rachel. Stan lived his life for his family, yet found time to be a published author of seven books. Frequency Manager for Radio Free Europe for 27 years, valued consultant to WYFR Radio for 37 years. We cherished our time with him. He is, always and forever will be, our beloved hero.

WISE--Robert, 91, on February 3, 2012. Born in New York City, Robert graduated from Princeton, during World War II served in Europe, worked with dedication at Planned Parenthood New York until retirement. Survived by his brother William. Donations to Planned Parenthood.

HE was an upstart Cockney photographer. She was his girlfriend, an unknown model he'd met at an advertising shoot for Kellogg's Corn Flakes. Together, David Bailey and Jean Shrimpton took 1960s London by storm as his images of her beauty -- doe eyes, arched brows, a sumptuous mouth and those newfangled miniskirts -- came to represent the city at its swingingest. But first they would wreak havoc across the ocean. ''WE'LL TAKE MANHATTAN,'' on Ovation on Saturday at 9 p.m., reimagines the 1962 New York photo shoot for British Vogue in which the It couple, portrayed by Aneurin Barnard and Karen Gillan, were treated like royalty. ''They are adorable,'' exclaimed Diana Vreeland, the American Vogue editor. ''England. Has. Arrived.''

CALDER--Bebe Etlin, on February 24, 2012. Widow of Bruce, beloved mother of Daniel, Lawrence and Judith, grandmother of Anne Sternberg, sister of Murray Etlin and Elaine Shulman, cherished friend of many. Services February 26 at 10am, Edwards-Dowdle, 64 Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry, NY, burial following at Cedar Park.

As if booking a gig wasn't hard enough, tightened baggage regulations and inconsistent policies among airlines have made it difficult for musicians to figure out how to get their instruments to the next show. But a new bill passed by Congress this month sets a uniform national policy on the matter. The Federal Aviation Administration will permit any instrument that can be safely stored in the overhead compartment or underneath a seat to be treated as carry-on luggage. It also sets size and weight requirements (150 linear inches and 165 pounds) for instruments checked as baggage, and it allows musicians to purchase an extra seat on a plane for instruments that are either too large for the overhead compartment or too fragile to be stored in the cargo hold.

GIBSTEIN--Alan. We are so sad about the loss of Alan Gibstein. We all used to talk about how handsome and smart he was, as everyone always did, but what really defined him was his warmth and generosity. Alan was a friend to our family in every sense of the word. He was a healer and a helper. And there was never a time any of us needed anything--guidance, support, advice--that he wasn't there in a flash. We miss him and will continue to miss him for a long, long time. The Koppelman Family

EISENBERG--Ronnie, passed away at her home in Florida on February 25, 2012. Loving wife of Walter, sister of Laura Benedek.

8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 84TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The tried-and-true Billy Crystal returns for his ninth stint as host of this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles (above, setting the scene). George Clooney is up for best actor for ''The Descendants,'' but oddsmakers are predicting that Jean Dujardin will take home the Oscar for his role as a silent-movie star in ''The Artist,'' the black-and-white tribute to a golden age in Hollywood. That film is expected to win best picture as well, while its director, Michel Hazanavicius, is favored for the directing award. Viola Davis is the top best-actress contender for her turn as a courageous maid in ''The Help,'' though Meryl Streep, as Margaret Thatcher in ''The Iron Lady,'' could make it a close race. And in the best-supporting category, Christopher Plummer is expected to win as a father who comes out of the closet near the end of his life in ''Beginners,'' as is Octavia Spencer, who portrayed another determined maid in ''The Help.'' ''A Separation,'' the domestic drama set in Iran, is favored to win for best foreign film. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 4 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Tim Gunn, Robin Roberts, Jess Cagle, Nina Garcia and Louise Roe interview celebrities on the red carpet at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! 7 A.M. (Sho2) THE KING'S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, below, in the role for which he won the best-actor Oscar last year, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps him conquer his debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Bertie's wife and staunch support system, who can't quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie's older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. ''It isn't exactly 'Pygmalion,' not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie's biggest draws,'' Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 nominations and earned Mr. Hooper an Oscar as best director. ''Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, 'The King's Speech' wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.'' The film also won Academy Awards for best picture and original screenplay (David Seidler).

HUTCHINSON--Richard Ashton 1930-2012 Richard Ashton Hutchinson (Dick) of Vineyard Haven, Mass died peacefully at home, surrounded by family on February 1, 2012 after a brief battle with cancer. He was 82 years old. Dick was a Senior Executive with Philip Morris International for over 30 years in a career that included senior management positions in Argentina, Venezuela and New York City. He was born in Paris, France in January 1930, and later moved to South Bend, Indiana where his father assumed the role of President of Studebaker. Dick graduated from The Hill School in 1948 and from Yale University in 1953. He married June Adams is Paris, France in September 1957 and were happily married for over 50 years. He was a resident of Wilton, Connecticut from 1977 to 1994. During his retirement he worked for IESC (International Executive Service Corps). He then retired in Savannah, Georgia from 1994 to 2010 where he was actively involved with Habitat for Humanity. Dick was a well loved summer resident of Martha's Vineyard where he and his wife June have owned a home for more than 40 years. He was an active member of the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club and the Farm Neck Golf Club. Dick considered Martha's Vineyard his home and he cherished the time he spent there with friends and family. His generosity, sense of humor, and twinkle in his eye will be missed by all. Dick is survived by his devoted wife June Hutchinson of Vineyard Haven, Massachusetts, and two daughters, Diane Hutchinson Reilly and husband Paul C. Reilly of Chicago, Illinois and Darien, Connecticut and their children Paul, Nate and Caroline Reilly; and Alexandra Hutchinson Kline and her husband Richard Gruver Kline of Darnestown, Maryland and their children Ashton, Tori and Drew Kline. He is also survived by his sister Patricia Robert of New York City and his brother Paul Kennedy Hutchinson of Tampa, Florida and all his wonderful nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dick Hutchinson's name to the Martha's Vineyard Hospital or the Good Shepherd Parish of Martha's Vineyard. Memorial Service will be held at Saint Augustine Church in Vineyard Haven on Monday, July 30th at 11am. Services by Shepherd Funeral Homes.

IN the 1960s and 1970s, the fashion designer Rudi Gernreich, his model and muse Peggy Moffitt, and Ms. Moffitt's husband, the renowned photographer William Claxton, were a dynamic and inseparable trio. Gernreich designed bold and often daring clothing that has come to epitomize the swinging '60s. Ms. Moffitt, above, inspired him and became the face and body (and hairdo) that we identify with his work. And Mr. Claxton brought it all to life in fashion shoots and in the film ''Basic Black.'' ''The Total Look: The Creative Collaboration Between Rudi Gernreich, Peggy Moffitt, and William Claxton,'' at the Museum of Contemporary Art Pacific Design Center satellite in West Hollywood (coincidentally not far from the original location of Gernreich's design studio), celebrates the work the three created together. Curated by Cameron Silver, the founder of the Los Angeles haute vintage boutique Decades, the exhibition features pieces from Ms. Moffitt's personal collection, many of which have never been on display before. ''The Total Look'' is on view at the Pacific Design Center until May 20. BROOKE HODGE

Provocative dashes of color provided the zing to enliven the drab, all-black of midwinter during New York Fashion Week. Worn here on the guests at many of the fashion shows, the color splashes were the most fun when the shows were near the Chelsea art galleries. Three colors proved to be favorites: chartreuse, followed by an almost fluorescent orange, and a dash of blue, particularly in shoes and bags.

ANTHONY DAVIS, left, a Kentucky freshman, scored a career-high 28 points, doubling his season average, and was 10 of 11 from the field. He also had 11 rebounds and 6 blocked shots. Julie Wojta, a senior who is the leading scorer for 12th-ranked Green Bay, had 27 points, 13 rebounds, 6 steals and 5 assists in a victory over Butler. For the season, Wojta is shooting 51 percent.

HEALY--Doris Turner, 98, died in Stuart, Florida on February 20th. Beloved wife of the late Michael Stephen Healy; devoted mother of Patricia Shea (Mrs. Terence) of Hinsdale, Illinois, Mary Shapiro (Mrs. Allan) of Scarsdale, New York, Gail Hilson (Mrs. John) of New York City, Stephanie Cullum (Mrs. Robert) of Garden City, New York, and the late Michael Stephen Healy Jr.; loving grandmother of eighteen, great-grandmother of thirty-two and great-great-grandmother of one. Prior to living in Stuart, Mrs. Healy, with her husband, lived in Hinsdale, Illinois; Delray Beach, Florida; and Palm Desert, California. Doris Healy was a gifted artist and fine pianist but always the main focus of her life was her family. Funeral services and interment will be in Chicago, Illinois.

SULMAN--Rochelle, on February 19, 2012, after a long and courageous battle with illness. She is survived by her mother, Anne Chanen, children, Erik (Dara Less) of and Stacy (Moti Kahana), five grandchildren, David, Miki, Yarden, Raya, and Michael; brother, Larry Chanen (Jack Burkhalter); and dear cousins and friends. She is predeceased by husband, Michael and father Hyman. We remember her warmth, boundless kindness, big smile, and love of music. We also remember her inner strength and determination in the face of many challenges. Funeral services were held in Tucson Arizona. Memorial contributions may be made to MD Anderson Cancer Center, or for cancer research at the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science.

Into the scrum of artist-performing-whole-albums concerts lands this doozy. The New Jersey rapper JOE BUDDEN hasn't released a major-label album in almost a decade, but has used mixtapes and the Internet to become a true hip-hop cult act, with a rabid coterie of followers who are fans of his self-flagellation, polysyllabic rhymes and brusque attitude. Over two nights at Irving Plaza he'll perform his series of lauded, sometimes thrilling ''Mood Muzik'' mixtapes (which he's been releasing since 2005) in their entirety -- Nos. 1 and 2 on Sunday night, Nos. 3 and 4 on Monday night. Mr. Budden is a modern version of the old regional rap star, except his region is mostly online, where his songs cause stirs, and where his mouthy Twitter can get him into trouble. A member of the brawny Eminem-approved crew Slaughterhouse, he's quick with wordplay and punch lines, but the true stars of his songs are feelings. When he's mad at a woman, he examines his own culpability. When he's beefing with other rappers, he indicts himself. When he's talking about his former drug habit or his difficult childhood, he sounds completely at home. 7:30 p.m. Sunday and Monday, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $51 each night.

MANY young actors would have been thrilled to make their New York stage debut in Harold Pinter's ''Celebration,'' directed by Pinter at the 2001 Lincoln Center Festival. But for Nina Raine, playing a waitress in the show ''was the torture I had to endure to watch him work,'' she said by telephone from London. ''I hate being onstage.'' (Though she enjoyed Manhattan's ubiquitous deli salad bars, she said.) Fortunately for Ms. Raine, 36, the career she actually wanted, as a playwright and director, is now thriving. Her play ''Tribes,'' which had its premiere at the Royal Court Theater in London in 2010, is in previews at the Barrow Street Theater in a production directed by David Cromer (''Our Town''). It is currently running in Australia too, and productions are coming in Germany and Hungary.

EISENPRESS--Alta, of White Plains, NY, on February 19, 2012 at age 87. Cherished wife of Harry for 54 years. Survived by beloved sons Aron and his wife Dorothy, Eli and his wife Angela, and Samuel. Delighted grandmother of Ben, Sasha, and Pooja. Alta loved to share her knowledge of books and her Jewish heritage with everyone from 1 to 120. Her smile was like the sun breaking out and her effervescence and indomitable spirit created a legacy that continues to be a blessing. Services were on Monday. Donations may be sent to Temple Israel Center's library in White Plains, which she cultivated for 33 years.

SCHUELER--Mary Coxe "Teenie" 85, of Delray Beach, Florida and Prouts Neck, Maine, died of cancer, peacefully, on February 17th, surrounded by her children, outside of Boston, MA. Born in Philadelphia on the eve of the Depression, she was the daughter of Eckley Brinton Coxe III and Mary Parsons Owens Coxe of Savannah, Georgia. After attending St. Timothy's School, she moved to Boston and spent much of her adult life in Brookline. She was formerly married to C. Richard Schueler and together they had six children: Linda Brown; Dr. Leila Schueler Rossiter; Mary (Molly) Hurley; Charles R Schueler Jr.; Jane Gordon (Jennie) Schueler, and Elizabeth (Lizzie) Schueler, who now span the East Coast from Vermont to Florida. At various times, Teenie taught at Chestnut Hill School, worked part-time at Bloomingdale's and volunteered at WBZ's Call for Action and Perkins School for the Blind. She was a member of various clubs in Boston, Florida and in her beloved Prouts Neck, Maine, where she spent her summers beginning at a young age. Teenie had a remarkable zest for life and was devoted to many close friends. Her engaging sense of humor, unconventional tastes, and free spirit will be lasting legacies for her family and all who knew her. In addition to her children, she is survived by her sister, Louisa Coxe Finch, eight grandchildren, and a great-granddaughter. She was predeceased by a sister, Elizabeth Coxe Spalding and a brother, Eckley B. "Buzz" Coxe, IV. A memorial service will occur at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Delray Beach, Florida, on Saturday, March 17th at 11am.

ROTHENBERG--Michael. The world tragically lost a champion for people in communities in need in our society. Michael Rothenberg, age 47, was the executive director of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, a center where lawyers and community organizers came together to create lasting social change. He oversaw a talented team of attorneys and community activists who have fought to remove toxins from public schools, gain park space for communities overflowing with waste treatment plants, make sure families of union workers killed on 9/11 received necessary aid, give students with disabilities full educational access, and open emergency rooms to all without regard to language barriers that restricted the quality of medical care. Always facing economic barriers to creating a broad-scale institution, Michael was relentlessly creative in finding new ways of raising money to support NYLPI, and he was very successful: luncheons, golf tournaments, raffles, art shows, capital campaigns, government grants he was relentless because his goals were so important to him and to his clients. Rothenberg used several tools at once to effect change: litigation, organization, the media, and direct political contacts all in order to get NYLPI's clients' voices heard. The New York Times Company recognized the genius of Michael's approach in 2010 when it awarded NYLPI one of its top three Nonprofit Excellence Awards, which recognize management excellence in the city's nonprofit community, the first legal organization to be so recognized. He was a wonderfully thoughtful man, generous to his friends, and extremely proud of his talented wife Zerline Goodman, and their three children, Brice, Garon and Zaya. He was loved and will be terribly missed by all who knew him. Our world has lost someone of real worth who made a real impact. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. Emeritus Board, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest

SITTING cross-legged on the floor of his Manhattan apartment, casually dressed in a plaid shirt, jeans and socks, Gabriel Ebert looks more like a gentlemanly lumberjack than a theater hotshot. It's no costume. ''I had a rural childhood, tucked away, growing up chopping wood,'' he said.

It has long been one of Wall Street's favorite guessing games: Who will succeed Warren E. Buffett as chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway? Mr. Buffett, in his annual letter to Berkshire shareholders on Saturday, said for the first time that he had chosen a successor. But Mr. Buffett, 81, did not name the candidate, and emphasized that he and his longtime business partner, the 88-year-old Charlie Munger, were sticking around.

GOODMAN--Helene nee Rosenblatt, 79, of Los Angeles and formerly of Searingtown, NY, Boynton Beach, FL, on February 6, 2012. Devoted, beloved wife of Arthur S. Goodman for 56 years, cherished mom of Dr. Ira (Helen) Goodman, Roberta (David) Goodman-Rosenberg and Deborah Cohen, adored bubbie of Adina, Havivah, Sam and Jonah, treasured sister of Phyllis (late Richard) Roslow and Norman (Lorraine) Rosenblatt, dear aunt, sweet cousin, amazing friend. Received her BA from NYU, MA from Adelphi. Balabusta extraordinaire, respected audiologist, dedicated volunteer, life-long learner, avid reader. We'll always remember our eshet chayil; her delicious food, elegant style, wise words, optimistic outlook, enthusiastic laughter, infectious smile, embracing hands. Donations to Walter J. Cohen fund at www.tbala.org, provide scholarships in Jewish education.

McCANN--Edith D. Beloved mother of James J. III (Cindy), Louise, Peter D. (Deborah Berke), and William died peacefully February 21, 2012, ten days short of her 93rd birthday. THE impetus for ''Sculpture in Motion: Masterpieces of Italian Design,'' an exhibition that opened this weekend at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles, came from the return of some familiar nameplates to the United States that are closely associated with Italian coachbuilders. ''With Fiat back in the U.S. and Alfa coming, it's a good time to show that the Italians have influenced international brands for a long time,'' Leslie Kendall, the museum's curator, said in a telephone interview. Fiat began sales of its 500 in the United States last year, and limited sales of the Alfa Romeo 8C Competizione supercar occurred in 2008. Alfa is expected to begin sales of its mainstream models in America in coming years.

The scouting combine, once a relatively poky event on the N.F.L. calendar, has picked up a lot of speed in recent years. The NFL Network has given it a push; it will cover the combine Thursday through Tuesday in Indianapolis. Rich Eisen will be a face of the coverage and also run the race -- his annual 40-yard dash in his work clothes has become a combine highlight. He answered a few questions via e-mail this week. Q.

CROCKER--Barbara Stout, of Naples, FL, died peacefully on February 23, 2012. Born March 18, 1909 to Ethel G. Jacquelin and Joseph S. Stout of Manhattan and Hohokus, NJ. Attended Miss Chapin's School and Vassar College. Raised two sons, Harrington Putnam, Jr. (Tony) and Tarrant (Terry) Putnam. In 1961 married Arthur M. Crocker. They lived in Laurel Hollow and Locust Valley, NY, later moving to Naples. "Barbo", as she was known to her grandsons and great grandchildren, loved her gardening, flower show judging, playing and watching tennis, shelling around the world, and her dogs. She also enjoyed reading, poetry and bridge. She is survived by her son, Terry and daughter-in-law, Mary Ann, of Hilton Head Island, SC, and her grandsons, Jeffrey of Minneapolis, MN, Jonathan of Cabin John, MD, and Christopher of Excelsior, MN, and her great-grandchildren, Ethan, Samuel, Eli, Sydney, Lindsey, and Matthew and by her step-children, Chester Crocker and Elizabeth O'Hara and their children and grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Moorings Park in Naples on March 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Avow Hospice of Naples, Doctors Without Borders, or The Three Harbors Garden Club of LI.

DIAMOND--Theodore L.,95, died February 22, 2012. Ted was a graduate of Harvard Business School and Lehigh University where he served as a trustee for three decades. He passed away peacefully at home. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Claire Winston Diamond, his son Peter Diamond, daughter Trish Diamond and grandchildren, Anna Diamond and Eric and Chris Dodds.

THE popularity of ''The Devil Wears Prada'' -- both the execrable novel and the so-so movie -- spawned a small spate of what might be called assistant lit: books about monstrous bosses and the humiliations their underlings endure as the price for proximity to the powerful. The sharp-eyed playwright Leslye Headland now brings this topic to the stage with ''ASSISTANCE,'' about a cadre of young workers under the thumb of a powerful magnate. The play is one in a series Ms. Headland has written inspired by the seven deadly sins. The theme of ''Assistance'' is greed. New York audiences will be familiar with ''Bachelorette,'' another play from the series, inspired by gluttony, which made a splash a couple of seasons ago at the Second Stage Theater Uptown. A frank and at times exuberantly mean-spirited look at mean girls and the damage they do, the film version, directed by Ms. Headland and starring Kirsten Dunst, had its premiere at Sundance last month.

Douglas Kennedy, the youngest son of Robert F. Kennedy, the senator from New York who was assassinated in 1968, has been arraigned on charges resulting from a confrontation that began as he tried to take his newborn son out of a Westchester County hospital. Two nurses said they were injured by Mr. Kennedy's actions. A lawyer for Mr. Kennedy gave a different account of what happened and said his client would fight the charges, two counts of harassment as well as one of endangering the welfare of a child, a misdemeanor.

An article in the special Your Taxes report on Feb. 12 about tax planning for retirement accounts referred incorrectly to a federal tax break that expired at the end of 2011. It allowed people at least age 70 1/2 to donate up to $100,000 from an I.R.A. to charity without any tax liability; it did not let people of any age make such donations and avoid only capital gains liability. The article also omitted a 2010 rule change affecting nonspouse beneficiaries of 401(k) plans that offer only lump-sum distributions. Since 2010, those beneficiaries have had the option of making a direct rollover of such plans into an inherited I.R.A., so they can stretch out the payout.

WHILE glass has served artists for centuries, it's a material that remains relatively unexplored in contemporary practice. Following in the footsteps of Peggy Guggenheim, whose involvement in Fucina degli Angeli (Force of Angels) brought some of the most prolific artists of the mid-20th century to Venice to work with the city's glass artisans, the Italian entrepreneur Adriano Berengo opened his own glass studio in Venice in 1989 to ''help artists translate their ideas, their projects and sometimes their dreams into glass sculptures.'' ''Glasstress New York: New Art From the Venice Biennales,'' at the Museum of Arts and Design, features works by 24 of those artists, including Kiki Smith, Vik Muniz, Yutaka Sone, Patricia Urquiola, Tony Oursler and Jan Fabre, whose Bic pen-painted glass doves and pigeons are shown here. MARINA CASHDAN

ZIPCAR, the international car-sharing service, has led a $13.7 million investment in Wheelz, a start-up company that has helped students at Stanford University rent their personal vehicles to other students on campus since September. Hundreds of Stanford students are signed up and using 25 vehicles registered with Wheelz, according to Jeff Miller, a co-founder and the company's chief executive. Wheelz plans to start a network next week at the University of California, Berkeley. Additional programs at the University of Southern California and the University of California, Los Angeles are expected to follow.

MYERS--Robert J.,77, of Fairfield, CT and formerly of New York City died on February 14, 2012. He was born on December 31, 1934 in Grand Rapids, MI to the late Helen Oleson Myers and Charles Myers. Bob was the quintessential Renaissance Man who measured success not by fame or profit but by having integrity and by the pleasure and challenges of his endeavors. By that definition, he was a tremendously successful man in each of his careers. His formal training as a bio-chemist began informally at age ten with a chemical laboratory in the family basement and as a teenaged Certified Pharmacist's Apprentice. When he was 13 an elderly man in Grand Rapids showed him a box of coins. That day he bought his first coin, a bronze of Augustus, and paid less than a dollar for it. Bob studied biochemistry at Indiana University supporting himself by starting a coin shop offering ancient and foreign coins. He joined the Army where he was the official Signal Corps photographer. Because of his expertise in bio-lab work, Cornell Medical College brought him to New York to do medical research until the mid 1970's. All this time he was building an extensive library on numismatics and ancient art. In his spare time, he appeared in Off Broadway productions. Bob Myers became an internationally recognized and respected dealer/appraiser of ancient coins and antiquities. He held his own auctions and obtained an auctioneer's license. Calling auctions in three languages in Switzerland was a challenge. Under his own name he issued 13 catalogues of ancient coins and antiquities. He was the author of several journal articles, prepared appraisals and was, on occasion, called by the IRS as expert witness. In the late 70s, he opened a food/fashion photography studio in Manhattan. In 1985 Bob became interested in sailing and joined the Penfield Sail & Power Squadron in Fairfield, CT serving as Commander. He loved sailing Long Island Sound in his 32' yawl, "Njord." Robert Myers was a man of exceptional generosity, intelligence and wit, the combination of which was irresistible. He had that rare quality of making everyone feel like royalty, tapping into their interests which by reason of his all-embracing knowledge were his as well. He was passionately devoted to his children and grandchildren, always seeing them as people, not just kids. They were adoringly enthralled in discussions of spiders or starfish, in beating grandpa at chess, handling ancient coins or learning to tie shoelaces in the weird Myers' double loop. He is survived by his life partner of 36 years, Rita Ortiga Waterman to whom he wrote, You are half of my life and all of my love;" brothers Richard (Diane), and Jim (Nicole); children Charles Myers and Gina DeVries (Doug); daughter-in-law Nancy Lynn Myers; grandchildren Ty (Shannon), Brad (Marisol), Sarah (Aaron), Andy and Derek; great-grandchildren Brooklyn, Jaxon, Piper, Britney and Stephanie; nephews Anthony and Benjamin; former wife Patsy Downs. A celebration of Robert Myers' life will be held at a later date. To sign an online register, please visit LeskoPolkeFuneralHome.com

Draftniks are N.F.L. draft enthusiasts, speculators who prefer gathering information about rookie prospects to watching basketball or hockey or enjoying a more socially acceptable hobby like Dungeons and Dragons. Draftniks fuel a cottage industry of specialized programming, Web sites and magazines, and they helped turn the N.F.L. draft into a combination tailgate party and debutante ball, a late-April mini-Super Bowl without the bothersome game. The draftnik subculture has its own rituals, some fun and accessible for the layperson, others arcane and mysterious. Some activities can help the uninitiated dip their toes into the draftnik lifestyle. Be warned: in an egalitarian landscape with minimal separation between professional television analysts and some guy with old Auburn games on his DVR, one can easily go from curious newcomer to nationally recognized expert who gets 3 a.m. text messages about Mohamed Sanu in just a few weeks. Draftniks quickly reach the point at which baseball sabermetricians appear mainstream and virile by comparison, so proceed cautiously through the steps below.

The Surfacing column on Feb. 12, about the Funk Zone neighborhood in Santa Barbara, Calif., misstated the highway that the neighborhood is near. It is wedged between the Pacific Ocean and U.S. 101, not the Pacific and Interstate 101.

YESNER--Dr. Raymond, M.D. Lung tumor expert, 97, died at home February 8, 2012. He was Professor Emeritus and former Associate Dean at the Yale School of Medicine, and a former Director of Anatomical Pathology and Chief of Staff and Lab Services in the VA Hospital system. Dr. Yesner was an expert witness in landmark cases brought against the cigarette industry for the health effects of smoking. He was author and editor of the WHO International Classification of Lung Tumors and a former Chair of the WHO Expert Committee on Lung Cancer As a researcher and educator, Dr. Yesner received the Lifetime Achievement Award of the Pulmonary Pathology Society and the International Academy of Pathology Gold Medal. He was preceded in death by Bernice, his loving wife of 62 years, and is survived by his three children and four grandchildren. A memorial will be held in Brady Hall, 310 Cedar St., New Haven, CT, 2:00pm, March 12.

Events in Syria turn the old French "plus Ça change" adage on its head. The more things change there, the worse they get. President Bashar al-Assad promised to lighten up when he replaced his tyrant father, but his rule grew geometrically more ugly. ROTHENBERG--Michael. With great sadness we announce the passing of Michael Rothenberg, a wonderful father and husband, devoted colleague and exceptional Executive Director of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. Upon graduation from NYU, Michael worked as a litigator in the housing unit of Brooklyn Legal Services. After receiving a fellowship from the Rockefeller Family Foundation, he worked on jury reform issues at the Vera Institute. Drawn to institution-building, Michael joined New York Lawyers for the Public Interest and was named Executive Director in 2001. In addition to his work at NYLPI, in 2010 Michael was appointed by Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman to serve on his Task Force to expand access to civil legal services in New York. A man with an enormous heart, Michael Rothenberg is survived by his wife, Zerline Goodman; their children, Brice, Garon and Zaya Rothenberg; his mother, Eleanor; and his brothers, David and Seth. His funeral service will be held Sunday at 3:00pm at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, a historic site in Brooklyn Heights. The family's rabbi will be officiating. Board and Staff, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest

KISSEL--Howard, passed away at his Manhattan home on February 24 at the age of 69. The longtime New York arts and theatre critic was born in Milwaukee, WI but was a true New Yorker from his college days at Columbia University until his death. The son of the late Leo and Ruth Kissel followed in his father's career footsteps into journalism with a Master's degree from Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism first serving as arts editor for Women's Wear Daily before becoming the chief theatre critic for the New York Daily News for more than 20 years. He had served as chair of both The New York Film Critics and The New York Drama Critics circles. Most recently his blog, The Cultural Tourist, was featured in Huffington Post. He authored several books including a biography of David Merrick, The Abominable Showman. Howard was a devoted husband to his late wife, Christine. He was cherished by his surviving sisters, Judy Kissel of Coral Springs, FL and Anne (David) Elliot of Palm City, FL. His many wonderful, caring friends created an amazing family that supported him throughout his life and during his recent illness. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, February 28 at 11:30am at Temple Shaaray Tefila at 250 E. 79th in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations in Howard's memory to the American Cancer Society or the JCC of Ft. Lauderdale.

He'll be dearly missed by all who knew him, and remembered for his work ethic, boundless energy, and love of life.

SAP just got social, whether it likes it or not. Yammer, software for creating social networks inside businesses, just released a new feature that connects Yammer with the central component of SAP's enterprise resource planning software. That means SAP customers can have on their computer screens a network ticker, like the updating sidebar on a Facebook page. Instead of the latest news about friends, this sidebar delivers updates whenever something relevant to people's jobs happens inside their SAP systems.

Faycal Karoui, New York City Ballet's music director for the past five years, will step down at the end of the spring season in June, the company said late on Friday. Mr. Karoui's increasing commitments in France have made him too busy to stay on, it said. Mr. Karoui is also music director of the Orchestre de Pau Pays de Bearn in southwest France and was appointed to the same post at the Orchestre Lamoureux in Paris last year. Mr. Karoui said that until now he had been able to manage his commitment to City Ballet ''with the rest of my artistic life, but this is no longer possible.'' The company said the assistant music director, Andrews Sill, would take over the position while a replacement is sought. Mr. Karoui, who became music director in December 2006, has been credited with bolstering the City Ballet orchestra's quality.
