An article on Saturday about the government-ordered suspension of operations at ALJ Investment Advisors, a Japanese money management firm, misstated the given name of one of its executives. He is Kazuhiko Asakawa, not Kazuhiro.

Having taken a deep dive into the world of hardened gamblers for the HBO drama ''Luck,'' the director Michael Mann is reteaming with that cable channel to create a documentary series about the lives of combat photographers. HBO said on Tuesday that it had ordered a nonfiction series titled ''Witness'' that will be produced by Mr. Mann and David Frankham, a director of commercials and documentaries, and that will focus on young photojournalists in conflict zones in Mexico, Libya, Uganda and Brazil. Mr. Mann, whose films include ''Heat,'' ''The Insider'' and ''Public Enemies,'' and who directed the pilot episode of ''Luck'' and serves as an executive producer of that series, said in a statement: ''David Frankham and I share an admiration for combat photography that captures the universal - and sometimes the indescribable - in a single frame in the midst of chaos and danger.''
SCHAFFER--Stanley J. and Beverly. Married 3/1/1947. Captain and mate of the Bebby Dear. Your ideals sail on. Loved and missed by Your grateful daughter and Disick descendants

If you have ever found yourself nostalgic for ''It's a Small World,'' the ride found at Disney theme parks, here is your chance to take your children on the popular boat trip around the globe on an iPad instead. The app, from Disney Publishing Worldwide, was inspired by a children's book illustrated by Joey Chou. The artwork is beautifully rendered, evoking the charm and delight of the ride without being overly saccharine.

Home prices in most parts of the country appeared to bottom out in the summer of 2009 and to begin a slow recovery. Markets where prices peaked in 2007, rather than earlier, generally seem to be suffering the most now.

Google started its unified privacy policy on Thursday. The company has been telling users of its services - search, YouTube, Gmail, Google Maps and Google Docs, among others - that information it collects about users will be compiled in a single dossier for its use.

The National Gallery in London announced on Thursday that it had secured funding to purchase Titian's ''Diana and Callisto'' together with the National Galleries of Scotland for $71.7 million, thereby ensuring that the work, along with another great painting by the 16th-century master, would stay on public view. ''Diana and Callisto'' belonged to the Duke of Sutherland, who sold another Titian, ''Diana and Actaeon'' to the two museums for $71 million in 2009. At the time, the Duke gave the institutions the option of purchasing the second painting for about the same price. They were also given 2012 as a deadline.

The playwright Mark Snyder is a native of Ohio, where he has set ''As Wide as I Can See,'' a drama now at the Here Arts Center. Given the play's rigorous balance, it appears he bears a pronounced ambivalence toward the state. Dean (Ryan Barry), a journalist formerly in Chicago, now unemployed, has returned to his hometown and lives with Jessica (Julie Leedes), a headwaitress. Their home includes a backyard with a trailer inhabited by Dean's gruff best friend, Tyler (Joshua Levine), and his live-in girlfriend, Nan (Kay Capasso); Tyler is a mail carrier, while Nan is content with child rearing.

BIRKETT--Dr. David Peter. The Columbia University Stroud Center mourns the loss and honors the memory of Dr. David Peter Birkett, a valued colleague for 35 years. He generously shared his encyclopedic knowledge and innovative ideas in the field of geriatric psychiatry, and served with distinction in its international research and as medical Director of its clinical training program.

SPOKANE, Wash. -- Rick Santorum implied Thursday night that he had won the primary on Tuesday in Michigan, where he actually lost the popular vote to Mitt Romney and, as of now, is behind him in delegates. He did not mention the controversy over the delegates that had sprung up overnight after the Michigan Republican Party changed its rules and, instead of awarding an equal number of delegates to both candidates as expected, gave two additional delegates to Mr. Romney, who won the popular vote with 41 percent compared with Mr. Santorum's 38 percent.

LITTLE--Donald V. The Masters (50+) show jumping division mourns the untimely passing of their fellow equestrian and competitor, Donald V. Little. A passionate horseman, Don displayed exemplary sportsmanship ringside, sharing our successes (and failures) as we shared his. We extend our condolences to his wife, Judy, his children, Donald Jr. and Andrea and their families, to Schuyler Riley, his trainer, and to Mr. Nighttime and Superior, his horses. The Masters Division

In an effort to extend its reach and ''celebrate the written word in action,'' the annual PEN World Voices literary festival, to be held this year from April 30 through May 6, will include not only panels, readings and lectures but also events that wed literature and live performance. Among the collaborations scheduled is one that will pair the Kronos Quartet with the writers Tony Kushner, Marjane Satrapi and Rula Jebreal and another that will feature puppetry on the High Line by the Processional Arts Workshop. As in years past, the festival will bring together prominent writers from all over the world, including the Romanian-born 2009 Nobel laureate Herta Muller; Martin Amis of Britain; Ludmila Ulitskaya of Russia; the festival chairman, Salman Rushdie; and a contingent from the Middle East. American authors scheduled to participate include E.L. Doctorow, Jennifer Egan, Paul Auster and Claire Messud, but to a larger extent than in the past, the festival will also attempt to focus on the spoken and acted word.

MANN--Theodore. Founder of Circle in the Square. The Board of Directors and Members of the Off-Broadway League mourn the passing of an industry pioneer. With vision, drive, and creativity, Ted introduced audiences to a generation of innovative actors, playwrights, directors and designers in what became known as Off-Broadway. We send condolences to Mr. Mann's family and friends, with the promise he will never be forgotten. The Off-Broadway League

DIAL--Terri. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Terri Dial, a tremendously generous and deeply committed supporter of Legal Momentum, the nation's oldest women's advocacy organization. Terri was an extraordinary business leader, a gifted mentor to other women, and a vibrant champion of equal rights for all women and girls. We extend our deepest sympathies to Terri's husband Brian Burry. The Board and Staff of Legal Momentum

8 P.M. (MTV) THE BREAK (2012) More than 1.5 million children are estimated to live on the streets, in shelters and on friends' couches in the United States. Many come from troubled families and have run away from abuse or have aged out of the foster care system. Their futures often involve prostitution, crime and illegal drug use, and one in three are likely to attempt suicide. This documentary follows Ava, Nancy and Rob, young people currently without homes and in desperate need of improving their lives. Anne Mahlum -- an advocate for the homeless whose organization, Back on My Feet, uses running as a way of building strength and self-esteem -- offers them the opportunities and tools to bring about change. The project was envisioned by the Edge, from the band U2. 7:30 A.M. (Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson is Matty, the major league pitcher whose spell she falls under, and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd, above with Ms. Witherspoon) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date and then as a friend whose father-cum-boss (Jack Nicholson) isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it, that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.''

PERLBERG--Toni Aronsohn, died peacefully on February 3, 2012 at the age of 82, after suffering a stroke on Christmas Eve, 2011. Toni was born in New York City to the late Micky Babin Aronsohn and the late Cornelius K. Aronsohn. She attended Goucher College prior to getting married. After raising her family in Rye, NY, she returned to Manhattan where she worked for many years at The Business Council to the United Nations (formerly U.N. We Believe.) While at BCUN, Toni returned to college at the age of 44, received a BA in Business, after which she worked for Phillip Morris USA., and then the Lupus Foundation. In her retirement, she was able to turn her sharp eye for all grammatical infractions into a position as a professional proofreader and copy editor for Hyperion/Miramax Books. We have lost a dear relative and friend who will be remembered for her elegant style, lack of pretense, unrelenting positive disposition, sharp wit, and passion for her family. She was the loving sister of the late Alan JB Aronsohn of New York and mother to H. James "Jim" Perlberg III, Nancy Segal, and Janet Pierson. She will be missed by their spouses, Marilyn, Beau and John; her six grandchildren, Jason, Kate, Barrie, Milo, Georgia and Wyatt; her nephew Lee and nieces Judie and Abby, and beloved friend and sister-in-law Bette Aronsohn. There are a great many other relatives and friends who will miss her .. all of whom she adored .. as they did her. A Memorial will be held in the future. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation to the charity of your choice in her name. She was particularly fond of the arts.

An article on Monday about the decreased focus on Arizona's illegal immigration policies misstated the timing of a campaign advertisement that featured Senator John McCain of Arizona and Sheriff Paul Babeu, who recently stepped down as a co-chairman of Mitt Romney's Arizona campaign amid accusations that he threatened to deport a former lover. The advertisement was for Mr. McCain's 2010 Senate campaign, not for his 2008 presidential run.

KNIGHT--Townsend Jones Townsend Jones Knight, a retired Senior Partner with the New York law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, died peacefully on March 1, 2012 at the age of 83 in Long Island NY. Townsend was born in New York City on August 10, 1928 to Jesse Knight and Marguerite Jones Knight. He attended St. Bernard's School in New York City and St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H. He graduated from Harvard University and from Columbia University Law School before serving as a 1st Lieutenant in the Air Force from 1952-1953. From 1953 until 2010 Townsend worked at the New York law firm Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle where he was a partner from 1965 until his retirement. Townsend spent summers in Long Island where his family had strong ties and where he served on the Board of Directors at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory for 12 years. He was also an active board member of the Metropolitan College of New York, formerly the Audrey Cohen College, since 1966. Townie's happiest moments were those spent at the family home in Penobscot Bay with his friends and many generations of family where he was a deeply committed member of the Island community. He will be remembered for his friendly manner, positive outlook and his infectious smile. Townsend is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years Elise, his three daughters Margaret Dudley, Elise Wallace and Jessica Knight and his eight devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. at 2 o'clock on Sunday March 4th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

The Rolling Stones are marking the band's 50th anniversary with a new book, their publisher is expected to announce on Friday. Hyperion will release ''The Rolling Stones at Fifty,'' a ''photographic autobiography'' with images that have not been seen before and new text from the band. The book drew from the archive of The Daily Mirror in London, the largest collection of Rolling Stones photography, the publisher said. It is scheduled for release in the United States and Canada in the fall. Ellen Archer, the president and publisher of Hyperion, said in a statement: ''An anniversary such as this calls for an amazing book. Mick, Keith, Charlie and Ronnie have been hard at work -- approaching the book's content from every conceivable angle -- to make it so.''

When President Obama boards Air Force One and departs New York City on Thursday night, he will have hit a notable milestone: He will have held more than 100 fund-raising events for his re-election effort in less than a year. That is more than President George W. Bush held during the entire 2004 cycle, according to unofficial tallies kept by the CBS reporter Mark Knoller, suggesting the intense pace of Mr. Obama's fund-raising as he prepares to battle Republicans and the independent groups likely to spend tens of millions of dollars to defeat him.

ENGMAN--Patricia Hanahan, of Anna Maria, FL, died February 20, at home, surrounded by her family and friends. Mrs. Engman was born on May 1, 1942 at Camp Stuart in Hinesville, GA. and grew up in Lakeland, FL, where she attended Lakeland Senior High School. She was the daughter of the late Phyllis Anderson Hanahan and Dr. Ralph B. Hanahan, III. In 1965, Mrs. Engman received her A.B. degree, cum laude, from Coker College in Hartsville, SC and her J.D. degree from the University of Florida Law School in Gainesville, FL in 1969. Following graduation from law school she clerked for Judge David McCain of Florida's Fourth District Court of Appeals. In 1970, she was assistant to the campaign manager of Lawton Chiles' first "Walkin' Lawton Campaign" for the United States Senate and moved to Washington, DC in 1971 as a staff attorney for the Senator. In following years, Mrs. Engman served as a Congressional Liaison Officer for the Federal Trade Commission, Counsel for Legislative and Administrative Affairs for Bristol-Myers, and as the Executive Director at The Business Roundtable, an association of CEOs of leading US companies comprising nearly 1/3 of the value of the US stock market. Her role was to develop and implement public policy positions with Congress and the Administration. In 2006 she was appointed by President George W. Bush to a President's Emergency Board to investigate, report and make settlement recommendations in a major dispute between a New York rail carrier and its employees represented by multiple labor unions. Active in numerous community and civic affairs in Washington, DC and in her Florida retirement, Mrs. Engman was a member of St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square in Washington, DC and Church of the Annunciation in Anna Maria, FL. She was a member of the Washington Women's Forum. She served on the Board of Trustees of Coker College from 1993-1999 and received their Distinguished Alumni Award. In her retirement she sat on the board of Florida House and was a member of the Suncoast Women's Forum. She was a member of Key Royale and Bradenton Country Clubs. She was married to Lewis A. Engman (who served as Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission under both Presidents Nixon and Ford, was President of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and President of the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association) from 1978 until his death on July 12, 1995. Mrs. Engman is survived by three sons, Geoffrey Engman of Texas, Jonathan Engman of Michigan and Richard Engman of Florida; her brother Dr. Ralph Bailey Hanahan, IV and sisters Christy Hanahan Powell and Elizabeth (Lisa) Hanahan Taylor; eight grandchildren and her fiance, John Kolojeski. The funeral was held on Saturday, February 25 at 2pm at the Church of the Annunciation in Anna Maria, FL. Memorial donations may be made to Tidewell Hospice of Bradenton, FL.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about remarks by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton that the United States and Egypt were involved in ''very intensive discussions'' to end the criminal prosecution in Egypt of staff members at four American-financed nonprofit organizations misstated, in some editions, the day on which the judge removed himself from the case. It was Tuesday night, not Thursday, Feb. 23. (An article about the Americans' being allowed to leave Egypt on Thursday is on Page A6.)

The TV Watch column on Tuesday, about ''Titans at the Table'' on Bloomberg TV, in mentioning rivals to Bloomberg, paraphrased incorrectly a comment by a Fox Business Network anchor about the cost to taxpayers of fuel used on Air Force One. He said, ''Not a lot of other options, not like he's going to fly Southwest or something.'' He did not suggest that President Obama fly Southwest Airlines.

An article on Thursday about an announcement by North Korea that it would suspend its nuclear efforts in return for a United States pledge to ship tons of food aid to the isolated, impoverished country misstated, in some editions, the time frame for the collapse of the last significant negotiations on dismantling North Korea's nuclear weapons. It was more than three years ago, in December 2008 -- not more than four.

SHENKER--Phyllis F.,age 84, passed away peacefully, February 29 in Madison, WI. Born June 15, 1927 to Hyman and Pauline Finkelstein of the Bronx. Raised two daughters with Joseph Shenker, Robin and Kathy, in Forest Hills. Phyllis had great spirit, a winning smile, a zest for life, great style, was loving and generous to all, and a wonderful grandmother. Survived by daughters, Robin Abbady and Kathy (Patrick Powers); grandsons, Aidan and Matt; sister, Sylvia Baer; loving nieces and nephews, Lauren (John) Veronis, Gloria (Marv) Schwartz, Randy (Clara) Baer, Jeff (Annie) Stein and Steve (Joyce) Bernfeld. Preceded in death by her sisters, Rae, Molly and Rosalind; companion of many years, Leon Fagin. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. Memorials to Temple Beth El or Jewish Social Services of Madison, WI; or to Technion Institute.

King, and Muddy Waters, died on Saturday in Morro Bay, Calif. He was 84. The cause was complications of kidney failure, his manager, Linda Knipe, said.

In a 2012 Williamstown Theater Festival summer season that includes a new play by Katori Hall and a musical adaptation of ''Far From Heaven,'' it takes a very special revival of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' to catch our eye. And the production of that classic Oscar Wilde farce that David Hyde Pierce plans to direct there might just meet that standard. Here, for starters, is how this ''Earnest'' is described in the news release announcing the Williamstown season:

A two-hour edition of ''American Idol'' - which focused on the top 12 female performers - provided another easy ratings win for Fox on Wednesday. According to Nielsen estimates, the singing competition averaged just over 17 million viewers, although it suffered another slight drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared to last week. The downward trend for ''Idol'' in adults 18-to-49 has allowed ''Modern Family'' on ABC to get within striking distance in the advertiser-beloved category; it was just one tenth of a ratings point below ''Idol.'' Elsewhere, it was another rough Wednesday night for NBC as ''Are You There, Chelsea'' and ''Law and Order: SVU'' both matched season lows in the 18-to-49 demo. NBC was also beaten soundly by Spanish-language Univision in that category and finished fifth overall.

The musicians' union for New York City has begun an advertising campaign and plans to expand protests outside of jazz clubs as part of its efforts to win pension benefits for jazz artists, union leaders said Thursday. The union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, started handing out leaflets outside the Blue Note in Greenwich Village in December, arguing the club owners have reneged on a promise they made to the union in 2006 to begin contributing pension benefits for jazz musicians in return for a sales tax break passed by the legislature. No formal agreement to finance pensions for jazz artists was ever reached between the union and the clubs, and some club owners even dispute the union's claim that they made a tentative pact to do so.

Pennsylvania prosecutors released security-camera photos on Thursday of two men who they say used the credit cards of a missing Brooklyn cafe owner, Joshua Rubin, hours after his burned body was found along a rural road in Pennsylvania. The photos were taken Nov. 1 at Woodbury Common, an outlet center in Orange County, N.Y. They show two young men with close-cropped hair in hooded jackets carrying shopping bags.

KNIGHT--Townsend J. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL) Board of Trustees, faculty and administration mourn the passing of our long-time friend and supporter Townie Knight who served three terms on the Laboratory's Board of Trustees from 1970 through 1995. Townie led several board committees, including the Audit and Commercial Relations Committees and served as the Assistant Secretary of the CSHL Board from 1992-1994. In 1995, Townie was made an Honorary Trustee in recognition of his dedication to the research and education mission of CSHL. A respected attorney, his legal and finance expertise contributed greatly to the Laboratory's success in commercializing biomedical technologies. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife Elise and their family. Bruce Stillman, President Jamie C. Nicholls, Board Chairman James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer
VENETIOU--James. 16 years we think of you with love everyday. Irene & Buddy

The restructuring of Greece's debt that is scheduled to start next week may well demonstrate how effective credit-default swaps are. These financial instruments, which played a major role in both the 2008 financial crisis and in the European debt crisis, are meant to pay out if a company or country defaults. But the twists and turns over Greece's debt are revealing their potential limitations for investors who hope the swaps will protect them against losses if Greece defaults.

A report in the Media Decoder column on Monday about the independent film ''Boy'' and its slow road to distribution gave an incorrect name for a New York theater where it will open on today. It is the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, not the Eleanor Bunim Film Center.
An obituary on Thursday about Anna Lou Dehavenon, an urban anthropologist, erroneously included a survivor. Andre de Havenon, a stepson, died in 2000.

''West of Memphis,'' a documentary about the West Memphis Three killings whose producers include Peter Jackson, the Academy Award-winning ''Lord of the Rings'' director, and Damien Echols, one of the West Memphis Three, has been acquired for release by Sony Pictures Classics, that division of the Sony studio announced. Directed by Amy Berg, an Academy Award nominee for ''Deliver Us From Evil,'' ''West of Memphis'' chronicles the case of Mr. Echols, Jason Baldwin and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who in 1994 were convicted of the murders of three boys in West Memphis, Ark., and who were released from prison last August but are not considered innocent men in the eyes of the law. The film, which made its debut at the Sundance Film Festival in January, looks at a new investigation into the case that turned up new evidence relating to the murders. The investigation was paid for in part by Mr. Jackson and his wife, Fran Walsh.

An art review last Friday about ''Cindy Sherman,'' an exhibition of Ms. Sherman's photographs at the Museum of Modern Art, referred incorrectly to an exhibition of Richard Serra's work there in 2007 in discussing how much space is allotted to the Sherman photographs. The Serra exhibition was on part of the sixth floor, as well as in the large second-floor galleries and part of the garden. It did not occupy the entire sixth floor.

Dr. Tina Strobos, a fearless woman who hid more than 100 Jews in a gabled attic in Nazi-occupied Amsterdam just a few blocks from the hideout where Anne Frank was captured, died on Monday at her home in Rye, N.Y. She was 91. The cause was cancer, said her son Jur Strobos. The ethos of rescuing the imperiled was something Dr. Strobos absorbed from her parents -- socialist atheists who took in Belgian refugees during World War I and hid German and Austrian refugees before World War II. Her actions as a young medical student were recognized as extraordinary by Holocaust organizations like Yad Vashem, which listed her with other rescuers as one of the Righteous Among the Nations.

For 31 years, Stefan Graff has been haunted by Summons No. 1Q72724926S. Actually, it is that summons and two others that have shadowed Mr. Graff all these years. Mr. Graff, 52, a lifelong (but currently unemployed) cabdriver, said he incurred the three tickets while driving a livery cab in Jamaica, Queens - on Dec. 2, 1980, according to the summonses.

LOS ANGELES -- The Walt Disney Company on Thursday went on the attack against a shareholder advisory service that earlier in the week criticized the entertainment conglomerate's management structure and the compensation it awards its chief executive, Robert A. Iger. ISS Governance, which advises institutional investors on how to vote on corporate proxies, on Wednesday issued a 28-page report looking at Disney's decision to give Mr. Iger the added title of chairman at its annual meeting on March 13. ISS's report said the move represents an ''about face'' by Disney on independent board leadership.

Terri Dial, who climbed the ranks of Wells Fargo from bank teller to senior executive before being tapped to revamp Citigroup's consumer banking business during the financial crisis, died on Tuesday in Miami. She was 62. The cause was pancreatic cancer, said Karen Kaplowitz, a friend. Ms. Dial, who lived in San Francisco; Napa, Calif., and Miami, died in a hospice.
An Op-Ed essay on Thursday about Israel and Iran's nuclear development program misstated the date of Israel's 1981 airstrike against the Osirak nuclear reactor in Iraq. It was June 7, not July 7.

Yelp, the online hub for local business reviews, priced its initial public offering at $15 a share on Thursday, above its expected range. At that price, the company has raised $107.25 million, at a $898.1 million valuation. Its market debut, set for Friday morning, will be another critical test of investor appetite for technology stocks, ahead of Facebook's multibillion-dollar public offering expected this year.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about Ace Hardware's marketing campaign for a new line of paint, used an outdated name for the employer of Jack Horst, a retail strategist who commented on the matter. He works for Kurt Salmon -- not for Kurt Salmon Associates, which the company was known as before it merged with Ineum Consulting. The error also appeared in an article on Feb. 21 about limits on some care in Catholic hospitals.

KALKSTEIN--Abraham, on February 25, 2012 at age 97. A WWII Veteran, he was a highly regarded executive in the garment industry for more than five decades. He is survived by his sons and their partners Julian and Helene Fromm, Joshua and Laura Beach; grandchildren Aleta, Molly, Noah, Trevor and his wife Elyssa, Maxim and Sarah and a great-grandson Aaron.

The Pearl Theater Company, an Off Broadway troupe that stages classical plays, has signed a 20-year lease on a new home: the 160-seat venue on West 42nd Street that Signature Theater Company occupied for years before moving into its new center this winter. Pearl executives announced on Tuesday that their 29th season would begin this fall at the company's new theater, which was known as the Peter Norton Space during the Signature era. Mr. Norton is the chairman of the board of Signature; a spokesman for the Pearl said the theater would be renamed. The Pearl will undertake a $3 million capital campaign to renovate the theater, its executives said in a statement. J.R. Sullivan, the Pearl's artistic director, said the new theater ''offers audiences an intimate relationship to an especially fine stage space.'' He added, ''It will prove a perfect fit for the classics to come from the Pearl,'' whose critically praised productions included the recent ''Wittenberg'' - a comic mash-up featuring Hamlet, Doctor Faustus, and Martin Luther as characters.

GREENBERG--Marilyn, 88, of Harrison, NY, Manhattan and Palm Beach died February 26. She was predeceased by husband, Joseph and is survived by children, Lou-Ellen (Mel) and William (Martha); four grandchildren, Tony, Sara, Michael and Rebecca, four great-grandchildren and niece, Cathy Robinson. Memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter, Care Consultation, 360 Lexington Ave. NYC 10017.

Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska and 2008 vice-presidential nominee, stepped up her war against the HBO movie ''Game Change'' on Thursday by releasing a video that highlights positive comments about her from Republicans who later became her fiercest critics. The movie, which premieres on March 10, is based on the book of the same name by Mark Halperin of Time magazine and John Heilemann of New York magazine. The film portrays Ms. Palin in a largely negative light during the 2008 campaign, suggesting that she knew little about policy and became difficult to deal with as the campaign wore on.

On Friday, High Line Art, the public art program of the New York park built on a historic elevated rail line, announced its plans for its spring 2012 season. Work on view will include, in April, a new contribution by the Scottish artist David Shrigley to the High Line Billboard series, presented on a 25-by-75-foot billboard next to the park on Tenth Avenue at West 18th Street, and films and videos in the High Line Channel series, an outdoor program featuring projections on a building to the east of the High Line at West 22nd Street after dark. Also in the spring, High Line Art will present performance art pieces by Alison Knowles (April 22, Earth Day), Channa Horwitz (May 17) and Simone Forti (May 24), on and around the High Line. And the park's first group exhibition,''Lilliput,'' inspired by Jonathan Swift's ''Gulliver's Travels,'' will assemble sculptures of diminutive scale by various artists, scattered along the High Line.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a concert scheduled for Tuesday to commemorate the anniversary of last year's earthquake and tsunami in Japan, at the Rose Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the presenter. It is the Japan Foundation, not the Japan Society.

As part of a campaign to block loans to foreign museums with disputed objects in their collections, Turkey is refusing to lend artifacts to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, The Art Newspaper reported. The Met told the newspaper that a dozen antiquities in its collection are now being claimed by Turkey, but would not identify the individual items, saying the matter was ''under discussion with the Turkish authorities.'' And Tolga Tuyluoglu, who runs Turkey's culture and tourism office in London, confirmed to the newspaper that claims for the return of two artifacts in the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert are being pursued, adding that his government wants to resolve the issues ''before discussing loans for exhibitions.'' The British Museum had requested loans of 35 items for its current exhibition ''Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam,'' but the ministry of culture blocked them, leaving the museum to find alternatives on short notice. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8:50 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON - The election-year fight over the administration's birth control policy escalated Friday, with two unlikely figures - a Georgetown University law student and the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh - taking center stage in the politically charged conflict and pulling much of official Washington into the fray. On Friday, one day after Senate Democrats beat back a Republican challenge to the new policy, President Obama called Sandra Fluke, the Georgetown student who had come under incendiary attack from Mr. Limbaugh, to thank her for publicly backing his regulations mandating contraception coverage.
An article on Thursday about Robert Harling, an executive producer of the new ABC show ''GCB,'' misspelled the surname of another executive producer. He is Darren Star, not Starr.

The On Baseball column on Thursday, about the tension in Major League Baseball in the wake of Ryan Braun's successful appeal of a positive doping test, misstated the number of labor agreements in a row that the league reached without a work stoppage. The current one, completed in 2011, is the third in a row, not the second.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a White House meeting set for Monday in which President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel are expected to try to sort out their differences over Iran misstated, in some editions, the date of the photograph showing the two leaders in a meeting in the Oval Office. It was taken in July 2010, not last July.

A foundation set up in memory of the singer Amy Winehouse after her death last year from alcohol poisoning will provide a scholarship to a London theater school where she studied voice as a girl, the Winehouse family said. The scholarship to the Sylvia Young Theater School will go to a child whose family cannot afford to pay the tuition, the singer's father, Mitch Winehouse, told Reuters. Ms. Winehouse was only 13 when she auditioned at the school and impressed the founder with her version of ''On the Sunny Side of the Street.'' The Amy Winehouse Foundation was set up by her family after the singer's death in July to provide treatment to young drug addicts and alcoholics. Best known for her song ''Rehab,'' she was only 27 when she died. Ms. Winehouse, who helped to revive soul music in Britain with her sassy tone and no-nonsense lyrics, had a short but brilliant career, making two critically acclaimed albums before she was derailed by drug and alcohol abuse. That wild streak was evident even when she attended the Young school as a teenager; she dropped out before finishing and had behavioral problems.

Mark Teixeira is considered an all-around talent, and that includes his Michael Jackson impersonation. Teixeira unveiled his song-and dance act during the Yankees' team bonding event at a comedy club in Tampa on Thursday. Joe Girardi called Teixeira's impersonation ''priceless,'' while Russell Martin described it as the show stopper. Teixeira found it difficult to be humble about his performance. ''It's not really fair,'' he said, ''because when it comes to Michael Jackson, that's right in my sweet spot.''

Julie Taymor, who filed suit after she was fired as director of the $75 million Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' last March, said in court papers Friday that the producers' counter-suit was ''highly sensationalistic, false and misleading'' and aimed at ''assassinating her character and professional reputation.'' In a 46-page answer to the producers' counterclaim, filed in U.S. District Court in New York, Ms. Taymor contended that they secretly conspired to oust her while still asking her to make changes on the show's book while public performances were going on. The filing argues that the producers fired Ms. Taymor and blamed the show's problems on her as an ''opportunistic way'' to calm worried investors, buy more time, and ''sway critics' opinions'' by insisting that the show had been ''re-imagined.''
Breaking! The New York Times has learned more about the mysterious questioner who asked Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ''What is the air speed velocity of an unladen swallow?''

The longtime publisher and author James Atlas has signed up with Amazon to edit a series of biographies, he said this week, following in the footsteps of another veteran, Laurence Kirshbaum, the publisher and agent who jumped to Amazon Publishing last year. The series Mr. Atlas will edit, called Amazon Lives, is expected to be published beginning in June 2013.

An article on Tuesday about Wang Shu, winner of the 2012 Pritzker Architecture Prize, using information from a publicist, misspelled the name of a campus of the China Academy of Art designed by Mr. Wang. (HBO) HANNA (2011) Saoirse Ronan, above, stars as a teenage assassin trying to elude a ruthless C.I.A. operative (Cate Blanchett) and her two huntsmen in this action movie from Joe Wright, who also directed Ms. Ronan in her Oscar-nominated role in ''Atonement.'' Eric Bana is the warrior father, wrapped in animal skins, who has trained Hanna from childhood in northern Finland to become a killing machine. ''Round and round they go and where they stop, well, you probably know,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''In the end there might not be much to this tale other than titillation, but there's plenty to be said for Ms. Ronan, who was the best thing about 'Atonement' and holds her ground against forceful screen presences like Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Bana.'' That her translucent blue eyes, transformed here into opaque pools, ''don't reveal much is part of the big surprise as well as a liability in a movie that is by turns startling and generic, subtle and blunt, and consistently keeps you in its grip if not its heart,'' Ms. Dargis added. 7 P.M. There was Jeremy Lin on Wednesday night, blood streaming from his nose after taking a hit from Omri Casspi during the Knicks' victory over the Cavaliers. Walking off the court, he tilted his head back, two red streaks spilling into his mouth - a hero defeated. But before long he was back in the game, and it was clear: here is a man in need of a worthy theme song. Plenty have tried in the weeks since the beginning of Linsanity, the phenomenon that has sprouted a cottage industry of tribute songs by amateur singers and rappers, proving how quickly the combination of extreme fandom and low barriers to entry can create a glut.

HOWE--Bruce, a Newport, Rhode Island resident since the mid-1950s, died Wednesday, February 29, 2012 at Blenheim-Newport, an assisted living community in Middletown, Rhode Island. He was 99 years old. Born on November 20, 1912 in Washington DC, Bruce was the oldest son of Walter Bruce Howe, an international lawyer, and Mary Howe, the American composer. A graduate of Yale University, he received his doctoral degree in anthropology from Harvard University. After more than four years of service in the United States Army during World War II, he joined forces with the American School of Prehistoric Research at Harvard. Between 1947 and 1975 he did fieldwork and excavations in prehistoric archaeology across North Africa for the American School of Prehistoric Research, Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology (Harvard University), and Howard University. He also worked in Iraqi Kurdistan and Turkey for the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago. The results of his work in anthropology have been published by the Peabody Museum and the Oriental Institute. For a number of seasons he was a member of the Prehistory Department of the University of Istanbul in Turkey. In Newport, Bruce served for many years as President of the Newport Art Association and was on the Redwood Library's Board of Directors. He also devoted much of his time and resources over the past half-century to conserving his home, Berry Hill, a twenty-two acre historic landscape and wildlife refuge in Newport's Ocean Drive District, which the Howe family sold in 2010. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Aquidneck Land Trust, 790 Aquidneck Avenue, Middletown, RI, 02842.

SOLIS-COHEN--Virginia "Ginny". Born Virginia Rosalie Kaufman to Alice and Otto Kaufman in New York City on January 31, 1922, passed away peacefully at the age of 90 on March 2, 2012 at her home in Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. A resident of Rydal, PA for over 50 years, she was married to her remarkably sweet husband, Hays, for close to 50 years before he died in 1991. Ginny took immense pleasure in being a mother (and mother-in-law) to Betsy (Peter), David (Carole) and Kate (before she died in 1973); a grandmother to Emily, Sarah, Daniel, Flavia, Hannah, Emma and Ben; a great-grandmother to Paul, Oliver, and Mateo and loving aunt to Frank, Robert and Jim. She graduated from Birch Wathen School in New York City and Tyler Art School in Philadelphia, and was a talented artist and sculptor. Her lively character and spirit will be missed by family and friends, but her positive outlook on life and her art will remain a part of us forever. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Abington Art Center, Jenkintown Library, PBS or other charity of one's choice.

That's because they need to prepare multiple sets of tax returns: each partner needs to file a separate federal tax return since the federal government defines marriage as between a man and a woman (though some couples refuse to comply, but that's another story). So same-sex couples also need to prepare a dummy tax return as if they were filing jointly so that they can transfer that information onto their state returns, which they must file as a couple. The situation becomes ridiculously more complex for gay couples living in the three states that have both community property laws and recognize same-sex unions. In that case, officially partnered gay couples need to follow their state's community property laws on their federal returns -- even though they need to file separately.

KLEIMAN--Murray. With great sorrow we announce the passing of Murray Kleiman, March 1st in Atlantis, FL at age 89. Treasured husband of Adele, beloved brother of Dorothy Lang, adored father of Mitchell and Nancy, Randi and Oron Brokman, Leslie and David Gleaner, precious Pop Pop to Yuval and Sarah, Aviv, Kineret, Alexis, Ian, Ariel and Seth, and special friend and cherished uncle and cousin. Murray had an insatiable thirst for knowledge. He was an avid wordsmith and famous among all who knew him for always jotting down words and quotes to share. A man with a spectacular sense of humor, his delight in telling a good joke was only surpassed by hearing one. He was an ardent Knicks fan basking in their current season's storyline. But Murray was also a deep thinker. He was as interested and knowledgeable in Torah as the most serious biblical scholar. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Yeshivah University, he was a psychologist by training. He and Adele took over his parents' catering business, Kleiman Caterers, a premiere kosher catering enterprise, well known throughout Long Island. This venture highlighted Murray's other great passion -- food. Murray not only was comfortable in the kitchen, he thrived in it. Most of all, Murray was a true mensch. He will be remembered for his sweetness, incredible warmth, kind heart, and how he delighted and basked in the love of his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to UJA/ Federation of Jewish Philanthropies or Anti-Defamation League. Funeral at 1pm Sunday at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ.

William Randolph Hearst was born in California in 1863. William Randolph Hearst died in California in 1951. His most famous home, at San Simeon, is in California. His tomb is in California. And it was in California, 125 years ago Sunday, that he laid the foundation stone of his media empire, when his name appeared for the first time in The Daily Examiner of San Francisco as ''W. R. Hearst, Proprietor.'' You know what, though? He was really a New Yorker. From 1895 onward, his empire was anchored here, where it remains, headquartered at Hearst Tower. He represented the city in Congress for two terms and campaigned - unsuccessfully - to lead it as mayor. The monuments and landmarks of his tumultuous personal and professional life can be found around the city. Hearst continues to affect New York day in and day out, as anyone who has struggled over the senseless Robert F. Kennedy Bridge dogleg approach can tell you. (Which is to say, just about everyone.) Had the bridge been designed by traffic engineers, and not politicians, its Manhattan terminus would have been at East 100th Street, directly across from the Queens end.

KNIGHT--Townsend Jones Townsend Jones Knight, a retired Senior Partner with the New York law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, died peacefully on March 1, 2012 at the age of 83 in Long Island NY. Townsend was born in New York City on August 10, 1928 to Jesse Knight and Marguerite Jones Knight. He attended St. Bernard's School in New York City and St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H. He graduated from Harvard University and from Columbia University Law School before serving as a 1st Lieutenant in the Air Force from 1952-1953. From 1953 until 2010 Townsend worked at the New York law firm Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle where he was a partner from 1965 until his retirement. Townsend spent summers in Long Island where his family had strong ties and where he served on the Board of Directors at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory for 12 years. He was also an active board member of the Metropolitan College of New York, formerly the Audrey Cohen College, since 1966. Townie's happiest moments were those spent at the family home in Penobscot Bay with his friends and many generations of family where he was a deeply committed member of the Island community. He will be remembered for his friendly manner, positive outlook and his infectious smile. Townsend is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years Elise, his three daughters Margaret Dudley, Elise Wallace and Jessica Knight and his eight devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. at 2 o'clock on Sunday March 4th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

An answer in the Q&A column on Feb. 26, about Jodi Ettenberg, a travel blogger and consultant, misstated the name of a small tour company she recommended for people traveling alone and omitted Ms. Ettenberg's connection to that business. The company is G Adventures, which she travels with and writes about once or twice a year; it is not Geo Trekkers.

An article on Feb. 19 about Margaret Edson, who wrote the Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Wit,'' which is back on Broadway, referred incorrectly to one of several interests that occupy her days now that she no longer focuses on playwriting. She does not read Dante in Italian every day, although she once did.

DELPIN--Olinto, O.M.,died February 23 in New York City from respiratory failure. Born to Maria and Antonio in Sottomonte in 1926. Joined the Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the US and Canada in 1954. Settled in Queens, with his wife Luciana, became a US citizen 1962. He worked on many New York City projects, including the World Trade Center, JFK airport and Bronx Co-op City. He is remembered on the NIAF Wall of Honor in Washington, DC. He is survived by his daughters Sandra Failla, Scarsdale and Dr. Christina DelPin Cella, Greenwich CT, as well as five grandchildren, brother Bortolo, and the children and cousins of brother Louis and sisters Anna, Irma,Elda Angelina, and Gilda. He will be buried in Meduno, Italy next week. He taught us: 1. Family is the cement, the foundation; 2. Don't be afraid to change your place, it is an elemental and natural right, can not be impeded, and at times a painful necessity, leaving no recourse 3. Learn to communicate with all people 4. Love your partner(s)fiercely 5. With a brain and hands, do good work, do it yourself, finish what you start 6. Be tolerant of people different than you 7. Protect your identity at all costs, 8. If you fall into dark Times, recognize it, see the dead space, respect it, find a new purpose, do what you have to to turn it around 9. embrace your community, enhance it. Light up your Xmas tree, for all to enjoy. And just keep going! In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made in Dad's memory to the Olinto DelPin Famee Furlana Educational scholarship fund.
Cooking for the sick; the secret lives of dogs.

A PENTHOUSE that sold for $15.587 million at the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The 4,105-square-foot five-bedroom condominium is distinguished by details like a gas fireplace, a walnut spiral staircase and Bianco marble in the master bathroom -- and 1,280 square feet of outdoor space. The apartment is one of two in the building, at Broadway and 76th Street, that have private rooftop space, and the listing promotes the panoramic views that can be enjoyed year-round in the comfort of an outdoor hot tub. Shlomi Reuveni, the broker at Brown Harris Stevens who has led the sales team at the Laureate, declined to comment. But unlike nearly every other sale at the Laureate, this one did not shield the buyer's identity behind a limited liability company. The new owners are G. Peter and Marguerite D'Aloia, according to city records. Mr. D'Aloia works in the chemical industry and serves on the boards of several companies .Mr. D'Aloia is listed as the owner of another penthouse, at the Coronado at 70th and Central Park West, that he bought in 2007 for $3.35 million, according to city records. Whatever that home may be lacking, the Laureate most likely has, including a kitchen designed by Deborah Berke that opens up to a breakfast room with French doors and a Juliet balcony.

An article last Sunday about the high-rise neighborhood on the Upper West Side along Riverside Boulevard described incorrectly the transfer of the site from Donald J. Trump to Extell and the Carlyle Group. Mr. Trump and his partners sold the property to Extell and the Carlyle Group for about $1.8 billion; he did not lose control of the property.

Synths and drum machines litter the Brooklyn bedroom inhabited by the rising electronic artist Frank Midnite, a k a Bright Future. But they never get hooked up to his laptop. ''What can I say?'' Midnite asks. ''I don't understand how to make music with a mouse, on a screen. It's way over my head.'' Whether recording to four-track tape or performing at venues legal and not, he actually plays his instruments; there are no samples. The resulting mix is gritty and emotional, a rare combination for the genre. ''Fidelity isn't really important,'' he says. ''Human error in recordings shows that the artist is with you every step of the way. They endured the same length of time to create the melodies - or antimelodies - as it takes to listen.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CYWINSKI--Bernard J. FAIA. March 2, 2011 "Architecture has been my life." Co-founder of Bohlin Cywinski Jackson, Bernie was more than just the architect behind Philadelphia's 1st Apple Store, the rebuilt Independence Mall and Liberty Bell Center. He also served as paterfamilias of the city's architectural community and is missed everyday by his wife Nancy Oklesson and sister-in-laws MaryAnn, Dorothy, Ginny, his brother Ed and sister Theresa and many nieces and nephews.

LEVEY--Alex William. Born March 31, 1919 to Yetta and Louis Levy at 161 Broome St., NY. Beloved brother of Millie and Anna, and devoted husband of Shirley. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School, RCA Institute Engineering Program, Hofstra University BA and MA Physics and Education, and Columbia University Post-Grad in Education. Valiant WWII Veteran served in Italy and N. Africa; six honors and medals. Commercial radio technician 14 years, author of "Radio Laboratory Manual" published by J.F. Rider. '56. Professor of Electrical Engineering 27 years at State University of New York at Farmingdale. Mayor of Cochiti Lake, NM, seven years. He was a determined survivor of hardship, and a hard-working and generous provider. He is survived by his son Jay, daughter-in-law Karen, and grandsons Jared and Daniel. He will be missed.

To the Sports Editor Re ''Braun Blasts 'Flawed' Testing Process,'' Feb. 25: It appears that Ryan Braun's self-serving statement had more omissions, misstatements, exaggerations and innuendos than fact, including his failure to mention that the collector's son is an employee of the testing company whose job is to chaperon players during testing. What could be more appropriate to ensure privacy?

The acclaimed New York restaurant Le Cirque (lecirque.com) is taking its lobster salad and other recipes on the road in a series of pop-up dinners across the country. On 10 Friday nights from March 9 through June 1, the restaurant will ship its signature china as well as its chef, Olivier Reginensi, to cities including Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Orlando, Fla., and San Diego. The dinners, though open to the public, will be held at private clubs run by ClubCorp.

MANN--Theodore. Founder of Circle in the Square. The Board of Directors and Members of the Off-Broadway League mourn the passing of an industry pioneer. With vision, drive, and creativity, Ted introduced audiences to a generation of innovative actors, playwrights, directors and designers in what became known as Off-Broadway. We send condolences to Mr. Mann's family and friends, with the promise he will never be forgotten. The Off-Broadway League

JACUZZI--Giocondo, died peacefully in his sleep on February 22, 2012. He was born in Berkeley, California on September 12, 1921, the first son of Frank and Rena Jacuzzi. He attended Berkeley High School, University of California at Berkeley and was a member of Phi Kappa Alpha fraternity. On October 13, 1942, he married Lillian Mintzman in a civil ceremony in Carson City, Nevada. He served in the intelligence department of the Army during WWII and was honorably discharged on February 4, 1946. He worked his entire career at Jacuzzi Brothers Inc., which was founded by his father and six brothers in 1915. In 1960, he relocated from California to New York where he headed up a new branch of Jacuzzi Brothers. He retired, following the sale of Jacuzzi Brothers Inc. to The Walter Kidde Company, in October 1979. He and Lillian spent their retirement years between New York and Phoenix where they enjoyed golfing, walking, reading, socializing and dancing. They also loved to travel and spend time with their children and grandchildren. Giocondo was a devoted and loyal husband (69 years),to Lillian and father to his three children Janice Hussey, Marc Jacuzzi and Carol Lisai. He leaves behind his wife Lillian, three children, eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. He was admired and loved by those knew him and will always be remembered for his kindness, fairness and generosity.

A report on Feb. 19 in the In Transit column about a new Web site, cultivora.com, with destination guides for music festival fans, misstated the given name of a founder and chief marketing officer of the company. He is Joseph Sunder, not Joshua.

The cover photograph last Sunday with an opinion essay about Bell Labs and its contributions to scientific and technological innovation was published in error. The picture, from Magnum Photos, most likely showed workers at Allied Chemical in 1967 -- not at Bell Labs in New Jersey in 1966. The photograph had been incorrectly labeled in the studio of the photographer, Elliott Erwitt. Also, a timeline with the essay incorrectly attributed a distinction to Bell Labs, based on information from the Web site of its corporate successor, Alcatel-Lucent. In 1933, Bell Labs gave the first demonstration of long-distance transmission of three-channel high-fidelity stereo sound -- not the first transmission of stereo sound. (Clément Ader demonstrated two-channel stereo sound transmission in Paris in 1881.)

The 36 Hours column on Feb. 19, about New Orleans, misspelled the name of a restaurant serving classic south Louisiana cuisine. It is Brigtsen's, not Brigsten's. (The misspelling was repeated in the name of its Web site, which is brigtsens.com.)

DAVID BROOKS Gail, we've been having our online conversations since the 2008 election, but this is the first one they've asked us to do for the actual newspaper. Are we really ready for the big time? My view is that it's like when Jennifer Aniston tried to make the leap to the big screen. A possible disaster, leading to embarrassment for all involved. GAIL COLLINS Yeah, right now we're talking for Web and print. Does that make us biplatform? I've never had a conversation on paper before. It's making me feel all crinkly. But our mission is to discuss the Republicans. Super Tuesday is coming! What are you feeling?

In ''Black at Stuy,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, Fernanda Santos profiled Rudi-Ann Miller, a 17-year-old senior who is one of 40 black students, out of a total 3,295, at Stuyvesant High School, long considered New York City's flagship public school. Readers commented on NYTimes.com about the new demographics of Stuyvesant, which is 72.5 percent Asian, and on its admissions test; a selection of responses is below. I've faced a similar, though less intense, challenge as Rudi-Ann, and I wish her the best. It's quite hard to be a minority teenager battling the negative stereotypes that society throws at you, especially during a time when you are just forming ideas of who you are supposed to be.

''I got the name of being a pretty good fiddle player,'' Joe Thompson once said. ''I even been to Carnegie Hall playing fiddle.'' He also played at the Kennedy Center in Washington and at folk festivals from coast to coast, including one at the Smithsonian. The National Endowment for the Arts awarded him a National Heritage Fellowship. And he is credited with helping to keep alive an African-American musical tradition -- the black string band -- that predates the blues and influenced country music and bluegrass.

''To make a single photograph,'' Khan says, ''I use a lot of found imagery. A lot of photographs (the Houses of Parliament, Tower Bridge, St. Paul's) were from the 1930s onward. I looked at a lot of stock photography as well, and went to all the horrible tourist shops in London to get every postcard I could find. ''I used 70 to 100 images for each picture. I wouldn't necessarily take the whole image, but fragments of images, and bring them together on the computer. I would try to choose something that really stands out in the photograph. Roland Barthes called it the punctum.

GROSSMAN--Irwin, 96, on March 1. Columbia '36; officer, U.S. Army 1941-46 (Bronze Star); President, Grossman Clothing Company, manufacturer of fine men's suits; with his beloved late wife Sylvia, he was active in Roslyn community affairs: founder of two synagogues and second president of Temple Beth Sholom; original member, Shelter Rock Tennis Club and avid tennis player until age 92. Survived by sons Edward (Rochelle Stanfield, Bethesda, MD) and Richard, grandson David (Washington, DC), niece Laurie Gioia (Robert), nephews John (Mollie) and Robert (Kathy) and their families; predeceased by eldest son, Bill. Funeral 11am, Monday, March 5, at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights. Shiva: 7:30pm, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at the family home in Roslyn Estates. Memorials to Temple Beth Sholom.

MATHERS--Myra Martin, 90, passed away on February 29, 2012 in Wallingford, CT. Myra was an avid gardener, passionate sailor and loving mother. Over the years, Myra was actively involved with numerous clubs, including the Cosmopolitan Club, the Garden Club of America, and the Horticultural Society of New York. Myra was predeceased by her husband of 68 years, William Mathers, and leaves behind six children, six grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. Beecher & Bennett, 2300 Whitney Ave, Hamden, in care of private services. Donations may be sent to the Arc of Steuben, One Arc Way, Bath, NY 14810. To send a condolence to Myra's family, please see obituary at www.beecherandbennett.com.

Unlike Aunt Jemima or Uncle Ben, Colonel Sanders was a real person, although never a real colonel. It was some honorary title bestowed on notable Kentuckians by the governor. Yet Sanders introduced himself to his associates by it. It's one of many entertaining affectations - including bleaching his beard - that Josh Ozersky uncovers in ''Colonel Sanders and the American Dream'' (University of Texas Press, $20). Geoff Dyer is at his discursive best in ''Zona'' (Pantheon, $24), a book that's nominally about the Andrei Tarkovsky film ''Stalker.'' If he hadn't seen it in his early 20s, Dyer says, ''my responsiveness to the world would have been radically diminished.'' Even dance naifs can appreciate the work of the polymorphically gifted choreographer Merce Cunningham in ''A Pictures Book for John Cage Xmas 1984'' (The John Cage Trust, $45), a spiral-bound facsimile of one of his exquisite sketchbooks. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

''RENDEZ-VOUS WITH FRENCH CINEMA,'' the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual glimpse into the state of that art, this year grows richer with the addition of ''Rendez-Vous +'' (through Thursday), a sidebar showcasing documentaries, older movies and at least one certifiable classic: Jean Grémillon's ''LUMIÈRE D'ÉTÉ,'' presented in a newly restored version by the Cinémathèque Française. Made in 1943 during the Nazi occupation, Grémillon's film of interlocking, thwarted romances has a dreamy, corrosive atmosphere all its own. Though Germans and the war are never mentioned, the film's villain -- an aristocrat with a penchant for taking target practice in a crowd -- easily stands in for unwanted overlords. (Vichy, unsurprisingly, banned the film.) Explosions from a dam-building site rock the countryside and contribute to the sense of unease, as do all the trapped things: birds in cages, an indentured artist, women who've come to this lonely corner of France only to suffer disappointment. At the Guardian Angel hotel, guests eat and pass the time in a glassed-in porch, a kind of sun-filled specimen jar that Grémillon contrasts with the dam site: a place of clanging technology that sometimes soars skyward but more often, with its darkness and steam, seems a punishing inferno for the film's heroes, ordinary working men. 1:15 p.m. Thursday, Film Society of Lincoln Center, Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center; filmlinc.com; $10.

Erwin Frankel, a radio host and concert promoter who broadened the American cultural palette by introducing audiences to Andean pan flute music, the whirling dervishes of Turkey, and the notion of belly dancing as an art form fit for Carnegie Hall, died on Feb. 18 in New York City. He was 76. The cause was complications of a series of strokes, his son Gideon said.

The Strategies column on Feb. 19, about the initial public offering of the Boston Beer Company, misstated part of the educational background of its founder, Jim Koch. He completed a joint Harvard business-law graduate program after taking some time off from it; he did not drop out.

The Austin Motel (1220 South Congress;512-441-1157; austinmotel.com) keeps the hip hotel scene on South Congress Avenue real, with rates starting at $85. Its kitschy rooms and friendly service are a throwback to its 1950s roots, as are its buildings and pool. But its prime location is hard to beat. For the grande dame of Austin hotels, stay downtown at the Driskill (604 Brazos Street; 512-474-5911; driskillhotel.com). It offers free shoeshines and Town Car service, when available, and bike rentals are available (512-391-7013). Rooms with two queen beds from $209.

LAST March, bowing to his health problems, James Levine resigned as music director of the BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. (In December he withdrew from the Metropolitan Opera's schedule through its 2012-13 season.) Forging on, the Boston orchestra has altered lineups and recruited guest conductors. It has three programs this week at Carnegie Hall. On Tuesday, John Oliver, who is replacing Kurt Masur, who is ill, will stick to Mr. Levine's plans and conduct Beethoven's late ''Missa Solemnis'' with the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and four impressive soloists: the soprano Christine Brewer, the mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung, the tenor Simon O'Neill and the bass-baritone Eric Owens. The other programs have been changed significantly. Christoph Eschenbach takes the podium on Wednesday for Berlioz's Overture to ''Benvenuto Cellini''; Ravel's Piano Concerto in G, with the French pianist Cédric Tiberghien; and Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique,'' which Mr. Levine had planned to perform. On Friday Stéphane Denève conducts Ravel's ''Mother Goose'' Suite, Stravinsky's exhilarating Concerto for Piano and Winds (with Peter Serkin), and Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony. 8 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday and 7:30 p.m. Friday, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $24 to $148.

In the 1960s and '70s, Rod Gilbert played wing on the Rangers' Goal-a-Game, or GAG, line, with Jean Ratelle and Vic Hadfield, compiling 406 goals and 1,021 points over 16 seasons, with 34 playoff goals. Gilbert, who wore No. 7 and was the first Ranger to have his number retired, was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1982. Now 70, he is the Rangers' director of special projects and devotes much of his time to charitable causes. Gilbert is on an advisory board for Ed Randall's Fans for the Cure, which is dedicated to prostate cancer awareness and education. He also developed the Power Arm, a training device for wrists and forearms designed for players of all ages in hockey and other sports.

Every day, beautiful young people from all over the world descend on London in the hope of becoming fashion models. But what inspired the photographer Gareth McConnell to document this phenomenon was not the promise of glamour but the daily life of working immigrants. He sought to depict the models away from the fashion shoots and the catwalks; all were photographed without stylists or makeup artists and using only available light. McConnell set up the shots where they lived, which tended to be in London's poorer neighborhoods: Brixton, Hackney or Peckham rather than Chelsea or Notting Hill. McConnell considers the model the ''foot soldier of the fashion industry,'' although he allows that there are perks to the job. ''At least if you are a model,'' he says, ''you might get to go to a few parties, drink a few free cocktails and sleep with a pop star.'' Jennifer O'Mahony

Bruce Surtees, an Oscar-nominated cinematographer known as the Prince of Darkness for his skill at summoning sharply etched figures from the inky depths of prisons, nightclubs and other inhospitably lighted places, died on Thursday in Carmel, Calif. He was 74. The cause was complications of diabetes, his wife, Carol, said.

THERE was more than fashion on display in Paris this past week. The photographer Raymond Cauchetier worked behind the scenes of the Nouvelle Vague. He snapped the iconic image, above, of Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg strolling down the Champs-Élysées on the set of ''Breathless'' (''À Bout de Souffle''). He was also a wartime photojournalist in Cambodia, and those photos are as haunting as his cinematic photos are insouciant. His show at Polka Galerie, 12 rue St. Gilles, has closed, but might we see a Seberg moment next season? All signs say, ''Oui.'' SARAH MOROZ

WHEN the artist Dan Colen was working on ''Trash,'' a series of paintings made with and from New York City's finest, garbage just kept building up in his studio, as garbage tends to do. Mr. Colen assumed that the leftover paint-encrusted tires, rusted cans, busted shoes and dismembered bicycle parts would eventually be kicked back to the curb, whence they came. But after some time, they took on a life of their own, culminating in ''Blowin' in the Wind,'' a brief and aptly titled show at Gagosian Gallery on the Upper East Side. A selection of pieces, including the wonderfully irrepressible basketball above, are currently on display at Karma, the graphic designer Brendan Dugan's bookstore-cum-guerrilla gallery. Meanwhile, Mr. Colen continues to try to wrap his head around his found body of work. ''I was intimidated at first,'' he said of its inherent accidentalness. ''I think it might be some of my strongest work.'' 21 Downing Street (Bedford Street); karmakarma.org. ALIX BROWNE

AN uproar recently ignited on automotive blogs over a post about a Tesla Roadster whose battery needed replacement after its owner parked the car, low on charge and unplugged, for more than two months. The battery, which had fully discharged, could not be revived. While controversy has swirled around the incident -- with bloggers arguing about an owner's responsibility to keep the battery charged and the motivation in making the details public -- Tesla has confirmed basic facts about the situation.

KNIGHT--Townsend Jones Townsend Jones Knight, a retired Senior Partner with the New York law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, died peacefully on March 1, 2012 at the age of 83 in Long Island NY. Townsend was born in New York City on August 10, 1928 to Jesse Knight and Marguerite Jones Knight. He attended St. Bernard's School in New York City and St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H. He graduated from Harvard University and from Columbia University Law School before serving as a 1st Lieutenant in the Air Force from 1952-1953. From 1953 until 2010 Townsend worked at the New York law firm Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle where he was a partner from 1965 until his retirement. Townsend spent summers in Long Island where his family had strong ties and where he served on the Board of Directors at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory for 12 years. He was also an active board member of the Metropolitan College of New York, formerly the Audrey Cohen College, since 1966. Townie's happiest moments were those spent at the family home in Penobscot Bay with his friends and many generations of family where he was a deeply committed member of the Island community. He will be remembered for his friendly manner, positive outlook and his infectious smile. Townsend is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years Elise, his three daughters Margaret Dudley, Elise Wallace and Jessica Knight and his eight devoted grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. at 2 o'clock on Sunday March 4th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

MAKING an impression in the crowded cop-show field isn't easy, especially for a series on a cable network, but A&E has certainly given its drama ''BREAKOUT KINGS'' an attention-getting Season 2 premiere. The episode, at 10 p.m. Sunday, includes about as big a jolt as can be delivered by a show with an ensemble cast. No spoilers here, except to say that barring some corny it-was-only-a-dream twist the episode's outcome will mean that Season 2 will be noticeably different from Season 1. ''Breakout Kings'' is about a pair of United States marshals, Charlie (Laz Alonso) and Ray (Domenick Lombardozzi), who use three convicted criminals to help them track down prison escapees. In the second-season premiere the targets are two especially brutal serial killers who break out of separate jails in a coordinated escape.
GREENWICH VILLAGE ONE-BEDROOM $950,000

Let it be known that while he was defeating Nazis and chewing on cigars, Winston Churchill wore light pink underwear of the finest woven silk. (Such extravagant bloomers were necessary, he claimed, because of his very sensitive skin.) Dandyish details like these abound in Barry Singer's ''Churchill Style'' (Abrams Image, $25), certainly the first book dedicated to the wartime leader's fashion sense, among his other intriguing superficialities, like dictating a speech in the nude. Singer's book is part of a flurry of new titles connecting Churchill's historical substance to his idiosyncratic swagger. ''Winston Churchill: Portrait of a Unique Mind'' (Pen and Sword Books, $40), written by an M.D., Andrew Norman, examines Churchill's bouts of suffocating depression - his so-called Black Dog days - when he would contemplate suicide. He avoided bedrooms with balconies: ''I've no desire to quit the world, but thoughts, desperate thoughts come into the head.''

In this preview of our Spring Men's Fashion issue, on newsstands this Sunday, a photojournalist on assignment in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya finds the humanity behind the headlines. A girl on the subway lets her auburn locks tumble down her back. I'm startled, and my heart skips a beat. Then I remember it's O.K. I'm in New York, back in the unveiled world. The last subway I rode was in Cairo, rushing to photograph Tahrir Square. I stumbled into the ladies car, and a woman in hijab asked me to get off at the next stop.

A friend recently told me about a new app for the treatment of phobias. You stare at pictures of dental drills, snakes or airplane interiors, depending on your affliction, and these totems of menace -- interspersed with reassuring images of teddy bears -- gradually cease to provoke you. Does it work? We can't know. My friend has a phobia of stuffed animals. It's something, he says, about the soulless glass eyes. We were talking on the phone, but I could picture him shuddering.

KERMAN--Garret, artist, former ice skater with Holiday on Ice, and teacher of fine art, photography and printmaking at the High School of Music and Art died on February 13 at the age of 86. He LOVED New York and all it had to offer. He is survived by his brother Joseph and sisters Beatrice and Bunny, and 22 nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his parents, Louis and Sussie Kerman, brothers Oscar, George and Max Kerman, sisters Eva Welte and Sarah Lehrman, nephew Bruce Kerman, and his longtime partner, William Muchmore. Memorial contributions may be made to SAGE, 305 7th Ave., 12th Fl., New York, NY 10001.
An entry on the children's picture book best-seller list last Sunday for ''Blackout,'' by John Rocco, misidentified the publishing imprint. It is Disney-/Hyperion, not Hyperion.

IN the new ''Dior Joaillerie'' by Michèle Heuzé (Rizzoli, $75), the magnificent work of Victoire de Castellane, Dior's director of fine jewelry, is chronicled in sparkling detail. Organized in chapters devoted to each of her wildly imaginative collections -- Excentriques, Belladone Island and Harem, to name a few -- the book combines Christian Dior lore with Ms. Castellane's exquisite gem-heavy interpretations of it. ''I didn't set out to shock,'' she writes in the preface, though her diamond-riddled roses and spellbinding blooms-as-brooches (odes to Monsieur Dior's love for gardening) have a peculiar, jaw-dropping effect on people. Here, the Ancolia ring (from the Milly Carnivora collection) is a colorful, cartoonlike rendering of a flower made from yellow gold, diamonds, yellow tourmalines, rubellite and lacquer. ''My rings are so voluminous,'' writes Ms. Castellane, ''that the first thought that pops into your head is, They're incredible!'' EDWARD BARSAMIAN

Readers commented on ''Streetscapes: A Beauty? Or a Menace With a Fiendish Grasp'' (Feb. 26), about a debate over artificial ivy in Greenwich Village. Following are edited excerpts from nytimes.com: My remedy for nearly all the lousy opera and ballet sets I see? Ivy-covered walls. It never disappoints me, on the stage or on buildings. ajsnyc, Levittown, Pa.

The Senate can't agree to cross the street. Iran has done more to bring us together than anything in the world. SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM,Republican of South Carolina, on momentum for tougher action against Iran. [4]

HOFFMANN--Myrna, 93, passed away peacefully on February 25, 2012. Devoted wife of the late Armin; beloved mother of Judith, Claudia, Kendall, Dyanne and Andrew; loving grandmother of David (Beth), Andrew (Lotta), Macoe (Marc) and Allison (Phil); and proud great-grandmother of Aaron, Micah, Emma and Sarah. She will be missed terribly. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.

MORGEN--Howard. Beloved husband of Estelle, father to Donna and Gary (Susan), grandfather to Adam, Mathew, Jacqueline, Jessica, and Daniel, and teacher to thousands. Revered innovator, performer, clinician and educator of Fingerstyle Jazz Guitar. Author of popular instructional books, videos, and online learning tools. A wonderful friend. Succumbed to a five year battle with Leukemia. A memorial service will be held at The New School, Sunday March 4th at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to: UNC-Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, PO Box 7295, Chapel Hill NC 27599-7295. He will be greatly missed.

SULICK--George T.,Sr., 89, Fairfield, CT, died at home on March 2, 2012. He was a veteran and POW of WWII. Survivors are his wife, Emma Sulick; children, George T. Sulick, Jr., Patricia Mazella, Michael Sulick, Sr. and Mary Sullivan. To view the full obituary, memorial donations and to send an online condolence, visit: www.shaughnesseybanks.com

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Julie Bosman with notes from the field, and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Children's Books Weekly online-only reviews of picture books.

Eddie Stern is spoken of with reverence and a certain amount of mystique - the downtown New York guru for serious yoga students, among them some boldfaced names. Stern's school, Ashtanga Yoga New York, opened in 1995 with no advertising or fanfare. ''My teacher told me not to advertise,'' he remembers. ''He said, 'If you are any good, people will come. Don't advertise. The empty pots make the loudest noise.''' That teacher was Patthabi Jois, affectionately referred to as ''Guruji,'' whom Stern met in Mysore, India, in 1990. When a local bookseller told him there was a great yoga master living in town, Stern took down his address and just showed up one morning, greeted by a big man wearing what looked like a dish towel wrapped around his waist. ''He was not at all what I expected,'' Stern says. Nevertheless, he stayed to chat with Jois and returned the following year to study with him.

An article last Sunday about the economic concept of moral hazard misstated a statistic cited by Shaun Donovan, the secretary of housing and urban development. He said that the best evidence indicated that only about 10 or 15 percent of mortgage defaults were by homeowners still financially capable of paying their mortgages, not that 10 or 15 percent of Americans who can pay try to walk away from their debt.

As comfortable wearing vintage YSL at a fashion show as he is tending his tomato plants in Bugatti-blue French work clothes, this pedigreed private chef (he catered Kate Moss's wedding dinner!) is passionate about produce. ''I was brought up on a farm with a wonderful vegetable garden and was lucky enough to taste things at the very top of their game -- a carrot pulled from the ground and eaten with a sprig of tarragon, a newly dug beet bathed in horseradish vinaigrette,'' he says. ''For me, food is about simplicity and vitality, and the finest, freshest ingredients you can find.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE
