A news analysis article last Sunday about the role of ultrasound in abortion debates misspelled, at one point, the surname of a medical sociologist at the University of California, San Francisco, who studies abortion care. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, she is Tracy Weitz, not Dietz.

A pair of serious running shoes first entered my wardrobe last January, by accident. I'd left my gym bag at home and couldn't be bothered to retrieve it preworkout. So midafternoon I found myself leaving a Champs Sports store in Times Square, wearing a new pair of Nike Free Run+ sneakers in black, with a red Swoosh and a white tread. The svelte silhouette had caught my eye. Light and easy to pack, the Frees got shoved in my suitcase a few weeks later when I headed to Europe for the men's fashion shows. During an outfit panic in Milan, I made a gamble, pairing the shoes with a spring 2010 Prada suit; they looked good outside the gym. Soon I bought a pair of the updated Nike Free Run+ 2 and Lunar Glides (both in all black with a white tread). More recently I added Lunar Glides+ 3 (yellow tread with black upper, touch of aqua) and replaced my worn-out Frees. And my running followed, going from the treadmill to the road, from 3 miles to 10. I'm not special: running and running shoes are cool right now. But a random fashion trend this is not. These latest shoes are a result of 40 years of sneaker culture, an eon of human evolution and the eureka moment of a track-and-field star turned Nike designer named Tobie Hatfield.

''The London Olympic Stadium is the lightest stadium for the Olympics ever built and used minimal materials. It's a delicate building, all unnecessary functions are stripped out of it. ''You need a confident city to do a building like that. The more traditional approach is the Beijing approach, which is a big, bold statement. London didn't want to compete on that basis. ''The way we designed it is the way you put a plastic kit together for an airplane. Every little part comes as a design element itself. The roof, and the diagonal legs that hold the roof up, are a completely separate system from the seating tiers. It's like a kit of parts, capable of being transfigured and put back together in different ways -- whether it's for a football team or as a summer amphitheater.''

EASTON--Joan. The Helicon Foundation deeply mourns the death of friend, board member, and benefactor Joan K. Easton. A Director since 1994, Joan's love of chamber music and her enthusiasm for life's joys were cherished by Helicon's members and musicians. She will be profoundly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. James Roe, Artistic Director Lisa Welch, President

de MARGITAY--Gedeon, died peacefully at home on February 28 at age 87. Born in Budapest, Hungary, son of Jozsef and Anna (nee de Bessenyei) de Margitay. He was educated at the University of Budapest Graduate School of Economics and Ecole Sciences Politiques in Paris, where he later worked for the New York Times and the European Information Division of the Mutual Security Agency. Immigrating to the US, he served as Chief Executive of Magnum Photos, Inc., then as Director, Time Life Editorial Services, and Director, Broadcast and Corporate Planning at NBC, where he co-authored "Broadcasting, the Next Ten Years, 1977". A gentleman and a scholar, he will be remembered for his courtly manners and his keen sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at the First Hungarian Reformed Church, 344 East 69th Street, New York City on Saturday, March 10 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the Hungarian Church, or the Hungarian Johanniter ("Johanniter Account", c/o Rev. Gabor de Nitsch, 30 Saxman Drive, Latrobe, PA 15650).

LOWENHEIM--Cynthia Abowitz, passed away peacefully on February 24. Cherished wife of Jerry for 61 yrs; beloved mother of Carla and Sharon; devoted sister to Jocey and the late Janice; doting grandmom to Russell, Joanna, Emily, and great-grandmom to Abbey. Donations can be made to the Queens Library Foundation.

It's unclear whether any rats were actually spotted that night, but the abandoned meatpacking plant where Siki Im, a German-born designer of Korean descent, presented his first men's collection back in September of 2009 must have played host to a varmint or two. As editors arrived, a noisy band set up in the middle of the damp concrete floor. As the band drummed, the models - clad like castaways in bits and pieces of fine tailoring - encircled the band and audience. There was no fire pit in the middle, but there could have been. Conjuring the spirit of William Golding's ''Lord of the Flies'' in order to introduce a line of exquisitely constructed men's suits seemed odd at the time, but odd in a good way, the perfect antidote to an overly commercial moment. It also felt brave: as New York continued to descend into the financial crisis, here was an upstart showing well-made suits with skirts, sleeveless suits and shorts/slacks with straps and bandages.

SINGER--Miriam (nee Brown) of Manhattan. Beloved wife of Jacob for 46 years. Adored mother of Karin and Rose. Spirited and independent, she was an accomplished pianist, who took up painting in later years. Compassionate, devoted to her family, affiliated with charitable groups, she led an exemplary life. With her charm and luminous smile, she will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched.

MY mother always said I must be part Mongolian, because of my lotus-pale complexion and squid-ink black hair. ''Something you're not telling me?'' I was tempted to ask. But I knew she'd visited Mongolia with my father long after I was born. What I didn't know is that one out of every 200 males on earth is related to Genghis Khan. An international team of geneticists conducting a 10-year study of men living in what once was the Mongolian empire has discovered that a surprisingly large number share the identical Y chromosome, which is passed down only from father to son. One individual's Y chromosome can be found in 16 million men in Asia, from Manchuria, near the Sea of Japan, to Uzbekistan and Afghanistan in Central Asia.
Over abundance.

An article on Feb. 19 about the photographer Cindy Sherman, who has a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, misidentified the college where she was an undergraduate. It is Buffalo State College, not State University of Buffalo (which is now known as the University at Buffalo).

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- It's much too early in the season for the Mets to be taking any chances with injuries. Manager Terry Collins held David Wright out of the team's intrasquad scrimmage Saturday afternoon because he has felt stiffness in his rib cage since earlier this week.

WHEN Diane Von Furstenberg first introduced her wrap dress in the 1970s, the jersey shift with its sexy, kimonolike simplicity spoke to a generation of women just starting to reap the benefits of women's lib. Now, with her collections for Gap Kids and Baby Gap, Ms. Von Furstenberg addresses the 14-and-under set with equal exuberance. The collections, which will be available on March 15, reprise vintage prints from the DVF archives and translate them into the kinds of easy pieces that kids -- and the moms who dress them and do their laundry -- love. There is even a version of the wrap dress, modified to fit the pint-sized. ''It is never too early to start empowering young girls to become the women they want to be,'' Ms. Von Furstenberg insists. ''The biggest joy was seeing all of the beautiful little ones in the clothes on the day of the shoot. They were so full of energy and confidence.'' ALIX BROWNE

SOLIS-COHEN--Virginia "Ginny". Born Virginia Rosalie Kaufman to Alice and Otto Kaufman in New York City on January 31, 1922, passed away peacefully at the age of 90 on March 2, 2012 at her home in Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. A resident of Rydal, PA for over 50 years, she was married to her remarkably sweet husband, Hays, for close to 50 years before he died in 1991. Ginny took immense pleasure in being a mother (and mother-in-law) to Betsy (Peter), David (Carole) and Kate (before she died in 1973); a grandmother to Emily, Sarah, Daniel, Flavia, Hannah, Emma and Ben; a great-grandmother to Paul, Oliver, and Mateo and loving aunt to Frank, Robert and Jim. She graduated from Birch Wathen School in New York City and Tyler Art School in Philadelphia, and was a talented artist and sculptor. Her lively character and spirit will be missed by family and friends, but her positive outlook on life and her art will remain a part of us forever. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Abington Art Center, Jenkintown Library, PBS or other charity of one's choice.

FISHER--Muriel Streit Gross, at the glorious age of 87, died peacefully the morning of March 1. Beloved mother of Annie and the late Mel Gross. Adored grandmother of Bari, Matthew, Aaron, Tiffani and Samantha. Cherished sister of Renee Adler Kaplan. Loving wife of the late Aaron Gross and the late Sam Fisher. Devoted daughter of the late Mary and Irving Streit. Her great-grandchildren, Maya, Josh, Eva and Mason, were the delights of her last years. She was a special gift to us all and will live in our hearts forever. Service Sunday, March 4, 11am at "The Riverside", 76th and Amsterdam. Donations may be made to MJHS Hospice & Palliative Care.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Damned Yankees,'' Feb. 26: I have spent countless hours explaining the many mediocre and outright bad seasons I suffered through as a Yankees fan. I still feel that those lost years outweigh the more recent championship years -- and I wouldn't trade a single memory.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Not Too Young to Fight,'' Feb. 29: I played hockey in Saskatchewan, including a year (1951-52) in the Carrot River Valley League. Fighting was no part of the game except as a spontaneous flare-up quickly doused. Things changed when the six-team N.H.L. expanded south into potential fan bases that, unfamiliar with hockey's fine points, presumably needed to be enticed by ''red meat.''

An article on Page 34 this weekend about London and Londoners misspells the surname of a member of the royal family at one point. As the article correctly notes elsewhere, she is Kate Middleton, not Middleteon.

Hockey is joining the drive to end homophobia in sports with a public-service message featuring eight N.H.L. players, including Henrik Lundqvist of the Rangers, Corey Perry of the Anaheim Ducks and Daniel Alfredsson of the Ottawa Senators. You Can Play, the campaign the players will introduce, is another in a series of efforts by hockey's Burke family to open doors for gay athletes to participate in sports. It is intended to ''make locker rooms safe for all athletes, rather than places of fear, slurs and bullying,'' said Patrick Burke, a scout with the Philadelphia Flyers and a founder of the project.

LOMBINO--Robert J. Peacefully on March 2 at age 75. Beloved husband to Linda; father to Kathi, Tracey, Scott, Sherry, Mary-Kay and David; brother to three; grandpa to 14. Passionate, intelligent and a lover of life; we've lost someone great. Memorial March 5 from 5-8pm at Green Funeral Home, Danbury, CT.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports for Feb. 24 to March 1. 1. TIGHT-KNIT FAMILY SHARES LIN'S ACHIEVEMENT Jeremy Lin's parents, Gie-Ming and Shirley, encouraged him to play basketball, helping to build an elite youth program. (Published Feb. 25)
MATHERS--Myra Martin. I mourn the loss of my dear friend. A great lady whose kindness, humor and intelligence brought joy to those privileged to know her. Anne Higgins Petz.

The art collective Still House occupies the fourth floor of a 19th-century warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn, across from Fairway, where the road ends and the water begins. The 7,000-square-foot space houses the studios of eight young artists, a gallery and a residency program. ''We're a bit bootleg and off the beaten path,'' says Isaac Brest, 24, one of the founders. The name was inspired by a tattoo on the arm of Alex Perweiler, 25, a photographer and Still House Group co-founder. But as luck would have it, a ''still house'' is a term for a distillery, and the group is more than happy to riff on the idea of swaggering moonshiners. ''Our product is homemade and home brewed, good but definitely not what you are used to tasting,'' Brest says. ''It's not that brand-name stuff. It's a little strong; it's a little nasty.'' As he speaks, an artist carries in metal salvaged from the Dumpster, while others smoke and discuss three moody oil paintings hanging on a white wall. Another sits on the floor and situates crushed beer cans covered in concrete.

WEYL--Janice Manley. Author and cousin of Adolph Ochs. Janice Manley Weyl, nee Louise Janice Mandelberg, died, peacefully in her sleep, on February 9, 2012 Mrs. Weyl, known as "Sister", was the youngest daughter of Sidney and Evelyn (Franck) Manley of Manhattan. She was the granddaughter of Ben C. Franck, for many years, secretary of The New York Times Company, and a second cousin to Adolph Ochs, the paper's owner and publisher. Born in Chicago on July 30, 1916, Mrs. Weyl grew up in St. Louis, Omaha and then New York City. Janice married Max Weyl, son of Adolph and Pearl (Fischel) Weyl of, Washington, D.C., on May 28, 1936. The couple lived in Manhattan, Woodmere and, finally, Madison, Connecticut. She was a graduate of Alquin Preparatory and Julia Richmond High School. She studied at Le Sorbonne in Paris and held a Masters degree (Magna Cum Laude) in English from Southern Connecticut State University. She attended Trinity College in Dublin, Ireland, where she studied, and wrote exclusively about, Ulysses by James Joyce. Mrs. Weyl was an accomplished author with her prose and poetry published in the Belletrist Review among other journals. Her wonderful sense of humor and avant-garde philosophy were hallmarks of her writings taking inspiration from Twain, Proust, Mary Baker Eddy and Elisabeth Kubler-Ross. Janice was also a devoted philanthropist, donating to the many organizations that support animal welfare. One such effort was a helicopter trip, in her eighties, to an ice floe in the North Atlantic to witness the birth of baby seals and to aid in the effort to protect them. Janice is pre-deceased by her husband, Max Weyl, her daughter, Karen Weyl, her older sister, Jean Manley Joseph, her nephew Billy Joseph and her beloved nanny, Mary Miller. She is survived by her son Kevin Weyl, her step-daughter Nancy Seamon, her daughter-in-law Mia Wood, her granddaughter Maraina Weyl, her step-grandchildren, Brian and Melissa Dimetres and her nieces, Laurie Joseph and Margie McCabe. Mrs. Weyl wanted no formal tributes at her passing but she would have greatly appreciated any remembrances taking the form of contributions to the cause of animal protection around the world.

Having walked for Dior Homme, Dries Van Noten, Calvin Klein and J. Crew, the model Armando Cabral is no stranger to designer shoes. So it was not a stretch that the 30-year-old Portuguese native who earned a business degree in London would start his own line of men's footwear. ''As a model traveling a lot, I was looking for versatile shoes that I could wear all the time and for any occasion,'' says Cabral, who introduced the collection two years ago and now sells it in stores like Odin and Steven Alan in New York. In the spirit of adaptability, Cabral's spring shoes include leather-and-denim oxfords, suede brogue-inspired sneakers and espadrilles with rubber soles. ''The idea is to combine the sensibility of classic design with casual wear,'' he says. ''Easy dressing for men.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
The Trend Checks, mate! Bold geometry gives a graphic punch to a usually more sedate look.

PERLBERG--Toni Aronsohn, died peacefully on February 3, 2012 at the age of 82, after suffering a stroke on Christmas Eve, 2011. Toni was born in New York City to the late Micky Babin Aronsohn and the late Cornelius K. Aronsohn. She attended Goucher College prior to getting married. After raising her family in Rye, NY, she returned to Manhattan where she worked for many years at The Business Council to the United Nations (formerly U.N. We Believe.) While at BCUN, Toni returned to college at the age of 44, received a BA in Business, after which she worked for Phillip Morris USA., and then the Lupus Foundation. In her retirement, she was able to turn her sharp eye for all grammatical infractions into a position as a professional proofreader and copy editor for Hyperion/Miramax Books. We have lost a dear relative and friend who will be remembered for her elegant style, lack of pretense, unrelenting positive disposition, sharp wit, and passion for her family. She was the loving sister of the late Alan JB Aronsohn of New York and mother to H. James "Jim" Perlberg III, Nancy Segal, and Janet Pierson. She will be missed by their spouses, Marilyn, Beau and John; her six grandchildren, Jason, Kate, Barrie, Milo, Georgia and Wyatt; her nephew Lee and nieces Judie and Abby, and beloved friend and sister-in-law Bette Aronsohn. There are a great many other relatives and friends who will miss her .. all of whom she adored .. as they did her. A Memorial will be held in the future. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation to the charity of your choice in her name. She was particularly fond of the arts.

10 P.M. (ABC) GCB It's payback time in this new prime-time soap opera, based on the novel ''Good Christian Bitches'' by Kim Gatlin and counting Robert Harling (''Steel Magnolias'') and Darren Star (''Sex and the City'') among its executive producers. Leslie Bibb stars as Amanda Vaughn, a onetime high school mean girl who is forced to return to Dallas in disgrace after her marriage ends in scandal. Annie Potts plays Gigi, her socialite mother who wants nothing more than to have her daughter back in the fold, the better to give her teenage grandchildren a proper Southern upbringing. Kristin Chenoweth, above, is Carlene Cockburn, a former ugly duckling who was tortured by Amanda as a girl but has made an ''assisted transformation'' into a picture-perfect life of luxury with a gorgeous husband -- if only she could let go of old grudges. Miriam Shor is Cricket Caruth-Reilly, whose boyfriend Amanda stole and later married. Jennifer Aspen is Sharon Peacham, whose chance at the Miss Teen Dallas crown was snatched away when Amanda started a malicious rumor. And Marisol Nichols is Heather Cruz, an outsider turned member of this clique of God-fearing women capable of instilling terror. ''The result is a network comedy that sends up sex, sin and Southern Baptists, or at least the pious parvenus of Dallas,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Newt Gingrich discusses whether he can again become a contender for the nomination as Super Tuesday approaches. He also appears on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

Who knew the polo shirt - that yuppie staple - could be so versatile? The model and actor Michael Borne auditions three new variations. Catch Mr. Borne in the play ''Look for the Woman'' opening on March 5 at Richmond Shepard Theater, 309 E. 26th Street.

MATT CHARMAN, a British writer in his early 30s, has had the kind of meteoric rise that usually happens only in the movies. Eight years ago he was working on a theater Web site when he got his big break, winning an award for his debut play, ''A Night at the Dogs.'' His second and third plays had their premieres at the Royal National Theater, where he is a writer in residence, and he already has a pile of glowing reviews and calls from Hollywood. Now he is making his New York debut at the Manhattan Theater Club with ''REGRETS,'' about a man who flees Hollywood in the 1950s to get a divorce in Nevada. This plot brings to mind the second act of Clare Boothe Luce's play ''The Women,'' set in Reno, Nev., in the 1930s. It sounds as if this play has a darker edge, promising more secrets revealed than acid-tongued zingers. The Tony winner Adriane Lenox (''Doubt'') stars along with Richard Topol (''The Normal Heart'') and Alexis Bledel (''Gilmore Girls''). Carolyn Cantor directs. Previews start Thursday, City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan; (212) 581-1212, mtc-nyc.org.

The Big Deal column last Sunday, about brokers' teaming up with sellers of high-end merchandise to attract wealthy buyers, described incorrectly the financial structure of Azure, a residential building on the Upper East Side. It is a condop, not a condo. The article also misidentified the club that was invited to show several classic cars at the inauguration of the Carriage House last June. It was the Classic Car Club of Manhattan, not Cooper Classic Cars.

The Modern Love column last Sunday, about an American woman who became pregnant while she and her husband were living in Djibouti, described that country's maternal mortality rate incorrectly. It is lower than the infant mortality rate, not higher.

Update, March 7, 4:30 p.m. | The polls are now closed. You may continue to recommend your favorite story-ettes, but the voting is now done. We have our winner. Details soon. Update, March 5 | Click to read the actual opening of ''Atlantic Avenue'' and a profile of its author. Her name was Maggie. It was Eleanor. It was Velma: a night-time name for a night-time broad. She clicked down the subway stairs in stilettos, saddle shoes, red pumps with one heel worn down to the nail. In her purse was her granddaddy's revolver. A snub-nose .38. A knife, coated in crimson.

GREENE--Jean L.,95, of West Orange, NJ, formerly of South Orange, died February 26 at home. Born in New York City on June 2, 1916, she was a graduate of Fieldston School, Ethical Normal School, and Columbia University and taught at Ethical Culture and Bright Side. A founder and president of Essex County Garden Club, honored as life member in Garden Club of New Jersey. In 1968 she completed the AOPA Air Safety Pinchhitter course to land a twin engine plane to ensure safety when flying with her husband. Jean loved and was loved by all, especially her children Andrew and Ellen (Philip Drill), grandchildren Douglas (Lori), Kenneth (Jun), Kristina (Markus), William (Cara), great-grandchildren Jessica, Lara, Johanna, Gabriel, Cameron; and her husband of 66 years, Elliot, who predeceased her. A memorial service will be private. For those wishing to make a donation, please consider Barnabas Health Hospice and Palliative Care, 95 Old Short Hills Rd, West Orange, NJ 07052.

BARDAVID--Charlotte. January 18, 1925 - February 25, 2012. Devoted wife of the late Isaac, loving mother of Herb and Jane Bardavid, Elliot and Debra Bardavid, Lynda and Jack Kauffman. Adoring grandmother of Jessica and Steve Graff, Joshua Bardavid and Jennifer Pan, Jonathan and Jennifer Bardavid, Jennifer and Robert Franck, Karen Bardavid. Beloved great-grandmother of Samantha and Carter Graff, Gabrielle and Harrison Bardavid, and Charlotte Franck. She was dearly loved and will be missed.

''You get ugly when you get old,'' Martin Amis said at the 2011 Hay literary festival in Mexico. ''It's all perfectly simple. Everything seems fine until you're about 40. You look in the mirror with your old habit of thinking, 'While I accept that everyone grows old and dies, it's a funny thing, but I'm an exception to that rule.' Then it becomes a full-time job trying to convince yourself that it's true.'' Amis, whose new novel, ''Lionel Asbo: The State of England,'' is due in August, has made a career as a chronicler of the male gaze - gazing, that is, at itself. Over decades, he has impeccably rendered the effects of aging on the half of the population for whom aging is supposed not to matter.
KUTNER--Elliott. A fond farewell to my life-long friend since the age of six. I will miss our Friday chats and you will remain in my memory forever. Sandy Batkin

RIDLESS--Adele Phyllis (Strassberg), 69, of Boca Raton, Florida and East Hampton, New York passed away suddenly on March 1. Devoted wife to her late husband Monroe Ridless and loving companion to Morton Victor. Cherished mother of Joshua (Adam), Hank (Brian), Glenn (David) and Jennifer (Suzanne), loving sister to Mark (Howard) and Gail (Ellen). Beloved aunt. A designer in the garment industry, Adele led a creative life, filled with energy. She was a compassionate, entertaining, and generous woman, whose love of life was sunshine to many. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 4, 3pm at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton.

To get to Rochelle Canteen, you must ring a buzzer at the boys' entrance of the Rochelle School, a Victorian-era building that now houses artists' studios. A path leads through a grassy courtyard -- once the school's playground -- to a converted bike shed, where, on weekdays, Margot Henderson and her partner, Melanie Arnold, serve up a hearty English lunch. The menu leans toward whole-hog fare -- wild-boar stew, rabbit rillette -- and makes good use of a recipe concocted by her husband, Fergus Henderson, for ''trotter gear,'' or heavy stock made from pigs' feet. ''Serious good lunch,'' Margot says. ''That's the idea.'' ABBY AGUIRRE

MARCUS--Jack, passed away on February 17, 2012 at the age of 101, at Kittay House, Bronx, NY. He earned a BA degree at CCNY in 1935. He served in the US Army from 1942-1946 as a medical and surgical technician for Tank battallions in the United States. He married Ruth (nee Zimmerman) in 1946. The marriage, characterized by mutual devotion, closeness and being best friends, was to last 60 years. He worked for the New York State Insurance Fund for 34 years as a hearing referee. After retirement, he volunteered with the Better Business Bureau and teaching English as a second language. Beloved brother to the late Blanche Siegel, the late Ethel Newman, and the late Frank Marcus. Devoted uncle to Joan Azarva and her family. Devoted uncle to Robert Newman, David Marcus, Shielah Friedman and their families. Devoted cousin to Charles Sternberg.

The Riff column on Feb. 19, about the TV program ''Downton Abbey,'' misspelled one film title and omitted the first word of another while comparing the program to each of them. They are ''Howards End,'' not Howard's, and ''The Remains of the Day.''

RUBIN--Sam, of Woodmere, NY, died January 25, 2012 at 101 years old. He was the husband of his beloved wife Jesse who died in 2007. His daughter Linda died in 2010. He is survived by Sarri Gilman of Langley, WA, Adam Gilman of Austin, TX, Ben Cass of San Francisco, Alice Rubin Singer of Brooklyn, NY, and her children Mike, Carol, Ronnie and Lisa.
WERTENTHEIL--Dr. Alvin of Englewood, NJ, passed away on March 2, 2012. He was "the greatest" and "the best" husband, father, grandfather, son, brother, doctor, uncle and friend.

FISHER--Muriel Streit Gross. The employees of the Streit's Matzo Company wish to express their deepest sympathy to the family of Mrs. Fisher. She has touched the lives of so many and will be missed by all.
von FLUEGGE--Hans H.,retired Vice President, Citibank N.A., New York, NY. Born in Gross Helle, Germany, December 20, 1927. Deceased in South Kingstown, RI, on February 24, 2012.

JULIA HOLTER, a singer and composer from Los Angeles, is ascending fast. Looked at coldly, it could be because she fills so many slots. She's a songwriter who works with electronics and multitracked voices. She uses beats, or doesn't; her music is ambient, or not; it's contrapuntal and quite complex. She studied composition with the excellent and underrecognized Michael Pisaro at Cal Arts, and singing -- open structured, floaty, droney -- with Pandit Pashupati Nath Mishra in Varanasi, India. She could be putting on sound installations at Experimental Intermedia, or more scuffed-up gigs at Glasslands and Death by Audio. She could be making records for the audiences who love the vanguard of female indie-pop singer-songwriters -- Tune-yards, Joanna Newsom, St. Vincent -- or for those discovering the old connections between New York minimalism and California folk-mysticism via Steve Reich and Terry Riley. Anyway, her new album, ''Ekstasis,'' to be released Thursday by the New York label RVNG Intl., is an artifact of the now. You'll want to have a feeling about it. She performs at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday at 8 p.m., on a double bill presented by Wordless Music, with Sarah Cahill, a Bay Area pianist-composer. lepoissonrouge.com; $12, or $15 at the door.

An opinion essay last Sunday about Napoleon's legacy misstated the location and timing of the Battle of Berezina. It took place in what is now Belarus in November 1812, not outside Moscow in the spring of that year.

The most innovative fashion statements made by guests at the recent New York fashion shows came not from women but from creative young men, like the many pictured at left. There are some who consider such clothes to be little more than costumes and the wearers to be intoxicated with alternative styles of dress. But I'm always reminded that creative people like these often become the fashion contributors and fixtures of the future. A designer who blends the inventive with the more traditional is Thom Browne (1., center), who released his rare talent and wildly imaginative fashion statements on clothes for both sexes, showing his women's collection in New York and men's in Paris

THOUGH pegged as the show everyone loves to hate, the Whitney Biennial delivers something everyone wants: a distinctive look. At least four of the 50 artists in the 76th version of the show, which runs through May 27, are offering works that are right up the street of the style-conscious. Take Nick Mauss, who has recreated an opulent purple velvet and gold entrance to an antechamber designed in 1939 by the fashion illustrator Christian Bérard for Guerlain in Paris. Or the postpunk choreographer Michael Clark, whose Modern Dance Club will make its debut with costumes by BodyMap's Stevie Stewart. And, on May 20, K8 Hardy (below, an example of her work) will present what the Biennial curators Elisabeth Sussman and Jay Sanders are calling ''a high-production fashion show.'' Expect an emphasis on social class that will twist accepted definitions of glamour, while polished models walk a thin line between parody and sincerity on a runway designed by the artist Oscar Tuazon. His steel or wood constructions, also in this year's lineup, are generally just this side of unstable. LINDA YABLONSKY

Olivier Theyskens For ''Over Abundance'' (Page 87), Olivier Theyskens, the Belgian designer who has breathed new life into Theory, spent days with his team glued to satellite maps, turning our trademark T into a reimagined Manhattan. That's a metaphor, he says, for ''how the magazine has the potential to shape our view of the city.'' Theyskens's piece started as a T-shaped lake in Central Park. But then he decided, ''No, it has to be the whole city, with the boats and the bridges, everything.''

''This is sort of a dream scenario from an automaker's perspective. ''Jesse Toprak, vice president for market intelligence at TrueCar.com, which tracks pricing and sales. Auto sales jumped 16 percent last month over the month before, with buyers adding more optional features even as they downsized to save money on gas. ''If the 1 percent isn't doing well, the city's not doing well. ''Nicole Gelinas, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute in New York. The total payout to security industry workers in New York is forecast to drop 14 percent during this bonus season, according to a report by the state comptroller, compared with 51 percent last year.

GREEN--Edward F.,died peacefully at his home on February 26, surrounded by his family. Son of the late Elizabeth and Samuel Green, former Sr. Vice President of the Brooklyn Union Gas Co. A native of Brooklyn, Edward was a graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and Cornell University, with a dual bachelors and masters degree in mechanical engineering. Served as a first Lieutenant in the US Air Force during the Korean War. Worked as a project engineer at Hazeltine Electronics, was manager of manufacturing at Otis Elevator's defense division and for the last 44 years worked in the finance industry, most recently as First Vice President at Morgan Stanley. evoted husband of forty-four years to wife Susan; loving father to Nancy and son-in-law Steve; Richard and daughter-in-law Smita; proud and doting grandfather to Sophie, Madeleine, Hannah, Lucy, Zubin and Zahra. Survived also by brother Robert and wife Marti. He was predeceased by Molly Malka, his black lab. He was a man of integrity, intelligence, loyalty, witty humor and kindness. Donations may be sent to the United States Memorial Holocaust Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, D.C. 20024 or Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Paramus, NJ, 07652.

Last summer while the Morning Benders toured Japan, Chris Chu, the indie pop band's boyish frontman, turned the trip into a heritage tour. Chu was born near Tokyo but raised in California. ''I'm soft-spoken and a little shy,'' he says. ''And I just felt immediately like I related to people there.'' SLURPEES The band binged on ramen, sampling something like 25 different noodle joints. Chu says that for classic tonkotsu, or pork-bone ramen, Nantsuttei in Tokyo (3-26-20 Takanawa, Minato-ku; 011-81-3-5791-1355) ''blew everything else out of the water.'' They also swooned for the summertime staple tsukemen, or dipping ramen, the best of which they found at Fu-Unji (2-14-3 Yoyogi, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo; 011-81-3-6413-8480).
An article last Sunday about Bear Grylls, the star of the television survivor show ''Man vs. Wild,'' misstated the first name of his wife. She is Shara Grylls, not Shana.

While the Eastman Kodak Company's early picture contests were national - and by the 1930s, international - there was no shortage of submissions from intrepid New York photographers. Werner Weile, who lived in Yonkers, N.Y., won $25 for his photo of Bernard Reinckens, the baby peeking out from behind a blanket (Slide 6). And the Harlem resident Sidney Bernstein submitted a street portrait of a young boy in Far Rockaway, Queens, named Earl Johnston - one of the few African-American subjects to appear in the albums (Slide 3).

BRIGHT AUTOMOTIVE, a start-up company in Indiana that hoped to sell a plug-in hybrid delivery vehicle to fleet customers, is closing, but it's not going quietly. The company had applied for a loan under the Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing Loan Program, administered by the Energy Department. The company's request, which was reduced to $314 million from $450 million, had been under review for more than three years before Bright announced on Tuesday that it would withdraw the application.

A soldiers' barracks seemed an unlikely backdrop for a men's fashion show. But for Umit Benan's fall-winter 2012 collection in Milan, soldiers were seen packing up their gear after a battle ended in a truce. Benan, a designer with origins in Turkey - giving him a link to political volatility - created a scenario of soldiers showering, facing a senior officer or being tattooed in front of the audience. It was far from the first time men's fashion had doffed a soldier's cap to military-inspired clothes. Burberry's raincoats were originally designed for the British army, hence the name ''trench coat,'' and men's closets are filled with khaki parkas and bomber jackets as weekend wear. So what was new this time around?

Adored grandfather of Michael, Daniel and Katherine Hellige, Ryan, Brittany, Sean and Kyle Morrissey and Lucas and James Marino. Services were conducted by Towers Funeral Home Inc. Oceanside, NY on February 14, 2012. The family requests memorial donations be sent to Brain and Behavior Research Foundation, 60 Cutter Mill Rd. Great Neck, NY 11021-9866, Suite 404, www. towersfuneralhomeny.com

WHITMAN--Johnston de Forest, Sr.,Mr. Whitman died on February 17, 2012 from Neuroendocrine Carcinoma. Born May 8, 1936 in New York City. Educated at The Buckley School, Brooks School, and Colby College. Husband of Christina. Father of Susan D. Whitman-Mazzuckelli and Johnston de F. Whitman, Jr. Grandfather of Johnston de F. Whitman, III. He is also survived by a brother Benjamin T. Whitman, a sister Helen D. Dickerson, and several nieces and nephews. Memorial service on March 10, 2012 at 11:00am at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, where he was a dedicated tenor in the choir for over forty years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: St. John's Church Organ Fund, Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724; Caring for Carcinoid Foundation, www.caringforcarcinoid.org; and Huntington Choral Society, Box 349, Huntington, NY 11743.

Jeremy Lin is not the only N.B.A. player to be an immediate success in his team's starting lineup. With the emergence of Sacramento point guard Isaiah Thomas, Lin was not even the only player to do so in February. In a league that values superstars above all else, the stories of unheralded players who have been able to make an impact are few and far between. But through seven games as a Kings starter, Thomas gained notice by averaging 17.1 points and 6.3 assists.

GREENBERG--Marilyn. The Board, staff and volunteers of the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter are saddened by the loss of Marilyn Greenberg, mother of Lou-Ellen Barkan, President and CEO and William Greenberg and grandmother to Sara, Tony, Michael and Rebecca. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her loving family. Jeffrey N. Jones, Co-Chair Heath McLendon, Co-Chair Jed A. Levine, Executive Vice President

KLEIMAN--Murray. With great sorrow we announce the passing of Murray Kleiman, March 1st in Atlantis, FL at age 89. Treasured husband of Adele, beloved brother of Dorothy Lang, adored father of Mitchell and Nancy, Randi and Oron Brokman, Leslie and David Gleaner, precious Pop Pop to Yuval and Sarah, Aviv, Kineret, Alexis, Ian, Ariel and Seth, and special friend and cherished uncle and cousin. Murray had an insatiable thirst for knowledge. He was an avid wordsmith and famous among all who knew him for always jotting down words and quotes to share. A man with a spectacular sense of humor, his delight in telling a good joke was only surpassed by hearing one. He was an ardent Knicks fan basking in their current season's storyline. But Murray was also a deep thinker. He was as interested and knowledgeable in Torah as the most serious biblical scholar. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Yeshivah University, he was a psychologist by training. He and Adele took over his parents' catering business, Kleiman Caterers, a premiere kosher catering enterprise, well known throughout Long Island. This venture highlighted Murray's other great passion -- food. Murray not only was comfortable in the kitchen, he thrived in it. Most of all, Murray was a true mensch. He will be remembered for his sweetness, incredible warmth, kind heart, and how he delighted and basked in the love of his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to UJA/ Federation of Jewish Philanthropies or Anti-Defamation League. Funeral at 1pm Sunday at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ.

Port Moresby, the blighted Papua New Guinean capital, is among the world's most dangerous places, lorded over by curiously garbed outlaws armed with pistols made of bored-out iron pipes. In 2004, the photographer Stephen Dupont infiltrated this dystopian underworld and convinced its inhabitants to pose with their weapons. Newly collected in ''Raskols'' (powerHouse Books, $30), his unmoralizing portraits are both visually striking and emotionally disturbing: some raskols are only children, others bear horrific scars. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

In an about-face, the conservative talk radio host Rush Limbaugh said Saturday that he was sorry for denouncing as a ''prostitute'' a Georgetown University law student who had spoken publicly in favor of the Obama administration's birth control policy. On Saturday, a day after President Obama telephoned the student, Sandra Fluke, to say he stood by her in the face of personal attacks on right-wing radio, Mr. Limbaugh published the apology on his Web site.

KALKUT--Esther (nee Dalick), born June 5, 1920 died February 27, 2012. She lived a full life and had a wonderful sense of humor, which stood her in good stead even during her many illnesses. She was a loving aunt, devoted sister caring cousin and loyal friend, with an indomitable spirit. She was truly loved and will be missed.

ENGMAN--Patricia Hanahan, of Anna Maria, FL, died February 20, at home, surrounded by her family and friends. Mrs. Engman was born on May 1, 1942 at Camp Stuart in Hinesville, GA. and grew up in Lakeland, FL, where she attended Lakeland Senior High School. She was the daughter of the late Phyllis Anderson Hanahan and Dr. Ralph B. Hanahan, III. In 1965, Mrs. Engman received her A.B. degree, cum laude, from Coker College in Hartsville, SC and her J.D. degree from the University of Florida Law School in Gainesville, FL in 1969. Following graduation from law school she clerked for Judge David McCain of Florida's Fourth District Court of Appeals. In 1970, she was assistant to the campaign manager of Lawton Chiles' first "Walkin' Lawton Campaign" for the United States Senate and moved to Washington, DC in 1971 as a staff attorney for the Senator. In following years, Mrs. Engman served as a Congressional Liaison Officer for the Federal Trade Commission, Counsel for Legislative and Administrative Affairs for Bristol-Myers, and as the Executive Director at The Business Roundtable, an association of CEOs of leading US companies comprising nearly 1/3 of the value of the US stock market. Her role was to develop and implement public policy positions with Congress and the Administration. In 2006 she was appointed by President George W. Bush to a President's Emergency Board to investigate, report and make settlement recommendations in a major dispute between a New York rail carrier and its employees represented by multiple labor unions. Active in numerous community and civic affairs in Washington, DC and in her Florida retirement, Mrs. Engman was a member of St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square in Washington, DC and Church of the Annunciation in Anna Maria, FL. She was a member of the Washington Women's Forum. She served on the Board of Trustees of Coker College from 1993-1999 and received their Distinguished Alumni Award. In her retirement she sat on the board of Florida House and was a member of the Suncoast Women's Forum. She was a member of Key Royale and Bradenton Country Clubs. She was married to Lewis A. Engman (who served as Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission under both Presidents Nixon and Ford, was President of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and President of the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association) from 1978 until his death on July 12, 1995. Mrs. Engman is survived by three sons, Geoffrey Engman of Texas, Jonathan Engman of Michigan and Richard Engman of Florida; her brother Dr. Ralph Bailey Hanahan, IV and sisters Christy Hanahan Powell and Elizabeth (Lisa) Hanahan Taylor; eight grandchildren and her fiance, John Kolojeski. The funeral was held on Saturday, February 25 at 2pm at the Church of the Annunciation in Anna Maria, FL. Memorial donations may be made to Tidewell Hospice of Bradenton, FL.

It is an almost inviolable rule that Hollywood attempts at surf movies are not received well by surfers. Part of it has to do with a studio tendency toward surf tropes and clichés (''Cowabunga!'' ''Hang Ten!''). More of it has to do with the nature of the sport itself: it breeds localism. Not just the xenophobic, occasionally violent expressions of localism that enforce the pecking order, but, more prevalent, a fierce love of place. To learn the personality of a particular wave is to become intimate with the contours of a landscape, to map that landscape and make it yours. Surfers will say that the character of a break influences the local culture. In other words, a filmmaker who wishes to get a surf spot right by its locals has his work cut out for him. It was with this in mind that the team behind ''Of Men and Mavericks,'' due out this fall, went to rather prodigious lengths to make their film anthropologically correct. Directed by Curtis Hanson (''8 Mile,'' ''L.A. Confidential''), the biopic tells the story of Jay Moriarty, a surfer who helped put Maverick's - an enormous break a half-mile offshore near Santa Cruz, Calif. - on the map when, in 1995, a photograph of him wiping out in a 30-foot swell made the cover of Surfer magazine. He was 16. Though he died young, in 2001, Moriarty remains the spot's most celebrated stylist, the standard by which all performances at Maverick's are judged. More...

The Blind Barber, the East Village barbershop-cum-speakeasy, is fusing its twin obsessions in a new line of cocktail-inspired grooming products. The creams and aftershave are infused with juniper berries (a key ingredient of gin), and the hair wax and pomade are made with hops. But ye olde barbershop ablutions these are not: ''We thought using a badger brush to whip up shaving cream, apply a preshave oil, lather twice, etc., was just too much for the guy at home,'' says Jeff Laub (above), who founded Blind Barber with Josh Boyd and Adam Kirsch in 2010. ''These products are for the style-conscious guy that's got better things to do than spend an hour in front of the mirror.'' Like forgetting about a bad haircut with a stiff drink. Blind Barber grooming products will be available in March in stores and at blindbarber.com.

In 1912, the first two of 3,000 trees that the mayor of Tokyo gave to Washington were planted around the Tidal Basin. The centennial will be marked by the National Cherry Blossom Festival, whose typical 16-day run (nationalcherryblossomfestival.org) will be extended to 5 weeks this year. Held March 20 through April 27, the festival includes art exhibitions, classical music performances and sustainable sushi tasting in addition to the signature parade, on April 14.

It is striking that Londoners, notorious for being convulsed by courtesy, embarrassed by display and unwilling to look people in the eye on the street, should have theater as their most celebrated art form. And never more so than now: even in this last dark year, when recession has threatened to make directors less adventurous, and innovative small companies have begun to struggle because of underfinancing, the range of work has been tremendous. We've had Jacobean gore, 18th-century romping, a revelatory musical work based on the murder of prostitutes and a love story involving quantum physics. Disused warehouses are regularly now taken over for gorgeously constructed immersive events: the stage is part of the fabric of the city. The diversity of acting styles is tremendous as well, drawing not only on the long tradition of speech work but also on movement theater, circus talent, television underplaying. As is shown here: from the peerlessly subtle Eileen Atkins and Judi Dench -- whose voice is a mille-feuille of crackles and whispers -- to Bertie Carvel, one of the buoyant acting hopes of a new generation. But then, London has never been dominated by one kind of theatrical experience. The city's variety is its distinction. I pin this surprising gift on Shakespeare, a dramatist who was never constrained by good taste. Interviews by Hattie Crisell

''I'VE been doing this so long I don't even think about it,'' Hussein Chalayan said on Friday as models cheered after a stellar show. ''It's just instinctual.'' Mr. Chalayan's clothes reflect nearly 20 years of knowledge: innovative cutting, meditations on culture and identity and, inevitably, the struggles of an independent London designer. An exhibition in Paris last year gave insight into his early work as it illuminated an entire creative period in fashion.

KUTNER--Elliott Robert, devoted Husband, Father, Grandfather and Friend. Heroic WWII veteran, awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, founding member and past President of the South Shore Audobon Society, published author, passed away on March 2, 2012. Survived by his beloved wife Shirley (Krinsky), son Michael, daughter Cathy Rubin, granddaughters Pam and Lisa, son-in-law Howard Rubin, nieces, nephews, in-laws, cousins and friends. He was a special kind charitable man deeply connected to his Jewish roots. He will be missed by the many lives he touched and loved in his 88 years. His enthusiasm for life was exceptional and contagious. Our lives will never be the same without him.

SEARCH--Robert Walter. October 7, 1924 - February 15, 2012. Husband, brother, father, uncle, veteran WWII and Korean War. My darling, my best friend. You are in my heart forever. You are a keeper. Sheila

STEPHEN PETRONIO is not, perhaps, praised quite enough for his consistent ambition. Although his movement style, with its visceral whipping limbs and rippling torsos, is instantly identifiable, he almost always tries to stretch himself and his dancers beyond what they know. And while many choreographers of Mr. Petronio's stature can call on big-name collaborators, his choices always seem like deeply felt, adventurous ones. Beginning on Tuesday Mr. Petronio offers a marvelously rich program. A new piece for 11 dancers, ''THE ARCHITECTURE OF LOSS,'' is set to an original score by the Icelandic composer Valgeir Sigurdsson, with contributions by Nico Muhly, and features images by Rannva Kunoy, a painter from the Faroe Islands who is based in London. Equally intriguing is the prospect of two solos, each offering an unexpected meeting of dance minds: Mr. Petronio himself in a reimagining of Steve Paxton's 1970 ''Intravenous Lecture,'' a meditation on censorship; and, thrillingly, the New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan (only Tuesday through Friday) in Mr. Petronio's ''Ethersketch 1,'' based on a solo from his 2003 ''Underland.'' 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday through Saturday, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $10 to $59.

Two years ago, Stephen Gill, a London-based photographer, purchased 9,000 negatives on eBay that were said to contain images of London's East End in the 1950s. Gill was hoping the negatives would document the area's vibrant street life. Instead, there were thousands and thousands of pictures of East Enders on their wedding days. He spoke about his find: ''All the images were made by one photographer, but since the negatives passed from hand to hand, no one is sure who the photographer is. He used a high-quality medium-format camera with flash, which gives you incredible detail in fabric and textures and those overexposed cakes and flowers. The pictures were probably taken between 1956 and 1959. Some of the couples are a little old, and this is because many people were remarrying around that time after losing their first spouses in the Second World War. Some couples had three or four films from their wedding day and others just six frames. I feel this reflects what the couple or the couple's parents could afford. But something special always seems to happen when the photographer asks the couple to kiss.''

FOR the last three years, Honda, Subaru and Toyota have monopolized the top three spots, respectively, on the Consumer Reports Automaker Report Card, the central feature of the magazine's spring auto issue. That order has been significantly reshuffled for 2012, with Honda falling out of the top three. Subaru received the highest score on the report card for the first time, moving up from No. 2 last year. Honda, including Acura, its luxury subsidiary, had held the top spot for the last four years. The automaker fell to No. 4 out of the 13 automakers included in the feature.

THERE'S no way around it. New York this week is knee deep in contemporary art fairs. There are over a dozen, most at ARMORY ARTS WEEK, and they come in several shapes and sizes. Most open Thursday, including the sprawling Armory Show at Piers 92 and 94, at 12th Avenue and West 55th Street; the trés chic Independent, at 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea; Volta, at 7 West 34th Street, Manhattan; and the all-video Moving Image at the Waterfront New York Tunnel, at 11th Avenue and 27th Street. Friday will bring the youthful Pool Art Fair at the Flatiron Toshi, at 26th and Broadway, on East 27th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, and the Fountain Art Fair, which graduates to its own armory: 69th Regiment's, at Lexington Avenue and 26th Street. The venerable Art Show at the Park Avenue Armory (643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street) and Scope New York, at 12th Avenue and West 57th Street, start Wednesday. The unusually manageable Salon Zürcher (only seven galleries, no entrance fee), at 33 Bleecker Street, between Lafayette Street and Bowery, in the East Village, opens Monday and will feature only female artists.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the HBO documentary ''God Is the Bigger Elvis,'' using information from the network, described incorrectly screenings scheduled at Bantam Cinema in Litchfield, Conn., and also misstated the title of an HBO official involved in the film. A screening on March 24 at noon is private; a screening on March 25 at noon is free and open to the public, though reservations are required. And the HBO official, Sheila Nevins, is president of HBO Documentary Films, as well as executive producer of the film; she is not an executive director at HBO.

Robert R. McElroy, a photographer who documented the evanescent when he snapped hundreds of images of the Happenings art movement, a free-spirited blend of art and performance in the late 1950s and early '60s, died on Feb. 22 at an assisted-living center in White Plains. He was 84. The cause was Alzheimer's disease, his wife, Evelyn, said.

Alex Webster, a powerful running back who helped propel the Giants to six division titles and a National Football League championship in the late 1950s and early '60s and later became their coach for five seasons, died Saturday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 80. The cause was lung cancer and emphysema, said his daughter, Debbie Moberg.

de MARGITAY--Gedeon, died peacefully at home on February 28 at age 87. Born in Budapest, Hungary, son of Jozsef and Anna (nee de Bessenyei) de Margitay, he is survived by his wife of 47 years, Virginia Varet (nee Martin). He was educated at the University of Budapest Graduate School of Economics and Ecole Sciences Politiques in Paris, where he later worked for the New York Times and the European Information Division of the Mutual Security Agency. Immigrating to the US, he served as Chief Executive of Magnum Photos, Inc., then as Director, Time Life Editorial Services, and Director, Broadcast and Corporate Planning at NBC, where he co-authored "Broadcasting, the Next Ten Years, 1977". A gentleman and a scholar, he will be remembered for his courtly manners and his keen sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at the First Hungarian Reformed Church, 344 East 69th Street, New York City on Saturday, March 10 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the Hungarian Church, or the Hungarian Johanniter ("Johanniter Account", c/o Rev. Gabor de Nitsch, 30 Saxman Drive, Latrobe, PA 15650).

An article in some editions on Wednesday about Fabian Johnson, a German-born player for the United States national soccer team who once played on youth and professional clubs in Germany, misidentified the game in which he first played for the American team. As an accompanying picture caption correctly noted, the game was against France, not Slovenia. (The game against Slovenia, played four days later, was the game in which he was a starter for the first time.)

Christina Aguilera (above right) partners with Jewel and Lionel Richie, Adam Levine with Alanis Morissette and Robin Thicke, Cee Lo Green with Kenny Edmonds (a k a Babyface) and Ne-Yo, and Blake Shelton with Kelly Clarkson and Miranda Lambert. (Showtime) VIDAL SASSOON: THE MOVIE (2011) Craig Teper chronicles the life and times of Mr. Sassoon, whose wash-and-wear philosophy changed the world of hairstyling. (Above, models with Sassoon haircuts.) An ''extravagant verbal fusillade introduces a screen biography that sometimes feels like an infomercial,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But in the documentary's defense, its upbeat tone, perky visual rhythm and sleek graphics capture the 'swinging '60s' aesthetic epitomized by Mr. Sassoon's major invention: the geometric 'five-point' haircut.''

Pent-up demand for a family film and a well-executed marketing campaign by Universal Pictures sent ''Dr. Seuss' The Lorax'' into the box-office stratosphere over the weekend. With an estimated $70.7 million in ticket sales in North America, ''The Lorax,'' about a mustachioed critter with a tree-saving mantra, was a huge No. 1 despite poor reviews. (In The New York Times, A.O. Scott called it ''a noisy, useless piece of junk.'' The strong opening, fueled partly by turnout at Imax theaters, puts business pressure on other cartoon studios, particularly the publicly traded DreamWorks Animation, which spends over $130 million per movie in production costs alone. Universal's Illumination Entertainment unit, pursuing a leaner business model, made ''The Lorax'' for about $70 million. To put the opening results for ''The Lorax'' into context, Illumination's relatively inexpensive ''Despicable Me'' took in $56.4 million over its first three days in 2010 and went on to sell over $543 million in tickets at the global box office.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about retail stores at the Time Warner Center misspelled the name of the chairman and chief executive of Related Companies, the project's developer. He is Stephen M. Ross, not Steven Ross.

On a recent Friday afternoon, Joshua Johnson danced down a Q train car with an Air Jordan sneaker on his left foot to keep from slipping and a tap shoe on his right foot to play a beat as he collected money from several riders. ''Thank you, folks,'' Mr. Johnson told the straphangers. ''If you know Penn State, you know it ain't cheap. Every dollar counts.''

By the time mid-March rolled around in 2008, all of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Democratic rivals for the White House except one, Barack Obama, had dropped out of the race. A one-on-one competition with Mitt Romney is what Rick Santorum would like to see now. But instead, he is locked in a four-way battle in which none of the Republican presidential candidates shows any sign of departing.

Three books by Christopher Hitchens that had gone out of print will be revived in paperback and e-book, the publishers of the titles said. Twelve, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, will release the three books on April 10. The titles are ''The Missionary Position,'' a study of Mother Teresa; ''No One Left to Lie To,'' a best-selling examination of Bill Clinton; and ''The Trial of Henry Kissinger.'' Mr. Hitchens, a prolific author and columnist, died in December at the age of 62 of pneumonia, a complication of esophageal cancer. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DELPIN--Olinto, O.M.,died February 23 in New York City from respiratory failure. Born to Maria and Antonio in Sottomonte in 1926. Joined the Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the US and Canada in 1954. Settled in Queens, with his wife Luciana, became a US citizen 1962. He worked on many New York City projects, including the World Trade Center, JFK airport and Bronx Co-op City. He is remembered on the NIAF Wall of Honor in Washington, DC. He is survived by his daughters Sandra Failla, Scarsdale and Dr. Christina DelPin Cella, Greenwich CT, as well as five grandchildren, brother Bortolo, and the children and cousins of brother Louis and sisters Anna, Irma,Elda Angelina, and Gilda. He will be buried in Meduno, Italy next week. He taught us: 1. Family is the cement, the foundation; 2. Don't be afraid to change your place, it is an elemental and natural right, can not be impeded, and at times a painful necessity, leaving no recourse 3. Learn to communicate with all people 4. Love your partner(s)fiercely 5. With a brain and hands, do good work, do it yourself, finish what you start 6. Be tolerant of people different than you 7. Protect your identity at all costs, 8. If you fall into dark Times, recognize it, see the dead space, respect it, find a new purpose, do what you have to to turn it around 9. embrace your community, enhance it. Light up your Xmas tree, for all to enjoy. And just keep going! In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made in Dad's memory to the Olinto DelPin Famee Furlana Educational scholarship fund.

An article on Thursday about the expulsion from South Africa's governing African National Congress party of Julius Malema, the firebrand leader of the party's Youth League, misstated the number of post-apartheid presidents South Africa has had. There have been four, not three. (Two of them once led the Youth League, a powerful organization that is often a springboard to national leadership.)

Aging or ageless? That's the question for Nickelodeon and its plucky sea sponge who lives in a pineapple under the sea. In 2014,Viacom's Paramount Pictures unit will introduce a new''SpongeBob SquarePants''movie intended to give the global franchise and its Nickelodeon network a boost. In addition to box-office sales, Viacom is hoping the movie will also set off a rush on related consumer products.

WRIGHT--William. A former publishing executive who is credited with helping to revive the industry in the 1990s, died on February 26, 2012 surrounded by family at his home in Zionsville, Ind. He was 62 years old. The cause was complications from ocular melanoma, a rare cancer, his daughter Diana said. His strong and loving character, wisdom and generosity will be missed by all. Mr. Wright had a reputation in the publishing industry as a strong motivational leader. He left the Chief Operating Officer post at Random House Inc, to serve as President and CEO of the Hearst Book Group in 1995 after the publisher fell into tumult when many of its top authors and editors defected. Mr. Wright streamlined costs and grew the business by attracting new editorial talent. He published numerous bestselling books from authors as diverse as Pope John Paul II, President George H. W. Bush, Sidney Sheldon and Whoopi Goldberg. Mr. Wright was dedicated to promoting the publishing industry and serving his community. He was a past Chairman of New York is Book Country and was a board member of the Association of American Publishers from 1996 to 1998. While at the helm of Hearst Book Group he was a strong advocate for Literacy Volunteers, a statewide network of community-based volunteer services that exists to foster and strengthen literate communities throughout New York. His community service continued during his retirement. He served as a volunteer for Child Advocates of Indiana, an organization that intervenes on behalf of abused and neglected children. Prior to joining Random House in 1992, Wright was Senior Vice President of Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group. Before that he was Senior Vice President of CBS Educational and Professional Publishing. He joined CBS in 1980 as Director of Distribution and went on to hold several positions of increasing responsibility. Mr. Wright held a B.S. in Economics from Villanova University (1972) and an M.B.A from Temple University (1973). Bill received a scholorship to play basketball at Villanova but later relinquished his scholarship to focus on the arrival of his first child. "Despite his pressing job and community service responsibilities, Bill remained close to his children and remarked in his final hours that their success and happiness as adults was his proudest accomplishment," remarked Patricia Reber, his beloved longtime executive assistant. Mr. Wright is survived by his second wife Chandra of Zionsville, IN, his daughter Diana Wright Milkowski and her husband Matt Milkowski of Rumson, NJ and his son Jason Wright of Manhattan. He is also survived by grandchildren Kevin, Jake, Lyla and Mia and stepchildren Brittany, Charles and Corttany. There will be a memorial service at Assumption Church in Fairfield, CT on Friday, March 9, 2012 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Opportunity Network, 55 Exchange Place, Suite 503, New York, NY 10005 or online at opportunitynetwork.org.

An obituary last Monday about Erland Josephson, a Swedish actor who worked frequently with Ingmar Bergman, described incorrectly the character Mr. Josephson played in the 1976 movie ''Face to Face.'' He was a friend of a woman coping with mental illness; he was not the woman's husband.

LEIBLER--Max, passed away on Friday, March 2 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY at the age of 92. Survived by his beloved wife Martha of almost seventy years, sisters Ann Jacobson and Jay Roth, daughter Linda Golden, son Kenneth, four grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Last year, researchers at the Project for Excellence in Journalism persuaded six companies that own 121 newspapers to share private data about the financial performance of many of their papers. And the findings were grim. On average, for every new dollar the newspapers were earning in new digital advertising revenue, they were losing $7 in print advertising revenue. The papers seemed not to be diversifying their revenue streams or coming up with innovative products at a fast enough clip.

SAN FRANCISCO - Here is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and scarier happenings taking place at the annual RSA security conference here this week. DIABETICS BEWARE: HACKERS CAN TAKE OVER YOUR INSULIN PUMPS. Panel discussions piled fear-mongering upon fear-mongering. Of the more egregious examples: One RSA panel discussion about trojans, malware and targeted hacks included a slide featuring a month-old online ad for a hitman's services. The hitman offered to ''eliminate someone while keeping above suspicion'' within 30 days for $9,133. It's still not entirely clear what this had to do with trojans, or cyberattacks, but it was scary nonetheless. In another talk, Stuart McClure, McAfee's chief technology officer, demonstrated how easily a diabetic's insulin pump could be commandeered by hackers. This could ''affect a patient's health dramatically,'' Mr. McClure told a crowd of hundreds. He concluded his speech this way, ''When communications cannot be secured, it can lead to death.''

On Wednesday, Microsoft demonstrated its new operating system, Windows 8, which is expected later this year. It is a critically important piece of software for Microsoft, which still depends on Windows and Office for most of its revenue. For all the attention given to Apple's iPhone and iPad, or Google's Android OS on phones and tablet computers, Microsoft's lasting market power can still influence how most people think about computing. ''In its time, Windows 95 put the Internet browser in the OS, and that led to widespread communications using computers,'' said Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Nomura securities who has followed Microsoft for years. Windows 8, he said, ''could be a platform shift for enterprises, and for personal productivity.''

LITTLE--Donald Vaughan, 77, of Ipswich, MA, horseman and stockbroker, the beloved husband of Judith Ann (Lewis) Little, died February 29, 2012 in Wellington, FL. He was the loving father of Donald V. Little, Jr. and Andrea Little Eaton and grandfather of four. For a complete obituary please visit www.whittier-porter.com

The top newspaper Web sites lagged behind general news sites in January, as people tracked big stories like the Republican primary race, the economy, a one-day Web blackout, the State of the Union address and the grounding of a cruise ship off Italy. Over all, general sites had a 3 percent increase in visitors from January 2011 to January 2012, and newspaper sites rose 7 percent. For the month, average minutes per visitor rose 14 percent for general sites, to 87 minutes, and fell for newspapers by 8 percent, to 36 minutes. SHELLY FREIERMAN

An article on Wednesday about the effect the furor surrounding Virginia's ultrasound bill has had on other states misidentified, in some editions, the chamber of Pennsylvania's legislature in which a committee approved a bill regulating ultrasounds. It is the Pennsylvania House, not the Senate. And because of that error, the article also misidentified, in some editions, the legislative position of the bill's main sponsor, Kathy L. Rapp. She is a representative, not a senator.

SCHON--Arthur, 81, beloved husband of Jean (nee Cohen), father of Eileen, Lew, and Diane, zaydie of eleven, died peacefully on Shabbat. He was a musician, singer, endodontist, leader, educator, and athlete, whose warmth, creative energy, compassion, and humor, infused every action. Dr. Schon was deeply spiritual and ethical, and brought insight, clarity, and comfort to all. His life was filled with love and happiness

SAN FRANCISCO --I wouldn't describe the car industry as fun. The airline industry isn't fun either. Phone companies are far from fun. Yet these industries all started out fun. They began with tinkerers and innovators, just like, say, the Internet today. The fun was sucked out when companies grew large and started squashing smaller competitors. In the process, these companies also stopped making products that were in the best interest of their customers. Either customers moved on, or the regulators were forced to move in. And we all know that regulators are far from fun.
EPSTEIN--Sidney S, on March 3, 2012. Beloved husband of the late Adele. Devoted father of Mitchell (Donna), Edward(Helen), Joan (James). Adored grandfather and great-grandfather.

Updated 3:07 p.m. | Critics of the plan to eventually place the unidentified remains of 9/11 victims at bedrock in the National September 11 Memorial and Museum gathered on Sunday near ground zero to release an informal survey of some victims' families that showed that more than nine-tenths of respondents opposed the proposal. A group of 17 families sued the city, seeking to require officials to solicit opinions from the relatives of the over 2,700 victims at the World Trade Center. The group lost its case but is appealing the decision. In the meantime, the group conducted its own informal poll, using a list of 2,100 victims' family members and close friends.

HONIG--Dr. Edward. On Sunday, March 4th we lost Dr. Edward Honig, who was one of a kind. Never in a hurry, he was always available to anyone who needed him. Life partner of Paula, devoted father to Lisa, David, Emily, Lee Ann, Samantha, Eden; grandfather to Evan, Lindsay, Erica, Sarah, Dylan, Ricky, Jon, Fiona, Ruben, Jacob, and Rumi. Cherished uncle and father-in-law. Dedicated cardiologist and teacher, who practiced for over fifty years. Lover of art, music, food, good political discussions, and apple deserts. He touched many lives through his caring and kindness. He was cherished and will be deeply missed. Funeral to be held at: Riverside Nassau North Chapel. Wednesday at 3pm 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck.

When a century of seniority and experience voluntarily walks away from Congress, it is a watershed moment. Over the course of a few days last week, Representatives David Dreier of California and Norm Dicks of Washington followed Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine in announcing they would not be running for re-election in November. Together, the three long-time colleagues will have amassed 102 years of House and Senate service by the time they depart.

WASHINGTON -- From its perch in a spacious brand-new headquarters blocks from the White House, the Cato Institute has built on its reputation as a venerable libertarian research center unafraid to cross party lines. Now, however, a rift with one of its founding members -- the billionaire conservative Charles Koch -- is threatening the institute's identity and independence, its leaders say, and is exposing fault lines over Mr. Koch's aggressive and well-financed brand of Republican politics.

It is a family feud as longstanding and reliable as the swallows' return to Capistrano: Congressional campaign committees want more fund-raising help from the president, and the president, despite fat coffers, is reluctant to give it. This year is no different. As President Obama churns towards a likely haul of over $700 million for the cycle, Democrats on the Hill, eager to retake the House and preserve their hold on the Senate, have asked for a little bit of the action, requesting a combined $30 million in transfers from the Democratic National Committee, which raised $108 million last year with help from Mr. Obama.

Winning Our Future, the pro-Newt Gingrich ''super PAC'' responsible for the commercials that featured a computer-animated, bobble-headed President Obama, is at it again with a new ad that promotes the former House speaker's moxie. Or, as the ad puts it, ''The guy's a fighter, and he ain't afraid to hurt nobody's feelings.'' In the 60-second commercial, a host with a husky frame sits behind a microphone and takes a call from Joey, a disaffected conservative voter. When asked which candidate can beat Mr. Obama, Joey does not mince words.

(HBO2) MAGIC & BIRD: A COURTSHIP OF RIVALS (2010) This documentary chronicles the testy relationship, on and off the basketball court, between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, from their first meeting on a college all-star team in 1978, when Mr. Johnson called Mr. Bird ''the baddest white dude I've ever seen,'' to the 1984 N.B.A. championship, which Mr. Bird's Boston Celtics won over Mr. Johnson's Los Angeles Lakers. ''You know, not only winning the game makes you feel good, but just knowing the other guy's suffering,'' Mr. Bird says in the film. ''And you know he was.'' The basketball theme continues at 9:15 with ''Just Wright'' (2010), starring Queen Latifah as Leslie Wright, a no-nonsense physical therapist and, in her words, ''the perfect homegirl,'' who lands an invitation to the birthday party of her favorite New Jersey Nets player, Scott McKnight (Common), only to have him fall head over heels for her conniving friend Morgan (Paula Patton). But that doesn't stop Leslie from helping Scott when he's injured, or when his heart is broken.

This could be bad for Sony, in many senses of the word: that media giant has confirmed that several tracks recorded by Michael Jackson were stolen from its Web site after it was hacked, BBC News reported. Sony has not said what Jackson tracks were taken, but in 2010 it closed a $250 million deal with the singer's estate to acquire his back catalog (including best-selling albums like ''Thriller'' and ''Bad'') and to release previously unheard recordings, beginning with a posthumous album, ''Michael,'' that went on sale in December of that year. Last April a Sony online network for its PlayStation game consoles was hacked, compromising the personal data of some 77 million users; the Sony Music Japan site and Sony Ericsson online store were also hacked in the following weeks. The BBC said the Jackson tracks were taken during this time. In May two British men, James Marks and James McCormick, were arrested in connection with the hacks and are to go on trial next January. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DELPIN--Olinto, O.M.,died February 23 in New York City from respiratory failure. Born to Maria and Antonio in Sottomonte in 1926. Joined the Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the US and Canada in 1954. Settled in Queens, with his wife Luciana, became a US citizen 1962. He worked on many New York City projects, including the World Trade Center, JFK airport and Bronx Co-op City. He is remembered on the NIAF Wall of Honor in Washington, DC. He is survived by his daughters Sandra Failla, Scarsdale and Dr. Christina DelPin Cella, Greenwich CT, as well as five grandchildren, brother Bortolo, and the children and cousins of brother Louis and sisters Anna, Irma,Elda Angelina, and Gilda. He will be buried in Meduno, Italy next week. He taught us: 1. Family is the cement, the foundation; 2. Don't be afraid to change your place, it is an elemental and natural right, can not be impeded, and at times a painful necessity, leaving no recourse 3. Learn to communicate with all people 4. Love your partner(s)fiercely 5. With a brain and hands, do good work, do it yourself, finish what you start 6. Be tolerant of people different than you 7. Protect your identity at all costs, 8. If you fall into dark Times, recognize it, see the dead space, respect it, find a new purpose, do what you have to to turn it around 9. embrace your community, enhance it. Light up your Xmas tree, for all to enjoy. And just keep going! In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made in Dad's memory to the Olinto DelPin Famee Furlana Educational scholarship fund.
