Clea Howard is hardly a tuned-out, disinterested high school student. She likes to be busy: In addition to maintaining an excellent scholastic record at a demanding high school an hour from her Brooklyn home, she studies art, takes dance classes and plays soccer. Yet during her freshman and sophomore years, she was always tired, no matter how much she slept at night. She often fell asleep in class, on the subway, while doing homework or talking to her boyfriend.

LIEBRAND--Jerome T.,age 84, formerly of East Lyme, CT, beloved husband of the late Catherine Carroll Liebrand, entered into eternal rest on Monday, March 5, 2012. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Liebrand had lived in Farmingdale, NY for many years before moving to East Lyme over twenty years ago. Mr. Liebrand was a Veteran of WWII serving in the U.S. Navy. He had worked for the Pfizer Corporation for nearly forty years until his retirement. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 9:30am directly at St. Pius X Church, 834 Brookside Dr., Fairfield, CT. Private interment will take place in St. Mary's Cemetery, New London, CT. Calling hours will be held on Wednesday, 4-8pm in the Lesko & Polke Funeral Home, 1209 Post Rd., Fairfield Center. To view a complete obituary, please visit: LeskoPolkeFuneralHome.com

An article on Jan. 14 about the competitive future of the New Jersey Nets misidentified the location of the team's new arena in Brooklyn, which will open later this year. It is on rail yards and other land in Prospect Heights and on a block in Park Slope; it is not in Downtown Brooklyn, although it is near that neighborhood. (The error also appeared in a number of articles in 2011, including ones on June 30, Aug. 27, Nov. 3 and Nov. 16.)

The Tate Modern in London announced on Monday that it had purchased one of Ai Weiwei's famous installations of life-size, hand-painted porcelain ''Sunflower Seeds.'' It bought 8 million of the 100 million seeds that were on view in a giant installation at the museum a year and a half ago. The mini-version was bought directly from the artist, officials at the Tate said, and the remaining 92 million seeds have been returned to Mr. Ai. When ''Sunflower Seeds'' was originally installed in the Tate Modern's cavernous Turbine Hall, the museum encouraged visitors to touch and even walk on the piece. But it reversed course days later after officials found that the movement of the crowds released hazardous dust. It was also determined that there were traces of lead in the paint.

Success breeds success, according to one saying. In sports, it also breeds higher ticket prices. The Madison Square Garden Company said that the average price of Knicks season tickets would increase 4.9 percent next season, while Rangers season tickets will rise 9.5 percent.

The Tony Award-winning director Bartlett Sher will stage a revival of Clifford Odets's 1937 drama, ''Golden Boy,'' on Broadway in November for Lincoln Center Theater, and a new Chekhov-inspired play by Christopher Durang will also run this fall at that company's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, executives for Lincoln Center Theater announced on Monday. ''Golden Boy,'' about a young violinist who hopes to support his career by earning money as a boxer, risking injury to his hands, was originally staged on Broadway by Harold Clurman and the Group Theater, with the stage and film actor Luther Adler in the lead role. The play was revived briefly on Broadway in 1952. Mr. Odets also helped adapt the work into a musical, starring Sammy Davis Jr., that ran on Broadway in 1964.

Lloyd C. Blankfein had a script for his phone call. ''Hello, Doug - it's been a long time since we have had the chance to visit,'' say the notes prepared for his call with Doug Foshee, the chief executive of El Paso, the big energy company that last fall was in talks to be sold to Kinder Morgan. ''I was very pleased you reached out to us on this most recent matter,'' the script goes, thanking Mr. Foshee for using Goldman as El Paso's adviser in the transaction. Mr. Blankfein added that he knew Mr. Foshee was aware of Goldman's investment in Kinder Morgan ''and that we are very sensitive to the appearance of conflict.''

LIMITING LEGAL COSTS When a corporation is caught in a government investigation, the legal fees can quickly exceed $100 million -- and that's before the lawsuits even begin. Once the government files charges, those costs can grow as companies are required to pay the legal fees for any officers or directors accused of wrongdoing. But according to White Collar Watch, a bill in Congress might give companies a mechanism to recover some payments if a former officer or director is found to have violated the law. PETER J. HENNING

After a heart attack and quadruple bypass surgery in 2010, Steve Colburn of Portland, Ore., began taking a cholesterol-lowering statin at the maximum dose. Soon, he began experiencing memory problems. ''Thinking and remembering became so laborious that I could not even recall my three-digit telephone extension or computer password at work,'' said Mr. Colburn, 62, a sales representative and product developer. ''All day, every day, I felt like my brain was mush.''

McHALE--John L.,died February 23, 2012 in Stamford, CT. He was 87 years old and was a resident of the Edgehill community for the past four years, following over twenty five years as a Greenwich resident. The cause of death was melanoma. Mr. McHale was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA, in 1924, son of Capt. Leo J. McHale (US Army) and Edith Lamb McHale. He served with the U.S. Army Air Corps in New Guinea and the Philippines during World War II and graduated from LaSalle University in Philadelphia in 1949. He began a 43-year career in journalism and communications management as a copy boy at The Philadelphia Bulletin in 1946. He later became a business reporter for Fairchild Publications in Philadelphia, managing editor of the Penns Grove (New Jersey) Record, state news editor of The Wilmington (Delaware) Journal-Every Evening, and a news editor with The New York World-Telegram & Sun. From 1956 to 1963, Mr. McHale served as an editor of national, foreign and city news at The New York Times. He taught editing and headline writing as an Associate Professor of Journalism at Columbia University from 1959 to 1963. He later earned a M.A. degree in educational psychology from Columbia University in 1972. In 1963 he joined the United Parcel Service as internal communications manager until retiring 1989. An 11th-generation descendant of John Chew, a 1618 English colonist of Jamestown, Virginia, he was a member of the Connecticut Society of Colonial Wars, the Colonial Society of Pennsylvania and the Jamestowne Society. He was a past member of the Greenwich Country Club, John's Island Club of Vero Beach, FL, and the DuPont-Penns Grove (New Jersey) Country Club. Additionally, he was a former member of the board of governors of the Scarsdale (New York) Golf Club. He regularly taught computer basics to seniors through the nonprofit SeniorNet organization in Greenwich and Vero Beach. Surviving are his wife of 62 years, Genevieve M. Gorman, sons Bartholomew McHale and Kent McHale of Greenwich, daughters Amy McHale Pinchbeck of Darien, Holly McHale Biggins of Charlotte, NC, and his sister, Edith McHale Ricci of Newtown, PA, and eleven grandchildren. Mass was celebrated at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich, with burial at Putnam Cemetery.

Defending himself against a growing ad boycott, Rush Limbaugh told his audience on Monday that the companies that have defected from his radio program have decided ''they don't want you or your business anymore.'' ''So be it,'' he said, reassuring his audience that the advertisers would be replaced.

WATSON--Robert, a prominent American poet, passed away on February 27, 2012 in Greensboro, N.C. Born in Passaic, N.J. to Winthrop and Laura Watson in 1925, Mr. Watson served in the Navy during World War II. He received a B.A. from Williams College then an M.A. and Ph.D. in English from The Johns Hopkins University. He taught for several years at both institutions. In 1953, Mr. Watson came with his wife, the painter Betty Watson, to teach in the English Department at what is now the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. At the department's request, he activated the M.F.A program in 1964 and in 1965 founded The Greensboro Review, a distinguished literary journal. Mr. Watson published eight collections of poetry including Robert Watson: The Complete Poems published in 2011 (available from amazon.com), two novels, and numerous shorter pieces. He won honors from the National Endowment for the Arts and the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and gave many lectures and readings, including one at the Library of Congress. Mr. Watson is survived by his wife, Betty; his son and daughter-in-law, Winthrop and Signe Watson of Pittsburgh, PA; his daughter and son-in-law, Caroline and William Keens of Falls Church, VA; two granddaughters, Margaret and Elizabeth Watson, and two grandsons, Gavin and Benjamin Keens.

An article on Friday about the Club for Growth, a free-market advocacy group that rates members of Congress, misstated the number of congressional terms served by Representative Jack Kingston, a Republican of Georgia who said the group had gained influence over the years. He is in his tenth term in Congress, not his nineteenth. (He was sworn in 19 years ago, in January 1993.)

Cherished son of Dorothy Stein Froman and the late Harry Stein. Loving brother of Carol Stein and Robert Stein. Service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street in Manhattan, on Tuesday, March 6th, at 11 o'clock am. Shiva at the Landowne/Stein home in Millwood, NY.

Traffic was flowing smoothly under the hard, bright sky of a typically scorching Brooklyn summer. Garo turned into Court Street, the early morning sun warming his back. In his recently purchased summer-weight blue suit and shiny black shoes, and with his hair trimmed and oiled ten minutes ago in Aket's barber shop, he felt full of confidence, sure that things were finally breaking his way. Well, it was about time, wasn't it? As he neared Schermerhorn Street, he purposely slowed his steps. The clock in the window of the small loan bank near the corner showed ten to ten - a little too early for the business appointment (well, it was a business, wasn't it?) that had drawn him from his furnished room. It was natural, he thought, that he should be a little keyed-up. After all, maybe Ray and his boys weren't the biggest around, but they were a beginning, and they had connections. Besides, all he wanted was to get enough money to kiss them all good-by.

In the teams' first meeting since the exhilarating final of last summer's Women's World Cup, Japan on Monday again vanquished the United States again on Monday. In Faro, Portugal, at the 19th annual Algarve Cup, Japan scored another late goal, this one by striker Megumi Takase in the 84th minute, to hand the United States a 1-0 defeat, its first loss of the tournament, and deny the Americans a shot at their third consecutive title.

An article on Feb. 27 about a commitment by the European Union to review the size of its planned rescue fund misstated the amount of additional lending capacity that the International Monetary Fund director, Christine Lagarde, has said her organization will need to help countries withstand shocks in international markets. It is $500 billion, not million.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the events leading up to the burning of Korans by American military personnel in Afghanistan misstated, in some editions, the number of people who an American military official said would be recommended for disciplinary review by a joint American-Afghan panel investigating the burning. It is six, not five.

ROSTOV--Dorothy Brenner, died peacefully at her home in Greenwich, CT on March 2, 2012. She was 90 years old. Her caring daughters Terry Heinzmann and Jan Rostov were by her side. Dorothy was born on June 11, 1921 in New York City, the daughter of Philip and Esther Brenner. A world traveler, she first journeyed overseas to Japan at the age of 13. In September 1972, Dorothy and her adoring late husband Charles were among the first 50 private US citizens to visit the People's Republic of China seven months after relations were re-established. An inveterate seeker, she hiked throughout Nepal, journeyed to Lhasa, traversed the Khyber Pass, climbed Mt. Kilimanjaro and swam off the coast of Borneo. She lived a full life exploring uncovered corners of the world, all while raising her two daughters and her son, Gene. Dorothy pursued much: she diligently played the flute, skied black diamond runs, sculpted life into stone, played a fierce net game in doubles tennis, made hollandaise sauce the old fashioned way and entertained with the grace of a bygone era. A graduate of Goucher College who then attended the Yale School of Drama, Dorothy was an ardent lover of the arts as student, viewer, volunteer, collector and philanthropist. Most treasured was her house and farm in southern Vermont that, with Charles, she re-designed and brought back to life: some of her greatest joys over her last forty-two years were here. In addition to her three children, Dorothy leaves behind two sisters, Suzanne Geller of La Jolla, CA and Greta Rosen of Weston, MA, a brother-in-law Jerome Rosen, her grandson Eli Kutler who is following his grandmother's world-traveling ways, her son-in-law John David Heinzmann and daughter-in-law Heather Knapp along with many nieces and nephews. Interment will be private. The family encourages contributions to The Center for Healthy Aging (c/o The Greenwich Hospital Foundation, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830), whose staff skillfully helped Dorothy navigate her later years.

The Teacher Retirement System of Texas just went from hedge fund investor to hedge fund owner. Last month, the Texas pension took a $250 million stake in Bridgewater Associates, the giant money manager. Now, rather than plowing money into specific portfolios, it can claim a piece of the whole operation.

An article on Friday about an interview with President Shimon Peres of Israel paraphrased incorrectly from his comments on what might happen if the White House was not resolute in its stance against Iran's nuclear program. Mr. Peres emphasized the importance of international solidarity against the possibility of a nuclear Iran; he did not suggest that Israel might have to act alone against Iran.

Ivy League schools usually cloak their jealousies in politesse, but President Obama's decision to give the commencement speech at Barnard, and not Columbia, his alma mater across the street, has unleashed online exchanges as nasty as any hair-pulling, eye-gouging schoolyard brawl. Since the president's address was announced on Saturday, students have deluged popular forums -- notably the Web sites of The Columbia Spectator, the campus newspaper, and Bwog, a student-run blog -- with hundreds of anonymous comments, which range from gracious acceptance to gratuitous venom.

Treasured grandmother of Nicole (Charles) Poliacof, Evan (Allison) Greene, and Jonathan (Nora) Greene. Adoring great-grandmother of Jordan Daniel Greene. Shiva at home of Roberta Greene through Friday noon.

On Monday, the 30th anniversary of the death of John Belushi, his fans and former colleagues are commemorating the occasion in different ways: with solemn reflections on his loss, lively celebrations of his talent and the announcement of a new project based on one of his best-known films. As for the new project, Universal Pictures Stage Productions has said that it is developing a musical based on ''National Lampoon's Animal House,'' the hit 1978 college comedy in which Belushi, playing the seventh-year undergraduate Bluto Blutarsky, showed a generation of moviegoers how to use cafeteria food to impersonate a zit.

An article on Saturday about a dispute between Stephen A. Wynn and Kazuo Okada over the company they formed, Wynn Resorts, misstated Mr. Okada's status on the company's board. While Mr. Okada was forced off the board of its Wynn Macau subsidiary, he remains as a director of the parent company in Las Vegas; it is not the case that he was ousted from the Wynn Resorts board.

Ralph McQuarrie, the artist who transformed George Lucas's rudimentary concepts and earliest scripts into lush, vivid images of intergalactic expanse and light-saber combat that became the visual core of the ''Star Wars'' saga, died on Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, said Stan Stice, a friend and co-author of the 2007 book ''The Art of Ralph McQuarrie.''

Last month, we wrote about the Obama re-election campaign selling $30 ''O'Bama'' T-shirts ''just in time for St. Patrick's Day'' that were adorned with a four-leaf clover, to the mild dismay of some Irish purists who pointed out that the symbol of Ireland, the shamrock, actually has only three leaves.

Hoping to learn more about how inactivity affects disease risk, researchers at the University of Missouri recently persuaded a group of healthy, active young adults to stop moving around so much. Scientists have known for some time that sedentary people are at increased risk of developing heart disease and Type 2 diabetes. But they haven't fully understood why, in part because studying the effects of sedentary behavior isn't easy. People who are inactive may also be obese, eat poorly or face other lifestyle or metabolic issues that make it impossible to tease out the specific role that inactivity, on its own, plays in ill health. So, to combat the problem, researchers lately have embraced a novel approach to studying the effects of inactivity. They've imposed the condition on people who otherwise would be out happily exercising and moving about, in some cases by sentencing them to bed rest.

The highlights of Jazz at Lincoln Center's 2012-13 programming season will include six mini-festivals dedicated to major jazz figures, styles and institutions of the past and present, the organization said. The festivals will focus on John Coltrane; Duke Ellington; Chick Corea; Blue Note records; the idea of the ''cool,'' as traced through Gerry Mulligan, John Lewis and the Modern Jazz Quartet; and the bebop of Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie. Each will include large-cast concerts in the Rose Theater and smaller ensembles in the Allen Room. Other events include ''My Audio Biography,'' a retrospective concert by Bobby McFerrin with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra (Sept. 13 to 15); a collaboration between the Bad Plus and the guitarist Bill Frisell (April 12 and 13, 2013); and a performance of ''Blood on the Fields,'' the 1994 oratorio written by Wynton Marsalis, the organization's artistic director (Feb. 21 to 23, 2013). The full schedule is at jalc.org.

Two men and a woman have been arrested in the beating and strangulation death of a Bronx construction worker, the police said Monday. The woman told investigators that she was a prostitute and had been hired by the victim, Gene Lewis, 40, but felt threatened by him and called the men to hurt him. Mr. Lewis's death on Feb. 27 was heard - but not seen - by his elderly landlady, who rented him the second floor of her home on Wellman Avenue, in Middletown in the East Bronx. Her description of the clamor from above was the subject of Saturday's Crime Scene column.

As News Corporation seeks to contain a widening investigation into illegal information gathering at its British publishing unit, the company may face fresh allegations at another problematic subsidiary. News Outdoor Russia, a Moscow-based billboard company that News Corporation sold to a Kremlin-controlled bank in July, is the subject of an F.B.I.inquiry into whether the company bribed local officials to approve favorable sign placements, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday.

YOUNG--Phyllis B.,died on February 28. She had resided in Larchmont, with her husband, W.F. Young, since 1970. Mrs. Young was brought up on an apple orchard in Westport CT and attended Brown University. In New York City she worked as an assistant buyer for Henri Bendel. She did skillful work in watercolors. She is survived by her husband, their son Andrew, his wife Noel, and their three daughters. A memorial service will be held at the Larchmont Avenue Church on March 10th.

The American sweatshop opposition movement was born the day we discovered how our Nikes were stitched together. Two decades later, we are discovering how our cherished iPhones are made, giving Apple a ''Nike moment'' of its own. Worker suicides at Apple's main Chinese supplier, Foxconn, in 2010, followed by reports of forced overtime, child labor, minimum wage violations and unsafe working conditions at its suppliers, have contrasted with Apple's status as creator of hallowed devices and its spectacular $13 billion in profit -- 30 percent of sales -- in the first quarter.

Paulson, above, will now have to make more than 100 percent in investment gains to reclaim the lost ground. AZAM AHMED

MacArthur, president and publisher of Harper's Magazine, is scheduled to speak in May. It is Columbia College Class Day, not the university's commencement.

SCHULMAN--Ruth L. (nee Dunner) On March 5, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Frank Schulman. Loving mother of Marjorie Schulman. Devoted sister of Helene Susswein and Honey Kraemer and also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral services Thursday 12 noon from Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Interment to follow at Union Fields Cemetery.

MELARTIN--Cody Samuel, age 26, of Montclair NJ, died Friday, February 24, after a courageous struggle with a long-term illness. His perseverance and determination to live despite constant debilitating pain were testimony to his strength of character and love of family. Cody will be remembered for his perceptive and sensitive understanding of the world around him, his brilliant sense of humor, his love and compassion for animals, and his thoughtfulness towards others. He had a special place in his heart for his beloved cat, Willy, who pre-deceased him in May, 2011. We all miss Cody terribly, and will forever. Born in Brooklyn Heights NY, Cody attended the St. Ann's preschool for two years, after which he and his family moved to Montclair, where Cody then attended the Montclair public schools. Cody is survived by loving parents, Lisa Waitzman Melartin and Jussi Melartin, adoring sisters Noelle and Lilly, devoted grandparents Barbara Sheerin, Drs. Liisa and Richmond Prehn, and Dr. Erkki Melartin, special uncle Michael Waitzman, caring aunt Riikka Melartin, and a large, loving extended family of aunts, uncles and cousins. Pre-deceased by grandfathers Simon Waitzman and Raymond Sheerin. A memorial service was held March 3rd at the Montclair Unitarian Universalist Congregation. Donations in Cody's memory may be made to the American Migraine Foundation: http://www.americanmigrainefoundation.org.
MINDLIN--Michael. 3/11/23- 3/7/04 Forever loved & greatly missed. Freda

FORNARI--Maria Luisa (nee Della Seta), 92, beloved wife of the late Harry D. Fornari, passed away on March 4, 2012. Prohibited by racial laws from attending college in Italy, she came to the US after WWII, raised a family, earned a BS, and worked for many years as a Board Certified Cytotechnologist at Queens General and Long Island Jewish Hospitals. After retiring, she helped bring recognition by Yad Vashem as "Righteous Among the Nations" for the Ursuline nuns and a family friend who hid her family during the Nazi occupation of Italy. Survived by her devoted family, she was the mother of sons Jim and Daniel; Nonna and friend to Matthew Fornari and his wife, Kimberly, Sasha Fornari, and Simon and his wife Rachel Fornari. Mother-in-law of CL Fornari and Amy Gillenson. Memorial Service to be announced to friends and family. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Great Neck Public Library (http://www.greatnecklibrary.org/).

PRONER--Jacqueline L.,M.D., age 49, of Rye Brook, NY, passed away on March 6, 2012 after a courageous battle with heart disease. Loving wife of Westchester County Legislator, David Gelfarb, beloved mother of Daniel, Lauren and Allison. She also leaves behind her parents, A. Stanley and Viola Proner, brother and sister-in-law Mitchell and Caterina Proner, sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and David Brand, as well as many nieces and nephews. She was blessed with a wonderful marriage and her greatest joy in life was raising her three beautiful children. She was a 1983 graduate of Smith College and 1987 graduate of St. George's University School of Medicine. She was a board certified Allergist and Immunologist, and an officer and director of the New York Allergy Society. She was an accomplished skier and a past member of the National Ski Patrol. Her love, laughter and passion for life will always be remembered. She will be greatly missed and forever in our hearts. Funeral services will be held on Thursday March 8, 1:30pm at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King St., Port Chester, NY.
JACOBSON--Judy, 82, passed on March 5. Beloved wife, mom, nannie, teacher, director, mentor, community leader and inspiration to all.

An article on Tuesday about a fight for control of the Cato Institute, a libertarian policy center, misidentified the news organization that first reported the filing of a lawsuit in the matter last week. It was first mentioned on the Web site of The Washington Post, not on Politico.

DUNNE--Jane Chilson, of Obry Drive, Scarsdale, died of leukemia on March 5th at Calvary Hospital. It was a peaceful death; Jane was surrounded by her loving family. Born in 1934 in NYC, Jane moved at an early age to Scarsdale and called it her home place where she lived with John, her husband of thirty three years, who predeceased her in 1992, and where she nurtured her four sons. A graduate of Skidmore College, Jane was very active in her church, Immaculate Heart of Mary, and for thirty years taught in the parish School of Religion, leading their Confirmation Program, and for ten years taught English to newly arrived immigrants at the Adult Learning Center in New Rochelle. Jane was also a long time member of the Scarsdale Woman's Club. Jane rejoiced in her family and was proud of her sons' lives. She delighted in her grandchildren, her daughters-in-law, her entire family and all their activities. Jane will be remembered by her many friends for her gracious style, and a personality that was both joyful and peaceful. She loved books and she liked laughter, telling stories, listening to her friends' adventures, with a big smile on her face. Jane is survived by her four sons, Tim, John, Tom and Matt, her daughters-in-law Cindy and Anna, by her grandchildren Sean, Maggie, Deirdre and Alekha, her sisters Mary T. Kiley and Nancy Steinmann and will be mourned by her long time caregiver, Lois Tierney. Jane will be waked at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes 824 Scarsdale Avenue Scarsdale (914)725-1137 on Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Post Road, Scarsdale at 10am on Saturday, March 10th. Donations in Jane's name can be made to the Lakota Pine Ridge Childrens' Enrichment Project LTD, PO Box 581, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

LILIENTHAL--Felix, Jr. died March 5, 2012. A life-long resident of New York City, he was 92 years old. Son of Felix and Selma (Goldstein) Lilienthal. He attended Columbia Grammar School and graduated from Dartmouth College class of 1941 where he was captain of the speed skating team. He enlisted in the US Navy December 8, 1941 as a seaman and rose to the rank of Lieutenant serving in the North African Theater during World War II. In 1946 he joined his father at Felix Lilienthal & Co. in New York buying and merchandising for department stores throughout the United States and overseas. He assumed the presidency in 1955 running the company until it closed in 1989. He was a member of the Harmonie Club and a past member of the City Athletic Club and the Fairview Country Club. He is survived by his wife of 41 years Rae Fendler Lilienthal and her children Lynny Steiner, Gene Fendler (Linda), and Jo-Ann Lipman (Josh); her grandchildren Mark Kutash (Jennifer) and Ashley Boisfontaine (Arthur), Julia, Abigail and Benjamin Fendler, and Brooke and Rory Lipman; her great- grandchildren Adeline Kutash and Brandon and Madison Boisfontaine. Private interment at Ferncliff Cemetery March 7.

An article on Tuesday about changing views of the dingo in Australia misstated the region of the country where a ruling is expected in the fourth inquest into the 1980 death of Azaria Chamberlain, whose mother claimed the infant was taken by a dingo. It is the Northern Territory -- not the Northwest Territories, a part of Canada.

An article on Saturday about a dispute between Stephen A. Wynn and Kazuo Okada over the company they formed, Wynn Resorts, misstated the reason for Mr. Okada's leaving the vice chairman's position last October. He was forced out; he did not resign. The article also misstated the disposition of a previous company controlled by Mr. Wynn, Mirage Resorts. It was sold to Kirk Kerkorian's MGM Grand after an unsolicited offer; it did not change hands in a hostile takeover.

It was a welcome addition to the neighborhood, not an out-of-town tryout, when Foragers Market opened in Dumbo, Brooklyn in 2005. But success has led to a larger, more elaborate edition in Manhattan. Foragers City Grocer, which makes its debut on Friday in Chelsea, is a high-quality market, with much of the produce locally sourced and organic (though there will also be Hatch green chiles from New Mexico in season), as well as a fish counter that follows the sustainability guidelines of the Monterey Bay Aquarium. It will also feature an old-fashioned butcher with an aging room. Its eggs -- duck and goose in addition to hen -- will be delivered to the store within 24 hours of being laid. Small upstate farms are providing the milk products. Cheeses will be American-made, and not the usual supermarket brands.

Representative Donald M. Payne, a former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus who achieved a long-held goal of becoming the first black congressman from New Jersey, died on Tuesday in Livingston, N.J. He was 77. The cause was complications of colon cancer, his office said. He died at St. Barnabas Medical Center.

A chart on Feb. 24 about predictions of the winners of Academy Awards omitted a nominee for best adapted screenplay for ''Moneyball.'' Besides Steven Zaillian and Aaron Sorkin, Stan Chervin was also nominated. (Alexander Payne, Nat Faxon and Jim Rash won for the screenplay of ''The Descendants.'')

NEW ORLEANS -- For most city officials here, making plans to evacuate tens of thousands of residents from the wrath of a hurricane brings to mind a tangle of logistics: bus routes, out-of-state shelters, fresh water supplies, public safety. But for one young transplant named Robert X. Fogarty, evacuation means 12-foot-tall sculptures placed strategically around town. Mr. Fogarty, 28, a Nebraska native who came to New Orleans five years ago as an AmeriCorps volunteer, is still volunteering, as the head of the nonprofit Evacuteer.org, an organization that recruits, trains and manages an army of about 350 volunteers every year to evacuate the city in case of a hurricane.
A film review on Saturday about ''Tim & Eric's Billion Dollar Movie'' reversed the roles of two actors, who play themselves. Eric Wareheim falls in love, and Tim Heidecker adopts a boy.

WASHINGTON -- Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee was surrounded by a gaggle of constituents on Tuesday like a quarterback in a huddle, finishing a discourse on his commitment to stopping Iran from developing nuclear weapons. Andrew Groveman, a real estate developer from Memphis, was leading the group of delegates from an Israel lobbying group, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, through meetings on Capitol Hill. ''As you know,'' Mr. Groveman said, ''we always have three points.''

LIEBRAND--Jerome T.,age 84, formerly of East Lyme, CT, beloved husband of the late Catherine Carroll Liebrand, entered into eternal rest on Monday, March 5, 2012. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Liebrand had lived in Farmingdale, NY for many years before moving to East Lyme over twenty years ago. Mr. Liebrand was a Veteran of WWII serving in the U.S. Navy. He had worked for the Pfizer Corporation for nearly forty years until his retirement. Random House will mark John Updike's birthday this month with the re-release of some of his most beloved works, including the ''Rabbit'' series, the publisher said on Tuesday. Mr. Updike, who was born on March 18, 1932, died in 2009 after a career that produced 60 books as well as essays, criticism and poetry. Random House will also release e-book editions of the entire backlist of Mr. Updike's work, most of which has never appeared in e-book format. A posthumous essay collection, ''Higher Gossip,'' will appear in paperback for the first time.

Washington can take occasional breaks from politics this fall when the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opens its 42nd season. On Tuesday, Michael M. Kaiser, the center's president, unveiled highlights of the 2012-2013 program, which include celebrations of Woody Guthrie's and Bob Marley's music; a new production of Fernec Molnár's ''Guardsman,'' adapted by Richard Nelson and directed by Gregory Mosher; debuts of Lar Lubovitch Dance Company; a new production of ''Show Boat'' by the Washington National Opera; a weeklong residency with Chinese pianist Lang Lang; and the comedian David Alan Grier. From Feb. 19 to Mar. 17, 2013, the center will present a Nordic festival featuring not only the arts of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden, but also their food and Nobel laureates. Among the performers are Norway's National Theater and ice percussionist Terje Isungset, the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra, the Danish Dance Theater, and the jazz pianist Víkingur Olafsson of Iceland.

The New York Philharmonic appeared to have scored a coup nearly a year ago when Ricardo Morales, the stand-out principal clarinetist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, agreed to jump ship. Now, the Philharmonic said he has changed his mind. The orchestra announced on Monday that Mr. Morales, who was to have started in the position in September, has decided to stay in Philadelphia ''for family reasons.'' Mr. Morales' departure from the Philadelphia Orchestra had been seen as another blow for an institution that had filed for bankruptcy protection. He had played a few concerts in New York since the Philharmonic said they had signed a contract in April. The critical position of first clarinet at the Philharmonic will now continue to be vacant, as it has been since the end of the 2008 season.

Making his first spring training appearance of the year, Santana faced seven St. Louis Cardinals batters over two innings Tuesday. He threw 29 pitches, 17 of them for strikes, and continued his slow, steady recovery from surgery to repair a torn capsule in his shoulder in 2010.

Spring 1989 would not have seemed like the ideal moment to celebrate gay sex. The number of AIDS cases reported to the Centers for Disease Control was about to reach 100,000. (It had taken seven years for the first 50,000 to accumulate; a year and a half for the next 50,000.) Most cases involved gay or bisexual men. The artist Keith Haring, 31, was one of those men. And he was nine months away from death.

Call it the curse of the chief executive. Powerful, visionary chiefs can create billion-dollar brands. Steven Jobs at Apple and Mark Zuckerberg at Facebook are often-cited examples. But we've recently seen some illustrations in the takeover world of the dark side of the chief executive. Being powerful and visionary, or at least thinking you are, can lead corporate chieftains to great heights, but also to extreme narcissism. And the victims are often shareholders.

If it doesn't include new works from James Franco and Harmony Korine, is it really a film festival? The organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival will not have to contend with that existential question this year: among the offerings announced on Tuesday as part of its 2012 lineup are ''Francophrenia (or: Don't Kill Me, I Know Where the Baby Is),'' a hybrid documentary/fiction feature directed by Mr. Franco and Ian Olds, and ''The Fourth Dimension,'' directed by Mr. Korine, Alexey Fedorchenko and Jan Kwiecinski. ''Francophenia,'' which was shot during one of Mr. Franco's stints on ''General Hospital,'' turns his behind-the-scenes footage into ''an experimental psychological thriller set amid the spectacle of a celebrity's escalating paranoia,'' according to the festival's description of the film. ''The Fourth Dimension'' combines three short films about a group of friends in Poland; a Russian scientist building a time machine; and a motivational speaker named Val Kilmer (and played by the actor Val Kilmer) who are all seeking a mysterious plane of existence. Both films will be shown out of competition as part of the festival's Viewpoints program.

An article on Nov. 2, 2011, about changes in charitable giving referred imprecisely to a statement about active philanthropy by Dr. Gary Michelson, a philanthropist. Dr. Michelson's view is that active philanthropy that creates structural change provides greater long-term benefits than passive donations of money. Dr. Michelson did not describe any form of giving as not fulfilling.

Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago announced plans on Tuesday to produce a new drama by Tarell Alvin McCraney, the author of the critically acclaimed ''Brother/Sister Plays,'' and four other works as part of its 2012-13 season. Steppenwolf executives said that the new McCraney play, ''Head of Passes,'' is rendered in his ''signature style,'' which mixes prose and poetry and often features characters speaking in the third person about actions they are about to take. The play, set at the mouth of the Mississippi River, centers on a family birthday party that becomes overshadowed by secrets exposed from the past; Tina Landau, who previously directed ''The Brother/Sister Plays'' at Steppenwolf (and co-directed the work at the Public Theater in 2009), will stage the new play, which is scheduled to run April 4-June 9.

One of the many pleasures of going to art galleries regularly is that in addition to the formal exhibitions up front, art dealers often display unexpected gems off to the side, in project spaces, offices or even behind the reception desk: lost bits of history and unfamiliar early works by this or that artist. Recently, in the lull before the onslaught of this week's art fairs, one of these isolated treasures provided a useful reminder about close looking. On a visit to the George Adams Gallery in Chelsea, I came across a smallish work that Mr. Adams has put on view in a side gallery: a smooth, darkish painting of a female nude asleep on an empty beach, with the nose of a small sailboat nudging in from the right side. Mr. Adams invited me to guess its maker.

An article on Thursday about the arrest of Don Vaccaro, chief executive of TicketNetwork, an online reseller of entertainment tickets, misstated New York State's law on paperless tickets. The law says that ticket sellers who wish to sell paperless tickets must offer consumers an alternative in a form that is transferrable -- a requirement that has had the effect of curbing paperless tickets. It is not the case that paperless ticketing is banned.

ROSTOV--Dorothy Brenner, died peacefully at her home in Greenwich, CT on March 2, 2012. She was 90 years old. Her caring daughters Terry Heinzmann and Jan Rostov were by her side. Dorothy was born on June 11, 1921 in New York City, the daughter of Philip and Esther Brenner. A world traveler, she first journeyed overseas to Japan at the age of 13. In September 1972, Dorothy and her adoring late husband Charles were among the first 50 private US citizens to visit the People's Republic of China seven months after relations were re-established. An inveterate seeker, she hiked throughout Nepal, journeyed to Lhasa, traversed the Khyber Pass, climbed Mt. Kilimanjaro and swam off the coast of Borneo. She lived a full life exploring uncovered corners of the world, all while raising her two daughters and her son, Gene. Dorothy pursued much: she diligently played the flute, skied black diamond runs, sculpted life into stone, played a fierce net game in doubles tennis, made hollandaise sauce the old fashioned way and entertained with the grace of a bygone era. A graduate of Goucher College who then attended the Yale School of Drama, Dorothy was an ardent lover of the arts as student, viewer, volunteer, collector and philanthropist. Most treasured was her house and farm in southern Vermont that, with Charles, she re-designed and brought back to life: some of her greatest joys over her last forty-two years were here. In addition to her three children, Dorothy leaves behind two sisters, Suzanne Geller of La Jolla, CA and Greta Rosen of Weston, MA, a brother-in-law Jerome Rosen, her grandson Eli Kutler who is following his grandmother's world-traveling ways, her son-in-law John David Heinzmann and daughter-in-law Heather Knapp along with many nieces and nephews. Interment will be private. The family encourages contributions to The Center for Healthy Aging (c/o The Greenwich Hospital Foundation, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830), whose staff skillfully helped Dorothy navigate her later years.

DORAL, Fla. - In what amounts to the first golfing upset of the 2016 Summer Olympics, Jack Nicklaus, Annika Sorenstam, Greg Norman, Lorena Ochoa and Gary Player lost out to Amy Alcott in the competition to design the course for the Rio de Janeiro Games. The Games' organizers announced Wednesday that they had selected the American architect Gil Hanse of Hanse Golf Design, who will team up with Alcott on the project. They were selected over seven other finalists, including Gary Player Design, Greg Norman Golf Course Design, Hawtree Ltd., Nicklaus Design, Renaissance Golf, Robert Trent Jones II and Thomson-Perret Golf Course Architects.

His Eminence Cardinal Dolan will officiate. Interment Sea View Cemetery, Mt. Sinai, NY. Memorial donations may be made in Fr. Hammer's name to Manhattan College (call 718-562-7582). For condolences: www.greenwichvillagefuneralhome.com.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Representative Donald M. Payne, the first black congressman from New Jersey, referred incorrectly to his membership in the Congressional Black Caucus. He was a member from the time he joined Congress, in 1989, until his death -- not just from 1995 to 1997. (Those were the years he was chairman of the caucus.)

Three weeks after the Grammy Awards, Adele and Whitney Houston are still dominating the music charts. Adele's juggernaut, ''21'' (XL/Columbia), which took six prizes, is once again No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with 247,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album, which has been No. 1 for 23 of its 54 weeks of release, has sold almost 1.3 million copies since the Grammys. Her first album, ''19,'' has also been benefiting. It holds at No. 7 this week with 37,000.

AT&T last week clarified the limitations of its ''unlimited'' data plan. After you use a certain number gigabytes, your smartphone's Internet speed is subject to being slowed down, a practice known as throttling. Just how much you will be slowed down is a mystery, but people who have been throttled say their Internet connections became so slow they were unusable. For customers with smartphones that work with AT&T's third-generation networks, you can use up to three gigabytes of data before your Internet transfer speeds may be reduced, AT&T says. If you own a newer phone that works with the fourth-generation network, you get five gigabytes before you are throttled. When the slower speeds kick in, they last for the remainder of the billing cycle.

THE latest collaboration that the mega-retailer Uniqlo has up its sleeve is Uniqlo Undercover, designed by Jun Takahashi of the cult fashion label Undercover. The UU collection is based on the idea of a day in the life of a modern family, depicted in an ad campaign with stylized images of a family dressed casual-cool at the movies, on a picnic and the like. The adult pieces are a tweak on the neutral basics Undercover is known for: a motorcycle jacket with sweatshirt sleeves for men, a cropped trench with an animal-print collar for women, windbreakers with multiple zips. But it is the things for youngsters, Uniqlo's first foray into children's wear (which Mr. Takahashi designed with this wife, Rico), that are standouts. The little print raincoats, bloomer shorts, striped leggings and a mini-me version of the moto jacket, at Uniqlo prices, are close to irresistible. Available at the three Uniqlo
Jazz at Lincoln Center

She is survived by her children Ben (and Susan) Stein, Henry (and Sherry) Stein, Bella (and George) Savran, Shelley (and Chick) Paradis, Nanette (and Arthur) Brenner, and 16 grandchildren, great grandchildren, and her brother-in-law and sister-in-law, YU Benefactors Sam and Gladys Halpern, many nieces and nephews. May all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. YESHIVA UNIVERSITY Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

IF you're still on the fence about the floral prints that are so bountiful this season, start simple: a pencil skirt in a blossoming pattern as a sophisticated statement piece. To keep the look fresh, think about mixing prints: a small one with something splashier. Or match a floral bottom with a simpler pattern that is familiar to the eye: leopard spots, houndstooth, polka dots -- or a scarf print, as in this look from Zara. Then break up the patterns with a leather jacket or trench. From left: Zara floral-print pencil skirt, $59.50 (and blouse, $59.50) at Zara, zara.com; Versace cotton-spandex tropical print, $740 at stylebop.com; Rochas silk-blend pastel midi, $1,335 at net-a-porter.com; Tibi cotton print, $275 at Tibi, 120 Wooster Street, tibi.com.

Siri is perfectly lovely bit of artificial intelligence, but she isn't always cooperative. Ask Siri to book airplane tickets, make a dinner reservation or find a song on Pandora, and she politely declines. This is where Dragon Go comes in. It's a less personable but more capable app for people who like to speak instructions to the phone.

The former child star Raven-Symoné (''The Cosby Show'') will take over the lead role of disco singer Deloris Van Cartier in the Broadway musical ''Sister Act'' on March 27, the show's producers announced on Wednesday. Raven, as she is known, will replace Patina Miller, who was nominated for a Tony Award last year for her performance, and who will depart the musical on March 18. Raven, 26, played the young girl Olivia on ''The Cosby Show'' in the late 1980s and early '90s, and then had a featured role in the television series ''Hangin' with Mr. Cooper'' and starred more recently in ''That's So Raven'' and ''State of Georgia'' while also recording several albums. She will be making her Broadway debut in ''Sister Act,'' a musical adaptation of the 1992 movie starring Whoopi Goldberg as Deloris, a woman who - while on the run from killers - hides out in a convent and turns a choir of nuns into a hit act.

Kopff--Frederick III, died on March 3, 2012. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 6, 1944. Mr. Kopff graduated from Washington & Jefferson College. Fred founded Meta/Mat Ltd., a consulting firm. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Linda, as well as his two sons, Derick and Thomas, and their families. Memorial scheduled for 3pm on Saturday March 10, at West Side Presbyterian Church, Ridgewood, NJ.

Q. I used TurboTax's iPad app to do my taxes. It works well, but I need to print out the return for my records. If I don't have a wireless printer, how would I do that? It suggests sending the document to iTunes. Is that safe? Can I print it from there?

Mike Nichols has been a pre-eminent director in both theater and film since the 1960s. He has taken home a staggering seven Tony awards as best director, for work ranging from four Neil Simon comedies to Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing'' to the musical ''Spamalot.'' His movie career has spanned an equally wide range, from his debut with ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and the countercultural landmarks ''The Graduate'' (for which he won an Oscar) and ''Catch-22'' to popular comedies like ''Working Girl'' and ''The Birdcage.'' His fluency and popularity in both stage and film echo that of Elia Kazan, who was the foremost stage director of his generation, known for his work with both Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller, and a successful film director too. There are other parallels: Both men began their careers as actors before moving into directing. Mr. Nichols is now directing the new Broadway revival of ''Death of a Salesman,'' one of Kazan's signature works along with ''A Streetcar Named Desire.''

BALL--Dr. Eleanor Halpern (Ellie) passed away on March 4, 2012 in her home in Short Hills, New Jersey at the age of 77 after a 22 year battle with Parkinson's disease. She was born in New York City in 1934 and grew up in Borough Park, Brooklyn, the only child of immigrants Leah Tepper and Abraham Halpern. She excelled at school and graduated at the top of her class from Brooklyn College in 1956. She started medical school at New York University in 1958, one of 12 women among an entering class of 125. On the first day of school she met Charles Ball, a fellow student, when they were assigned as cadaver partners. Ellie and Charlie were married in 1961. While a resident in dermatology at NYU-Bellevue, also in New York City, Ellie gave birth to sons Thomas and Julian in 1965 and 1967, respectively. She practiced dermatology in Summit, New Jersey from the early 1970s until her retirement in 1992. Outside of work Ellie had many interests and pursued them avidly. First and foremost, Ellie was truly interested in people and getting to know them better. She was unfailingly kind and polite, taking a positive interest in peoples' lives and problems. Ellie had a musical spirit: She played the piano, had a beautiful soprano voice, and regularly attended concerts and operas in New York City. Ellie was a fantastic cook and hostess. She was the master chef in her kitchen, which eventually was renovated with counters to perfectly match her height. She had an excellent eye for art, design and fashion, which she applied to renovating the family's home on Summit Avenue in Summit, NJ over the course of many years. She always dressed beautifully and became very involved in drawing and painting later in life. Ellie took great joy in her grandchildren, David and Lauren Ball. Later in her life, Ellie was blessed with a new family. Her caregiver Marisa Vieira and Marisa's children, Andre and Danielle, moved in to live with Ellie and Charlie in their home in Short Hills. Marisa and her children provided Ellie with a new source of joy and love, without which her later life would have been immeasurably poorer. Ellie is survived by her husband and sons. A private gathering will be held to celebrate Ellie's life and achievements. Contributions in memory of Dr. Eleanor H. Ball can be sent to the National Parkinson Foundation or the New York University Medical School.

ABRAMSON--Albert. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its long time member, Albert Abramson, and extends sincere sympathy to his children, grandchildren and other members of his family. Arthur S. Loring, President Alan Curtis, Secretary

It's a little late in the game to worry about anticorruption measures because what in the world is the alternative going to be? If you find people who aren't corrupt it is largely because they haven't had the opportunity. ANTHONY H. CORDESMAN, a defense expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, on the corruption that pervades Afghanistan's business and political elite. [A8]

An obituary on Feb. 24 about Pierre Juneau, who as head of a Canadian broadcast commission helped create Canada's pop music industry by requiring radio stations to broadcast more Canadian music, misstated the year Brian Mulroney became prime minister. It was 1984, not 1982.

Plans for a public memorial service for Davy Jones, the singer with the Monkees who died of a heart attack last week, are still up in the air. Mr. Jones's family members have cremated his body and are holding a private service this week near his home in Florida, his publicist, Helen Kensick, said on Wednesday. The Hollywood Reporter said the funeral would be held on Wednesday, but Ms. Kensick declined to confirm that report. ''No one but the immediate family is attending,'' she said.

SCHENSUL--Bernard S.,loving husband of Ruth (Landy), caring father of Avis Gartin, devoted stepfather of Pamela Schachter and Hal Landy and cherished step-grandfather of Lisa (Steve), Robert, Alex, Steve and Mark, passed away on March 7, 2012, at the age of 88. A veteran of World War II and the Battle of the Bulge, Bernard was an ardent supporter of "Veterans for Peace". He was an avid amateur photographer and showed locally on occasion. Nature was a common subject but he had a special eye for unusual man-made objects which he shot with irony and whimsy. Music and literature were an integral part of his life and his drive for knowledge was unbounded. Bernard's wit and insight, especially regarding social issues, will be sorely missed by those who knew him best.

Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder are more likely to be prescribed opioid pain killers than other veterans with pain problems and more likely to use the opioids in risky ways, according to a study published Wednesday by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, also found that veterans returning from Iraq and Afghanistan who were prescribed opioids for pain - and particularly those with post-traumatic stress disorder -- had a higher prevalence of ''adverse clinical outcomes,'' like overdoses, self-inflicted injuries and injuries caused by accidents or fighting.

To the Editor: Re ''Relaxing at Home'' (Skin Deep, March 1): I hope Marisa Meltzer was speaking tongue-in-cheek when she wrote that ''even the most self-accepting curly haired woman'' secretly longs for the product that will ''magically straighten'' hair. I don't, and neither do other curly haired women I know. I've had curly hair all my life, and I like it. Sure, a different hairstyle makes some people feel temporarily prettier or sexier or more sleek. There's nothing wrong with that. But it's just hair, folks.

LONDON -- Anshu Jain, the incoming co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, is moving quickly to put in place his own management team in advance of his assuming joint control of the German banking giant on June 1. The longtime head of Deutsche's profit engine -- its corporate and investment banking business -- intends to appoint two investment bankers to replace him, according to a person with direct knowledge of the decision. They are Colin Fan, from the emerging-markets division of the bank, who will oversee sales and trading, and Robert Rankin, a former UBS executive who was the bank's Asia head and now will lead the origination and advisory businesses.

LONDON - It's hard to tell sometimes who is calling the shots at the Royal Bank of Scotland: management or politicians. When Britain bailed out the financial firm in 2008 and took a majority stake, the government promised to remain a passive investor. But some employees and analysts now say the line has blurred, as politicians push the bank to rein in executive compensation, bolster lending and limit risky businesses.

The celebrity chef and restaurateur Mario Batali and a business partner have agreed to pay $5.25 million to resolve a lawsuit filed on behalf of waiters, captains and other employees who claimed that his restaurants had illegally confiscated part of their tips to supplement their profits, court papers show. The proposed class-action settlement, which must be approved by a judge, could cover about 1,100 employees, including servers, busboys, runners and bartenders who worked at the restaurants, in some cases as far back as 2004, according to a filing made Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The suit is similar to others that have been brought in the past few years claiming labor violations by high-profile chefs and restaurants in New York and elsewhere.

WALLMAN--Joshua, on March 3, 2012. Neurobiologist at City College, the City University of New York. Beloved husband of Valerie Stalvey. Loving brother of Carl and so important to countless dear friends.
To the Editor: Re ''One is the Quirkiest Number'' by Steven Kurutz (Feb. 23):

The AirStash A02 by Maxell is an odd duck. It's basically a little USB-powered Wi-Fi hot spot with on-board storage. Using a related iPhone or iPad app, you can view the files stored on the AirStash - music, documents, photos, and movies - essentially adding up to 32GB of extra storage to your phone or tablet. The device is about as big as a pack of gum and has a single button that turns it on and off. A built-in SD card reader lets you add and remove storage. Using the AirStash app, you connect to the device and start adding and removing files. You can charge the A02 using any USB port and it shows up as a storage device when plugged into a computer.

AS befits a venerable Italian eyewear company, Persol is paying tribute to Capri and its architecture with a new style of sunglasses. The company (the name comes from per il sole, meaning ''for the sun'') drew on architectural details of the Casa Malaparte, a 1930s cliffside villa overlooking the Mediterranean, to redesign the trademark silver arrows, flexible hinges and etchings at the temple of its frames to reflect the shape of the house. For all that, the best part may be the range of electric colors, like island green and blue. Persol Capri Edition sunglasses, $310 at Sunglass Hut; sunglasshut.com.

The On Baseball column on Tuesday, about Jed Lowrie and Kyle Weiland, former Boston Red Sox players who were acquired by the Houston Astros, misstated the number of games the Astros lost last season. It was 106, not 100.
MITZNER--Alexander. Always in our hearts and minds. Your Family

PECHET--Maurice M.,Ph.D., M.D., of Cambridge, Massachusetts, died in his sleep on March 5 during his 95th year. He was a teacher, physician, scientist, beloved father and husband of 51 years. Originally from a trading post in Saskatchewan, Canada, he spent 70 years at Harvard University, earning a Ph.D. in chemistry in 1944 and an M.D. in 1948, and devoting the rest of his career to teaching and science. He held a number of posts on the faculty at Harvard University and Harvard Medical School. As a consistent presence at Harvard's Lowell House for decades, he mentored generations of students and biochemists. As a physician and endocrinologist, he cared deeply for his patients and served on the staff at Massachusetts General Hospital for over half a century. As a scientist, he published over 100 papers and contributed many new synthetic processes including a revolutionary process for fluorination used to create 5-Fluorouracil, still widely used in the treatment of cancer. His work was the foundation for much of modern steroid chemistry, including the synthesis of Aldosterone, which is important in the early understanding of the endocrine system and the development of Prednisone, which is still used throughout the world for treatment of myriad conditions. He devoted decades to his research on Vitamin D synthesis and metabolism. As a philanthropist, he gave generously of his time and money. Along with his wife, Kitty, he has been a major patron of the arts, supporting Marlboro Music School, the New England Conservatory of Music, the Longy School of Music, the Danforth Museum, and the Signet Society among others. He served as a Police Surgeon for the Cambridge Police Department. His passion was education where his support ranged from helping individual students travel and study through more than half a century of support for Harvard University. A memorial service will be held on March 9th from 5:00-7:00pm in the Lowell House Junior Common Room, 10 Holyoke Place, Cambridge, MA. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to contribute are asked to make a donation to the Maurice Pechet Fund for Lowell House, payable to Harvard University and sent to the Lowell House Office, Lowell A22, 10 Holyoke Street, Cambridge MA 02138.

BERK--Alan. The David and Minnie Berk Foundation notes with sorrow the passing of Alan Berk, its long-time Trustee whose many charitable works will continue to honor his memory. The Board extends its heartfelt condolences to the family, his loving wife Susan, children Debbie and Donald, stepchildren, grandchildren and step-grandchildren.

On its way to the public markets, Facebook is raising a huge war chest. In an updated prospectus filed on Wednesday, Facebook said it had effectively doubled its credit facility to $5 billion. It has also secured a $3 billion bridge loan, to help set aside money for costs associated with the vesting of employee stock.

KURNOS--Shirley. It's with the deepest regret we mourn the passing of our most dear and beloved friend, Mrs. Shirley Kurnos. Our love and deepest sympathies go out to Phil, Ken, Karen and the entire Kurnos family. Madelyn and Fred Freundlich

5:11 p.m. | Updated Prosecutors in the Bronx on Wednesday dropped several criminal charges against a 19-year-old man whose beating at the hands of police officers in January was described as ''troubling'' by New York's police commissioner. The move by the office of the Bronx district attorney,Robert T. Johnson, means that a civil lawsuit expected to be filed against the Police Department on behalf of the teenager, Jateik Reed, can move forward, according to Mr. Reed's lawyers. A notice of claim in that matter would be filed within weeks, the lawyers said.

The Rangers confirmed Wednesday that Sean Avery had been told he will be left off the postseason roster of the Connecticut Whale, their A.H.L. affiliate. This would effectively end Avery's tenure with the organization. Avery, an agitator who was a favorite with Rangers fans but often irked Coach John Tortorella, Rangers management and many N.H.L. opponents, has not played a game with the Whale since Jan. 27. He practiced with the team up until last week.

ZOLLER--Eleanor Coleburn, of Laurel Hollow, NY, passed away on March 3, 2012 at the age of 91. Her husband, Dr. Philip A. Zoller and her sister, Carolyn predeceased her. she was born in Norwalk, Connecticut until she attended Skidmore College. After graduating in 1941, she was faculty secretary to Skidmore's Department of Nursing in New York City for several years. Ellie resided in Cove Neck, New York for fifty years, during which time she volunteered and served on the board of Raynham Hall Museum. She was a proud member of the Daughters of the American Revolution. She passed away peacefully surrounded by her family. During her life Ellie had a passion for gardening, particularly orchids. She was a loving mother, sister and grandmother. She is survived by her brother Kenneth M. Coleburn (Carolyn) and her children: Dr. Philip A. Zoller, Jr. (Christianne), Thomas R. Zoller (Kathryn), Carolyn Z. Ritter (John), Dr. Robert C. Zoller (Janet), and six grandchildren; Jon, Alice, Kathryn, Rachel, Rebecca and Thomas. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Raynham Hall Museum, 20 West Main St., Oyster Bay, NY, 11771. Visiting Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St., Oyster Bay, NY, Friday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Interment Brookville Cemetery, Saturday 11:00am. oysterbayfuneralhome.com

The New York City Ballet's spring benefit will have more than its usual share of French glamour and celebrity chic. The gala, to be held on May 10, will have a French theme, the company announced on Wednesday, and will feature the world premieres of two ballets. Peter Martins, the company's ballet master in chief, will choreograph a work to a score by the French composer Marc-André Dalbavie, and the French choreographer and former principal dancer Benjamin Millepied will stage the debut of a piece set to a commission by the young contemporary classical composer Nico Muhly, their fourth collaboration. Mr. Millepied's fiancée, the actress Natalie Portman - they met when both were working on ''Black Swan'' - will serve as an honorary chairwoman of the event, which will also feature costumes by Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte (who did the ballet costumes for the Oscar-winning ''Black Swan'') and Gilles Mendel of the fashion house J. Mendel. The evening will include a revival of George Balanchine's ''Symphony in C,'' with a score by Georges Bizet, first performed at the Paris Opera Ballet in 1947, and with new costume designs by City Ballet's director of costumes Marc Happel in collaboration with Swarovski.

8:30 P.M. (HBO) SAVING FACE (2011) In Pakistan throwing acid on women to disfigure them is an alarmingly common form of revenge, often for rejected sexual advances or marriage proposals. The victims are left physically and emotionally scarred, with little or no access to reconstructive surgery, while the assailants, typically husbands or someone else close to the victim, are frequently released with minimal punishment. In this Oscar-winning short documentary Daniel Junge and Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy tell the stories of two women -- 39-year-old Zakia, above, whose husband threw acid on her after she filed for divorce, and Rukhsana, 25, whose husband and in-laws threw acid and gasoline on her, then set her on fire -- as they seek justice with the help of the Acid Survivors Foundation in Islamabad and Dr. Mohammad Jawad, a Pakistani-born plastic surgeon who stepped away from his London practice to help victims of what he called society's disease. The film also follows the push for stricter sentencing laws for attacks on the women whom Rukhsana calls ''the living dead.'' 6 A.M. (Sundance) AMREEKA (2009) Nisreen Faour, below, plays Muna Farah, a divorced Palestinian with a green card who at the outset of the invasion of Iraq in 2003 forsakes a relatively comfortable existence to travel to America with her 16-year-old son, Fadi (Melkar Muallem). The result is an exercise in confronting hostility and prejudice. Writing in The New York Times about this film from Cherien Dabis, a Palestinian-Jordanian whose parents moved to the United States before she was born, Stephen Holden said, '' 'Amreeka' (the Arabic word for America) stands alongside 'The Visitor' and 'Maria Full of Grace' as one of the most accomplished recent films about a non-European immigrant coming to the United States.''

VICTOR--Sondra Sarrow, age 76, died peacefully on March 7th, 2012 at her home after a long and courageous battle against Alzheimer's disease. An exquisite beauty, she lived a full, wonderful life, and was the proud matriarch of an adoring family. Beloved wife of Saul, devoted sister of Ellen. Dear mother of Donald and Eve, Alison, and Pamela; stepmother of Jonathan and Rosemarie, and Karen and Bob. Loving grandmother of Hilary and Pete, Joshua and Lisa, Max David, Stefanie and Julian, Alex, Adam, Rachel and Aaron. Funeral service at Plaza Funeral Home on Friday, March 9, at 12:30pm. Donations may be made in Sondra's memory to the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter. Shiva will be held Saturday evening 7:00pm until 9:00pm, Sunday 2:00pm until 7:00pm and Monday 4:00pm until 9:00pm at 241 Central Park West.

President Obama won the Democratic primary in Oklahoma with 57 percent of the vote on Tuesday, but it appears that a surprising showing by the anti-abortion advocate Randall Terry will cost the president one of the state's 45 delegates to the party's national convention. Mr. Terry, the founder of Operation Rescue, won 18 percent of the vote Tuesday in Oklahoma's Democratic primary, beating Mr. Obama in more than a dozen mostly rural counties across the state, according to unofficial election results.

It was not as if the New York health department had threatened the city's 24,000 restaurateurs with posting a scarlet letter - or even a skull and crossbones - in their windows. But dozens of restaurant operators descended on City Hall on Wednesday to vent their ire at the letter-grading system inaugurated 19 months ago by the department to promote food safety. A crowd of more than 300 people jammed the Council chamber and more than 80 had signed up to testify at a hearing on the city's grading system.
RUBIN--Benjamin A. 9/27/17-3 / 8/ 2010. Always with me. Mae

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a large lobbying effort on Capitol Hill Tuesday by delegates to the annual conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee referred incorrectly to the organization, known as Aipac. It is a pro-Israel lobbying group that works in the United States to advance Israel's interests. It does not work directly for the state of Israel or its government.

Before she was the creator and star of the coming HBO comedy ''Girls'' or the one-woman film-making bandwagon behind ''Tiny Furniture,'' Lena Dunham watched a lot of movies. They formed her authorial voice and directorial sensibility, but more to the point they gave her plenty of options for a weeklong series she has organized for April at BAMcinématek, the film program of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The series, called ''Hey Girlfriend! Lena Dunham Selects,'' will run April 2 to 8 and will feature eight films, ranging from independent works like ''Girlfriends,'' the 1978 directorial debut of Claudia Weill, to 1990s crowd pleasers like ''Clueless'' and ''The Craft.'' Her guiding principle, Ms. Dunham said in a telephone interview, is that she has chosen films ''about female relationships that are complex.'' She added: ''That's broad, but it's pretty specific in that you don't see it all the time.'' The series's opening-night screening will be ''This Is My Life,'' the 1992 directorial debut of Nora Ephron, which stars Julie Kavner as an aspiring stand-up comic raising two daughters.

The Economic Scene column on Wednesday, about Apple's responsibility for ensuring fair wages and safe workplace conditions at foreign factories that make its products, misidentified the institution with which Nicholas Lardy, an expert on China's economy, is affiliated. He is with the Peterson Institute for International Economics -- not the Brookings Institution, which he left in 2003.

Eager to preserve their majority in the Senate, Democrats are rolling the dice in Maine on a popular independent former governor who is seeking Senator Olympia J. Snowe's seat, in the hope that he sides with them next year if elected. On Wednesday, Representative Chellie Pingree, a Democrat, announced that she would not run to succeed Ms. Stowe, a moderate Republican who announced last week that she would not run for re-election. Another Democrat, former Gov. John Baldacci, may still run, but party strategists say Ms. Pingree was their strongest candidate.

If there were any lingering doubts about who Matt Drudge wants to win the Republican nomination, his Web site's homepage should dispel them. There, front and center, is a picture of a triumphant Mitt Romney holding an Olympic torch. Just one word appears below the photo.

Florence Wolfson Howitt, whose lifelong dream of recognition as a writer eluded her until she was in her 90s, when the diary she had kept as a teenager was found in a Dumpster and became the subject of a newspaper article and a widely publicized book, died on Tuesday at her home in Pompano Beach, Fla. She was 96. Her daughter Valerie Fischel confirmed her death.

Judy Blume books, those dog-eared paperbacks that have taught children and teenagers about the mysterious parts of growing up for more than four decades, will be released in e-book format, her publisher said on Wednesday. Beginning on Mar. 21, 13 of Ms. Blume's books, including ''Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret,'' ''Blubber'' and ''Starring Sally J. Freedman as Herself,'' will go on sale, published by Random House Children's Books. With their frank discussions of sex, class, divorce and puberty, Ms. Blume's books carried a universal appeal among younger readers, but were often dismissed by librarians and teachers, keeping them on banned books lists for years.

LONDON - It's hard to tell sometimes who is calling the shots at the Royal Bank of Scotland: management or politicians. When Britain bailed out the financial firm in 2008 and took a majority stake, the government promised to remain a passive investor. But some employees and analysts now say the line has blurred, as politicians push the bank to rein in executive compensation, bolster lending and limit risky businesses.

DUNNE--Jane Chilson, of Obry Drive, Scarsdale, died of leukemia on March 5th at Calvary Hospital. It was a peaceful death; Jane was surrounded by her loving family. Born in 1934 in NYC, Jane moved at an early age to Scarsdale and called it her home place where she lived with John, her husband of thirty three years, who predeceased her in 1992, and where she nurtured her four sons. A graduate of Skidmore College, Jane was very active in her church, Immaculate Heart of Mary, and for thirty years taught in the parish School of Religion, leading their Confirmation Program, and for ten years taught English to newly arrived immigrants at the Adult Learning Center in New Rochelle. Jane was also a long time member of the Scarsdale Woman's Club. Jane rejoiced in her family and was proud of her sons' lives. She delighted in her grandchildren, her daughters-in-law, her entire family and all their activities. Jane will be remembered by her many friends for her gracious style, and a personality that was both joyful and peaceful. She loved books and she liked laughter, telling stories, listening to her friends' adventures, with a big smile on her face. Jane is survived by her four sons, Tim, John, Tom and Matt, her daughters-in-law Cindy and Anna, by her grandchildren Sean, Maggie, Deirdre and Alekha, her sisters Mary T. Kiley and Nancy Steinmann and will be mourned by her long time caregiver, Lois Tierney. Jane will be waked at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes 824 Scarsdale Avenue Scarsdale (914)725-1137 on Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Post Road, Scarsdale at 10am on Saturday, March 10th. Donations in Jane's name can be made to the Lakota Pine Ridge Childrens' Enrichment Project LTD, PO Box 581, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

New films from Julie Delpy, Marjane Satrapi, Morgan Spurlock, Michael Winterbottom and Terry George are among the works that will be shown at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. Some of the films in the festival's Spotlight lineup are ''2 Days in New York,'' Ms. Delpy's follow-up to her 2007 film, ''2 Days in Paris,'' starring Ms. Delpy and Chris Rock as a lover meeting her family for the first time; ''Chicken With Plums'' (''Poulet aux Prunes''), a live-action feature about an Iranian violinist from Ms. Satrapi (''Persepolis'') and Vincent Paronnaud; Mr. Spurlock's new documentary, ''Mansome,'' an exploration of masculinity, body image and facial hair; ''Trishna,'' Mr. Winterbottom's adaptation of ''Tess of the d'Urbervilles,'' relocated to present-day India and starring Freida Pinto; and ''Whole Lotta Sole,'' by Mr. George (''Hotel Rwanda''), a crime comedy about a Belfast man's robbery at a fish market. The festival runs from April 18 through 29. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ZWILLINGER--Sandra Rudel. On Wednesday, March 7, 2012. One of the first and most prominent female executives on Wall Street in the 1970's, and a senior partner of Gruntal & Co. Funeral service will be held at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd NW, Washington, D.C., on Sunday, March 11, 2012 at 2:30pm. Interment Garden of Remembrance, Clarksburg, MD. Shiva will be observed at the home of Marc Zwillinger and Kirsten Chadwick, Sunday through Tuesday evening. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jewish Communal Fund, 575 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Services by Borgwardt Funeral Home.

He was 94. His nephew Allan Hoberman confirmed his death.
