(13) THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA AT THE ROYAL ALBERT HALL ''Great Performances'' is offering an encore presentation of this 25th-anniversary special, a staged production of the Broadway and West End musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber, based the novel by Gaston Leroux. Taped at the Royal Albert Hall in London, this mounting recreates the scenery and special effects of the original and stars Ramin Karimloo, above, as the Phantom and Sierra Boggess as Christine. Both actors earned Olivier Award nominations for their roles in ''Love Never Dies,'' Mr. Lloyd Webber's sequel to ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' In 2006 ''Phantom'' became Broadway's longest-running show. It has been seen in 145 cities in 27 countries and has grossed more than $5.6 billion worldwide. 8:30 A.M. (USA) 3:10 to YUMA (2007) James Mangold directed this remake of the 1957 western based on an Elmore Leonard story about an Arizona rancher (Christian Bale, right) who signs on to escort an outlaw (Russell Crowe) to catch a train to stand trial. But an unlikely bond is forged along the way.

VICTOR--Sondra. We note with great sorrow the passing of Sondra, beloved wife of our cherished friend Saul. May he and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Susan and Robert R. Schwartz

5:11 p.m. | Updated Visa processing snags have forced two European acts to cancel performances in the United States scheduled for this week. The rising Spanish flamenco-soul singer Pitingo was to have made his U.S. debut Friday night at the Manhattan Center, and the avant-garde Czech theater troupe known as Tantehorse had a two week-plus run at a theater in the Washington D.C. area cancelled after four of its six members were told they would have to resubmit their applications. Pitingo is the stage name of Antonio Manuel Alvarez Velez, 31, who has four hit CDs and a DVD to his name, as well as several prizes that are Spain's equivalent of the Grammy. ''For reasons still unknown to us, the Government of the United States has retained his passport and we have not received the indispensable work visa needed to be able to gain access to that country,'' his management firm, 33spot! Productions, said in a statement late Wednesday.

The director Diane Paulus, now represented on Broadway with ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' and the Montreal circus company Les 7 Doigts de la Main (or 7 Fingers) will collaborate on a new production of the Stephen Schwartz musical ''Pippin'' that will begin performances at the American Repertory Theater in December, the Cambridge, Mass.-based theater announced on Thursday. Ms. Paulus held a developmental reading of ''Pippin'' in 2010 with the Tony Award nominee Gavin Creel in the title role, stirring talk of Broadway, since the musical has not returned there since its original four-and-a-half year run ended in 1977. But her production went into limbo when Mr. Schwartz opted to work first on an experimental approach to ''Pippin'' last fall at London's Menier Chocolate Factory; that production drew mixed to negative reviews.

An article on Tuesday about the well-rounded season of Devils forward Ilya Kovalchuk misidentified the site of the Devils' game against the Rangers that night. It was at Prudential Center in Newark, not at Madison Square Garden.

POUST--Jay Keil, born December 26, 1926, died peacefully on February 4, 2012 after a long and courageous battle with brain cancer. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, he leaves behind his wife Joan; his son Fred and wife Jodi; daughters Julie and Tracy; granddaughters Sara Rose and Mercedes; and son Alex and wife Abby. An alumni of Columbia University, he spent his professional life as a wine importer including 35 years as President of Jack Poust & Company. His wisdom, charm and sense of humor will be missed by family, friends and all who had the good fortune to know him.

An article on Thursday about the growing role of the British government in the management of Royal Bank of Scotland, in which it took a majority stake as part of a 2008 bailout, referred incorrectly to the slogan on a poster that some bank employees have displayed on their desk. ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' was printed on a poster developed in 1939 for distribution in the event of a Nazi invasion of Britain. Only a few were ever distributed; it was not ''Britain's World War II slogan.'' (An original copy of the poster surfaced in 2000 and reproductions became popular.)

YOUNG-BRUEHL--Elisabeth. The New York Memorial for Elisabeth Young-Bruehl will be held Sunday, April 1, 2012, 2pm, New York University School of Law, Greenberg Lounge at Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South, NYC.

When you think of Shakespeare, you immediately think: bluegrass music. And when you think of bluegrass, you immediately think: Steve Martin. And if you don't think those things, you might at least be more inclined to connect those dots after this summer's Shakespeare in the Park season, for which Mr. Martin will compose original music for its production of ''As You Like It,'' the Public Theater said on Thursday. The director Daniel Sullivan's interpretation of ''As You Like It'' will relocate the heroine Rosalind and her Forest of Arden to the American South of the 1840s, ''where folk and roots music perfectly capture the mood of the time,'' the Public Theater said in a news release. The production will feature a live band that will perform the new compositions of Mr. Martin, who, when he is not writing, acting, tweeting or celebrating the arrival of new phone books, is also an accomplished banjo player who has recorded two bluegrass albums with the Steep Canyon Rangers.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the increasing marginalization being felt by Palestinians in the West Bank referred incompletely to the action of the Israeli soldiers shown. While the soldiers, whose activity was not recounted in the article, were indeed firing rifles at stone throwers in the West Bank town of Al Ram last month, the rifles contained rubber bullets.

Netflix may have hit a snag as it negotiates with cable operators. Comcast, the country's largest cable company, says it has no interest in offering Netflix to its Xfinity subscribers regardless of whether it's in the form of an on-demand service or a billing partnership.
An article on Thursday about Congressional testimony by the director of the F.B.I. carried an erroneous dateline. The article was reported and written in Washington, not in Baghdad.

An article last Friday about Bay Area Russian expatriates voting in the Russian presidential election misstated the length of Vladimir Putin's presidential terms. His most recent campaign was for his third term, not his third six-year term. (The law was changed. His first two terms were four years, but his third term will be six years.)

TOBIN--Barbara Crane, born March 19, 1923, passed away peacefully on March 6, 2012 after a brief illness. Predeceased by husband John Clarke Tobin and survived by her four children, Caroline Crane Tobin, Gretchen Krueger Tobin, John Clarke Tobin Jr., and Elizabeth (Betsy) Crane Tobin, as well as her grandchildren, Eric Tobin Peterson, Amy Chelsea Peterson, Sarah Ellis Tobin, Joshua Adam Tobin and Jesse Tobin Weiss. Her intelligence, humor, grace, and independent spirit will long be treasured by all that knew her.

SCHWARTZ--George DDS, of New York, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband and sweetheart of Bobby. They shared a sixty year fairy tale marriage overflowing with love and devotion. Adored father of Steven (Peggy), Karen (Martin) and Robin. Cherished Papa of Adam (Daniela), Jarrett (Elina), Lindsay (Zachary) and Erin. Dear to Ursula, Charles and Eric. A trusted, caring and compassionate doctor. A beacon of strength and inspiration to all those whose lives he touched. In our hearts forever and always. Funeral service will be private.

PLATT--Irene L. (nee Fleischman) on March 8, 2012. Beloved wife of 52 years to Harvey J. Platt. Devoted and loving mother of Andrew L. Platt, his wife Stacey Sager and the late Caren M. Haragsim. Cherished grandmother of Olivia May and Celia Jaye. Fond sister of Lawrence and Carol Fleischman and their children Jeffrey and Howard. Graduate of New York Law School in the early 60's. Practiced law in New York City for over three decades. Appointed as a Member of the New York State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled. Appointed as a Member of the New York State Commission on the Board of Parole. Served for over 34 years for both the New York City Chapter and New York State Association and was President of the State Association for the Help of Retarded Children. Funeral Services Sunday 11am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery. Donations in Irene's name can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, New York 10008.

BLADE--Erna. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with deep sadness the passing of Erna Blade. Through a Lion of Judah Endowment, Erna's generosity will continue to have a profound impact on the Jewish community and those in need worldwide. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Erna's daughter, Linda, and son-in-law, Arthur. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

COURTNEY--William H. on March 7, 2012 at age 81. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Kane). Loving father of William and the late Jean. Devoted grandfather of India, Will, and Jack. Retired U.S.M.C, Korean War. A 37 year veteran of NYPD. Past President of NYPD Anchor Club, C.O.P.S and former Commander of American Legion Police Post #

ROTH--Martha. Born June 30, 1918 in New York, she passed away peacefully in San Francisco, March 3, 2012. Martha Roth was an extraordinary woman. She was interested in people from all backgrounds and the worlds they inhabited. Martha was committed to justice and human rights: she was someone who drew people to her, because she treated everyone with respect and care. Martha was married to her beloved husband, Joseph, for 67 years. She worked as a researcher and later was chief administrator for the children's psychiatric clinic at Bellevue Hospital. She also helped run Camp Meadowbrook Lodge in Massachusetts for 15 years. Martha is survived by her brother, Bernard Thomas, by her sons, Robert and Daniel; her daughters-in-law, Judith Mirkinson and China Brotsky; her extended family, Muriel Gladstein, Allan and Muriel Brotsky, Leslie Mullin and Terry Forman; her grandchildren Ona, Gemma, Max, Jack and Corey and numerous family members. Martha will be missed beyond words.

BANNON--Patrick J.,Jr., of Bronxville, NY on March 6, 2012. Beloved husband of Dorothea, loving father of Kathleen Wroblewski, Patrick J. III, Kevin, Maureen Tamer, Deirdre, Bernadette Welch and the late Timothy. Grandfather of 12. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday March 10 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Regis High School or Calvary Hospital.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on Wednesday with an article about the Devils' 4-1 victory over the Rangers on Tuesday described the play shown incorrectly. The photograph was of the Devils' David Clarkson scoring against Henrik Lundqvist in the third period. It did not show the Devils' Marek Zidlicky toppling the Rangers' Ryan Callahan during the first period. (A picture of the Zidlicky and Callahan play was published in another edition.)

Once the fitness craze was Richard Simmons's ''Sweatin' to the Oldies.'' Then, other workouts like Billy Blanks's Tae Bo caught on. But while many fads have been relegated to VHS tapes in the attic, two big investors are betting that Zumba Fitness, the Latin American dance-based workout, will have staying power. Insight Venture Partners, a New York-based venture capital firm, and the Raine Group, a media and entertainment investment firm, have poured tens of millions of dollars into the fitness company, a deal that values Zumba Fitness, based in Florida, at more than $500 million, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

KAUFMAN--Edna M.,91, of Roslyn, NY, died peacefully March 7 after a courageous battle with cancer with her family at her side. She was predeceased by Harold, her husband of 63 years. Survived by her children David (Harriet), Robert and Karen (Steven) White and adoring grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was known for her knitting and baking, her kindness toward all and was a founding member of Temple Sinai of Roslyn. Services to be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY at 11:00am, Friday March 9, 2012. Contributions may be sent to the Edna Markowitz Kaufman '40 and Harold M. Kaufman '37 Prize Scholarship c/o of CUNY Bernard Baruch College, 1 Bernard Baruch Way, New York, NY 10010.

An article on Saturday about an Islamic school in Houston that sought membership in the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools misstated the name of the school that played an Orthodox Jewish school in Tapps's boys' basketball state semifinals, a game that was rescheduled under legal pressure because of the Jewish team's observance of the Sabbath. It is the Covenant School in Dallas, not the Convent School. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

PECHET--Maurice M.,Ph.D., M.D., of Cambridge, Massachusetts, died in his sleep on March 5 during his 95th year. He was a teacher, physician, scientist, beloved father and husband of 51 years. Originally from a trading post in Saskatchewan, Canada, he spent 70 years at Harvard University, earning a Ph.D. in chemistry in 1944 and an M.D. in 1948, and devoting the rest of his career to teaching and science. He held a number of posts on the faculty at Harvard University and Harvard Medical School. As a consistent presence at Harvard's Lowell House for decades, he mentored generations of students and biochemists. As a physician and endocrinologist, he cared deeply for his patients and served on the staff at Massachusetts General Hospital for over half a century. As a scientist, he published over 100 papers and contributed many new synthetic processes including a revolutionary process for fluorination used to create 5-Fluorouracil, still widely used in the treatment of cancer. His work was the foundation for much of modern steroid chemistry, including the synthesis of Aldosterone, which is important in the early understanding of the endocrine system and the development of Prednisone, which is still used throughout the world for treatment of myriad conditions. He devoted decades to his research on Vitamin D synthesis and metabolism. As a philanthropist, he gave generously of his time and money. Along with his wife, Kitty, he has been a major patron of the arts, supporting Marlboro Music School, the New England Conservatory of Music, the Longy School of Music, the Danforth Museum, and the Signet Society among others. He served as a Police Surgeon for the Cambridge Police Department. His passion was education where his support ranged from helping individual students travel and study through more than half a century of support for Harvard University. A memorial service will be held on March 9th from 5:00-7:00pm in the Lowell House Junior Common Room, 10 Holyoke Place, Cambridge, MA. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to contribute are asked to make a donation to the Maurice Pechet Fund for Lowell House, payable to Harvard University and sent to the Lowell House Office, Lowell A22, 10 Holyoke Street, Cambridge MA 02138.

The newest owner of The New Republic magazine is Chris Hughes, a new-media guru who co-founded Facebook and helped to run the online organizing machine for Barack Obama's presidential campaign. Mr. Hughes's purchase of a majority stake in the magazine will be announced on Friday, once again remaking the masthead of the nearly century-old magazine that helped define modern American liberalism.

The Emmy Award-winning actor Jack Klugman, best known for playing Oscar on the 1970s television series ''The Odd Couple,'' has bowed out of the George Street Playhouse's upcoming production of ''Twelve Angry Men,'' the theater announced this week. Mr. Klugman, a throat cancer survivor who will turn 90 next month, is withdrawing due to health reasons after concluding that he needed to stay close to his Los Angeles home and his physician there. (George Street Playhouse is in New Brunswick, N.J.) Mr. Klugman had been set to play Juror No. 9 in the production of the court jury drama ''Twelve Angry Men,'' with performances starting on Tuesday night - 55 years after he had a breakout performance as Juror No. 5 in the 1957 film ''12 Angry Men,'' which also starred Henry Fonda and Lee J. Cobb. In an interview in December, when his casting for the play was announced, Mr. Klugman said he was in good health and was optimistic that his voice and stamina would hold up for the run of the production. The theater company announced that the actor David Canary, best known for his Emmy-winning performances as twins Adam and Stuart Chandler on ''All My Children,'' would replace Mr. Klugman. The play is scheduled to run through April 8.

The Hell Gate Bridge looks like hell. ''It should be the jewel of New York City, but instead it's turned into eight shades of lavender,'' said Peter F. Vallone Jr., a city councilman through whose district in Astoria the railroad bridge cuts before it spans a section of the East River known as Hell Gate, across to Wards Island and Randalls Island, linking Queens to the Bronx.

An obituary on April 8, 2011, about the computer programmer Jean Jennings Bartik erroneously attributed a distinction to her. She was not the last surviving member of the group of women who programmed the Eniac, considered the first all-electronic digital computer. One other member of that group, Frances Bilas Spence, is still alive. The error was pointed out in an e-mail from Ms. Spence's son on March 3.

If MayorMichael R. Bloomberg were running for office again, he could use the jobs data released on Thursday to his advantage. And so could his opponents. The negative spin would be obvious: New York City's unemployment rate rose again in January, to a 16-month high, 9.3 percent, from 9.1 percent in December. That was a full percentage point above the national rate, which fell from 8.5 percent in December. (National figures for February are to be released on Friday morning.)

An article on Thursday about 403(b) retirement plans, used by employees of many nonprofit organizations, misspelled the given name and misstated the surname of a Los Angeles teacher who is on the school board's retirement investment advisory committee. He is Alan Warhaftig, not Allan Warfhig.

CENTER STAGE Fender Musical Instruments, whose guitars have been plucked by the likes of the Beatles and other top artists, filed on Thursday for an initial public offering of stock as it looks to reduce debt. Fender expects to raise $200 million from the offering, according to a regulatory filing. The company has yet to say how many shares it will sell, or at what price. The company claims to have the No. 1 market share by revenue in electric and acoustic guitars. It said it would offer its shares on Nasdaq under the ticker FNDR. BEN PROTESS

ASHENDORF--George. March 7th 2012. He will be missed by his loving grandson Justin Ashendorf, his nephew Daniel Maltz, his niece Linda Maltz and his caretaker Shavonne Moore. For additional information call Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels: 800-247-5235

NATHANSON--Lawrence L.,of Rye, NY, died on March 8, 2012 of complications following an auto accident. Larry is survived by his beloved mother, Sally, his loving wife, Larraine, and his beloved children Lily, Charlie, and Jack. Larry attended the Fieldston School, graduated from The Wharton School and received an MBA from the Stern School of Business. He had a long and distinguished career as an investment banker and was a cofounder of Milton Capital Holdings. Larry was an avid skier and bike rider and lived and loved life to the fullest. His greatest joy was spending time with his wife and his three cherished children. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The memorial service will take place on Sunday, March 11 at 2pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.
LUKASHOK--Muriel. Beloved mother of Ruth and Edward; grandmother of Jane, Harris, Rachel, Michael; great-grandmother of Sophia, Ray, Cyrus, Sam and Spencer. She was unique, she will be missed.

VICTOR--Sondra Sarrow, age 76, died peacefully on March 7th, 2012 at her home after a long and courageous battle against Alzheimer's disease. An exquisite beauty, she lived a full, wonderful life, and was the proud matriarch of an adoring family. Beloved wife of Saul, devoted sister of Ellen. Dear mother of Donald and Eve, Alison, and Pamela; stepmother of Jonathan and Rosemarie, and Karen and Bob. Loving grandmother of Hilary and Pete, Joshua and Lisa, Max David, Stefanie and Julian, Alex, Adam, Rachel and Aaron. Funeral service at Plaza Funeral Home on Friday, March 9, at 12:30pm. Donations may be made in Sondra's memory to the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter. Shiva will be held Saturday evening 7:00pm until 9:00pm, Sunday 2:00pm until 7:00pm and Monday 4:00pm until 9:00pm at 241 Central Park West.

Coming soon from the Academy Award-winning director Davis Guggenheim: ''The Road We've Traveled,'' an action-packed film for the Obama campaign that puts a Hollywood shine on President Obama's record. On Thursday morning, the movie's two-minute trailer ran on ''The Today Show'' on ABC before being posted on the campaign Web site. Copies of the full-length film, which lasts 17 minutes, will go out nationwide for supporters to view on March 15 at house parties, union halls, campuses and perhaps even some theaters if they can be rented, campaign officials said.

FELLER--Allan. The Board of Directors and membership of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved member of 45 years. The club was his second home and the membership his extended family. We will forever miss the warmth and charm of his smile and the familiar and comforting sound of his unmistakable voice. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to Nancy and his family. Alan Howard, President

The 19-song playlist released Friday by Mitt Romney on Facebook, called ''On the Road,'' has surely been vetted by his campaign to make his image a little more down-home. The songs extol love and perseverance, maturity and positive aspiration, adding a little road-weary loneliness to deflect thoughts of cold elitism. It starts with ''I Am a Man of Constant Sorrow'' (the best-selling version from the soundtrack to ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?''), which proclaims, ''I've seen trouble all my days.''

The writers Jonathan Franzen, Michael Chabon and Jhumpa Lahiri are among the new members named to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, The Associated Press reported. Other new members named to the group, which was founded in 1898 and is based in Upper Manhattan, include the artists Kara Walker and Lynda Benglis, the architect Elizabeth Diller, and the composers Stephen Jaffe and Tobias Picker. The new class will be officially welcomed to the 250-member society at a ceremony in May, where the artist Chuck Close will give an address. Membership in the academy, which elects new members only after the death of existing members, is commonly described as one of the most distinguished honors in the arts. Mr. Chabon, 48, attributed his elevation to the color of his facial hair. ''I knew that when the gray came in it was only a matter of time before my augustness would be recognized,'' he told The A.P. Mr. Chabon, like Ms. Lahiri, has won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction.

George Braith has not taken a break since he first picked up the saxophone in seventh grade. ''When you stop playing, you lose something,'' he said. ''You got to keep it going.'' That's why at 72, he still plays twice as hard as any horn man out there. He can't help it - his specialty is the Braithophone, a rich-sounding instrument he made by welding together two saxophones. After years of tinkering with various incarnations at his Staten Island home workshop, he now plans to travel to Taiwan soon to explore manufacturing.

An article on Friday about Hector Xavier Monsegur, a computer hacker and informant who led law enforcement agents to several prominent fellow hackers, misstated the given name of one of those he exposed. He is Jeremy Hammond, not Darrell.

FELLER--Allan, our loyal and devoted friend, son, husband, father, grandfather. You valiantly fought this battle with dignity, courage and grace and cared more for your family and friends than yourself, revealing your selfless character, warm heart, and sense of humor. Our hearts are saddened and we will always miss you and your generous, kind spirit. Our heartfelt sympathies to our dear friend, Nancy, his Mother Marian, and beloved children and grandchildren. There will forever be a void in the physical space you occupied; but, there will forever be a place in our hearts for this special man. Rest in peace, dear friend. Melinda and Stanley Jaffe Laura and John Pomerantz

Four and a half months after undergoing surgery to remove a growth from his vocal cords, John Mayer said on his blog on Friday that the condition had returned and he had no choice but to ''take an indefinite break from live performing.'' Mr. Mayer, known for his acoustic rock and blues songs, said he was canceling a tour to promote his new album that was to have begun on April 9 in Bloomington, Ind. The album, ''Born and Raised,'' is still to be released by Columbia Records on May 22.

In a week when Lionel Richie learns he's going to be inducted into the Apollo Theater's Legends Hall of Fame and is announced as a star of ABC's summer singing competition, ''Duets,'' we expected his excitement would have him dancing on the ceiling or partying all night long. But this former Commodores frontman-turned-solo singer-songwriter instead referred to another title in his smoother-than-smooth back catalog. ''This is 'Can't Slow Down,' Part 2,'' Mr. Richie said on Friday, describing the current phase of his career. ''There's only one way I look at the business: you're either going to be in it or you're going to be out of it. I started thinking I'd better make some big changes when they start calling you 'a living icon.' That's not good. It makes me sound like a museum exhibit.''

LONDON - Barclays said on Friday that it had awarded its chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., £6.3 million ($10.3 million) in compensation for last year, a reduction in pay as profit at the British bank slipped. Mr. Diamond is to receive a pay package that includes £2.7 million in deferred shares and a £1.35 million salary for last year. That compares with a total compensation of £9 million for 2010, when he was still head of Barclays' investment banking operation.

There have been a few substitutions, but the jury in the George Street Playhouse's production of the courtroom drama ''Twelve Angry Men'' may finally be set. A few days after it was announced that he would replace Jack Klugman as Juror No. 9, David Canary has also withdrawn from that role. Mr. Canary, best known for his Emmy-winning turn on ''All My Children,'' bowed out because of ''a family emergency,'' said David Saint, the artistic director of the theater, which is in New Brunswick, N.J. (Mr. Klugman, who will turn 90 next month, decided he needed to stay closer to his Los Angeles home and doctor for health reasons.) Terry Layman, a veteran stage and TV actor who understudied the part in the 2004 Broadway revival, will take over.
INTERNATIONAL CRITICS SAY JAPAN IGNORED WARNINGS OF DISASTER

ZWILLINGER--Sandra Rudel. On Wednesday, March 7, 2012. One of the first and most prominent female executives on Wall Street in the 1970's, and a senior partner of Gruntal & Co. Beloved wife of the late Eugene M. Zwillinger. Mother of Marc (Kirsten), Grandmother of Jonah and Gabriel. Also survived by a brother, Jerome Glickman. Funeral service will be held at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd NW, Washington, D.C., on Sunday, March 11, 2012 at 2:30pm. Interment Garden of Remembrance, Clarksburg, MD. Shiva will be observed at the home of Marc Zwillinger and Kirsten Chadwick, Sunday through Tuesday evening. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jewish Communal Fund, 575 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Services by Borgwardt Funeral Home.

An article on Page 28 this weekend about teenage girls in a New York town afflicted with a twitching disorder misstates the number of times the mother of one was laid off in the last year. It is two, not three.

Teju Cole, writer in residence at Bard College, has won the Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award, which honors outstanding first works of fiction, for his novel ''Open City.'' Previous winners of the prize include Bobbie Mason, Renata Adler, Ha Jin, Jhumpa Lahiri and Dagoberto Gilb. Mr. Cole, 36, was born in the United States and raised in Nigeria. His novel, about a Nigerian studying psychiatry in New York who takes to wandering Manhattan and then the world after he breaks up with his girlfriend, was nominated by the National Book Critics Circle in January as one of five finalists for best novel of 2011; the winner of that competition will be announced Thursday evening.
Daylight saving time resumes at 2 a.m. on Sunday.

PLATT--Irene L. (nee Fleischman) on March 8, 2012. Beloved wife of 52 years to Harvey J. Platt. Devoted and loving mother of Andrew L. Platt, his wife Stacey Sager and the late Caren M. Haragsim. Cherished grandmother of Olivia May and Celia Jaye. Fond sister of Lawrence and Carol Fleischman and their children Jeffrey and Howard. Graduate of New York Law School in the early 60's. Practiced law in New York City for over three decades. Appointed as a Member of the New York State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled. Appointed as a Member of the New York State Commission on the Board of Parole. Served for over 34 years for both the New York City Chapter and New York State Association and was President of the State Association for the Help of Retarded Children. Funeral Services Sunday 11am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery. Donations in Irene's name can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, New York 10008.

He campaigned as an outsider, governed as an outsider and left as an outsider. PETER FLAHERTY, a top aide to Mitt Romney when he was governor of Massachusetts who now works on Mr. Romney's presidential campaign. [A13]

GINZBERG--Marc, passed away March 9, age 82. Beloved husband of Denyse, father of Nadine, Michael, and Nicole (Steve), loving grandfather of Natasha and Jacob, brother of Sunny and David. He passed away after a short illness. Private interment. Memorial service to be announced.

An article on Jan. 15 about talks that Palestinian Authority leaders were conducting with Israeli negotiators in Jordan and with Hamas leaders in Gaza misidentified the person killed in an explosion at a house in southern Gaza. The victim was a Palestinian militant -- not Zuhair al-Qissi, the secretary general of the Popular Resistance Committees, a group that Israel blames for an August attack across the border with Egypt that left eight Israelis dead.

SEITENBACH--Ronald K.,March 8, 2012 at the age of 57. After battling cancer 12 years ago, he went to work at B'nai Jeshrun Synagogue. Greatly loved by brother, Irwin, mother, Ilse, children, Justin and Johanna, wife, Lori, as well as a multitude of friends and family. Funeral will be held Sunday, March 11 at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Yonkers, NY. He will be deeply missed and never, ever forgotten.

Updated, 5:34 p.m. | For two men in St. Louis, it seemed like a romantic way to spend their 20th anniversary: a weekend in New York, with a marriage ceremony in Central Park on Friday and a Broadway show, ''Priscilla: Queen of the Desert,'' on Saturday. But for one of the men, Al Fischer, 46, a teacher at a Catholic school, there were unforeseen consequences.

An art review on Friday about the Art Show, at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, misidentified the artist whose work is shown at the Sperone Westwater gallery's booth. She is Carla Accardi, not Allan McCollum. (His work is at the Friedrich Petzel booth.)

PETSCHEK--Max L.,of New York, New York passed away on March 8, 2012 in La Jolla, California at age 86. Born in Berlin, Germany, he grew up in Scarsdale, New York. A World War II Army veteran, he served in the Pacific Theater. He was a graduate of Harvard College's class of 1946 and completed his advanced studies at the Sorbonne in Paris, France. An avid world traveler with a deep interest in global affairs, he pursued a long-time career in the travel and tourism industry. He was a dedicated Rotarian and life-long lover of classical music, actively supporting the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts. He is survived by his loving wife, Christine; son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Vera Petschek of Norwalk, CT; son Christopher Petschek of El Centro, CA; and son and daughter-in-law Clark and Michelle Petschek of Katonah, NY. He is also survived by his grandchildren Ryan, Chad, Amy, Tyler and Kyle Petschek.

An article on Wednesday about arrests in a government crackdown on a confederation of hackers, using information from court documents, misstated the age of Jake Davis, one of those arrested. He is 19, not 29.

1960s New England will find a new home on the French Riviera: Wes Anderson's ''Moonrise Kingdom'' will open the Cannes Film Festival in May, festival organizers announced on Friday. Mr. Anderson's seventh feature, set in 1965, takes place on an island off the New England coast. With a cast that includes Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand, it's the story of a romance between a pair of precocious 12-year-olds who run away, presumably to somewhere really picturesque. ''Moonrise Kingdom'' is the writer-director's first live-action film since ''Darjeeling Limited'' in 2007 (the animated ''Fantastic Mr. Fox'' was nominated for an Oscar in 2010). The festival runs May 16-27, with Nanni Moretti, the Italian filmmaker, serving as president of the jury.

FELLER--Allan. Allan loved his family and his friends and he was loved right back. His positive outlook on life will be missed. Our deepest condolences to Nancy, Adam and family. Diane & Marshall Felenstein

An art review on Friday about the Independent contemporary-art fair, at 548 West 22nd Street in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of an artist whose work is displayed on the third floor. She is Thea Djordjadze, not Djordhadze.

PENDIAS--Sophie Rene, of Garden City, NY, March 7, 2012. Loving wife of the late Stephen Peter Pendias, devoted mother of Joan Pendias and Calli McCaw, adoring grandmother of Matthew Checki, dear sister of Helen Papadeas and caring mother-in-law of Robert McCaw. Her loving spirit and zest for life will be missed by all. Viewing at Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, NY 2-4 and 7-9pm on Sunday, March 11. Services on Monday, March 12 at 10:30am at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral, West Hempstead, NY. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery.

President Obama has appointed Todd Park to be his top technology adviser, the White House announced on Friday. Mr. Park will become the chief technology officer for the executive branch, filling one of two vacancies left in the Office of Science and Technology Policy by Aneesh Chopra, who returned to the Advisory Board Company in February. Mr. Park has been the chief technology officer in the Department of Health and Human Services since the position was created in August 2009. He was responsible for modernizing the department's data infrastructure, and led the development of Health.gov, an online directory of public and private health insurance plans, and Health.Data.gov, an public inventory of the agency's data sets.

When it comes to inspiring Tea Party support, Mitt Romney often seems more burdened by his record than helped by it. There is his Massachusetts health care plan, complete with an individual mandate of the sort that helped fuel the rise of the Tea Party movement when President Obama adopted it on a national level. There is his willingness as governor to turn to revenue increases as well as spending cuts to balance the budget in his state, the kind of fiscal compromise that almost no Republican in Washington could support these days without provoking Tea Party wrath. There is his history of evolving ideologically along with changing political circumstances, raising a flag among those Tea Partiers who demand steadfast principles.

GOLDMAN--Shirley M.,86, passed away on Friday March 9, 2012, beloved wife of Robert. She was the loving mother of Ronald and Stephen and Shari Goldman and the grandmother of Samantha and Alexandra. She was the icon of Continental Auto Body. Services will be held on Sunday, March 11 at 11:30am. For service information call: 201-843-9090

A Spare Times for Children entry in some editions Friday about ''A Day of Reflection'' scheduled for Sunday at the Japan Society in Manhattan, using information from the society, misstated the number of photographs of work by elementary school students that will be on display. It is 80, not 54.

The report from the court-appointed examiner in the Dynegy bankruptcy case is out, and it's a bombshell. As I've noted in earlier columns, the Dynegy case has been distinguished from inception by hardball tactics that the parent company shareholders have used to try to salvage some value, after their earlier attempts for a merger or takeover failed.
SCHALLER--Charles Ridings, 76, of Spring Island, SC and Fairfield CT, husband of Susan Schaller, died March 5, 2012 at Beaufort Memorial Hospital in Beaufort, SC.

NATHANSON--Lawrence L.,of Rye, NY, died on March 8, 2012 of complications following an auto accident. Larry is survived by his beloved mother, Sally, his loving wife, Larraine, and his beloved children Lily, Charlie, and Jack. Larry attended the Fieldston School, graduated from The Wharton School and received an MBA from the Stern School of Business. He had a long and distinguished career as an investment banker and was a cofounder of Milton Capital Holdings. Larry was an avid skier and bike rider and lived and loved life to the fullest. His greatest joy was spending time with his wife and his three cherished children. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The memorial service will take place on Sunday, March 11 at 2pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.
A film review on Friday about ''Attenberg'' referred incorrectly to the movie. It is the second feature directed by Athina Rachel Tsangari, not her ''debut feature.''

A picture caption on Friday with an art review of the Armory Show, at Piers 92 and 94 in Manhattan, misstated the title of a work by Kehinde Wiley on display. It is ''The Tribute Money II,'' not ''The Tribute Monkey II.''

Edith Pearlman won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday for ''Binocular Vision,'' (Lookout Books), a story collection that has elicited praise from reviewers for its delicate and wry character portraits. Its publication is ''a triumph for Pearlman's distinctive storytelling, bringing it to a larger audience,'' the board of the National Book Critics Circle, a group of 600 book reviewers, said in a statement. Ms. Pearlman is not widely known and chose a small publisher in North Carolina to release the book, making its win something of a coup.

9 P.M. (HBO) GAME CHANGE (2012) Julianne Moore, above, channels Sarah Palin in this drama about the 2008 Republican presidential campaign of Senator John McCain, portrayed here by Ed Harris, and his selection of Ms. Palin, then the governor of Alaska, as his running mate. Woody Harrelson plays Steve Schmidt, the McCain strategist who championed Ms. Palin for the ticket; Peter MacNicol is Rick Davis, the campaign's national manager. The cast is rounded out by Ron Livingston as Mark Wallace, the senior adviser who led Ms. Palin's debate preparation team; Sarah Paulson as his wife, Nicolle Wallace, another senior adviser; Jamey Sheridan as the speechwriter Mark Salter; and Bruce Altman as the media strategist Fred Davis. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called the film, directed by Jay Roach and adapted by Danny Strong from the best seller by Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, ''a sharp-edged but not unsympathetic portrait of a flawed heroine, colored more in pity than in admiration. Ms. Palin's detractors will consider it generous, and her advocates have already dismissed it as a liberal smear job.'' The real tribute, she added, ''is that it exists at all.'' 7 P.M. (CMT) THEM IDIOTS WHIRLED TOUR The Blue-Collar Comedy veterans Bill Engvall, Jeff Foxworthy and Larry the Cable Guy reunite to offer their views on marriage, family and colonoscopies. Reno Collier hosts.
Say you've filled out your tax return, and discovered some bad news: you owe money. But suppose you can't afford to pay the bill. What should you do?

Greece's debt restructuring will prompt payouts on credit-default swaps tied to the country's government bonds. The decision by the International Swaps and Derivatives Association ends months of speculation that a Greek default might not set off the swaps, a result that could have undermined their role as insurance against debt defaults.

Another 2 percent rebate in the card business has bitten the dust. I was equally delighted and skeptical when PerkStreet Financial began offering many of its consumers access to a checking account that earned a flat 2 percent back on all the debit card transactions that they signed for.

LORCH--Harry "Hans", 90, Holocaust survivor, on February 27, 2012. He was predeceased by his wife Sandy, son Mel and second wife Ruth. He's survived by daughters Iris and Donna, ten grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to Gesher Shalom, Fort Lee, NJ or US Holocaust Memorial Museum.

An article on Thursday about the difficulty of jury selection for a court case against Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets, who have been accused of running the team with illegitimate profits from Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme, referred incorrectly to the size of the jury. It will be a 6- to-12-person panel, not a 6-person or a 12-person panel. The article also misspelled the given name of a partner in the securities firm Aidikoff, Uhl & Bakhtiari, which has represented clients defrauded by Mr. Madoff. He is Philip Aidikoff, not Philipp.
Peyton Manning made Denver the first stop of his free-agent tour Friday, and the Broncos are said to be a serious contender for his services.

HYMAN--Edgar. Born January 15, 1932, Edgar Hyman was a Manhattanite, retired in Woodstock. Married Marie-Claude in Paris. Sons Harold and Philippe. Owned Lady Continental, Italian shoe store, on Madison. Edgar left us March 5, 2012, surrounded by family.

Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, joined the fight over the tax status of ''Super PACS'' on Friday, accusing Senate Democrats of a ''politically motivated witch hunt'' for their efforts to rein in tax-exempt political groups. Mr. Hatch, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, was responding to a letter by seven Senate Democrats demanding that the Internal Revenue Service establish a clearer test limiting the politicking of 501(c)(4) groups like American Crossroads, a Republican group, and Priorities USA, a Democratic outfit. The letter, which still has not been sent, also requests stronger rules preventing corporate donors from deducting Super PAC contributions from their taxes, and it threatens legislative action if the I.R.S. fails to act.

Robert L. Nardelli is ending his formal ties to Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that installed him as the chief executive of Chrysler nearly two years before the carmaker filed for bankruptcy. In a statement on Friday, Cerberus said that Mr. Nardelli had stepped down as the chief executive of Cerberus Operations and Advisory Company, or COAC, a unit of the firm that provides management and operations advice to Cerberus portfolio companies. Mr. Nardelli is also resigning as the chief executive of the Freedom Group, the sprawling conglomeration of gun makers that includes Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, which is also owned by Cerberus.

BAVEN--Beverly, on March 8, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Michael (Meyer), devoted mother of Mark, dear aunt of Curt, Steve and Howard Palatsky. She loved life and people. Service Sunday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Casting aside the controversy, shareholders of the El Paso Corporation have approved Kinder Morgan's bid, originally valued at $21.1 billion. During a special meeting on Friday, a group of shareholders representing about 79 percent of El Paso outstanding shares, voted overwhelmingly -- in excess of 95 percent -- for the deal. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter.

The comedian Louis C.K. has withdrawn from his role as the host of a dinner for the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association in Washington, the Caucus blog reported. No explanation was given by his press agent, but the announcement comes one day after the Fox News commentator Greta Van Susteren called for a boycott of the event over jokes the comedian had made about Sarah Palin, saying ''he denigrates all women and looks to the crowd for laughs.'' Read more at the Caucus blog This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixar's top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, "Dr. Seuss' The Lorax" (Universal Pictures) -- featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito -- was North America's No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data.

The scant few blocks north toward the dizzy roofline of St. Patrick's Cathedral passed unreal, falsely familiar. Paper cutouts for a newsboy's stage. The air came hot so near the ground, gritty and thick as we flew by a cloyingly stuffed sinkhole, and as I yearned for more speed, I wished I hadn't yet solved the crime of the horse I had just stolen from the Elizabeth Street grocery. We wheeled left at Prince Street, and there was St. Patrick's, the pale moonlit monument to the Catholic God before us. It was the only time of night in New York when the streets even approach quiet: the sheltered alleyway of lost time lying between three-thirty and four in the morning. Not anywhere near two a.m., drenched in gin and smelling of late-night chops and after-opera coffee and back-alley sex. Not yet approaching five a.m., horses streaming back into the streets and roosters crowing maniacally. Between play and work, when a mab just heading for bed following an all-night debauch might bump into a still sleep-blinded stonemason trudging to his work three miles from home.

The cover article last Sunday, ''Everybody Inhale,'' tackled the question of how many people Manhattan could hold. Following are edited excerpts from comments on the article and readers' experiences in a crowded city, from nytimes.com: In answer to your question, how do I deal with living in a crowded city: I try to shop at stores during less crowded times; I order online so that I don't have to go and stand in lines in person (hopefully my carbon footprint from online shopping is somewhat offset by the fact that I take public transportation). I remind myself to be patient, polite and courteous when in a crowded situation (failing more times than I'd like to admit). I meditate and take yoga to touch stillness in mind and body. I also live in Astoria, Queens, which, while eschewed by many in favor of the excitement of Manhattan, helps me to survive and thrive in NYC. ...

THERE'S a proud tradition of brotherly alliances in jazz, exemplified by a pair of engagements running from Tuesday through next Sunday. THE HEATH BROTHERS represent its gold standard, despite the death of its eldest member, the bassist Percy Heath, in 2005. Jimmy Heath, a saxophonist, and Tootie Heath, a drummer, have experienced more than a century of jazz history combined, and they bring a soulful enterprise to their quartet, otherwise made up of attentive youngsters. 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village; (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover $25, with a one-drink minimum. The attentive youngsters run the show in THE RODRIGUEZ BROTHERS BAND. Robert Rodriguez, a pianist, and Michael Rodriguez, a trumpeter, were raised in New York and Miami, and their music toggles between post-bop and Latin jazz. They couldn't be leading a better crew: the percussionist Pedrito Martinez, the drummer Jeff (Tain) Watts and the bassist John Patitucci. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover $30 to $40, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar.

THE Dutch harpsichordist, organist and conductor TON KOOPMAN has invariably found fresh, often surprising ways to get to the heart of Baroque masterpieces. At times he has used adventurous ornamentation to make his points, and in some cases -- a notable 1985 recording of Handel's ''Messiah'' for example -- he has found reason to experiment with idiosyncratic ideas about scoring. The Bach Cantatas have long been a specialty. He has recorded the full cycle, but no doubt his ideas are still evolving. In a Thursday evening concert with his superb period instrument ensemble, the Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra, as well its associated choir and a slate of soloists that includes Teresa Wakim, soprano; Bogna Bartosz, alto; Tilman Lichdi, tenor; and Klaus Mertens, bass-baritone, Mr. Koopman offers two of those church works: the Cantata No. 104, ''Du Hirte Israel, höre'' (''You Shepherd of Israel, Hear'') and the Cantata No. 147, ''Herz und Mund und Tat und Leben'' (''Heart and Mouth and Deed and Life,'' best known for its 10th movement, the chorale ''Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring''). Between them, Mr. Koopman and company will perform Bach's Magnificat. 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $45 to $77.

UPPER WEST SIDE TRIPLEX $1,195,000

In the year since restrictions on travel to Cuba were eased for those on cultural exchange itineraries, new trips to the island have focused on art, history and music. Now there's one for foodies. Guillermo Pernot, the chef and owner of Cuba Libre Restaurant and Rum Bar in Washington and three other cities, will lead a five-day trip to Cuba next month with the tour operator Insight Cuba The trip, to focus on Cuban cuisine, will feature visits to the Cuban Culinary Association, an organic urban farm and several ''paladares,'' home-based restaurants run by trained chefs as well as amateurs.

In 1898, as history students learn, the battleship Maine blew up in Havana's harbor, but that was also the year the Bayer Company offered a new opiate cough medicine called Heroin, and the year the Kellogg brothers introduced cornflakes, which were so unpopular at first they grew stale on grocers' shelves. Thank James Trager for making these historical nuggets readily available to the reading public. They're part of his 1,206-page book ''The People's Chronology: A Year-by-Year Record of Human Events from Prehistory to the Present,'' published in 1979. For each year he discussed, he divided events into categories like literature, crime and everyday life.

PARALLELS, the current Danspace Project Platform series, has been on one heck of a roll, even by the high standards set by previous Platforms. Perhaps the New York Dance and Performance Awards might consider creating a Bessie for ''hitting one out of the park'' and give the inaugural honor to the Parallels curator, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones. For this week's Platform installation he has invited two Bessie Award winners, NORA CHIPAUMIRE and OKWUI OKPOKWASILI, to create new pieces for a shared evening. It gets better: both women, exceedingly powerful stage presences, will be performing their work. Each has created a solo. Ms. Chipaumire's is called ''The Last Heifer'' (a reimagining of a previous solo, ''Dark Swan''). Ms. Okpokwasili's new work, ''Bronx Gothic,'' incorporates song and unfolds as a letter between two adolescent girls living in the Bronx, where the choreographer was born and raised. 8 p.m., Thursday to Saturday, Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (866) 811-4111. The complete Platform 2012 schedule is at danspaceproject.org. The artist Wangechi Mutu will lead a post-performance discussion on Friday.
MINDLIN--Michael. 3/11/23- 3/7/04 Forever loved & greatly missed. Freda

BOMEISLER--Douglass M.,85, of New York City, died March 1, 2012. Born August 16, 1926 to Dorothy Topping Bomeisler and Douglass Bomeisler, he attended Phillips Andover, served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1944-1946 and graduated from Yale in 1948. He worked in advertising. He was predeceased by his wife Anne Kniffin Bomeisler and his sister Virginia Rotan. He is survived by his sons Douglass T. Bomeisler of Jensen Beach, FL and Stuart B. Bomeisler of Cohasset, MA, his four grandsons, and his brother Stuart Douglas of Little Compton, RI. Donations in remembrance may be sent to Phillips Andover.

An article on Feb. 26 about Joan Jeanrenaud, a longtime cellist with the Kronos Quartet, omitted one of the composers of ''Ice Music for London,'' later refashioned into ''Ice Cello.'' ''Ice Music'' was created by the composer and conceptual artist Jim McWilliams and the cellist and performance artist Charlotte Moorman, not just by Ms. Moorman. The article also misspelled the surname of Kronos Quartet's first cellist. He is Walter Gray, not Grey.

A chart on Friday with the continuation of an article about the state of nuclear power in Japan a year after the country suffered a nuclear disaster misstated the number of Japan's 54 commercial reactors that have been shut down since then. It is all but two, not two.

HALL--Walter David, 67, died on Tuesday at his home on Captiva Island, in Southwest Florida. He was known as David and also had a home in Mount Vernon, NY. David retired in 2007 after 20 years at ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, where he was a loan review officer in the International Diamond and Jewelry Group in New York. He was born on February 9, 1945, in Council Bluffs, Iowa, to Walter and Marie Hall. He attended the University of Colorado and graduated from the University of Iowa and from the Thunderbird School of Global Management. He served in the Peace Corps in the Philippines and in the U.S. Army. He is survived by his partner, Charles McEwen, of Mount Vernon; his brother, James T. Hall of Arvada, Colorado; and his sisters, Barbara Roberts of Villisca, Iowa; Judy Geddes of Kelowna, British Columbia; Kathy Savage of Villisca, and Laurie Hall of Two Rivers, Wisconsin. A memorial service is scheduled at 11:30am Wednesday at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). Burial will follow at the Crum Elbow Rural Cemetery in Hyde Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial gifts be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10013, or to a charity of the donor's choice.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the number of people Manhattan could actually hold misstated part of the name of the agency where Sarah Kaufman, a transportation and data expert, worked before moving to New York University to do research. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not ''Transit'' Authority.

TOBIN--Barbara Crane, born March 19, 1923, passed away peacefully on March 6, 2012 after a brief illness. Predeceased by husband John Clarke Tobin and survived by her four children, Caroline Crane Tobin, Gretchen Krueger Tobin, John Clarke Tobin Jr., and Elizabeth (Betsy) Crane Tobin, as well as her grandchildren, Eric Tobin Peterson, Amy Chelsea Peterson, Sarah Ellis Tobin, Joshua Adam Tobin and Jesse Tobin Weiss. Her intelligence, humor, grace, and independent spirit will long be treasured by all that knew her.

An article last Sunday about couples therapy misidentified Terry Real's profession. He is a licensed independent clinical social worker, not a psychologist. The article also misidentified the university where William J. Doherty is a professor of family social science. It is the University of Minnesota, not the University of Wisconsin.

SWENSON--Nancy Tiernan, passed away peacefully on March 8, 2012 at her home in Dallas, TX. Born December 2, 1924, to Martin F and Purcell Tiernan, she spent her childhood in Essex Fells, NJ. Her five siblings predeceased her. She married Bruce Swenson of Montclair, on December 30, 1944. They moved to Dallas and raised six children all of whom are living. After 66 years of marriage Bruce predeceased Nancy on July 6, 2011. Nancy won many tennis tournaments and held top rankings in the senior divisions. She was ranked number one in Texas five times. Her top national singles ranking was second in the 55's. She was ranked in the top five in the country in doubles five times. In 1998 Nancy was diagnosed with Parkinson's. She combated its symptoms without complaint. She became involved with The Voice Project, a foundation dedicated to helping Parkinson's patients preserve their speaking ability and she received great enjoyment, appearing in several of the Project's plays. In 2010 the foundation awarded Nancy its annual Proud-to-be Loud Award for "extraordinary courage, perseverance and determination." She is survived by her six children and their families; including 11 grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Her children and their families are: Bruce (Smokey) Swenson and his wife, Lindsley, of Dallas, and their children Tiernan Cavanna and Tiernan's husband Kieran Cavanna, and Harris Swenson and his wife Lauren. Tiernan and Kieran are the parents of three of Nancy's great-grandchildren while Harris and Lauren are the parents of the fourth; Stephen Swenson and his wife, Carla, of Dallas; Christopher Swenson and his wife, Emily, of Montclair, and their children, Billy, Mike and Lisa; Merritt Swenson, of San Antonio and her sons, Swen, Jamie and Peter McCulloch; Carroll Swenson-Roberts and her husband, Truett Roberts of Dallas, and their daughter, Sara Roberts; Nancy E. Swenson, of Dallas, and her daughters Allison and Hayley Caldwell. Nancy's companionship, cheerfulness, graceful determination, full love of life and love for us will be greatly missed. A Funeral Mass will be performed at St. Joseph's Church in Richardson, TX on Wednesday, March 14th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the Parkinson Voice Project, 500 N. Coit Rd Suite 2085, Richardson, TX 75080.

She came from Harlem, her broadcasts exemplifying the spirit of the city she served: vibrant, feisty, occasionally profane. He came from Canada, seemingly born to his anchorman's hair and diction.

CANNOLD--Dan (David Leon), died peacefully at his home in Rye, New York, March 10, 2012, surrounded by his loving family. Dan, Danny, Dad, Poppa, Uncle Danny, Cousin Danny was a man for all seasons and much, much more. As a son, brother, then husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather, uncle, cousin, teacher, business leader, historian, philanthropist, architect, artist-in-life, raconteur, and dedicated, dependable friend to all, he was our truest hero. Few of us can excel at all the roles in life that we are called upon to fill; Danny was our role model in each and every one of them. Dan was a source of limitless wisdom for each of us, for family and friends, far and wide across the globe. He was selfless, generous and devoted to those he loved, to his beliefs, particularly as an American, a Jew and to Israel. His commitment to Westchester Jewish Center, Weizmann Institute, The Technion, UJA and AIPAC are among many that were important to him and will be everlasting beacons for us all. Dan's remarkable trajectory of self-made success in business began with the leadership of Manhattan and Bronx Electric Wire and Cable, later Manhattan Cable, then finally The Manhattan Group of companies. The son of Sidney and Anna Cannold, brother to Sheryl Cannold Benjamin, Dan grew up in the Bronx. A proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and Rochambeau Avenue, Dan went on to the University of Iowa. It was toward the end of his US Army service during WWII that he met Beverly Brodwin in Larchmont, New York. He proposed to Bev on Valentine's Day, 1945 and from that moment on, their lives were blessed by a loving, romantic partnership for the ages. Married later that year, they soon moved together to Scarsdale, later to Rye, Pound Ridge and Palm Beach. Dan and Bev celebrated their 66th wedding anniversary last August, continuing to inspire all their family, all who know them, with the power of love they shared with each other and those around them. Dan and Bev won many dance contests together; they were a joy to watch for those of us fortunate enough to be there. In Dan's final days, he never missed an opportunity to give or blow a kiss, or sing a love song, be it in English, Hebrew, Polish, Italian or Yiddish to his Bev. Their sons Mitchell, Scott, Tom, daughters-in-law Dori, Gail and Kim, grandchildren Anna Cannold Weiser and Dan Weiser, Lilly, Sammi, Noah, Spencer, Julie, great grandson Elliot Cannold Weiser, have lost their giant. Yet, they appreciate fully that they have been immeasurably empowered by Dad and will want to hold his hand, his love, his memory and his life lessons close to their hearts for all time. The Cannold Family wishes to thank all of the doctors, nurses and extraordinary caregivers who devoted themselves to making Dan's final year, his 91st, healthy, happy and peaceful. Dan lived his life to the fullest, with style, humor, judgment, dignity and high character. We all know Dad will be singing and dancing forever in the stars, dreaming sweet dreams of his Bev and the family of which he was so proud. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Westchester Jewish Center. Funeral Services will be held at Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, New York on Monday, March 12th at 10am with interment to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

A picture caption on Feb. 26 with an article about British bands that are coming to America misidentified the group that is scheduled to perform at Radio City Music Hall this spring. It is Pulp, not the La's.

The Big City column last Sunday, about the Park Slope Food Co-op, which is considering a boycott of Israeli products, erroneously attributed a distinction to the co-op. It is one of the largest in the country, not the largest. (The largest is PCC Natural Markets in Washington State.)

To the Editor: Re ''Farewell to Youth but Not to Beauty'' (Sunday Styles, March 4): For years I have had the same beauty regimen: Stay out of the sun, use cleansing cream on my face every night and cream it night and morning.

It's clear from this story that Scott Ritter has problems. Big problems. He's a pervert who has earned his stint in jail. . . . Still, it's interesting to contemplate part of his point here: that no prominent figures who argued for the war in Iraq have suffered for the disaster they visited upon this country. Rick Santorum, a big and unrepentant Iraq war hawk, a senator who voted for the war, is a leading candidate for the G.O.P. nomination. Mitt Romney likes every position on the Iraq war and has among his elite national security advisers two men -- Eliot Cohen and Robert Kagan -- who were leading Iraq war proponents among the policy elite. The fact that Iraq isn't even an issue in the G.O.P. primary race tells you that the American public, or at least G.O.P. voters, aren't interested in learning any lessons from the Iraq debacle. ROD DREHER,theamericanconservative.com

APTMAN--Sol. Died peacefully at home in Miami on March 9, 2012 at 101. He loved life, his family, his faith and Bet Shira Congregation. He was a devoted husband to his wife Beatrice until her death. Beloved father of Wallace (Eileen), Michael (Lynn), Suellen (Sam Goodbaum). Loving grandfather of Lowell (Eileen), Gregory, Melissa (deceased), Matthew (Jessica) and Jessica Aptman, Joshua and Anna Goodbaum. Adored great-grandfather of Isabel, Madeline, Gabrielle and Hudson Aptman. His positive attitude was an inspiration to all. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to The Melissa Institute, www.melissainstitute.org

GREENBAUM--Robert Saul, of New York and East Hampton, died peacefully at home, March 5th, age 89. Born in Newark, NJ on May 4, 1922, the son of William L. and Minna P. Greenbaum, he is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Theodora Simon Greenbaum; their three children Roger, William, and Margot; five grandchildren, Olivia, Aliza, Ariela, Emma, and Iris; and his brother, Arthur. He was a 1943 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he was an intercollegiate fencing champion. He served in the United States Navy as a commissioned officer aboard the destroyer USS Ludlow in World War II in the Mediterranean, Atlantic, and Pacific theaters. He was graduated from the Columbia University School of Law in October 1948 and joined his father's law practice in Newark in 1949. That firm is now Greenbaum Rowe Smith & Davis of Woodbridge and Roseland, NJ. Eminent in the field of real estate law, Bob was a member of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers, chairman of the American Bar Association Section on State and Local Government Law, and has been named to "The Best Lawyers In America" since 1983, in the Real Estate Law, Arbitration, and Mediation categories. He was chairman of the Board of Trustees of Guild Hall in East Hampton, NY, where he also chaired the Building and Grounds committee for the recent reconstruction of that cultural institution. With his brilliant mind, a heart of gold, and courage beyond measure he inspired all who knew and loved him. His ashes will be buried at sea. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Columbia University School of Law or to Guild Hall, 158 Main Street, East Hampton, NY 11937.

An article on Feb. 26 about the 1994 movie ''Vanya on 42nd Street,'' which has just been released in a restored edition on DVD and Blu-ray, misidentified the Broadway theater where ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' is running. To the Editor: Re ''Three's a Crowd'' (Sunday Styles, March 4), by Elizabeth Weil. I was interested to read how ''frightening'' couples therapy can be for therapists. I find this work difficult, but incredibly rewarding. The partners may have different agendas and try to manipulate the therapy, but this can usually be spotted and used as grist for the mill -- as can arguing -- rather than causing the therapist anxiety.
International TO HELP CLOSE DEBT,

The impact of Eva and Juan Perón extended far beyond the capital city, and was particularly strong in the Province of Buenos Aires, where Eva grew up. If you have soaked up all the Evita you can in the city, there's plenty more a short drive or train ride away. 12. QUINTA SAN VICENTE MUSEO DE 17 DE OCTUBRE AND JUAN PERóN MAUSOLEUM This country home of Juan and Eva Perón was built in 1947 in the well-to-do San Vicente suburbs, about an hour southwest from Buenos Aires. The interior dates to a renovation done in the 1970s, when Perón returned to power after being in exile for 18 years throughout Latin America and Spain. The museum contains his car collection and a car from the presidential train, as well as statues from a monument he planned to erect in Evita's honor on Avenida Libertador before the coup. The museum garden is the now the final resting place for Perón, whose body was moved here from Buenos Aires's Chacarita cemetery in 2006. A companion tomb was built for Evita, but her family will not allow her body to move here, saying it has been on too many journeys since her death.

CHO--Sihak Henry, 78, passed away on March 8, beloved husband of Myung Sook. He is the loving father of Kenneth K. and David P., and the grandfather of Jonathan, Lauren, Stephanie and Brittany. Korean Community leader and Martial Arts Pioneer recipient of the 2011 Lifetime Achievement award by the President's Council on Sports, Fitness & Nutrition. Services will be held on Sunday, March 11, Monday, March 12 and the funeral on March 13. For more information, please visit: www.henrycho.com.

Detectives are investigating the death of a 23-month-old boy in Brooklyn whose bruised body was discovered after his mother called 911 early Saturday morning to say that he was unconscious and unresponsive, the police said. The boy, Jacqil Degraffenreid, had been left in the care of his mother's boyfriend for about four hours, though where the mother had gone was not immediately clear, according to a law enforcement official. It was not known if other children were present at the time.

Memorial contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Foundation, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106 or Rossmoor Jewish Congregation, 2 Rossmoor Dr., Monroe Twp., NJ 08831.

Office Life 8. CITY LEGISLATURE BUILDING This building, with its 318-foot clock tower, is just off the Avenida de Mayo, a few blocks from the Casa Rosada. Though its legislative chambers are still active, the building maintains one of Evita's satellite offices for her foundation, which is open to the public. The room, now called the Salón Eva Perón, contains a desk, chair, lamp, folders and other objects she used. Nearby, see Evita Vive, a tango show celebrating her life, inside the Moreno Hotel Theater.
SARGENT JohnT. A memorial service for John T. Sargent Sr. will be held at 4pm on Friday, March 23rd at: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 325 Park Avenue (at 51st Street).

''The tablet is like a temptress.'' James McQuivey, a Forrester Research analyst who studies electronic devices. People who read e-books on tablets like the iPad are realizing that while a book in print or on a black-and-white Kindle is straightforward and immersive, a tablet offers a menu of distractions that can fragment the reading experience. ''Our research raises real concerns about whether health information technology is going to be the answer to reducing costs.'' Dr. Danny McCormick, an assistant professor at Harvard Medical School. He was lead author of a study that found that computerized patient records were unlikely to cut health care costs and might actually encourage doctors to order expensive tests more often.

The Place They Met? 4. LUNA PARK Legend has it that a 1944 fund-raiser for earthquake victims at this concert and sports hall near the Puerto Madero neighborhood is where Juan Perón first laid eyes on the rising starlet Eva Duarte. The moment is marked by the song ''Charity Concert'' in the show, though some historians say it is likely that they had already met. Today the building is a great place to hear local rock favorites or aging American pop icons like the Village People and Liza Minnelli at prices significantly cheaper than they are in the United States.

''TOUCH OF EVIL,'' the Orson Welles movie that isn't ''Citizen Kane,'' plays a bit like creaky melodrama these days, but partly that is because it's often squeezed into a television screen. On Friday and Saturday the Museum of the Moving Image lets it stretch out, showing it in the main theater as part of the See It Big! series, which in recent months has presented films like ''The Sound of Music'' and ''Manhattan'' in a big-screen format. The film, which stars Charlton Heston, Janet Leigh and Welles himself in a Mexican border town yarn, is full of Wellesian visual touches. ''Using a superlative camera (manned by Russell Metty) like a black-snake whip, he lashes the action right into the spectator's eye,'' Howard Thompson wrote in his review in The New York Times in 1958.

Fans of the travel show host and writer Anthony Bourdain can now follow in his footsteps using a new application for iPad, iPhone and iTouch. The Travel Channel Layover Guide With Anthony Bourdain, introduced this month, features his picks for restaurants, bars and attractions in the 10 cities he covered in the first season of his television show ''The Layover'' and content from his first show, ''Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations.'' ''The app is built around destinations and eateries I actually like,'' Mr. Bourdain wrote in an e-mail. ''The thing is intended to be useful and personal. If you're looking for hours of operation for the Eiffel Tower or Disney World, look elsewhere.''

THE sale of an $88 million penthouse at 15 Central Park West was entered into the city record books this week, enshrining it as both the most expensive transaction of the week and the highest price ever paid for a Manhattan apartment. It has been a wildly successful week for astronomically priced properties in the city. The top four sales were worth a total of nearly $156 million, including two homes each over $25 million and a downtown penthouse for $15 million.

IT is an intriguing and sad coincidence that a survey of FRANCESCA WOODMAN'S brief, tantalizing career in photography will be on view in New York at the Guggenheim Museum at the same time as Cindy Sherman has hers at the Museum of Modern Art. Born four years apart -- Ms. Sherman in 1954, Ms. Woodman in 1958 -- both women used their own shape-shifting, intensely charismatic and photogenic selves and bodies as subjects for staged, psychologically charged photographs. But Ms. Woodman committed suicide at the age of 22 in 1981, as Ms. Sherman was beginning her now long run as the most celebrated art photographer of the postmodern era. While Ms. Sherman mainly has played with clichés of popular culture, Ms. Woodman constructed gothic and surrealistic tableaus in which her body, often partly nude, appeared in decayed rooms obscured and fragmented by pieces of old furniture, mirrors and wallpaper. Had she lived, might Ms. Woodman have produced an oeuvre to rival Ms. Sherman's? There is no way to know, of course, but it is likely that the differences would have been as striking as the similarities. Through June 13, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (800) 329-6109, guggenheim.org.

''To me, they're almost like a sleepwalker's view of the city,'' the filmmaker Jem Cohen said of the ghostly Polaroids he has taken of New York over the past 30 years. ''I might walk around for a whole night, but only shoot one or two pictures.'' Elusive, impressionistic, full of vaporous landscapes, acid colors, deadpan close-ups and long, lonesome vistas, Mr. Cohen's images could be said to capture those parts of the city its residents have forgotten - or even, if such a thing is possible, what the city has forgotten about itself. The images emerge, like chemical memories, from a far-off or sometimes not-so-distant past: an aerial view of a fruit cart, a corner of the stage at CBGB, industrial ruins, a deliveryman in Chinatown, Brooklyn fog.

MILLER--Victoria. The owners and employees of Hilson Management Corporation extend heartfelt condolences to Myrna Penzel, our long-time Office Manager on the passing of her dear mother. We all hope for happier days to come.

The weakness in an economic system that increasingly demands that young people work for little or nothing is that most of the young people willing to do this come from families that can support them. Far from creating a huge talent pool from which employers can promote top talents, this limits the talent on offer. Not many poor people can afford months of an internship. ANNE THACKRAY,Toronto

The Cube, a temporary, sustainable restaurant designed by the Milanese architects Park Associati, is on the road again this spring. Conceived by Electrolux, a Swedish appliance brand, the restaurant is atop the Galleria Victor Emanuel in Milan through April 26. For its stint there, Michelin-starred chefs assume two-week residencies to experiment with locally sourced ingredients and regional cuisines. The atmosphere is interactive, thanks to its open kitchen arena, Electrolux-outfitted, where chefs like the Colleoni brothers, of San Martino in Bergamo, create three-hour-long lunches and dinners for 18 guests seated at a single table. (Reservations must be made in advance at electrolux.com/cube.) Contrary to what its name suggests, the Cube is more like a lunging trapezoid. Its glass walls and ceilings provide a front-row view of the historic Duomo's Gothic spires, with the Piazza del Duomo underfoot.

Adoring grandfather of Elizabeth, Tierney, Katherine, Kathleen, James and Jessie. Services and interment are private. A generous, caring and gracious man who will live on in our hearts and deeds forever.

The daffodils were bursting in Paris last week, and the mimosa trees were in full bloom outside many restaurants. The city's fall collections ended on Wednesday, and the guests attending the shows from all over the world -- the newest group from China -- were as much a spectacle as the shows themselves, as they were pursued by hundreds of street photographers looking for trends and celebrities.

CLIFF MAY (1908-1989) designed more than 1,000 ranch houses in the 1940s and '50s, helping define what we now think of as the California living dream. The photographer Catherine Opie was asked to photograph two May houses as they look today for ''Catherine Opie Photographs Cliff May,'' an exhibition of 15 images running concurrently with the exhibition ''Carefree California: Cliff May and the Romance of the Ranch House,'' at the University of California, Santa Barbara Art, Design and Architecture Museum through June 17. Ms. Opie's photographs of the houses (including the dwelling shown here, in one of Mr. May's planned communities) are portraits, revealing the houses' individual identities and the qualities that have ensured their enduring appeal. BROOKE HODGE
