KABUL, Afghanistan -- Afghan defense officials are impeding an investigation into accusations that members of their air force are smuggling opium and weapons and that an Afghan officer who shot and killed eight American service members last year may have been involved in the suspected trafficking, two American officials said. The accusations first surfaced in 2010 when some Afghan Air Force personnel voiced suspicions to American officers that smuggling was occurring on the military side of Kabul's airport. But the two American officials, who have knowledge of the investigation, say the inquiry by the American-led coalition has made scant progress in large part because top Afghan generals and Defense Ministry officials have provided only minimal cooperation, a fact that has deepened American suspicions.

GINZBERG--Marc. Treasured friend. We will miss you and all that you gave to so many. Our sympathies to your beloved Denyse, children, grandchildren and family. Gail and George

Where That Song Was Sung 1. THE CASA ROSADA, also known as the Pink House, is the Presidential Palace, home to the balcony that Evita often used to address throngs of Peronists -- known as the shirtless ones because many were poor laborers -- gathered in the Plaza de Mayo and up Avenida de Mayo. It became iconic as the setting for ''Don't Cry for Me Argentina,'' the signature song of the musical ''Evita.'' Free weekend tours of the palace allow visitors to peer from the balcony themselves. The Museo del Bicentenario, sometimes called the Presidential Museum, opened in 2011 behind the Casa Rosada. It contains objects related to the Peróns, such as presidential regalia, clothing and campaign posters.

Women Only, Please 6. CONGRESO AND THE SALON ROSADO OR SALON EVA PERóN The gray granite Congress building is among the most impressive neo-Classical -style structures in Buenos Aires. After women gained the right to vote in 1947, a wave of female politicians came into office. Evita opened the women-only Salon Rosado, or the Pink Room, so that they could discuss issues important to them without men around. Now called Salon Eva Perón and open to the public, the room bears a plaque explaining its importance, contains a bust of Eva Perón, and has retained its original furnishings. The building's rotunda was a viewing site during the official two-week mourning period for Evita.
WOLF--Barry. Farewell to the dearest of friends, who wisely lived life with gusto and joy. Abby and Bob Fink

Because of an editing error, an answer on Feb. 12 in the Q&A column, about the increasing number of single people in the United States, misquoted the New York University sociology professor Eric Klinenberg, who researches and writes about the issue. He said that ''globally 277 million people live alone;'' he did not say that 277 million Americans live alone. (Almost 50 percent of the 311 million people in the United States live alone.)

Oh I Could Tell You Stories 7. LA MUESTRA DE EVITA, EL MUSEO DEL PUEBLO The museum, which opened in 2009 in a union hall, houses material related to public works from the Perón era as well as objects, like rare photos and old magazine covers, from Evita's film and radio career from the late 1930s to 1945. Visitors might also have the chance to speak to one of the volunteers here who actually knew Evita. Eighty-something Clementina Beba Gil, above, worked on the women's suffrage campaign and will happily tell stories from the time period.

MIRZA--Muzzi, 3/2/58 - 3/10/07 The years with you were too few, but the precious memories are infinite. We were so blessed by your love! We strive to keep your brilliant spirit alive in us and we work to keep your legacy strong and lasting. Your generosity, laughter, wisdom and comforting presence are missed today and every day! With love and prayers, Sue, Alexander, Christina and Sean and all your loving family and friends.
TABAK--Robert Keith. May 18, 1955-March 6, 2012. Kind, Loving Sweet Man. Will be sorely missed by Marian, Sheldon, Jeffrey and Steven.

In honor of the long-awaited return of ''Mad Men'' on March 25, the Big City Book Club is getting in the spirit of 1960s Manhattan. Our next selection is James Baldwin's 1962 novel, ''Another Country,'' which chronicles the descent of the jazz drummer Rufus Scott. Baldwin recreates the world of Greenwich Village bohemians for an examination of race, emotional denial, professional rivalry, tortured marriages and other subjects that the AMC series has mined so well. Join us for an online conversation April 4 at a new time, from 7 to 10 p.m.

And Here She Is, 10 Stories Tall 10. MINISTRY OF HEALTH BUILDING One of Buenos Aires's tallest structures, the Ministry of Health was built by the Peróns and dominates Avenida Nueve de Julio. Because it was too large to demolish during the 1960s expansion of the avenue, a process that made it the world's widest boulevard, the road simply goes around it. A stage at the base of this building was the site of a 1951 rally at which the crowd, estimated at two million people, called for Evita to announce her candidacy for vice president. (She decided against it.) Today, the building is home to the city's newest Evita monument: two 10-story images of Evita's face on the central tower, made of steel. The work on the south facade was unveiled on July 26, 2011, the 59th anniversary of her death, by President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, a former first lady herself who has drawn comparisons with Eva Perón. A defiant Evita on the northern facade harangues the city's wealthy oligarchs, while on the south facade, facing a poor area, she is smiling. A few blocks away, dine at El General, filled with Perónist memorabilia.

Even Her Corpse Was Controversial 5. CONFEDERACIÓN GENERAL DEL TRABAJO The General Confederation of Labor is a union office building constructed by the Peróns in the late 1940s. Tourists will recognize it by the portrait of Evita on its central tower, lighted by an eternal flame. Her body was embalmed in this building and it lay here until 1955, when a military coup forced Juan Perón from power. (The body was brought back to Argentina in 1974 after a multi-country journey involving Spain and Italy.)

UNGAR--Evelyn (Shapiro), age 92, passed away March 3 at her home in Woodmere, NY. Widow of the late Daniel Isaac Ungar to whom she was married for 58 years. Formerly of Boca Raton and originally from Philadelphia and Brooklyn, as well as Valley Stream, NY. Cherished mother of Steven (Aviva) Ungar, Roberta (Allan) Greene, Jerrold and Diane Ungar. Treasured grandmother of Nicole (Charles) Poliacof, Evan (Allison) Greene, and Jonathan (Nora) Greene. Adoring great-grandmother of Jordan Daniel Greene. Shiva at home of Roberta Greene through Friday noon.

KNOWN for its decadent baubles, the Milanese jewelry house Pomellato is adding something new and, dare we say, improvisational to its couture PomPom collection this spring. ''Each piece embodies the freedom of creativity and is created around stones whose rarity, magnitude and irregular shapes render them unique,'' said Andrea Morante, the company's chief executive. These additions to PomPom (which was introduced in 2007) include 12 rings, 11 bracelets and 3 earrings set ''in a more daring way, one that breaks the rules of traditional fine jewelry,'' Ms. Morante said. The cocktail ring shown here is made of a cushion-cut red tourmaline bursting from an almost messy bed of flat rose-cut diamonds. Each piece is one of a kind and the collection arrives at Bergdorf Goodman Thursday. Prices start at $28,700. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

RUBLER--Robert S.,died on March 5 at the age of 75. Son of the late Helen and Dr. Herman Rubler. He was raised in Southampton, NY and attended The Gunnery School in Washington, CT. A graduate of The University of Pennsylvania, undergraduate and dental schools and U.S. Air Force Veteran, he had a long and highly successful career as a dentist in Manhattan and Scarsdale, NY. He is survived by his wife Leila; his son Neil and daughter-in-law Allison, his daughter Leslie and son-in-law Gregory Warner; his grandchildren Madeleine and Olivia Rubler and Jack Warner, his step granddaughters Hailey, Amanda and Brooke Warner and his sister Carol Rubler. Contributions in Robert's memory may be made to: White Plains Hospital Center: www.wphospital.org

An article on Feb. 26 about the mystery of a trove of Abstract Expressionist paintings that ended up in the courts misstated the connection of Mike Solomon to the Ossorio Foundation, which is devoted to the life and work of the Filipino painter Alfonso Ossorio. SCHWARTZ--George DDS, of New York, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband and sweetheart of Bobby. They shared a sixty year fairy tale marriage overflowing with love and devotion. Adored father of Steven (Peggy), Karen (Martin) and Robin. Cherished Papa of Adam (Daniela), Jarrett (Elina), Lindsay (Zachary) and Erin. Dear to Ursula, Charles and Eric. A trusted, caring and compassionate doctor. A beacon of strength and inspiration to all those whose lives he touched. In our hearts forever and always. Funeral service will be private.

ERDMAN--Joan Doris, of New York, wife of the late Saul Erdman, mother of Jill (Donald) Cohen, Julie Budd, Susan Erdman Shlang, grandmother and great-grandmother, passed away in Rhode Island on March 10, 2012. Joan, who was a beautiful, giving and artistic soul, was beloved by all who knew her and will be missed by so many. Service Sunday, March 11, 1pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Major League Soccer's 17th season kicked off Saturday night in Canada, where the Montreal Impact lost to the Vancouver Whitecaps, 2-0, in their first game in the league, but the league's most pressing questions involve last season's champion. Can Los Angeles become the first M.L.S. club to finish first over all (winning the Supporters Shield) in the regular season in three consecutive years? Can the Galaxy become the first team since Houston in 2006 and 2007 to win back-to-back M.L.S. Cup titles? The only other team to win two straight years was D.C. United, which captured the league's first two titles, in 1996 and 1997. And guess who coached them? Bruce Arena, who has brought back the core of the Galaxy's championship team, including the peripatetic David Beckham, who re-signed with the league rather than head back to Europe.

Enthusiast: Chris Pavone, author of the new novel ''The Expats,'' a thriller about an American expat couple living in Luxembourg. Object of Enthusiasm: This line of dialogue from ''Margin Call,'' as delivered by Jeremy Irons: ''Please, speak as you might to a young child or a golden retriever. It wasn't brains that got me here, I can assure you of that.''

OVERTON--Mary M.,90, of Hilton Head Island, SC died Sunday, February 26, 2012 at her home. Mary died much as she lived; a closed book to all, with exception of a privileged few the lucky ones. Mary is best described as stated in her book, "Cruising in the Fast Lane." "My life was gay, daring, sensible, seemingly without direction, not ordinary and rarely dull." Mary was born in Kankakee, Il, lived in Des Moines, South Bend, Syracuse, Stamford, Hollywood, Cambridge and New York. Her final years were spent on Hilton Head Island, SC with her beloved cat, Timothy. She is survived by Phillip Overton of Michigan, Douglas Overton of South Carolina and Hollee Temple, Shephanie Overton and Eric Temple, all of Florida. Please visit online at: theislandfuneralhome.com.

LOBEL--Selma, New York, New York. Selma was predeceased by her loving husband, Irving, as well as her inseparable companion, Monroe Geller. An article on Jan. 19 about Alanna Heiss, the art-show curator, referred incorrectly to a performance she presented at the Clocktower Gallery. It featured Charlotte Moorman playing a piece composed by Jim McWilliams on a chocolate-covered cello. It was not a Nam June Paik piece featuring a chocolate-covered woman playing a video cello, although Mr. Paik did create a famous (and chocolate-free) video-cello piece for Ms. Moorman in the 1960s. This correction was delayed because an e-mail from a reader pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

Fashionista Must-Stop 2. MUSEO EVITA Under Evita's direction, the Argentine state bought this mansion in the tony Palermo neighborhood in 1947 and turned it into a shelter for single mothers. After Juan Perón was deposed in 1955, the building remained in government hands as an office for the disabled. In 2002, the 50th anniversary of Evita's death, the building reopened as a museum showcasing her lavish wardrobe, as well as items from the Eva Perón Historical Foundation, including some of her early films. The foundation behind the museum is run by her grandniece, Cristina Alvarez Rodriguez. Its store sells Evita-related art and books. This year exhibitions will highlight the museum's own 10th anniversary as well as the 60th anniversary of Evita's death. The museum's cafe, above, is popular for its light, Mediterranean menu and has become a lunch destination favored by Kika Tarelli, director of Buenos Aires Fashion Week.

WEIGHING in at 10 pounds and more than 550 pages, ''Paris: Portrait of a City'' (Taschen, $69.99) is a photographic study of more than 160 years through the eyes of Jean Claude Gautrand, one of France's most eminent experts on photography. He spent three and a half years deep in the city's archives, libraries and private collections, searching for unknown images by anonymous photographers to pair with what he calls ''the greats'' (like this image of a 1950s carousel by Izis Bidermanas). The 500 photos, most of them black-and-white, show the transformation of the Paris landscape and the monumental events of the city's past, from the building of the Eiffel Tower to the riots of May 1968. It also captures more intimate moments: scenes of everyday pleasure and routine, in cafes, nightclubs and artists' ateliers. As Mr. Gautrand says, ''Paris happens to be the first city in the world to acquire a photographic record of itself.'' ELAINE SCIOLINO Elaine Sciolino writes The Moment's Lumière column from Paris.

GINZBERG--Marc, passed away March 9, age 82. Beloved husband of Denyse, father of Nadine, Michael, and Nicole (Steve), loving grandfather of Natasha and Jacob, brother of Sunny and David. He passed away after a short illness. Private interment. Memorial service to be announced.

A picture last Sunday with an obituary of the cinematographer Bruce Surtees was published in error. The photograph, supplied by Getty Images with incorrect caption information, shows Clint Eastwood on the set of his film ''High Plains Drifter'' with James Fargo, the assistant director; it does not show Mr. Eastwood with Mr. Surtees, the director of photography.

Like any sport, ice climbing has its own language. Ice that's too cold is brittle. Too warm, and it's plastic. And when conditions are perfect, you get ''fat, sticky, hero ice,'' according to Cory Jackson, a director of the Ouray Ice Park in Colorado. The ice has been especially heroic this winter in Ouray, a mining town hidden in a labyrinth of mountains and forests, a six-hour drive from Denver, Salt Lake City or Albuquerque. But Ouray is no secret among ice climbers, who descend on the town every year for the ice festival, where they take on the frozen waterfalls in the Uncompahgre Gorge. All day, climbers attack the ice cliffs; afterward, the party atmosphere is a release from the dangers on the mountain. But for an elite group, the real challenge of Ouray is the mixed climbing competition: a treacherous route of ice and rock that is kept secret until the race begins. This year, of the 16 who entered, only 2 finished -- six seconds apart. Water source: Overflow from City of Ouray municipal water tank. amount of water sprayed over the Gorge each night: Between 150,000and 200,000 gallons. number of shower heads used: 150. Cumulative vertical climbing terrain: More than 3 miles. First prize in the mixed ice-climbing competition: $2,000.

Free agency after the lockout was a scramble last year once the new N.F.L. labor deal was signed. Teams were unsure when free agency would begin, and at least one front-office staff went home for the night to rest up for what it thought would be a frenzied start the next day, before racing back to the office when the league suddenly let the signings begin. But labor peace does not mean this off-season will be dull, not with the future Hall of Fame quarterback Peyton Manning job hunting; two superstar quarterbacks at the top of the draft order; a coveted backup, Matt Flynn, also on the free-agent market; and more than one team bracing for the consequences of the New Orleans Saints' bounty scandal. With free agency beginning Tuesday afternoon and the draft six weeks later, the 2012 season has already begun. Here is a look at what each team needs as it heads into the N.F.L.'s shopping season.

HYMAN--Edgar. Born January 15, 1932, Edgar Hyman was a Manhattanite, retired in Woodstock. Married Marie-Claude in Paris. Sons Harold and Philippe. Owned Lady Continental, Italian shoe store, on Madison. Edgar left us March 5, 2012, surrounded by family.

KLEIN--Frances, at the glorious age of 85, died peacefully March 6, 2012. Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Martin and Judy. Adoring grandmother of Arielle and David. She leaves behind brother Irving, sister Faith and was predeceased by her brother Sidney and sister Mildred. She was truly loved and will be greatly missed.

Get Your Evita Here! 9. BOUTIQUE NORA INIESTA At this appointment-only boutique, you'll find creative, high-end memorabilia. Look for paintings, bric-a-brac and accessories for men and women, like Evita ties and scarves.

Bronze Goddess 11. EVITA MONUMENT AND THE NATIONAL LIBRARY There was no official monument to Evita until 1999, when this bronze statue, reminiscent of a 1960s church sculpture, was unveiled. It's on a hillside below the National Library, which sits at the site of the former presidential residence, where Evita died. (The residence was demolished after the coup.) The statue roughly marks the spot where Juan Perón had planned to build a colossal monument to himself, Evita and a symbolic worker, or Descamisado. After you've seen it, have coffee nearby at Un Café con Perón inside the presidential archive and research office Instituto Nacional Juan Domingo Perón, where tourists and locals pose with a statue of Juan Perón.

WHILE ''Belle du Jour'' was all about Gallic beauty (starring Catherine Deneuve in Yves Saint Laurent and Roger Vivier Pilgrim pumps), Jean Aurel's 1968 film ''Manon 70'' has the actress wearing Emanuel Ungaro with statement sunglasses, a pair of that inspired Oliver Peoples to create the new Mande frame ($340), shown here. In a pivotal scene, Ms. Deneuve's character, Manon, leaves the airport wearing cat-eye frames just as she decides to abandon one lover for another she met right before boarding the plane. She's a free spirit who needs the perfect amber shades to hide the intention in her wide eyes, or preserve the mystery that adds to her character's allure. Available at Oliver Peoples SoHo, (212) 925-5400. STEPHANIE LaCAVA

While both Hollywood and Nollywood create mainly garbage, Nigerian films are at least exuberant garbage. By contrast, the endless predictable sequels and other dreary ''entertainment'' commodities that Hollywood churns out are elevated only by their budgets; that is, they are professionally rendered trash. Nigerian films are much more honestly bad. That doesn't make them any better as ''art,'' but they do have an innocence that I find admirable. So I applaud the efforts of Kunle Afolayan even as I suspect he will fail to find an audience outside Africa. The larger failure could be if he actually does. MAX ALEXANDER, South Thomaston, Me., posted on nytimes.com

HAWTHORNE--Hazel R.,98, died peacefully on February 25, 2012, in Greenwich, CT. She was widow of Joseph C. Hawthorne, violist and symphony conductor. Hazel is survived by three children, Nancy S. Dickinson, Peter G. Snider, and Caro C. Hawthorne, as well as by five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In late summer there will be a memorial service in Provincetown, MA.

IF you like your entertainment blood chilling instead of heartwarming -- and failed to succumb to the magnolia-scented charms of ''The Help'' -- you might consider spending time with ''THE MAIDS,'' which opens on Thursday in a Red Bull Theater production. Like ''The Help,'' an Oscar nominee for best picture this year, ''The Maids'' considers the problems of sorely put-upon domestics, who are routinely humiliated by their affluent, self-centered employer. But because ''The Maids'' was written by Jean Genet, one of the most subversive dramatists ever, sentimentality doesn't figure in this coruscating one-act drama from 1947. The fire of homicidal rebellion glows in the hearts of the play's title characters (who were inspired by an infamous French murder case of 1933). And they do their darnedest to fan that spark into flame by acting out fantasies of their much-loathed mistress's destruction. Jesse Berger directs this in-the-round presentation of Genet's identity-bending chef-d'oeuvre. Ana Reeder and Jeanine Seralles portray the sisters in servitude, while the wonderful J. Smith-Cameron (of television's ''True Blood'' and the movie ''Margaret'') is the eminently killable lady of the house. Through April 1, the Theater at St. Clements, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 325-3101, redbulltheater.com; $25 to $75.

PENDIAS--Sophie Rene, of Garden City, NY, March 7, 2012. Loving wife of the late Stephen Peter Pendias, devoted mother of Joan Pendias and Calli McCaw, adoring grandmother of Matthew Checki, dear sister of Helen Papadeas and caring mother-in-law of Robert McCaw. Her loving spirit and zest for life will be missed by all. Viewing at Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, NY 2-4 and 7-9pm on Sunday, March 11. Services on Monday, March 12 at 10:30am at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral, West Hempstead, NY. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery.

STEVE KAZEE was more than a bit hesitant to sport spots. ''It's not really what I would go out and get on my own,'' he confessed while gearing up to wear trend-centric polka dots for a recent photo shoot. ''But it looks cool. I'd talk to Tom Ford about an opening night outfit.'' That outfit Mr. Kazee is referring to would be for the spotlight he'll soon be in again as the star of ''Once,'' the little musical with the big heart that's heading to Broadway (it's in previews now) after celebrating a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway at the New York Theater Workshop in the East Village. Based on the 2006 film about a Dublin busker's fateful romance with a young Czech piano player, the show features songs, including the Oscar-winning ''Falling Slowly,'' performed by a captivating Mr. Kazee as Guy, who accompanies himself with guitar skills that he's been honing since the age of 13. Here, he wears a Tom Ford shirt ($990) and tie ($245). ''Once'' is in previews at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, and is scheduled to open March 18. Go to oncemusical.com. BRUCE PASK

FOURTEEN aspiring fashion designers. Mentors and judges from within the industry. A supermodel at center stage. You've seen it before? Probably not quite like this. ''FASHION STAR,'' a new competition series on NBC having its premiere Tuesday at 9:30 p.m. (future episodes are Tuesdays at 10), takes the timeworn formula of ''Project Runway'' and merges it with something akin to ''The Voice.'' Each week buyers from Macy's, Saks Fifth Avenue and H&M bid -- or don't -- on contestants' outfits for the right to carry that designer's creations exclusively. Right after each episode viewers can buy the winning clothing as well. At the end of the season one designer will receive $6 million in orders from the three retailers. Sure, it's a little schlocky. The first episode opens with a runway extravaganza featuring lingerie designed by Elle Macpherson, the show's host, worn by masked Paris Hilton look-alikes straddling motorcycles. The high-decibel soundtrack makes you want to press mute. But the good-natured mentors -- the pop-culture princesses Jessica Simpson and Nicole Richie and the designer John Varvatos -- are willing to cut some slack where others might not. And the buyers, Caprice Willard, Terron E. Schaefer and Nicole Christie, keep the outlandishness in check by proving that they mean business.

DUBOIS--Carol Johnston Mali, 90, died peacefully at home in Oyster Bay Cove, NY on March 3, 2012, and was buried March 6 at a graveside service in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Tarrytown, NY. Born October 6, 1921 in New York City, daughter of John Taylor Johnston Mali, Belgian Consul General, and Caramai Carroll. Educated at Spence School, Vassar and Barnard Colleges. Widow of Eugene DuBois (1911-1975), travel writer and airline executive. A passionate environmentalist, she served for many years as President of Action for Preservation and Conservation of the North Shore of Long Island and on the board of the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery & Aquarium. She was a forty-year volunteer for the American Red Cross and taught a current events class at the Doubleday Babcock Senior Center in Oyster Bay. Survived by four daughters: Caroline Starin DuBois, Oyster Bay; Abigail DuBois, Arlington, MA; Patricia DuBois,Topsham, ME; Ariane DuBois, Washington, DC; and three granddaughters: Grace DuBois Johnston, Caramai DuBois Johnston, and Anna DuBois Bigelow. Donations in her memory may be made to the CSH Fish Hatchery & Aquarium, 1660 Rte 25A, CSH, New York 11724, or environmental organization of your choice.

SHERMAN--Mira Gutman, 88, Media, PA, formerly of New York. Holocaust survivor, loving mother of Sarah Poncz, proud grandmother of Ariella (Tal) Golomb and Elisa (Will) McEnroe and adoring great- grandmother of Eden and Dalia Golomb. Predeceased by husband Philip, son Leonard and granddaughter Esther Poncz.

Andrij Dobriansky, a bass who sang more than 900 performances with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Feb. 1 in Manhattan. He was 81. The cause was complications of diabetes and a heart condition, according to his family, which did not make news of the death widely known until this week.

INDIANAPOLIS SPEAKING here last week at the Green Truck Summit, an event held in conjunction with the Work Truck Show, Steven Chu, the head of the Energy Department, called on commercial fleet owners to consider converting their vehicles to run on natural gas, which he characterized as a ''no-brainer'' alternative to gasoline and diesel.

FELLER--Allan. Allan loved his family and his friends and he was loved right back. His positive outlook on life will be missed. Our deepest condolences to Nancy, Adam and family. Diane & Marshall Felenstein

Pay Your Respects 3. DUARTE FAMILY TOMB, Recoleta Cemetery. After 24 years of being shuttled about Argentina and even being buried in Italy for a few years, Evita's body came to rest in 1976 in this simple black tomb belonging to the family of her father, Juan Duarte. (He is buried in Chivilcoy, a few hours away in Buenos Aires Province.) Her admirers place flowers and notes at the tomb nearly every day, and the crowds grow to the thousands on July 26, the anniversary of her death. On Oct. 17, the date Juan Perón came to power, the arrangements -- many from political leaders and unions -- grow in size and number.

AT its essence, the Baja 1000, a long-running off-road race on Mexico's Baja peninsula, is a woolly, slightly unhinged competition celebrating horsepower and torque. This year, a new vehicle class called Ultra Green will give the race an air, however subtle, of environmental stewardship. Jeffrey Smith, a successful competitor in the 2011 race, has set his sights on winning the class in its inaugural year with a purely electric racecar. He and his team are building an E.V. with twin WarP electric motors rated at a combined 400 horsepower and 600 pound-feet of torque, and five packs of Flux Power batteries. The car is expected to achieve a top speed of 110 miles per hour and a range of about 80 miles.

SCHREIBER--Phyllis March 8, 2012. Phyllis Schreiber, a well- known collector and promoter of avant- garde Russian art, died today at the age of 94 in Palm Beach, Florida. Largely self-educated, she obtained a degree in art history in mid life and was among the very few in the 1960s and 1970s who identified the works of Goncharova, Larianov, Konchalevsky, Bogorovsky, Baronoff-Rosinee, Exter, Kluin, Suetin among others, all of whom worked in Soviet-exile, as powerful expressions of the politically unfettered mind and eye and displaying unique composition, color and subject matter. Beautiful and elegant, she was a forceful personality who was a low-key feminist before the label became fashionable. Active in community art and welfare projects for her entire life, in the 1950s, she was an early and outspoken supporter of community and school integregation in New Rochelle. Her late husband Samuel Schreiber, a designer of modern urban bus transportation systems and successful businessman, to whom she was married for 62 years, predeceased her in 2000. She leaves her sons Dale and Jim, nine grandchildren, three step-grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren. Contributions should be sent to Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Standwich Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

ELBAUM--Rosalind Mindlin, on March 7, 2012. Beloved mother of Susan Elbaum and Constance Goldsmith. Dear mother-in-law of Paul Goldsmith. Adored grandmother of Ashley. Graveside service Monday, March 12, 2012, 11am at Union Field Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Jewish Family and Children's Services of California, designated for Seniors at Home.

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about the increasing popularity of the Federal Housing Administration's 203(k) loans, also called ''rehab'' loans, in New Jersey, misstated the size of the down payment on such loans. It is 3.5 percent, not $3,500.

In ''Speed, Tips and Fear on Wheels,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, J. David Goodman followed Lin Dakang, a deliveryman for a Chinese restaurant on the Upper East Side, through his nightly rounds. Readers on NYTimes.com debated whether delivery bicycles were a menace and what constituted a fair tip; a selection of responses is below. Readers also commented on Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, about members of the Park Slope Food Co-op who are trying to organize a boycott of Israeli products.

PARIS Fashion Week ended with a grand party on a stairwell. Or that's what it looked like walking into the Arts Décoratifs wing of the Louvre on Wednesday for the opening of an exhibition on Louis Vuitton and Marc Jacobs. Hundreds of people were just standing there, crammed on the marble stairs leading to the show, presumably because drinks weren't allowed inside. The artist Takashi Murakami, who collaborated with Mr. Jacobs on a ridiculously successful line of handbags a decade ago, tried to make his way through the crowd. Lee Radziwill toured the neighboring Jean-Paul Goude exhibition, which was otherwise empty. Sarah Jessica Parker, who flew in just for the show, asked, ''How is Marc ever going to top that?'' She was speaking of the Vuitton show that morning, in which a custom-made locomotive discharged the models onto the runway.

ROME -- When five officials from Italy's internal revenue service entered the Dal Duca restaurant in Rome's trendy Trastevere neighborhood one night two weeks ago, they were not there to eat. Instead, over three hours the tax collectors interviewed the staff, took a look at the books and then checked out the cash register receipts at the end of a busy night of dinner service.

An article last Sunday about the Amelia Island Concours d'Élégance misstated an aspect of the history of a Corvette concept car, the Mako Shark design study of 1961. It remains intact and was not rebodied as a styling exercise for the 1968 Corvette production car.

MELARTIN--Cody Samuel, age 26, of Montclair NJ, died Friday, February 24, after a courageous struggle with a long-term illness. His perseverance and determination to live despite constant debilitating pain were testimony to his strength of character and love of family. Cody will be remembered for his perceptive and sensitive understanding of the world around him, his brilliant sense of humor, his love and compassion for animals, and his thoughtfulness towards others. He had a special place in his heart for his beloved cat, Willy, who pre-deceased him in May, 2011. We all miss Cody terribly, and will forever. Born in Brooklyn Heights NY, Cody attended the St. Ann's preschool for two years, after which he and his family moved to Montclair, where Cody then attended the Montclair public schools. Cody is survived by loving parents, Lisa Waitzman Melartin and Jussi Melartin, adoring sisters Noelle and Lilly, devoted grandparents Barbara Sheerin, Drs. Liisa and Richmond Prehn, and Dr. Erkki Melartin, special uncle Michael Waitzman, caring aunt Riikka Melartin, and a large, loving extended family of aunts, uncles and cousins. Pre-deceased by grandfathers Simon Waitzman and Raymond Sheerin. A memorial service was held March 3rd at the Montclair Unitarian Universalist Congregation. Donations in Cody's memory may be made to the American Migraine Foundation: http://www.americanmigrainefoundation.org.

An article in some editions on Feb. 26 about Harvard's loss to Penn in men's basketball carried an erroneous dateline. The article was reported from Boston, where the game was played at the Ray Lavietes Pavilion; it was not reported from the Harvard campus in Cambridge.

I empathize with Etgar Keret's conflicted feelings about the plight of the hirsute. I have had a beard for more than 20 years. A few years back, eager for some change, I shaved it down to stubble. My 14-year-old son looked at me quizzically. ''Different, huh?'' I asked. ''Not really,'' he replied. ''I just never realized you had a double chin.'' The beard is fuller again and will remain so until my death. TOM HAYOWYK, Somers, Conn.

SCHWARTZ--Beatrice (nee Glassman), age 92, died on March 5, 2012. Loving wife of the late Emanuel Schwartz, mother of Charles and Alice, Howard and Meryl, and Lois Feldman. Adoring grandmother of Brad and Ryuko, Adam and Janine, Heather and Jonathan Stern, Lee, Stacy, Lonnie and Kaitlin. Greatgrandmother of Ethan. Bea lived life to the fullest and her memory will forever shine bright.

Carlos Slim Helú, the Mexican billionaire, is financing an Internet television network called Ora.tv that will feature Larry King, the former CNN interviewer, in a return to the interviewer's chair. The network, to be announced on Monday, is the latest indication of Mr. Slim's interests in Internet broadcasting and in televisionlike content. It will have a slate of shows of varying lengths and will stream them via the Internet to computers, phones and television sets in the United States, Latin America and elsewhere, bypassing traditional television distribution systems.

AUSTIN, Tex. As words and articles became digitized over the last 15 years, they began to float, there for the plucking and replication elsewhere. Words like ''curation'' and ''aggregation'' became the language of the realm, sometimes used as substitutes for describing the actual creation of content. What had once been a craft was rapidly becoming a task.

To her many admirers, Elizabeth Bartlett Grannis was a humanitarian, social reformer and pioneering suffragist. To the First Church Disciples of Christ, which Grannis had attended faithfully for five decades, she was a ''disturber of the peace.'' Translation: she didn't think the pastor - a popular and successful rainmaker for the congregation - ought to be making unwanted advances on women. Or men. And Grannis further believed that a young girl whom she had informally adopted ought to be welcomed at Sunday worship. Unfortunately, the year was 1906. And the child was not only squirmy: she was black.

An article on March 1 about independent college counseling services erroneously included statistics about the benefits of independent counseling from a 2011 survey. They applied to undergraduate applicants -- not to students seeking master's degrees, which was the focus of the article. (The survey showed that 23 percent of admissions directors at private master's-granting universities and 20 percent from regional and state universities found the use of private counselors to be effective for undergraduate applicants.)

PETSCHEK--Max L. Memorial services will be held at 10:00am Friday, March 16, 2012 at Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 88th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Max's memory may be made to Gift Of Life International. (giftoflifeinternational.org).

CHO--Sihak Henry, 78, passed away on March 8, beloved husband of Myung Sook. He is the loving father of Kenneth K. and David P., and the grandfather of Jonathan, Lauren, Stephanie and Brittany. Korean Community leader and Martial Arts Pioneer recipient of the 2011 Lifetime Achievement award by the President's Council on Sports, Fitness & Nutrition. Services will be held on Sunday, March 11, Monday, March 12 and the funeral on March 13. For more information, please visit: www.henrycho.com.

SWENSON--Nancy Tiernan, passed away peacefully on March 8, 2012 at her home in Dallas, TX. Born December 2, 1924, to Martin F and Purcell Tiernan, she spent her childhood in Essex Fells, NJ. Her four siblings predeceased her. She married Bruce Swenson of Montclair, on December 30, 1944. They moved to Dallas and raised six children all of whom are living. After 66 years of marriage Bruce predeceased Nancy on July 6, 2011. Nancy won many tennis tournaments and held top rankings in the senior divisions. She was ranked number one in Texas five times. Her top national singles ranking was second in the 55's. She was ranked in the top five in the country in doubles five times. In 1998 Nancy was diagnosed with Parkinson's. She combated its symptoms without complaint. She became involved with The Voice Project, a foundation dedicated to helping Parkinson's patients preserve their speaking ability and she received great enjoyment, appearing in several of the Project's plays. In 2010 the foundation awarded Nancy its annual Proud-to-be Loud Award for "extraordinary courage, perseverance and determination." She is survived by her six children and their families; including 11 grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Her children and their families are: Bruce (Smokey) Swenson and his wife, Lindsley, of Dallas, and their children Tiernan Cavanna and Tiernan's husband Kieran Cavanna, and Harris Swenson and his wife Lauren. Tiernan and Kieran are the parents of three of Nancy's great-grandchildren while Harris and Lauren are the parents of the fourth; Stephen Swenson and his wife, Carla, of Dallas; Christopher Swenson and his wife, Emily, of Montclair, and their children, Billy, Mike and Lisa; Merritt Swenson, of San Antonio and her sons, Swen, Jamie and Peter McCulloch; Carroll Swenson-Roberts and her husband, Truett Roberts of Dallas, and their daughter, Sara Roberts; Nancy E. Swenson, of Dallas, and her daughters Allison and Hayley Caldwell. Nancy's companionship, cheerfulness, graceful determination, full love of life and love for us will be greatly missed. A Funeral Mass will be performed at St. Joseph's Church in Richardson, TX on Wednesday, March 14th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the Parkinson Voice Project, 500 N. Coit Rd Suite 2085, Richardson, TX 75080.

The nasty litigation between a group of banks and the bond insurer MBIA just got nastier. A lawyer for the banks has accused Joseph W. Brown Jr., MBIA's chief executive, of illegally trading in MBIA stock while in possession of confidential information. The insider trading claim was made during a hearing late Friday at Federal District Court in Manhattan.

Intel formally issued the specs Tuesday on its new Xeon E5 processor, a chip designed for use in the servers of big data centers. It is impressive, with an 80 percent improvement in processing power. You can read about the specs from Intel and from The Register, a news site specializing in hardcore tech issues. As much as processing power, what came through just as clearly in Intel's announcement is how much Intel's world has changed. Intel makes great technology, but it faces new competitors, new alliances, and new ideas about computing. In this regard, the Xeon announcement also told a sometimes desperate and defensive story about Intel's competitive landscape.

If there is one thing a president has to do in an election year, it is to find a way to balance official duties with campaign travel. Too much focus on official duties can make an incumbent look isolated and aloof. Too much electioneering risks exposing the president to attacks that he is losing focus on the nation's problems. President Obama will confront just that challenge in the coming days as he hosts a world leader and then travels to South Korea - cramming donor events and re-election rallies in between. His Republican rivals have already accused him of holding too many fund-raisers and playing too much golf.

HILL--Jeremy Michael, passed away March 7, age 43, after a tenacious battle with melanoma. Beloved son of Maureen and the late Tom and dearly loved brother, brother-in-law and uncle of Antony and Bae, Tim and Amy, and Maddy, Tom and Abigail. Jeremy's sharp intellect, understated generosity and unique perspectives on life will be greatly missed by his family and many friends from the U.S., New Zealand and around the world. Jeremy earned an MBA from the University of Chicago Booth School of Business and was Managing Director, Global Co-Head of Equity Finance, J. P. Morgan. He served on the Board of Advisors of the NYU Cancer Institute and Board of Trustees of the SAMFund for Young Adult Survivors of Cancer. Donations can be made by mail to Richard Shapiro MD, 160 East 34th St., New York, NY 10016 (checks payable to NYU Melanoma Research c/o Richard Shapiro') or to the SAMFund, online at http://www.thesamfund.org/. A memorial service will be held at 4.30pm on Wednesday March 14 at the Columbus Citizens Foundation, 8 East 69th St, New York, NY 10021.

An article on Thursday about the arrest of an Indian journalist as part of the investigation into last month's bombing in New Delhi of a van carrying the wife of an Israeli diplomat, one of three episodes that occurred at roughly the same time for which Israeli officials have blamed Iran, misidentified the location where a bomb was defused. It was in Georgia, not in Ukraine.

LOGAN--Malcolm. My heartfelt condolences to the Logan family and Malcolm's dear friend and business partner, Andrew Nelson. My thoughts are with you. Malcolm was a very special man and will surely be missed by all those whose lives he touched. Steven Neckman

The Catamounts have 32 road victories over the past three seasons, tied with Murray State for the most in the country.

There are Web sites that cover the actions and inactions of Congress. And there are Web sites that let voters contact their members of Congress and comment. CQ Roll Call wants to bridge the two. This week, the media company is revamping one of its Web sites, Congress.org, with an eye toward what one of its executives, Peter Anthony, calls ''informed action.''

Devoted grandmother of Richard, Sandra, and Sharon Yampell (Roie Some), Bryan Jacoby and Deborah (Mark) Ori. Great-grandmother of Daniel, Billy and Lucy.

An article last Monday about ''John Carter,'' a new movie based on the Edgar Rice Burroughs novel ''Princess of Mars,'' which was the first of a series, misstated the name of one of two warring city-states in the story. It is Zodanga, not Zadonga. The article also misidentified the publisher of the editions whose covers were illustrated by Frank Frazetta. It is the Science Fiction Book Club -- not Ballantine, which published other editions of the books.

CANNOLD--Dan (David Leon), died peacefully at his home in Rye, New York, March 10, 2012, surrounded by his loving family. Dan, Danny, Dad, Poppa, Uncle Danny, Cousin Danny was a man for all seasons and much, much more. As a son, brother, then husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather, uncle, cousin, teacher, business leader, historian, philanthropist, architect, artist-in-life, raconteur, and dedicated, dependable friend to all, he was our truest hero. Few of us can excel at all the roles in life that we are called upon to fill; Danny was our role model in each and every one of them. Dan was a source of limitless wisdom for each of us, for family and friends, far and wide across the globe. He was selfless, generous and devoted to those he loved, to his beliefs, particularly as an American, a Jew and to Israel. His commitment to Westchester Jewish Center, Weizmann Institute, The Technion, UJA and AIPAC are among many that were important to him and will be everlasting beacons for us all. Dan's remarkable trajectory of self-made success in business began with the leadership of Manhattan and Bronx Electric Wire and Cable, later Manhattan Cable, then finally The Manhattan Group of companies. The son of Sidney and Anna Cannold, brother to Sheryl Cannold Benjamin, Dan grew up in the Bronx. A proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and Rochambeau Avenue, Dan went on to the University of Iowa. It was toward the end of his US Army service during WWII that he met Beverly Brodwin in Larchmont, New York. He proposed to Bev on Valentine's Day, 1945 and from that moment on, their lives were blessed by a loving, romantic partnership for the ages. Married later that year, they soon moved together to Scarsdale, later to Rye, Pound Ridge and Palm Beach. Dan and Bev celebrated their 66th wedding anniversary last August, continuing to inspire all their family, all who know them, with the power of love they shared with each other and those around them. Dan and Bev won many dance contests together; they were a joy to watch for those of us fortunate enough to be there. In Dan's final days, he never missed an opportunity to give or blow a kiss, or sing a love song, be it in English, Hebrew, Polish, Italian or Yiddish to his Bev. Their sons Mitchell, Scott, Tom, daughters-in-law Dori, Gail and Kim, grandchildren Anna Cannold Weiser and Dan Weiser, Lilly, Sammi, Noah, Spencer, Julie, great grandson Elliot Cannold Weiser, have lost their giant. Yet, they appreciate fully that they have been immeasurably empowered by Dad and will want to hold his hand, his love, his memory and his life lessons close to their hearts for all time. The Cannold Family wishes to thank all of the doctors, nurses and extraordinary caregivers who devoted themselves to making Dan's final year, his 91st, healthy, happy and peaceful. Dan lived his life to the fullest, with style, humor, judgment, dignity and high character. We all know Dad will be singing and dancing forever in the stars, dreaming sweet dreams of his Bev and the family of which he was so proud. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Westchester Jewish Center. Funeral Services will be held at Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, New York on Monday, March 12th at 10am with interment to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.
BUTLER--Paul 32/42-1/12/10 Not a day passes without loving thoughts of you. Jonell, family and dear friends

Leonard F. Joy, who for more than two decades led New York's federal public defender's office, which represented some of the city's most infamous criminals, died on Sunday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 81. The cause was hemolytic anemia, a blood disorder, his daughter, Elizabeth, said.

GUITON--Margaret (Peggy), died peacefully at her home in New York City on Saturday, March 10, 2012 at the age of 94. She held degrees from Bryn Mawr, the University of Chicago and Radcliffe, where she was awarded a Ph.D. in political theory. During World War II and the immediate postwar years, she worked for the State Department and in the press section of the U.S. Embassy in Paris where she met her future husband, Jacques Guiton, with whom she enjoyed a long and happy marriage. He died in 2007. French literature was always Peggy's passion. Her published writings include a co-authored work on the French novel, a book on the fables of La Fontaine and most recently a collaboration on a translation of poems by Francis Ponge. She is survived by her daughter Nicolette, son John, daughter-in-law Linda Chesis and granddaughter Sophie Guiton. Her eldest daughter Jacqueline died in 2001.

A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixar's top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, ''Dr. Seuss' The Lorax'' (Universal Pictures) -- featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito -- was North America's No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. Finishing a distant second with about $30.6 million in ticket sales was Disney's ''John Carter,'' a space epic directed by Andrew Stanton of ''Finding Nemo'' and ''Wall-E'' fame for Pixar. Analysts say Disney faces a $100 million to $165 million loss because of the film's poor opening-weekend results. Disney noted that ''John Carter'' took in an additional $70.6 million overseas and said the film received a B-plus score from audiences in exit polls. ''Project X'' (Warner Brothers) was third, taking in about $11.6 million for a two-week total of $40.1 million. ''Silent House,'' an inexpensive horror movie from Open Road Films, placed fourth, with about $7.01 million, while ''Act of Valor'' (Relativity Media) was fifth, taking in $7 million for a three-week total of $56.1 million.

When the Marquette senior forward Jae Crowder attended the Big East's preseason media day in New York last fall, he was a bit stunned to learn that he had received honorable-mention all-conference recognition. South Dakota State has had little trouble adjusting to life at college basketball's highest level. Only four seasons after moving up from Division II, the Jackrabbits, champions of the Summit Conference, will be making their first appearance in the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament. They are seeded 14th in the South Region. Although this will be a new experience for South Dakota State, it is familiar with the postseason. The Jackrabbits reached the N.C.A.A. Division II tournament 24 times. Norfolk State, which is in its 15th season in Division I, is also in the tournament for the first time.

Wife of the late Amos Landman. Mother of Jonathan and Margot. Grandmother of Rachel and Aaron. Memorial service to be announced. Donations to Planned Parenthood, www.plannedparenthoodaction.org

SAN FRANCISCO -- With a couple of old desks, a beat-up couch and an off-white white board, the office space at 149 Turk Street, in this city's seedy Tenderloin district, is hardly remarkable. A collection of worn detective novels sits on the bookshelf, a couple of American flags hang limply from the wall and a coffee machine constantly percolates in the back kitchen. It is the tenants who set 149 Turk apart: a ragtag group of current and former drug users who make no apologies about their fondness for illegal narcotics, intravenous experiences and the undeniable rush of getting high.

Aaron Craft was sitting in math class during his junior year at Liberty-Benton High School in Findlay, Ohio, when he noticed the teacher had written 60 decimals from the mathematical constant, pi, on the chalkboard. Craft, who says he can retain information remarkably well, typed the number into his calculator and began to study. Today, he can recite all 60 digits on cue. He also can solve a Rubik's Cube in 70 seconds.

Elite universities across the country are sometimes referred to as the Harvard of their region. Vanderbilt, for example, has been called the Harvard of the South. It is worth pointing out that this proclamation is usually made by those associated with Vanderbilt, not those associated with Harvard. This week, bragging rights involving basketball and books could be on the line when the No. 5 Commodores face the actual Harvard, seeded 12th, in an East Region Round of 64 game. For now, Harvard may have an edge on both fronts: Jeremy Lin is the only player from either university currently playing in the N.B.A.

Memphis, which is playing as well as any team in the country and has a roster stocked with top-shelf recruits, is a popular pick. But St. Louis has quietly cobbled together an impressive season of its own, going 12-4 in the Atlantic 10 while playing the disciplined style and temperate tempo of Coach Rick Majerus. Until Memphis's Josh Pastner proves himself more, he has a decisive disadvantage against an experienced coach like Majerus. This pick will help earn points in your pool and not hurt too much if you are wrong: neither team will get by Michigan State in the second round.

DORAL, Fla.-A week after he posted the best closing round of his pro career to spur talk of a resurgence,Tiger Woodsfailed to complete the final round of the W.G.C.-CadillacChampionship on Sunday, casting doubt on his participation in the Masters next month. Woods was three over par after 11 holes - and six under for the tournament, 10 strokes behind the eventual winner, Justin Rose - when he hit a 321-yard drive on No. 12, a par 5. He shook the hand of his playing partner, Webb Simpson, who said Woods told him, ''I've got to go in.''

Davidson is making its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance since Stephen Curry's dazzling run to the Round of 8 in 2008. Whenever the 13th-seeded Wildcats' tournament run ends this year, they will have plenty of options to make up missed schoolwork. Davidson has one of the nation's most unusual honor codes. In-class examinations are not proctored, and professors often assign take-home tests. Students also schedule their own final exams so they can take them when they best fit their academic schedules. And to add to this low-stress setup, the university provides full-service laundry for students at no charge.

Google has a bit of an image problem. For people peering in, Google Plus, Google's latest attempt at social media, has been a ghost town. Some say it is a desolate wasteland that is used only by, well, Google employees and a few Google faithful.

Notre Dame's stunning run in the Big East regular season was one of the best stories in college basketball this season. But the Irish sputtered away from the Joyce Center late in the season and looked out of gas during the conference tournament at Madison Square Garden. Xavier looks as if it has recovered from the brawl with Cincinnati in early December that sidetracked its strong start. The quickness of Tu Holloway and Mark Lyons will give the Fighting Irish guards fits on the perimeter, and the freshman Dezmine Wells is not at all playing like a freshman.

The Labor Department reported on Friday an increase of 227,000 jobs in February, the third consecutive month with a gain of more than 200,000 jobs. When users searched for the term ''jobs'' related to a specific company, the corporate sites with the largest share of traffic included large employers offering entry-level jobs, like U.P.S., FedEx, Walmart and Target. More common searches were those for job-listing sites, like Indeed (1.94 percent share) and Monster (1.3 percent), and for broad terms like ''usa jobs'' (1.17 percent) or ''higher ed jobs'' (0.12 percent). SHELLY FREIERMAN

8 P.M. (Sho2) FAIR GAME (2010) Naomi Watts, above center, plays Valerie Plame Wilson, the C.I.A. operative whose cover was blown in apparent retaliation for the actions of her husband, the diplomat Joseph Wilson. Sean Penn portrays Mr. Wilson, who, having checked out allegations that Saddam Hussein had purchased large quantities of uranium and found nothing, wrote an Op-Ed article in The New York Times refuting President George W. Bush's statement in a State of the Union address that Iraq had indeed sought nuclear material in Africa. A result was a campaign by Mr. Wilson to expose the culprits and to defend his reputation and his wife's against an onslaught of spin and innuendo. The film's portrait of the modern marriage ''is graceful and subtle,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times of this drama from Doug Liman. ''That the rest of the movie is sometimes less so has to do with circumstances beyond the control of the characters or the filmmakers. American movies demand happy endings, in which wrongs are set right, and truth prevails over falsehood. 'Fair Game,' somewhat like Charles Ferguson's documentary 'Inside Job,' gestures in that direction, concluding on a note of idealism that does not quite seem warranted by the facts of the story.'' 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR The rumor mill has been churning that Ben Flajnik will put an engagement ring on Courtney Robertson's finger in the season finale. But speculation often proves wrong on this show, meaning that Lindzi Cox could walk away with the stone after all. In ''After the Rose,'' at 10, Mr. Flajnik and his chosen one will discuss their love connection.

Thrill-seeking bees that fearlessly leave their hives and search for new sources of food and hive locations have genetic brain patterns that set them apart from more timid bees, a new study suggests.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about efforts to set standards for online content aggregation, misstated a point in an Advertising Age column by Simon Dumenco that was widely picked up by other Web sites, and misstated the timing of its publication. Mr. Dumenco's column contrasted the social-media chatter on a salacious story involving Anthony Weiner, the former congressman, and the introduction of Apple's iCloud service; it did not contrast it with the death of Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder of Apple. The column was published last June, not July. (Mr. Jobs died in October.)

HILL--Jeremy. The Cancer Institute at NYU Langone Medical Center mourns with deep sadness the passing of our Advisory Board member and friend, Jeremy Hill. Jeremy was a dedicated partner in shaping our Board and a generous, unflagging supporter of our work. We extend our deepest sympathies to his mother Maureen; his brothers Antony and Tim and his entire family. He will be missed. Lori Fink, Chair; William L. Carroll, MD, Director.

An article on Saturday about opposition to New York University's expansion plan in Greenwich Village and its political implications misspelled the surname of the president of the Municipal Art Society, who urged the university to focus its expansion on Brooklyn. He is Vin Cipolla, not Cippola.

GROVER--Harriet. Passed away peacefully at home on March 11, 2012. Born in Brooklyn in 1928, loving wife to Perry for 62 years, beloved mother of Douglas (Emily), Anita (Tom) and Stuart (Lori), grandmother of Sarah, Harrison, Jenny, Elizabeth, Bryan and Melanie. A compassionate soul, politically concerned and committed to helping others, she was an inspiration to her family and friends. She will be missed. Service: Tuesday, March 13, 11am at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.

An obituary on Saturday about Peter Bergman, a founding member of the comedy troupe Firesign Theater, misspelled the name of a video game of which he created a parody. It is Myst, not Mist. And a subheading with the obituary misstated the number of members in Firesign Theater. As the obituary correctly noted, Mr. Bergman created the group with three friends, not with four.

Twenty-eight years ago, I wrote about drawing blood for the first time, about the pain of the patient and the self-doubt of the medical student. In my first clinical experience, I was learning a strange new color code: red-top tube for blood chemistries, purple top for hematology, green top, yellow top, and so on. In pediatrics, I soon discovered, the colors were the same but the tubes themselves were much smaller. And instead of those big needles I had learned to use on adults, we used butterflies, tiny needles with plastic wings to keep them stable.

An obituary on Saturday about the veteran umpire Harry Wendelstedt referred incorrectly to his arrival in the National League. Though he did arrive in 1966, he did not do so ''when the National League staff was supervised by Cal Hubbard.'' (Mr. Hubbard was the American League's umpiring supervisor from 1953 to 1969, not the National League's.)
An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors ahead of the 2008 housing market collapse.

9:29 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON - Rick Santorum's campaign has begun to argue forcefully that Mitt Romney will fail to win the 1,144 delegates needed to clinch the Republican nomination for president, leaving the decision to a wide-open national convention in Tampa, Fla., this summer.

An article on Saturday about the band Fun. included several errors. Its first album, ''Aim and Ignite,'' was produced by Steven McDonald, not by the band. A lyric from the song ''Some Nights'' includes the phrase ''some terrible nights,'' not ''some terrible lies.'' The call letters of a radio station in Philadelphia where Bruce Warren, who commented on the song, is the assistant station manager are WXPN, not WPXN. And because of an editing error, the article misidentified the station's frequency. It is 88.5 FM, not 104.9.

AUSTIN, Tex. - CNN, a unit of Time Warner, and the social news Web site Mashable are in advanced talks that may lead to an acquisition of the site, three people briefed on the talks said. If the deal was completed, Mashable would become the latest Internet media start-up company to be swallowed by a more diverse media company, in much the same way that TechCrunch was acquired by AOL in 2010. Mashable, which specializes in stories about technology and social media, could enhance CNN.com, which is one of the most popular news Web sites in the United States.

CANNOLD--David. A lifetime of representation and friendship may have ended today, but the depth of our mutual care will extend forever. Dan was a wise person who knew the importance of family and friends. We extend our love to Bev, Mitch, Scott, Tom and the entire family. Pearl and David

MISMANAGEMENT CHARGED The United States trustee has filed a motion seeking the appointment of a trustee in the Dynegy Holdings bankruptcy case, citing ''gross mismanagement by current management.'' A report by a court-appointed examiner in the bankruptcy case, released on Friday, found that a restructuring of assets before Dynegy Holdings, a subsidiary of the Houston-based power company Dynegy Inc., filed for bankruptcy protection represented a ''fraudulent transfer'' and that the board of Dynegy Holdings had breached its fiduciary duty.

Frisner Augustin, a Haitian vodou master drummer whose deep knowledge of traditional rhythms and leadership of the Brooklyn-based Troupe Makandal made him a major force in preserving and popularizing his Afro-Haitian heritage, died on Feb. 28 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He was 63. The cause was a brain hemorrhage, said La Troupe Makandal's executive director, Lois Wilcken.

Talk about sleepless nights. Patients taking prescription sleep aids on a regular basis were nearly five times as likely as non-users to die over a period of two and a half years, according to a recent study. Even those prescribed fewer than 20 pills a year were at risk, the researchers found; heavy users also were more likely to develop cancer.

A special tax provision granted to the American International Group during the financial crisis is drawing attention from the former watchdogs who oversaw the government bailout programs. On Monday, four former members of the Congressional Oversight Panel for the Troubled Asset Relief Program released a statement condemning a tax-related exemption given to A.I.G. in 2008 by the Treasury Department.

LONDON -- Loyalty and longevity are rare traits in the world of professional sports. In Premier League soccer, keeping a team manager who has not won a trophy in 10 years is almost unheard of. Everton's David Moyes is the exception.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a concert scheduled for Tuesday at Carnegie Hall at which several musicians will perform the songs from the Rolling Stones album ''Hot Rocks 1964-1971'' referred incorrectly to the album. ''Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)'' was the band's first compilation album, not ''Hot Rocks 1964-1971.''

5:15 P.M. (Showtime) ALL GOOD THINGS (2010) Ryan Gosling, above, portrays David Marks, a fictional character based on Robert A. Durst, the son of the New York real estate developer Seymour Durst, in this film by Andrew Jarecki (''Capturing the Friedmans''). Kirsten Dunst is Katie, a stand-in for Robert's wife, Kathie, who disappeared in 1982 in a case that remains open. Frank Langella is Sanford Marks, the domineering patriarch based on the older Mr. Durst, who seemingly drives his son to madness with his disappointment in Robert's inability to be a worthy heir. Not that David seems to care about following in the footsteps of his father, once the lovely Katie takes an interest in him. ''Through the good times and very bad the two leads are a comfortable, persuasive match,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Jarecki gets much right in this movie, his fiction feature debut, but he never invests it with urgency. After the bodies have bled out, the puzzle pieces have been assembled, and the final credits have rolled, you are left with the feeling that his principal goal was reopening the case.'' 1 P.M. (Sundance) THE U.S. VS. JOHN LENNON (2006) How did John Lennon go from beloved musician to antiwar activist and inspiration for peace? And why did the United States government want to deport him? This documentary from David Leaf and John Scheinfeld covers the years from 1966 to 1976 and argues that Lennon was a better person than President Richard M. Nixon. The filmmakers share access granted by Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, to the couple's archives and vignettes featuring some of the period's more notable figures, including Angela Davis, Bobby Seale, Walter Cronkite, G. Gordon Liddy, John Dean, Ron Kovic, Gore Vidal, Mario M. Cuomo and George M. McGovern.

Bruce Springsteen has still got it as far as the British are concerned. His new album, ''Wrecking Ball'' (Columbia), was the top-selling long-play recording in the United Kingdom last week, according to the Official Charts Company. It was the ninth time Mr. Springsteen, 62, has scored a No. 1 album in Britain, going back to ''Born in the U.S.A.'' in 1984. The latest release is full of protest songs and working-class anthems, inspired by the recession in the United States. Though the themes of income inequality and the loss of the American Dream are familiar ones in Mr. Springsteen's work, his latest effort with the E Street Band features a wider range of sounds and studio concoctions than anything he's done in recent years, incorporating rock, Irish folk music, gospel strains and a large New Orleans-style brass section into the mix.

Penn State's board of trustees issued a statement explaining its rationale for the firing of Joe Paterno on Nov. 9. In the statement, the trustees essentially reiterated that they moved to fire Paterno in part because he did not tell the police what he knew about a suspected 2002 sexual assault of a young boy by the former assistant Jerry Sandusky. Paterno met his legal obligations in reporting the allegations to two university officials, but he apparently did not follow up.

A ceremony in Iran to honor the Academy Award-winning director Asghar Farhadi was canceled on Monday after the authorities there denied permission for the event, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Farhadi's film ''A Separation,'' about an Iranian husband and wife in a dispute over whether they should remain in their country, won the Academy Award for foreign language film in February. At that time, Mr. Farhadi said in his acceptance speech that he hoped the win would call attention to other Iranian culture ''hidden under the heavy dust of politics,'' while the Iranian government hailed his victory for ''leaving behind'' a rival movie from the ''Zionist regime'' - the Israeli film ''Footnote,'' which was also nominated in the foreign language category.
COOK--Michael F. Sept. 2, 1941-March 13, 2011 We miss you everyday. You are in our hearts forever. Michele and Alessia

North Carolina was the latest school to test the N.C.A.A.'s will to hand out tough punishments for programs run amok and found the N.C.A.A. still has some will to hand out tough punishments. The football program was docked 15 scholarships and banned from a bowl after this season and placed on probation for three years after a two-year investigation turned up violations largely traced to improper benefits involving former assistant coach John Blake, who was given a three-year ''show cause'' penalty by the N.C.A.A. Blake had already been fired, along with the head coach Butch Davis, and the athletic director, Dick Baddour, announced his early retirement last year so a successor could start anew.

LONDON -- Norman St. John-Stevas, a Conservative politician who coupled a dandified manner with keen intellectual and aesthetic sensibilities, and who presented a ready target for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when she began culling left-leaning Tory dissidents from her cabinet in the early 1980s, died on March 2 at his home here. He was 82. His death followed a short illness, his family said.

At least once a week, someone, usually a woman over 50, asks me about vitamin D. Perhaps a routine checkup has revealed a deficiency, prompting the doctor to recommend an over-the-counter supplement or, in severe cases, large prescription doses to correct the problem. Often, though, the concern is bone health. Without vitamin D, the body cannot properly absorb calcium, and bones become fragile. At the annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons last month, researchers reported that among 889 adult patients treated for a fracture at a Missouri trauma center, blood levels of vitamin D were ''insufficient'' in 78 percent and ''frankly deficient'' in 39 percent. The study group excluded those with known risk factors for vitamin D deficiency.

Loving wife of the late Joachim Luwisch, M.D., loving mother of Michael, Edward, Ruth and the late Elizabeth and Joseph, mother-in-law to Cathleen and Hal Klopper, dear grandmother to Jennifer Zawis and Lauren Luwisch, great-grandmother to Ethan and Abigail Zawis, cherished sister and aunt. For service information please contact: Fox Funeral Home in Forest Hills, NY: 718-268-7711.

Because of an editing error, an article on March 5 about President Obama's speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee referred incorrectly to his comments about intelligence assessments of Iran's ability to produce a nuclear weapon. Mr. Obama said, ''The United States and Israel both assess that Iran does not yet have a nuclear weapon, and we are exceedingly vigilant in monitoring their program.'' His speech did not mention some European intelligence reports that have said there is no evidence that Iran has made a final decision to pursue a nuclear weapon.
''Our government told us to come back to the village and then they let the Americans kill us.'' ABDUL SAMAD, of Panjwai, Afghanistan. [A8]

Yahoo stepped up its new feud with Facebook on Monday, suing the social-networking giant and accusing it of infringing on 10 patents tied to an array of Web technologies. According to the lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., Yahoo contended that Facebook had knowingly and improperly violated some of the company's core intellectual properties. The patents, which were issued from 1999 to 2010, cover advertising, privacy, customization, social networking and messaging.

The thousands of MF Global customers whose lives and businesses were derailed after $1.6 billion vanished in the collapse of the brokerage firm have now received offers to sell their claims and recoup nearly the entire shortfall, people involved in the negotiations said. What was once thought to be a lost cause has erupted into a bidding war among Wall Street firms: Barclays, the Royal Bank of Scotland and the Seaport Group, a little-known firm that specializes in distressed assets, are all scrambling to buy MF Global customer claims.

Efforts to find a lost masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in Florence's Palazzo Vecchio have shown possible signs of success, researchers in Italy say. According to a BBC report, the researchers claim to have discovered a black pigment also used in the Mona Lisa after tiny probes were sent through drilled holes in Giorgio Vasari's ''Battle of Marciano.''

WITT--Vincent W.,CPA, of Cresskill, NJ formerly of Roslyn, NY and Boynton Beach, FL died March 11, 2012 at 96. Beloved husband of Bertha C. for 72 years, adored father of Barbara and Mark Kalik, Mady and Eric Caslow, Ellen and Peter Reiss. Devoted grandfather of Steven and Diane Kalik, Robert Kalik, Heather and Jeff Pavell, David and Lisa Caslow, James, Elizabeth and Joshua Reiss. Proud great-grandfather of nine. He was our inspiration and will be greatly missed.

In the department of much-buzzed-about cable serials that don't take 17 months between seasons, Showtime said on Monday that new episodes of its hit drama ''Homeland'' will resume on Sept. 30, along with additional installments of its long-running thriller ''Dexter.'' ''Homeland,'' which is produced by Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa and adapted from Gideon Raff's Israeli series ''Prisoners of War,'' last fall introduced viewers to the bipolar C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison; the rescued soldier Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis); and Saul Berenson (Mandy Patinkin), a veteran analyst with a truly spectacular beard. Showtime gave no details on plot lines or facial hair for Season 2 of ''Homeland,'' but said that new episodes would be filmed on location in Israel and in North Carolina.
GOLDBERG--Joseph. We have lost a great neighbor, friend and amazing retailer. Danny and Peter, Town Shop

SHANGHAI - Youku, a leading Chinese online video Web site, is buying its biggest domestic competitor, Tudou, in an acquisition valued at $1.1 billion. The unexpected deal, announced on Monday, is expected to create an online video goliath here. Despite reporting big losses in recent years, Youku and Tudou control about a third of the online video advertising market in China, according to Analysys International, a research firm.

ROWAN--Marie Agnes (Mullane), on March 8, 2012, at 98 years. Beloved wife of Martin J. (died 1968). Loving mother of Christopher, Martin R., and Bridget. Cherished mother-in-law of Don Burley. Doting "Granny" to Anne and Michael Burley. Graduate of Hunter College and Fordham School of Social Work. Dedicated teacher, P.S. 102, Bronx, and Our Lady Queen of Martyrs School, in Manhattan. Children's social worker, Catholic Home Bureau. Lifelong New Yorker, passionate Yankees fan, perpetual piano student and music lover. "And gladly would she learn, and gladly teach." Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, 91 Arden Street, New York, NY 10040, her longtime parish, on Thursday, March 15, 2012, at 9am, followed by burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Our Lady Queen of Martyrs School (to same address as church), or to a Veterans organization, in her memory, would be much appreciated.

MANN--Roland DeWolf. Died peacefully on March 11, 2012 in Newton, NJ in the presence of loving family. Born in Boston, MA, to Florence and William on June 24, 1926. Joined the Army at the end of WWII and met his beloved wife, Ingrid, in Salzburg, Austria after the war. Earned a M.A. in linguistics from the University of Maine and went on to study Sanskrit in Mysore, India as a Fulbright Scholar. Worked in the New York, Dusseldorf and London offices of McKinsey and Co. where he was Partner and Editor-in-Chief. Remained in the U.K. following his retirement and devoted much time to charitable activities, including establishing and leading the U.K. chapter of the global social entrepreneurial organization, Ashoka. Was passionate about classical music, poetry, literature, and Indology. Will be remembered for his devotion to family, keen intellect, compassion, generosity, and sense of humor. Returned to the U.S. in 2011 following almost 40 years of living in Kings Langley, Hertforshire, U.K. Survived by his loving wife, Ingrid, daughter, Elisabeth, sons William and Christopher, and five grandchildren.

FELLER--Allan B. A loving husband and father, a dear caring friend, a voracious competitor and a great story teller. The joie de vivre that emanated to those around you and the grace with which you handled your illness will not be forgotten. We will always have a special place in our hearts for you. Rest in peace. The Frankels, Slavens and Targoffs

NEW ORLEANS- ''We are all totally conflicted - get used to it.'' That's what Robert A. Kindler, vice chairman of Morgan Stanley, boldly acknowledged here five years ago at an annual conference of the nation's top corporate attorneys who converge on the Big Easy every March to discuss the current state of deal making and, yes, frequent double-dealing inside the boardrooms and executive suites of the Fortune 500.

Malinow and Silverman Mortuary 800.710.7100

On April 18, as part of the fifth anniversary of the Brooklyn Museum's Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, the museum will present the First Awards, given to 15 women who were first in their fields. Among the honorees are Sandra Day O'Connor; Jessye Norman; Toni Morrison; Connie Chung; the choreographer and director Susan Stroman; Faye Wattleton, a former president of Planned Parenthood; and Chief Wilma Pearl Mankiller, the first female chief of the Cherokee Nation. The award -- a glass sculpture designed by the artist Judy Chicago -- will be presented by Ms. Chicago, Gloria Steinem and Elizabeth Sackler, the art collector and philanthropist behind the center. Ms. Chicago is also the creator of the famous feminist artwork ''The Dinner Party,'' a triangular table with personalized place settings for 39 great women of myth and history that is now on permanent display at the Sackler Center. The award recipients ''will become 21st- century, permanent members of the symbolic fourth wing of 'The Dinner Party,''' the event's organizers said in a statement. The awards are part of the Brooklyn Artists Ball, the museum's annual gala that celebrates local artists. This year's focus is female artists; Martha Rosler, Amy Sillman and Mickalene Thomas will also be honored. Marisa Tomei, the Brooklyn-born, Oscar-winning actress, serves as an honorary chairperson.

BOCA RATON, Fla. - Reacting to concerns over player safety, N.H.L. general managers moved closer to changing the league's icing rule Monday. The managers also heard presentations from league officials that indicated concussion rates had remained stable after sharp rises in recent seasons.
