Max's enthusiasm and support for Caramoor's mission, programs, and performers was noted and greatly appreciated by his fellow Trustees and the staff. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Christine, and their children. James A. Attwood, Jr., Chairman

One would be hard pressed to find a more honestly titled theater production than ''Old Jews Telling Jokes,'' an new Off Broadway show that promises to reinvent classic Jewish jokes and perform them on stage. Co-created by the authors Peter Gethers and Daniel Okrent and directed by Marc Bruni (''Fanny''), the project is inspired by the Web site oldjewstellingjokes.com which, true to its name, hosts videos of older Jewish raconteurs telling some of their favorite jokes. In a telephone interview, Mr. Okrent explained how the concept behind the site became a stage production. Mr. Gethers had the notion of an Off Off Broadway show that was a cabaret act. That idea evolved into its current, and more theatrical, form in which Broadway actors will perform the jokes, complete with costumes. ''It is a real set and like all good Jewish operations the furniture will have plastic slipcovers,'' Mr. Okrent said. ''It's not standup. We've taken jokes and turned them into little playlets.''

A woman accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side reappeared in court on Monday for a hearing, but much of the spotlight was stolen by her dueling lawyers. One of the lawyers at the hearing, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was Richard Siracusa, who was appointed by the court. The other, Peter Gleason, has held news conferences on behalf of the woman, Anna Gristina. A third lawyer,Ronald L. Kuby, was there to represent Mr. Gleason.

Federal regulators are close to bringing cases against two brokerage firms that trade stocks of privately held companies, the first legal actions resulting from a yearlong investigation into the buying and selling of shares of closely held Internet start-ups. The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing civil charges against Felix Investments, a Manhattan-based broker-dealer that was among the pioneers in the trading of social-networking companies, according to a person with direct knowledge of the inquiry who requested anonymity because he was unauthorized to discuss it publicly. The firm is expected to be accused of violating securities laws related to soliciting investors.

McMULLEN--Jay. He was a man of purpose, of integrity and achievement. His life was testimony to the conviction that the documentary film should embody the highest standards of journalism and that serious reporting had a place in television. His career was dedicated to upholding the Murrow tradition at CBS News, an era firm in its belief in the separation of news and entertainment, in non-partisan reporting independent of ratings, and in the nobility of its mission. He was a trusted colleague, a cherished friend and an inspiration. We join the McMullen family in mourning his passing and honoring his legacy. Xiaoyan and Irv Drasnin.

The government of Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, one of the cities most afflicted by violence in that nation's drug war, has forbidden the norteño band Los Tigres del Norte to play there after a performance that included songs the government said glorified drug traffickers. The Associated Press reported that Los Tigres del Norte, whose principal members were born in Mexico and are based in California, performed in Chihuahua, the state capital, on Saturday, playing a set that included the group's song ''La Reina del Sur (The Queen of the South).'' The hit 2002 song was inspired by the Spanish author Arturo Pérez-Reverte's novel ''La Reina del Sur,'' about the rise of a female drug baron named Teresa Mendoza, and helped spawn a Telemundo television series about the character.

GOODWIN--Dr. Peter. Compassion & Choices honors the life and legacy of our dear friend Dr. Peter Goodwin of Portland, OR. He died peacefully at home on March 11, 2012, surrounded by his four children and their spouses. Peter began medical practice as a surgeon. He ended it as a role model and educator in family practice, promoting healing and growth from the beginning of life to its end. Peter called his accomplishments as chair of the committee to pass the Oregon Death with Dignity Act in the mid 1990s "the most gratifying of my entire life." His principled and passionate leadership laid the groundwork for expansion of end-of-life choice across the nation. We shall miss our dear friend. We draw comfort knowing his life was filled with love and that he died on his own terms with courage, grace and dignity. None of us could ask for more. With sincere gratitude we honor a true pioneer for end-of-life liberty, Dr. Peter Goodwin. Learn more about Peter and Compassion & Choices at: CompassionAndChoices.org/ Goodwin

FELLER--Allan B.,77 years old, of Harrison, NY, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family and friends on Thursday, March 8th, 2012 in Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his wife Nancy, his mother Marian Aronberg, his son Adam, his granddaughter Lily Ann, his step-children Kimberly and Joshua Kol and Solar Labrie, his grandson Isaiah Davir Kol, his siblings-in-law Eve and John Cohn and Jimmy and Diana Cohn, Adam's wife Quyen, and her children Vi and Jesse. Allan's generosity of spirit and loving capacity knew no bounds. He befriended and took care of everyone who entered his life. His joie de vivre touched anyone lucky enough to be in his presence. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. We cannot imagine life without Allan and the joy he brought to us. A memorial service will be held at noon on Sunday, March 18, 2012 at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY, continuing at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, 146 Griffen Avenue, Scarsdale, NY and ending at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Rogosin Institute, www.Rogosin.org, or Michael's Mission, www.michaelsmission.org.

The New York musicians union has denounced the Paul Taylor Dance Company for performing at Lincoln Center without a live orchestra, which the company said was far beyond its means. The union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, promised to distribute leaflets and provide outdoor performances to bring attention to the issue before the Taylor company's first show of a 21-performance run at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday night. Tino Gagliardi, Local 802's president, said the company management ''had no interest in using professional musicians'' at the performances. John Tomlinson, the executive director, said that in fact the company dearly wanted to have live music, calling it an ''essential element,'' but simply could not afford it. The works being performed almost all call for an orchestra of some sort, and he estimated the total cost, at union rates, to be $450,000 to $500,000. The budget for the run, Mr. Tomlinson said, was $1.5 million.

HONG KONG - Las Vegas Sands, the casino operator controlled by the billionaire Sheldon G. Adelson and his family, is facing a new $375 million lawsuit over how the company won a lucrative gambling license in Macau. A filing submitted to a court in the Chinese territory in January by Asian American Entertainment, an estranged former partner of Las Vegas Sands controlled by the Taiwanese businessman Shi Sheng Hao, who also goes by the name Marshall Hao, claims breach of contract and seeks compensation of 3 billion patacas, or more than $375 million.

CHIEF Richard Siewert Jr., below, the man Goldman Sachs has been courting to lead its public relations effort, has been officially hired, according to an internal memo from the investment bank. Mr. Siewert, known as Jake, accepted a job from Goldman weeks ago. But it was not formally announced until Tuesday because he had to clear corporate background checks, according to people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not disclosed when Mr. Siewert, a former counselor to Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, will start at Goldman. SUSANNE CRAIG

A crane on a barge being towed by a tugboat accidentally hit the scaffolding on the underside of the Brooklyn Bridge about 8:15p.m. Tuesday, damaging about 20 feet of scaffolding. The bridge appeared to be undamaged, officials said. ''The crane connected with some of the sheet metal under the bridge,'' said a United States Coast Guard spokesman. ''Vehicle traffic was never halted.''

The government's sweeping crackdown on insider trading has focused on hedge fund trading floors and corporate boardrooms. On Tuesday, it reached into Alcoholics Anonymous. Federal regulators charged a money manager with trading on confidential information about the acquisition of a Philadelphia-based insurance company passed to him by an executive at the insurer. The two men attended A.A. meetings together, and the insurance executive had confided in the money manager that the stress of the deal was driving him to drink, according to the complaint.

ZELINSKY--Frederick V.,December 10, 1946 - March 9, 2012. A man of lively and wide-ranging curiosity and interests - boyish to the end with a great sense of humor and love of family. A talented artist and printmaker, Fred worked writing software. Fred is survived by his sisters Ronhild McMillion Zelinsky and Katherine Zelinsky, nephew Jimm Pierson, his cousins, among them Ed and Kay Romard and Theresa and Joe Prozniak, and above all his beloved partner Gert Weil of Berkeley and her family.

PANJWAI, Afghanistan -- Militants riding motorcycles attacked a high-level Afghan government delegation during a memorial service on Tuesday in the village where an American soldier is said to have killed 16 people, mostly children and women, in a door-to-door rampage two days earlier. The Tuesday assault, on a mosque in the Panjwai district of Kandahar Province, left at least one Afghan soldier dead and punctured the calm that had largely prevailed in Afghanistan since the massacre. There was no immediate claim of responsibility from the Taliban, whose roots are in the area. But the attack belied the Afghan government's efforts to present itself as in control of the situation in Kandahar, where anger over Sunday's killings is perhaps deepest.

After 244 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica is going out of print. Those coolly authoritative, gold-lettered reference books that were once sold door-to-door by a fleet of traveling salesmen and displayed as proud fixtures in American homes will be discontinued, company executives said.

Because of an editing error, a picture credit on Saturday with an article about Roger Montgomery, the agent for the Knicks' Jeremy Lin, misidentified the photographer in some editions. The picture of Montgomery was by Jennifer Whitney for The New York Times, not by Victor J. Blue of Bloomberg.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The names of the city's storied neighborhoods roll off the tongue: Pacific Heights, North Beach, the Mission, Haight-Ashbury, the Castro. Bayview, a historically African-American district long isolated between Candlestick Park and the former naval shipyard at Hunter's Point along the city's southeastern waterfront, is not among them.

9 P.M. (Bravo) INTERIOR THERAPY WITH JEFF LEWIS Mr. Lewis, the obsessivecompulsive house flipper of ''Flipping Out'' fame, moves in with his clients in this new series. In each episode he and his assistant Jenni Pulos (above, second from left, with Mr. Lewis, far left, and clients) stay with members of a family to observe them in action, diagnose problems with their home and redesign the space over the course of five days. Mr. Lewis's longtime housekeeper, Zoila Chavez, tags along to make sure her boss doesn't venture too far over the line. The action begins as Mr. Lewis runs into construction woes while trying to renovate a master suite. 7:30 A.M. (Oxygen) IN THE BEDROOM (2001) Sissy Spacek and Tom Wilkinson earned Oscar nominations for their portrayals of Ruth and Matt Fowler, a small-town New England couple who deal with the murder of their college-age son, Frank (Nick Stahl), in an unexpected way in this film from Todd Field. Marisa Tomei, also nominated for an Oscar, plays the older, married girlfriend who unwittingly leads the golden Frank to his demise. This adaptation of the short story ''Killings,'' by Andre Dubus, is a ''perfectly observed, wrenchingly acted drama'' that ''cuts to the quick,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''It reminds us that, like it or not, the capacity to commit a crime of passion is part of being human.'' The movie was also nominated for best picture and best adapted screenplay.

ORLANDO, Fla. - As the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meeting opened here on Tuesday, its political director mapped out organized labor's plans for the 2012 campaign and how unions will respond to what he says will be $500 million in ''super PAC'' ads backing Republicans. The political director, Michael Podhorzer, said this election would be unlike any other. ''The elections in 2012 and this decade wouldn't be recognizable to Bill Clinton or even George Bush -- everything has changed,'' Mr. Podhorzer said at a news briefing. ''The money coming in already is unprecedented and it provides even greater power to the voice of the affluent.''

The case of an American soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians has roiled political support in Congress for the military campaign in Afghanistan, with a prominent Republican senator accusing his party's candidates for president of undermining the nation's military commanders. ''When Republican candidates for president, when Republican politicians talk about being for early withdrawal, it makes it harder for the general to do his job,'' said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and a senior member of the Armed Services Committee. ''I want to be in a Republican Party that understands the strategic consequences of winning and losing in Afghanistan and will back up a general who deserves to be backed up.''

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- It looks like a giant unfinished basement, and smells like one. And the Mets' future here could ultimately depend on whether this cavernous structure is finished, and furnished with another major league team. Over the winter, Digital Domain Park, the Mets' training center, underwent a $2.4 million remodeling that included the construction of a 12,000-square-foot basement underneath a newly built extension of the stands in right field.

One of Kyrgyzstan's top defense officials told Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Tuesday that a crucial United States air base here should have ''no military mission'' when its lease expires in July 2014. The request creates a potential hurdle to American plans to withdraw from Afghanistan in 2014. The base at the Manas airport, close to the capital, Bishkek, has been a vital hub for moving troops and matériel in and out of Afghanistan. Closing the base to the American military after July 2014, when tens of thousands of United States troops are expected to be flowing out of Afghanistan under current plans, would create logistical headaches for the Pentagon.

GREEN cabbage is not one of the sexier seasonal vegetables. Lacking the ruffled charm of kale or the dappled appeal of delicata squash, it is a pale, stalwart presence at the farmers' market, there all winter long and ready when you want it -- if you ever do. Many cooks don't. What often stops me from buying a green cabbage is the generosity of the vegetable. Most of the ones I see are as hulking and solid as a bowling ball, a pain to lug home.

SACHS--Gloria on March 12, 2012. Beloved mother of Nancy and Charles. Devoted grandmother of Alexandra, Olivia and Rachel. Dear sister of Betsy Lodwick and Joan Schwimmer. Services Thursday March 15, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

The Carlyle Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, is brimming with deal makers who have made billions for themselves and their fund investors. Yet they appear to be struggling to persuade people to buy into their most important deal yet - an initial public offering of the firm. Carlyle filed for an offering in September. Five months have passed, and the firm just added at least five more banks to its list of underwriters, according to Bloomberg News, apparently in an effort to help sell the offering.

With the presidential election in sight and a deadline looming at the end of the year to cut trillions from the deficit, the partisan debate over the budget has become an existential battle over the purpose of government. President Obama's insistence that the rich must pay more to preserve programs that help the poor and middle class has crashed against the Republican claim that the president's Robin Hood policies amount to class warfare.

An article on Saturday about the waning of support for the recent opposition movement in Russia misstated the surname of a voting monitor for the presidential election who said she and others were disappointed there were so few polling place violations because they had hoped the election could be declared illegitimate. She is Marina Chernetsova, not Chenetsova.

Riding outstanding reviews and a flood of attention because of the controversy around its portrayal of Sarah Palin, the HBO film ''Game Change'' attracted a big audience for the pay-cable channel Saturday night. The film pulled in 2.1 million viewers for its initial airing on HBO, making it the most-watched original movie on the channel in eight years. Viewer totals for the movie increased in each of its half-hours, topping out at 2.3 million viewers.

An article on Tuesday about the excavation of nomads' burial mounds in Kazakhstan misspelled the name of the society whose artifacts are the focus of the ''Nomads and Networks'' exhibition at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World at New York University. It is the Pazyryk society, not Pazyrk.

An article on Feb. 8 about genetically modified (or transgenic) crops misstated the United States Department of Agriculture's policy on allowing transgenic content in crops labeled organic. The department has a recommended guideline of no more than 0.9 percent transgenic content for organic crops; it does not have an official threshold for transgenic content. This correction was delayed because editors did not follow through when the reporter notified them of the error.

INDIAN WELLS, Calif. - Save for the chilly breeze that often blows through the desert air after sunset, it is hard to imagine a more perfect setting for tennis than mountain-lined Indian Wells, home of the BNP Paribas Open. The popular non-Grand Slam tournament, which attracts tennis fans from much of the western half of North America, even sells out of general admission grounds passes for certain sessions.

GERHARD RICHTER PAINTING Opens on Wednesday in Manhattan. Directed by Corinna Belz In English and German, with English subtitles 1 hour 37 minutes; not rated Gerhard Richter may not fling paint at the canvas, Jackson Pollock-style, but as Corinna Belz shows in her documentary ''Gerhard Richter Painting,'' he can be his own kind of action painter.
In an evolutionary twist, a study has found that the shape of crocodilian muzzles has no effect on bite force.
TAYLOR--Roy, of London and Athens, GA died peacefully March 12, survived by Gloria Ricks Taylor.

An article on Friday about the Boston University men's hockey team, which is being investigated by the university after two players were arrested for sexual assault this season, misstated, in some editions, the number of Beanpot tournaments the Terriers have won. It is 29, not 25.

WASHINGTON - Representative Bob Turner, a Republican who unexpectedly won a House seat in a closely watched special election last year, has decided to run for the United States Senate in New York, seeking to oust Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat. Mr. Turner made his decision after it became clear that his district, which includes portions of Queens and Brooklyn, was one of two that would most likely be eliminated this year in New York State as part of the redistricting process. The state must cut its Congressional delegation to 27, from 29, to reflect slow population growth identified in the 2010 census.

PUCCIO--Thomas P. On March 11, 2012. Devoted husband of 21 years to Kathryn Thayer Puccio. Prominent Trial attorney serving with the United States Department of Justice for thirteen years in various capacities including Chief of the Criminal Division and Executive Assistant U.S Attorney in the Eastern District of New York and Chief of the Organized Crime Strike Force; where he successfully investigated and prosecuted the Abscam case. He was one of the few recipients of the Attorney General's Distinguished Service Award, one of the highest honors that can be bestowed by the Department of Justice, to have been given the award on two occasions during his government career. In his private practice, he was a highly respected trial attorney and represented prominent clients Claus Von Bulow, and the New York City Patrolman's Benevolent Association. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral service Friday 10am at St. Jean Baptiste, 76 St and Lexington Ave. Donations in Thomas name may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave, 8th Fl., NY, NY, 10016

A terrorist suspect linked to Al Qaeda who the Philippine military maintains was killed last month probably escaped alive, a senior Malaysian police official said. Military officials announced last month that an airstrike on Jolo Island had killed Zulkifli bin Hir, a senior leader of the Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist network, along with several other senior militants. ''We believe he is still alive but he is badly injured,'' Ayob Khan Mydin Pitchay, the head of a Malaysian counterterrorism task force, said Monday evening. ''He is still on our most-wanted list.''

Readers will approach ''The Woman Who Wasn't There: The True Story of an Incredible Deception'' knowing how it's going to end. Tania Head, who claimed a place in the public's heart for having narrowly escaped death in the south tower of the World Trade Center - ''America's most famous survivor,'' the authors call her - will be revealed as an impostor. Her real name is Alicia Head, she is Spanish, and on Sept. 11, 2001, she was in Barcelona attending business school.

SCHERZER--Felix of Delray Beach, FL, formerly Cresskill, NJ, March 12, 2012. Born Vienna, Austria, 1926, to Shulim and Eva Scherzer. Evacuated to France after the Anschluss and sheltered by the Rothschilds at La Guette until the German invasion, he made his way with other refugee children across Vichy France and Spain to Lisbon. Oeuvre de Secours aux Enfants (OSE) and American Friends Service Committee reunited him with family who preceded him to Brooklyn. After college and a brief soccer career, he became a respected international businessman who embraced the joys of travel, food, skiing and golf. Loving husband of 54 years to the late Sylvia Warman Scherzer, father to Mark (Peter Davies), Howard (Susannah Thompson) and Jolie (Douglas Spindler). Grandfather to Matthew, Beth and Troy Spindler, Max and Nona Scherzer. Doting companion to Roslynne Wachtel. Service: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam at 91st, Thur, March 15, 11:30am. Donations: OSE (www.ose-france.org) or AFSC (www.afsc.org).

A report last Wednesday in the Off the Menu column rendered incorrectly the name of a food and music festival planned for Prospect Park, Brooklyn, in May. It is The Great GoogaMooga, not The Great Googa Mooga.

SCHREIBER--Phyllis. The College of New Rochelle (CNR) mourns the death and celebrates the life of Phyllis Schreiber, graduate of CNR's School of New Resources in 1974 and member of the College's Board of Trustees from 1975-1981. Her dedication to the arts was apparent to all who knew her. She co-founded the College's Castle Gallery in 1982 and served on the Castle Gallery Board of Directors for many years. She was also a past member of CNR's President's Advisory Council. She was a vibrant participant in the life of the College, and we extend our sympathies to her family. Judith Huntington, President Michael N. Ambler, Chair Board of Trustees

In her 30-some years as food critic for the Grand Forks, N.D., Herald, Marilyn Hagerty has reviewed the Dippin' Dots at a hockey rink, sung the praises of grilled salmon with North Dakota Prairie Sauce, and made her way through countless portions of lutefisk. But she has never reviewed a hot dog. Ms. Hagerty has also been to New York half a dozen times in her 85 years, and eaten any number of restaurant meals. But she had never tried a New York City dirty-water dog.

SILVERSTEIN--Murray (Mike) 86 years young. The employees of Nina Footwear mourn the passing of Co-Founder Mike Silverstein, who, along with his brother Stanley Silverstein, founded Nina with a fashion clog in 1953. Operating from a loft on Prince Street in NYC, the brothers built Nina Footwear into one of the most widely respected independent companies in the shoe industry. Mike combined a flair for showmanship with true business acumen. He was instrumental in developing the shoe industry's presence in New York City. Mike was also renowned in other circles. Along with his wife, Renee, he was an esteemed collector of twentieth century furniture. He will be fondly remembered by all of us here at Nina, and by friends in the industry in which for decades he played a central role. We send our deepest condolences to his brother, Stanley, Co-Chairman of Nina; his wife, Renee; his children, Scott, Baron, Nanci, and Neil along with their entire family.

The police in Colombia have announced the arrest of the man they say is responsible for the killing of the Argentine folk singer Facundo Cabral, who was on tour in Guatemala last summer when he was shot to death on his way to the airport. The authorities described the man, Alejandro Jiménez González, a Costa Rican, as involved in the ''leadership and direction of an organized mafia'' engaged in money laundering and other criminal activities throughout Central America. According to news reports from Colombia, Mr. Jiménez, 37, was arrested when he arrived there on Monday aboard a cruise ship. Mr. Cabral, who was 74 when he was killed, was famous throughout the Spanish-speaking world as a composer and singer of protest and spiritual-philosophical songs, the best-known of which is probably ''I'm Not From Here, I'm Not From There.'' In 1996, the United Nations designated him a ''worldwide messenger of peace.''

3:00 p.m. | Updated The Giants secured one of their biggest potential free agents on Tuesday shortly before N.F.L. free agency even began. Cornerback Terrell Thomas agreed to a new deal with the Giants, precluding him from the testing the open market after missing all of the 2011 season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Thomas confirmed the agreement on his Twitter account, then immediately began receiving congratulations from teammates, including an enthusiastic message from the defensive captain Justin Tuck.

It was his right hand.

SILVERSTEIN--Mike, renowned in the shoe industry as co-founder of Nina Footwear Corp., passed away on March 12th surrounded by his loving wife, Renee, his four children Scott, Neil, Nanci and Baron and spouses Betsy, Mara and Jan and his 12 grandchildren. Mike was born in Havana, Cuba in 1926 and emigrated to the United States in 1944 where he entered the U.S. Army and was stationed in the Philippines ultimately joining the Air Force on search and rescue missions. In 1953 Mike and his brothers Stanley and Larry started Nina Footwear Corporation, building a successful shoe business and making an indelible mark in the shoe industry. Mike will be remembered for his ever present fine Cuban Cigar and his elegance and personal style. To his family he will be remembered as a man with strength of character who enjoyed life and passed along his strong values and virtues. Donations may be made in appreciation of Dr. Valentin Fuster in Mike's memory to Mt. Sinai Medical Center. For details, call Sam Kelly, 212-659-8500.

The Newport Jazz Festival will be anchored this year by the guitarist Pat Metheny, the drummer Jack DeJohnette and the vocalist Kurt Elling, among dozens of other acts, George Wein, a festival founder, announced on Tuesday. Mr. Wein said he wanted to present not just veterans but also younger musicians who represent currents in contemporary jazz. These will include the saxophonist Miguel Zenon, the pianist Jason Moran, the trumpet player Ambrose Akinmusire, the composer Darcy James Argue and the drummer Dafnis Prieto.

An article on Thursday about post-recession prospects for retirees misstated the value lost by 401(k) plans in the downturn. It was $1.6 trillion in equity value, not $2.8 trillion. (The larger figure was the amount of equity losses in 401(k) plans and Individual Retirement Accounts combined.)

The Metropolitan Opera said on Tuesday that it was extending its opera on-demand service to iPads through a new app. The app is free but the streaming service starts at $14.99 a month, giving viewers access to several hundred radio and television broadcasts and more recent ''Live in HD'' transmissions to movie theaters, with more to be added regularly. An article on Page F7 today about uCurate, a computer program that allows members of the public to help design art exhibitions, misstates the name of the museum that uses the program. It is the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass. -- not the Francine and Sterling Clark Art Institute. The error was discovered after the section had gone to press.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it had filed civil charges against three firms that trade the shares of privately held technology companies: Felix Investments, EB Financial and SharesPost. The S.E.C. said fund managers at Felix and EB Financial had misled investors and reaped ''undisclosed fees and commissions.'' SharesPost, an online exchange where private shares are bought and sold, improperly brokered transactions without registering with regulators as a licensed broker-dealer, the agency said.

A majority of New York City voters approve of the public release of ratings for thousands of public school teachers, even though a plurality of voters believe that the ratings are flawed, a new poll has found. The poll, released early Wednesday by the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, found that 58 percent of voters approved of the release of the ratings, known as teacher data reports, while 38 percent disapproved and 5 percent were undecided or did not answer.

PROXY FIGHT Daniel S. Loeb, the head of Third Point, has told Yahoo that he will start a proxy battle within the week, according to a letter obtained by The New York Times. Mr. Loeb, who announced his intention to file a slate of directors last month, said he tried to cooperate with the board. But Yahoo's ''stonewalling, apparent insouciance and decision not to engage with us in a serious manner, has left us no choice,'' Mr. Loeb said in the letter, which was addressed to Yahoo's new chief executive, Scott Thompson, above. EVELYN M. RUSLI

Jazz has always been an adaptive art, possessed of certain essentials but receptive to variation at every turn. The pianist-composer-bandleader Vijay Iyer knows this as well as anyone. He has made a serious study of it, in theory as well as practice, and his last decade or so of music making can partly be understood as a pertinent provocation. ''Accelerando,'' his fourth release on the German label ACT, and an early front-runner for jazz album of the year, encapsulates his knack for making prickly experimentalism feel approachable, intuitive, even stylish.

NEW DELHI -- Salman Rushdie's plans to speak publicly in India are stirring controversy yet again. The author, whose 1988 novel ''The Satanic Verses'' is banned in India and has been condemned by Muslims around the world, is scheduled to speak Friday afternoon at an annual conference held by the publisher India Today Group.

The Skin Deep column on Feb. 23, about digestive enzymes, misspelled, at one point, the surname of the founder of Immunocologie, a company that makes skin care products. He is Manzoor Jaffery, not Jaffrey.

TOKYO -- Minoru Mori, a developer who helped shape Tokyo's skyline with towering buildings and then turned his attention to China, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 77. The cause was heart failure, officials of his company, Mori Building, said. Taking over a successful real estate business from his father in 1993, Mr. Mori built some of Tokyo's most prominent developments.

If anyone could bump Adele from No. 1, it would have to be somebody really big. Like, boss big. And that is what has finally happened, if only by a tiny margin. This week Bruce Springsteen breaks Adele's streak at the top of the Billboard chart with 196,000 sales of his new album, ''Wrecking Ball,'' Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is Mr. Springsteen's 10th No. 1, and it beat Adele's ''21'' by only 1,000 copies, sending that album to No. 2. Adele has held the No. 1 spot for a total of 23 times since ''21'' was released a little over a year ago, including each of the last 10 weeks.

Judges for the Intel Science Talent Search asked Mimi Yen hard questions, and she didn't know the answers to any of them. But Mimi was pleased. ''It was a good kind of brutal,'' Mimi, 17, said in a telephone interview on Wednesday, the morning after she was awarded third place in the prestigious science competition. ''The questions are geared at looking at the thought process about things I didn't know the answers to. I came out feeling foolish.''

FELLER--Allan B.,77 years old, of Harrison, NY, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family and friends on Thursday, March 8th, 2012 in Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his wife Nancy, his mother Marian Aronberg, his son Adam, his granddaughter Lily Ann, his step-children Kimberly and Joshua Kol and Solar Labrie, his grandson Isaiah Davir Kol, his siblings-in-law Eve and John Cohn and Jimmy and Diana Cohn, Adam's wife Quyen, and her children Vi and Jesse. Allan's generosity of spirit and loving capacity knew no bounds. He befriended and took care of everyone who entered his life. His joie de vivre touched anyone lucky enough to be in his presence. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. We cannot imagine life without Allan and the joy he brought to us. A memorial service will be held at noon on Sunday, March 18, 2012 at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY, continuing at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, 146 Griffen Avenue, Scarsdale, NY and ending at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Rogosin Institute, www.Rogosin.org, or Michael's Mission, www.michaelsmission.org.

This spring we're debuting a series of hair accouterments from her with amazing jewels and stones.

PUCCIO--Thomas P. On March 11, 2012. Devoted husband of 21 years to Kathryn Thayer Puccio. Prominent Trial attorney serving with the United States Department of Justice for thirteen years in various capacities including Chief of the Criminal Division and Executive Assistant U.S Attorney in the Eastern District of New York and Chief of the Organized Crime Strike Force; where he successfully investigated and prosecuted the Abscam case. He was one of the few recipients of the Attorney General's Distinguished Service Award, one of the highest honors that can be bestowed by the Department of Justice, to have been given the award on two occasions during his government career. In his private practice, he was a highly respected trial attorney and represented prominent clients Claus Von Bulow, and the New York City Patrolman's Benevolent Association. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral service Friday 10am at St. Jean Baptiste, 76 St and Lexington Ave. Donations in Thomas name may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave, 8th Fl., NY, NY, 10016

Rock stars, Hollywood celebrities, and senior White House officials will all be in attendance at Wednesday's state dinner, where President Obama will fete the British prime minister, David Cameron, on the occasion of Mr. Cameron's visit to the United States. And so will be more than two dozen of Mr. Obama's top donors, some of whom have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for his re-election campaign and for the Democratic National Committee.

Why do people look so blank, so vacant, so unnatural in portraits? Peter Hurley, a leading head-shot artist for actors, celebrities and executives, said people look like badly embalmed cadavers because they try to pose, but lack the skill to look natural doing it. Even professional models, experts at a certain haughty look, seldom know how to look natural. ''I have to deprogram them into something that is more real,'' said Mr. Hurley. How does Mr. Hurley get the personality to shine through in a flattering way? Here are some of his top tips from those offered in his instructional video, ''The Art Behind the Headshot.''

The producers of ''American Idol'' moved to disqualify one of that singing competition's semifinalists, Jermaine Jones, on Wednesday after discovering that he had not disclosed an arrest record. His departure was expected to be shown on Wednesday night's broadcast on Fox. It represented the first time in many years that ''Idol,'' now in its 11th season, has booted a ''top 12'' contestant for prior charges. In Season 2 the producers sent home another semifinalist, Corey Clark, for not disclosing his arrest record.

Less than two months after wolves in the Great Lakes region were removed from the federal endangered species list, the Wisconsin State Assembly approved a bill on Wednesday that would open the way for a wolf hunting and trapping season. The bill, supported by hunting groups, Republicans and some Democrats, passed by a 69-25 vote. It was opposed by environmental groups and the Great Lakes Indian Fish and Game Commission, which represents Ojibwe tribes in Wisconsin, Michigan and Minnesota. The tribes have significant rights in wildlife management in much of the area where wolves are found and said they were not consulted on the hunting plans as required by a treaty. State wildlife biologists also criticized various elements of the bill.

ARIANE GOLDMAN, the designer of a new maternity line called Hatch, knows how to turn a major milestone into a successful business. In 2007, after designing the bridesmaid dresses for her wedding, she left a Wall Street job to start twobirds, a collection of convertible dresses that bridesmaids could actually wear again. Last year, after giving birth to her first child, she had a similar epiphany, finding a lack of fashionable maternity staples for women to wear post-pregnancy, too. Her 14-piece collection includes mannish silk button-downs and an above-the-knee dress with sexy arm cutouts. For spring there are new pastel dresses and jumpsuits, all good looks for stylish moms-to-be eager to maintain their cool. Available for $200 to $350 at hatchcollection.com.

HBO said on Wednesday that it is ending further production on its high-profile drama ''Luck,'' one day after the announcement that a third horse involved in the show had been injured and euthanized. ''Luck,'' which was set in the world of California horse racing and made its debut in January, came with a top-flight creative team: its producers included David Milch, a creator of ''NYPD Blue'' and the HBO Western ''Deadwood,'' and Michael Mann, the director of ''Heat'' and ''Public Enemies,'' and it starred Dustin Hoffman as a recently released prison convict who returns to his gambling ways.

The case, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, is being decided by Justice Daniel P. Conviser; there is no jury.

EISNER--Henry (Hank), died on March 13, 2012, surrounded by his grieving wife Josephine, son Mark and his wife Claire, after a long illness. Henry started his career in advertising with Sam Goody and later on joined R.R. Donnelley & Sons until his retirement in 1990. He was one of their top salesman/account executives. He will be remembered for his personal style, love of classical music and the arts, traveling, and the Yankees and Giants. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

Keith Carradine, a Tony nominee for the title role in ''The Will Rogers Follies,'' will lead a cast of 15 in the La Jolla Playhouse's world-premiere musical adaptation of the 1997 documentary ''Hands on a Hard Body.'' The show (''Hardbody'' is one word in the title) brings together an eclectic creative team. Trey Anastasio of Phish wrote the music with Amanda Green (''High Fidelity''), who is also the lyricist. Doug Wright, a Pulitzer and Tony winner for ''I Am My Own Wife,'' wrote the book, while Neil Pepe, the artistic director of the Atlantic Theater Company, will direct.The fFormer New York City Ballet dancer Benjamin Millipied did the musical staging. Previews begin April 27 with a May 12 opening.
Until early Wednesday morning, Greg Smith was a largely anonymous 33-year-old midlevel executive at Goldman Sachs in London. Now everyone at the firm - and on Wall Street - knows his name.

The Gotham column on March 6 about a man in White Plains who was killed by a police officer when a confrontation ensued after the authorities had responded to the man's medical alert system referred incorrectly to that system. While he did use a medical alert system, it was not from the Life Alert Emergency Response company.

FOR most of the last decade, the watch industry has been entranced by the tourbillon's hypnotic revolutions, with brands spinning out the cagey little complication in ever-greater numbers and more ingenious ways. But watchmakers have recently broken free of the spell, shifting their attention from the visual fascination of the tourbillon, which aims to counter the effects of gravity on a timepiece by mounting the watch escapement and balance wheel in a rotating cage, to the tuneful appeal of the minute repeater. Minute-repeater clocks and pocket watches were invented in the mid-18th century, before the advent of electric lighting. Their practical function at that time was their ability, through chiming gongs, to sound the hours, quarter-hours and minutes in separate tones, enabling people to tell the time even in the middle of a pitch-black night.

In one of Britten's realities his wife, Hannah (Laura Allen), is upset that he can't attend an event honoring their dead son because he is tracking down a missing teenage boy. 10 A.M. (HBO) DRUMLINE (2002) Nick Cannon plays a self-righteous drummer from Harlem at odds with the fierce regimentation of the marching band at his college, where the whole point of a Saturday afternoon football game is the halftime show.

GREENBERG--Steven. A Celebratory Service in Loving Memory of STEVEN A. GREENBERG Will be held on Tuesday, March 20 at 5:30pm at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th St. (between Lexington and 3rd Avenues). Steven was a visionary creative genius who became the Nightlife King of NY. Owner of 230 Fifth, the Roxy and the Palladium. A renowned collector of Art Deco. He was a generous, charismatic and special friend to many.

FOR 27 days during the fashion weeks in New York, London, Milan and Paris, T Magazine featured one shoe from dozens of shows for its online feature ''The Daily Shoe.'' What rose to the top were ankle boots -- Proenza Schouler referenced high-top sneakers; Chanel's were asymmetrical; Balenciaga's came straight from the '80s -- and ladylike stilettos that shine via jewels, glitter and metallic leather (see Nina Ricci, Lanvin and Jil Sander, respectively). Heavy '40s-inspired heels should be popular next fall, too. At Louis Vuitton, Prada and Christian Dior, vintage proportions cover much of the foot and come with hidden platforms and very square toes, much like a loafer's or the destined-to-become-It pilgrim shoes championed by Marc Jacobs. JANE HERMAN

THOSE jackets with fur sleeves, a k a gorilla arms, that emerged on last fall's runway (a smoking Kate Moss at Louis Vuitton should ring a bell) are actually on the street. They were spotted on a bevy of models during the recent fashion shows, and the street-style photographer Candice Lake (above right) wore two from Rue du Mail for the shows in Paris. New incarnations of the furry-arm look showed up on the fall 2012 runways: at Fendi and Versace in Milan; at Prabal Gurung and BCBG in New York. The new ones are a long way from the shops, but you can surf the Web for sales: a Derek Lam fur-sleeve bomber is 70 percent off at shopbop.com.

SILVERSTEIN--Murray (Mike) 86 years young. The employees of Nina Footwear mourn the passing of Co-Founder Mike Silverstein, who, along with his brother Stanley Silverstein, founded Nina with a fashion clog in 1953. Operating from a loft on Prince Street in NYC, the brothers built Nina Footwear into one of the most widely respected independent companies in the shoe industry. Mike combined a flair for showmanship with true business acumen. He was instrumental in developing the shoe industry's presence in New York City. Mike was also renowned in other circles. Along with his wife, Renee, he was an esteemed collector of twentieth century furniture. He will be fondly remembered by all of us here at Nina, and by friends in the industry in which for decades he played a central role. We send our deepest condolences to his brother, Stanley, Co-Chairman of Nina; his wife, Renee; his children, Scott, Baron, Nanci, and Neil along with their entire family.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about a Mexican city's ban on the group Los Tigres del Norte after it performed songs that officials said glorified drug traffickers misidentified the city and referred incorrectly to it. The city is Chihuahua, not Ciudad Juárez, and it is Chihuahua that is the capital of the state of Chihuahua, not Ciudad Juárez, another city in that state.

FRANKLIN--Sylvia. Director of Membership Services at the Century Association for two decades, she died after a short illness in early March. Known affectionately to members and staff alike as Sylvia, she kept the place on track and more or less on time. A firm and cheerful presence, her hand could be seen everywhere, from the Meetings of Members to the Board of Management to the Admissions Committee and far beyond. Century newsletters and correspondence flowed freely from her desk and her computer. Though members and staff are picking up the pieces of the club's affairs she left behind, no one is quite sure how they all fit together. Her good nature and efficiency not to mention her knowledge of how this place works are sorely missed.

How can you compare the dishonoring of the Holy Koran with the martyrdom of innocent civilians? The whole goal of our life is religion. MULLAH KHALIQ DAD, a religious leader in Afghanistan, on the relatively muted reaction to the massacre of civilians apparently by an American soldier. [A4]

Donald F. Smith, a champion of high-style cabaret who founded both the Mabel Mercer Foundation and the New York Cabaret Convention, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 79. The cause was congestive heart failure, said Rick Meadows, the foundation's director and Mr. Smith's longtime assistant.

ISA TAPIA knew shoes were her calling after a trip to Italy with Oscar de la Renta. Ms. Tapia, who began working for the designer while still at Parsons, saw the construction of footwear firsthand and found her focus. Now the design director for accessories at Ann Taylor, she has just introduced her own shoe collection for spring, an impressive grouping picked up by Kirna Zabête and Saks Fifth Avenue. Standouts include taupe cutout booties, $495, and snakeskin sandals, $395, available in coral and bright blue, with sensible three-inch heels. ''I was sick of platforms and crazy heels,'' Ms. Tapia said. The most dramatic pair, hot pink and black lace-up evening sandals, look outrageously expensive but are, at $550, a step in the right direction.

President Obama is hoping for strong results from North Carolina, and not just in the presidential election. Mr. Obama picked the North Carolina Tar Heels to beat the Kentucky Wildcats in the final of this year's N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

The free Preview program included over the years with Mac OS X has always been useful for tasks like opening and displaying photos and PDF files. The latest version of Preview for Mac OS X 10.7 adds a few new features to the dependable little program, including the ability to snap a picture of your handwritten signature with the Mac's webcam -- a signature you can later embed into PDF files.

For many years the most underrated art museum in New York City has also, oddly, been the one with by far the most visitors, millions a day: the subway system. Since 1985, the Arts for Transit program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has commissioned permanent works by both well-known and lesser-known artists for the subway and also the commuter rail system. But finding these works, in a system that can sometimes feel like a lab-mouse maze designed by a sadistic scientist, has never been easy. So several months ago the authority began working with Meridian, a mobile software company based in Portland, Ore., and on Thursday it plans to announce its first licensed app to serve as a guide to the 186 permanent works installed throughout the stations, and to a few dozen more in the Metro North and Long Island Rail Road systems.

It is essentially a V-neck T-shirt with a padded compartment to protect your electronics.

Are you a Muppet or a Clancy? A Bobblehead or a Clampett? You may be, even if you do not know it. All of these are less-than-flattering code names that companies in a variety of industries have used to describe some of their customers or clients.

Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column on Wednesday, about the many tax breaks in the United States tax code, omitted part of a passage in describing the allocation of such breaks to taxpayers at different income levels. The passage should have read, ''Moreover, including this money creates an entirely different landscape of winners and losers of the government's largess: of the extra $1 trillion, almost $7 of $10 goes to the top fifth of taxpayers'' -- not ''almost $7 to the top fifth of taxpayers.''

CLARKE--Richard V. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Richard V. Clarke, a trusted advisor and friend who served with distinction as a Trustee beginning in 1996, and as a Trustee Emeritus since 2004. His wise counsel over the years benefited many areas of the institution, including membership, external affairs, and human resources, and his commitment to furthering audience diversity in the arts inspired him to lead the efforts to establish the Museum's Multicultural Audience Development Initiative in 1998. This initiative has been a tremendous success in welcoming the many communities within and beyond New York to the Metropolitan Museum, and it has become a model for many institutions internationally. We will miss him greatly, and send condolences to his entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

JACOB--Ruth Apprich,beloved matriarch and creative writer, passed away on March 10, 2012, at age 89. A resident of Wyomissing, PA, at the time of her death, she was formerly of Garden City, NY, and Philadelphia, PA. Ruth H. Apprich was born on July 2, 1922, in West Reading, PA. She was the oldest of four daughters of Nicholas and Ellen Beyer Apprich. She graduated with honors in 1940 from Wyomissing High School and went on to the University of Chicago to study drama. In 1944, she married Charles Richard ("Dick") Jacob. The couple raised four children in Garden City. Mrs. Jacob wrote creatively her whole life. She penned lyrics for a sacred cantata, "Miracles of Christmas," the music for which was written by Ned Rorem (published 1971). In 1986 Mrs. Jacob was commissioned by the Philadelphia Inquirer to write "We the People, A Family Guide to Constitution City," in honor of the 1987 Bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution. Her poetry was published in the anthology Birthday Candles Burning Bright (1960). During the 1950s to 1970s, Mrs. Jacob was a strong supporter of the civil rights movement. Her commitment to progressive Democratic Party ideals continued throughout her life. At mid-life, Mrs. Jacob completed her B.A. degree and obtained an M.S.W. degree from Adelphi University. She then worked for a number of years as a social worker. Later in life she moved back to Wyomissing, where she passed away from natural causes. Mrs. Jacob is survived by her daughters Ellen McDaniel of Columbia, MD, Stacie Webb of Harrison, NY, and Nora Jacob of Rancho Santa Margarita, CA; her son Charles R. ("Chuck") Jacob III of Brooklyn and Rhinebeck, NY; their spouses; 10 grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an obituary about George Kerchner, who as an Army Ranger was decorated for his actions on D-Day, misstated the rank of the man shown with him. He was Lt. Col. James E. Rudder, not ''Cmdr.'' (Colonel Rudder was the commander of the Second Ranger Battalion, but the rank of Commander does not exist in the United States Army.)

DOBRER--Kenneth, 92, of Hackensack, NJ on March 14, 2012. Born in New York, he was a Veteran of WW II. Kenneth was a restaurant owner, opening a restaurant in New York across from Columbia University. He later became the top salesman for Life Magazine, and then became a writer and editor for Research Institute of America. Kenneth's interests included the theater, opera and the New York Yankees. Beloved husband of Janet (nee Bergman) Intrater Dobrer. Devoted father of Nina Hoffman and the late Jean Dobrer, stepfather of Jon, Fred, Andy and James Intrater and Jeremy Dobrish. Cherished father-in-law of Stanley Hoffman. Devoted friend and former husband of Florence Dobrer. Loving friend of the late Cecilia Dobrish. Dear brother of the late Ruth Nagler. Loving grandfather of Emily, Amanda, Susannah, and Nicholas Hoffman and Dillon Intrater. Services: Friday, 12:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

The Wealth Matters column on Saturday, about the financial value of taking on certain debt, misstated current tax law regarding the deduction of mortgage interest. While the maximum for deductible mortgage interest is $1.1 million, that amount is not currently reduced at higher income levels, because of the Bush administration tax cuts that took effect in 2010. (Before that tax cut, the deduction was phased out starting at income levels of $200,000. And when the income stretched into the millions, as much as 80 percent of that deduction was phased out.)

SCLAFANI--Rose G.,on March 12, 2012, beloved wife of the late William M. Sclafani, loving mother of Mary Wagner and her husband Dick, and the late Nancy O'Malley and William G. EISNER--Hank. Howard's closest friend. You will be greatly missed by us all. The Garlicks

MOSS--Simon C.,of Woodmere, NY and later Houston, TX. On the first anniversary of his passing, Simon is remembered with love by his family: including former wife Peggy Moss; sons Alex, Nat and Jacob; daughters-in-law Margaret, Becca and Jennifer; and grandchildren Abby, Leila, Nina, Isaac, and Jessie. He attended Woodmere Academy, earned his doctorate in metallurgy at MIT, and served on the University of Houston physics faculty for over 30 years. For his enormous contributions to materials science, he was recognized with the Materials Research Society's Von Hippel Award and the Minerals, Metals & Materials Society's William Hume-Rothery Memorial Award. Simon was known affectionately to his grandchildren as "Pimon," so it is perhaps fitting that he died on "Pi" day, 3.14. He was an avid art collector and a lover of the ballet, classical music, opera, poetry and tennis. Today and every day, he is deeply missed.

LOS ANGELES-Next year's Oscar nominees will have a little more time to jockey for a prize on awards night, and will have a little less time jockeying to be a nominee. That's because the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Wednesday said it had set the date for the 85th Academy Awards ceremony on Feb. 24, two days earlier than this year's ceremony, while scheduling the announcement of Oscar nominees for Jan. 15, nine days earlier than this year's announcement. The net effect will be a small adjustment in campaign dynamics, as the nominees get an extra week to bask in what Academy officials sometimes like to call their ''nominee-ness,'' before the envelopes are opened on Oscar night. This pushes the nominations announcement into a mid-January spot that has normally been occupied by the Golden Globes - so the Academy seems to be crowding its competitor just a bit, though it shows no sign yet of jumping Oscar night into an early February or even late January date, as some have suggested.

SILVERSTEIN--Mike, renowned in the shoe industry as co-founder of Nina Footwear Corp., passed away on March 12th surrounded by his loving wife, Renee, his four children Scott, Neil, Nanci and Baron and spouses Betsy, Mara and Jan and his 12 grandchildren. Mike was born in Havana, Cuba in 1926 and emigrated to the United States in 1944 where he entered the U.S. Army and was stationed in the Philippines ultimately joining the Air Force on search and rescue missions. In 1953 Mike and his brothers Stanley and Larry started Nina Footwear Corporation, building a successful shoe business and making an indelible mark in the shoe industry. Mike will be remembered for his ever present fine Cuban Cigar and his elegance and personal style. To his family he will be remembered as a man with strength of character who enjoyed life and passed along his strong values and virtues. Donations may be made in appreciation of Dr. Valentin Fuster in Mike's memory to Mt. Sinai Medical Center. For details, call Sam Kelly, 212-659-8500.

Willy Loman, the tragic hero in ''Death of a Salesman,'' may think he has problems. But it turns out he's got nothing on the hypothetical road warriors in William J. Cook's new book, ''In Pursuit of the Traveling Salesman: Mathematics at the Limits of Computation,'' who are pushed to visit hundreds, thousands, even millions of cities, mostly in pursuit of someone else's mathematical glory. Dr. Cook, a professor of industrial and systems engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology, offers a cheerful biography of the Traveling Salesman Problem, which was born as a major mathematical preoccupation in the late 1940s, around the same time as Loman himself, but has gone on to have a far more satisfying career. Today the problem -- which involves finding the most efficient route among geographical points -- is a key concept in applied efficiency research and is used to direct telescopes, manufacture computer chips, map genomes, speed up video games, and even, Dr. Cook notes, ''minimize wallpaper waste.''

An article in some editions on Tuesday about a vote on a plan to replace a section of wood planks on the Coney Island Boardwalk with plastic and concrete overstated, in some copies, the significance of the action taken by the Public Design Commission on Monday. It gave preliminary -- not final -- approval to the plan. (The error was repeated in the headline in some copies.)

I had high hopes for the Jabra Supreme Bluetooth headset ($100). I like headsets with a boom (that protruding arm some headsets have) because it gets the microphone close to your mouth, usually meaning better sound quality on the receiving end and less yelling on the sending end. But the Supreme's performance did not live up to the design.

Apologies to Adam Levine and Maroon 5, but the people most likely to have ''moves like Jagger'' these days are women. At least that was the case at the benefit produced by the City Winery owner Michael Dorf on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, where dozens of musicians joined a tribute to the Rolling Stones. Performing all 21 tracks from the band's classic collected-hits album, ''Hot Rocks 1964-1971,'' on the 40th anniversary of its release, the ladies were the ones with Mick Jagger's cocky strut and sex appeal, not to mention the outré outfits. Peaches, the Canadian club singer, took the stage in a tight black hooded jumpsuit, open nearly to the navel, and swung the microphone through a rendition of ''Heart of Stone,'' her expanse of bare flesh turning pink as she panted feelingly through the chorus. The singer and actress Juliette Lewis, in silver sequined hot pants and with occasionally pursed lips, had women dancing in the aisles with her version of ''Satisfaction.'' She doffed her high heels -- also silver sequined -- halfway through.

The annual Pap smear, a cornerstone of women's health for at least 60 years, is now officially a thing of the past, as new national guidelines recommend cervical cancer screening no more often than every three years. In recent years, some doctors and medical groups, including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in 2009, began urging less frequent screening for cervical cancer. Even so, annual Pap smear testing is still common because many women are reluctant to give up frequent screening for cervical cancer.

The relative sales trends of different types of restaurants provide an indication of the health of the economy. When Americans feel better about their finances, they are more likely to eat at restaurants with full service, including bringing the food to the table, rather than at restaurants with limited service. At the moment, both the restaurant sales and the falling unemployment rate indicate the economy is doing better than the Gross Domestic Product figures would seem to show.

KAFANOVA--Ludmila. Russian language writer and journalist, died peacefully on March 13. She was 83. Born in Moscow, she emigrated to the US in 1974 and lived in New York with her late husband, Roman Romanov, a Russian gypsy singer. Ms. Kafanova is survived by her son Alexei Bayer, daughter-in-law Andrea and grandson Sam.

A Turkish helicopter plunged into a house in the Afghan capital on Friday, killing at least 12 NATO service members and two civilians, officials said.

Wall Street, once a magnet for America's best and brightest, is facing a recruiting problem. The industry's cachet, which was tarnished during the financial disaster, has been further stained by the lingering economic slowdown and a series of highly publicized industry scandals that have drawn critical attention to the big banks.

CLUETT--Virginia Ashcraft, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on March 6, 2012. The youngest child of the late Edwin M. Ashcraft II and Anna Strawbridge Ashcraft, she was born in Chicago, IL on June 21, 1915. Following the death of her first husband, Gerald H. Smith, she married George A. Cluett, Jr. in 1957 in Princeton, NJ where they resided for many years. In 1994, she moved to Fox Hill Village in Westwood, MA. She was also a long time summer resident of Blue Hill, ME where her family gathered every summer. A graduate of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, Ginny was active in the Princeton Garden Club and as a volunteer at the Princeton Hospital. She was predeceased by her two children, Ann A. Smith and Ralph O. Smith, her stepson A. Tucker Cluett, her sisters Barbara Ashcraft and Ann A. Mitchell, and her brother Edwin M. Ashcraft III. She is survived by her stepson Mark S. Cluett of Savannah, GA, her granddaughters Amanda C. Stanton of Pennington, NJ, Elizabeth C. Thors of Brookline, MA, and Julia S. Cluett of S. Egremont, MA, six great-grandchildren, and many nephews, nieces, grandnephews, and grandnieces. A family service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Historic Deerfield in Deerfield, MA.

ROSS--Richard C. Richard C. Ross, much loved husband to the late Joan Flug Ross, father to Marcia, William and Andrew Ross, father-in-law to Duncan, Diane and Summer and grandfather to John, Michael, and Alice passed away peacefully at JFK Hospital in Indio, California, Sunday March 11th. Born in the Bronx on May 5th, 1927, to Louis and Mollie Rosoff, Richard moved to Mount Vernon, New York in 1929 where he resided until his retirement in 2005 when he relocated to La Quinta, California. He graduated from A.B. Davis High School in 1944, at the age of 16, enlisting in the U.S. Navy later that year. After his honorable discharge he earned his Bachelor of Arts degree from New York University in 1950 and his Master of Laws degree from New York University Law School in 1953 where he was also on Law Review. Richard was a long time practicing attorney and had a 30 year history in politics and government. In 1963 he was elected to his first office as Supervisor, representing the City of Mount Vernon on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. In 1965 Richard was elected as a Mount Vernon City Councilman becoming President of the City Council in 1969. In 1973 he was elected as a member of the New York State Assembly for the 88th District serving four terms until 1981. Active in civic, religious and fraternal endeavors, Richard was past president of the Mount Vernon Lodge B'nai B'rith, a Neighborhood Commissioner of the Boy Scouts of America, a member of the Mount Vernon Lion's Club, Century Club of the Mount Vernon Hospital, Siwanoy F&A.M, Post 3 of the American Legion, Post 42 Jewish War Veterans, Mount Vernon Lodge 842 B.P.O. Elks, The Free Synagogue of Westchester and Trustee of its Men's Club, The Mount Vernon Bar Association, Westchester County Bar Association, NYU Law Review Alumni Association and of the Mount Vernon Y.M. & Y.W. H.A. He served as Counsel to the New York State Association of City Councils from its formation until his election as an Assemblyman. He also served as General Counsel to the Mount Vernon School Board and on the board of the Mount Vernon Library. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club and, as an avid tennis player, the New York Tennis Club. In addition he had an informal 35 year breakfast club as well as lunch and dinner clubs. He continued this tradition in his life in California. He will be dearly missed by his family and many friends and colleagues. A Service will be held for Richard Ross on Friday, March 30th at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:30 a.m, 21 W. Broad Street-Mt Vernon, NY. For further information please visit: www.riversidememorial mountvernon.com

MANDL--Otto, died after a brief illness, at age 89, on March 14, 2012, at home in Baldwin, and with his family. He is survived by his wife and life partner of 68 years, Ina, by his daughter Susan Mandl, sister Edith Hamberger and daughter-in-law Anita Mandl. He was predeceased by his son, David, in 2007. Graveside services will be held 1:00pm, Friday, March 16th at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

A film review last Friday about the documentary ''Shakespeare High,'' in which Kevin Spacey appears, referred imprecisely to his production company's connection to the film. While the company, Trigger Street, helped finance it and Mr. Spacey is an executive producer of the movie, it was made by Ifavor Entertainment, not by Trigger Street.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns over the resumption of bank dividends and share buybacks referred incorrectly to Anat R. Admati, a professor at Stanford University who commented on the issue. Professor Admati is a woman.

WASHINGTON -- The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers had been drinking alcohol -- a violation of military rules in combat zones -- and suffering from the stress related to his fourth combat tour and tensions with his wife about the deployments on the night of the massacre, a senior American official said Thursday. ''When it all comes out, it will be a combination of stress, alcohol and domestic issues -- he just snapped,'' said the official, who has been briefed on the investigation and who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the soldier has not yet been formally charged.

An article on Monday about the Millennium Theater in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, which offers programs for the Russian-speaking immigrants there, referred imprecisely to Yuri Bashmet, a musician who has played at the theater. He is an eminent violist who also plays the violin; he is not a violinist.

RUBENSTEIN--Steven Lee, Professor, Director Research Institute of Latin American Studies, University of Liverpool, UK. Beloved son of Ken and Fran, adored brother of Laurie (Rick Mallen), devoted uncle of Sophie and Sam. Friend, revered colleague, mentor to many worldwide. Funeral Sunday, March 18, 12pm, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the challenges in raising money for museums named for wealthy people misspelled the surname of the designated director of The Broad, a museum to be built in Los Angeles. Her name is Joanne Heyler, not Hyler.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- From the outset, many tabbed the Virginia Commonwealth-Wichita State contest on Thursday night as an underdog handoff, with last year's least likely national semifinalist (V.C.U.) matched against the team voted most likely to succeed it. Instead, this N.C.A.A. tournament received its first upset, if a win by a team that went to the Final Four the previous year can be considered as such.

Four conservative Republican senators kicked off a conversation Thursday on changes to Medicare, releasing a proposal that would end the federal fee-for-service insurance program in 2014 and enroll all recipients into the health insurance plan now offered to federal employees. The proposal establishes a right flank for the coming debate over the benefits program, which is expected to begin in earnest on Tuesday when the House Budget Committee, led by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, unveils the Republicans' plan. This proposal is expected to embrace ideas that Mr. Ryan wrote with Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, which would give seniors and other recipients a menu of health insurance plans to choose from, including the existing fee-for-service program. Seniors would be given a fixed subsidy to buy an insurance plan.

Our deepest sympathies go to the entire Schuhalter family, to Beverly, Murray's beloved wife, his daughters, Robbie, Ellen and Debbie, their families and all his adoring grandchildren who evoke that fabulous twinkle, joy and love in his eyes. LEE--James Tse-Chien, 84, of Scotch Plains, passed away peacefully on March 13, 2012, at the Peggy Coloney's House, a division of the Center for Hope Hospice, in Scotch Plains, NJ. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to a viewing on Friday, March 16, from 3-7pm, at the Walter J. Johnson Funeral Home, 803 Raritan Rd., Clark. To offer condolences, or for more information, please visit www.walterjohnsonfh.com James was born in Wujin, Jiangsu Province, China on December 25, 1927 and grew up in Taiwan. He attended Southern Illinois University where he received his B.A. in Journalism in 1962. In 1969 he received an M.A. degree from NYU. At Southern Illinois University he met Li Ma and the couple were married in 1961, settling down in Flushing, NY. Seventeen years later they moved to Westfield, NJ with their two sons, settling in Scotch Plains in 2003. From a young age, James shared a passion for newspaper writing with his father, and set a goal of joining the New York Times one day. Starting initially as a copy boy in 1964, James worked his way up to become an editor on the make-up desk of the New York Times. He retired in 1994 following 31 years of service for the paper. James then served as Managing Editor for the U.S. World Journal in Flushing, NY from 1995-1996. James authored The New York Times Style book which was published in 1998. He is survived by his beloved wife Li Ma, with whom he celebrated his 50th anniversary last year; his son David and wife Patricia of Pennington, NJ; his son Steven and wife Vitman of Westfield, NJ; and grandchildren Justin, Grace, Jonathan, and Jason. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made online to: "Team James Lee" of the Parkinson's Unity Walk, www.unitywalk.org

TUCHMAN--Audrey (Berkowitz), on March 15, 2012. Beloved wife of Stanley, loving mother of Ellen Sherman, Laurence and Jennifer Tuchman. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra, Gillian, Jack and Ross. Services Sunday 10am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
