MARGULIES--Harriett W.,on March 11, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Ned, adored mother of Alan (Gale), and Alissa (Emily). Although a child of a broken home, she finished high school at 15, graduated from the Traphagen School of Design and became chief designer and manager of a major fashion house in NYC. She married Ned in 1949, and raised her family on Long Island, creating an atmosphere rich in culture, music, art and travel. Whether helping with school papers, driving lessons or Little League practice, Mom was there for us. That, and her dry sense of humor, kept the travail of childhood in perspective. She was knowledgeable on almost any subject, well read, inquisitive, cool in a crisis, always logical; she was our Mr. Spock before we knew of Star Trek. Her Sunday Times crossword was finished in under 90 minutes- in ink, no less. Mom nurtured our independence and took pride in our accomplishments, yet was modest about her own. She taught herself to play the piano and violin, to paint and sculpt, to photograph, to knit and do needlepoint. She designed furniture, helped decorate our homes, mapped out gardens. Afraid of flying, she still managed to accompany our father to six continents. She mastered computers long before we did, and spent afternoons doing research on anything and everything, just because she could. She loved cooking and faxed us recipes that she had discovered, after trying them out first on a grateful husband. Cared for at the end by Veviene, Paula, Robinann and Grace, Mom was always the heart of her home. She was one of a kind, and we knew it, and we'll miss her always. And her pot roast.

The film and television actor Paul Giamatti (''Sideways,''''John Adams'') will play Hamlet next year at Yale Repertory Theater, during a 2012-13 season there that will include world premiere productions of plays by David Adjmi (''Stunning''), Sarah Ruhl (''In the Next Room, or the vibrator play'') and a new adaptation of the 1978 German film ''In a Year with 13 Moons,'' the theater announced on Thursday. Yale Rep's ''Hamlet'' will be the first time that Mr. Giamatti has played the role, a spokesman for the theater said. Many of the best-known productions have starred men in their 30s (like Laurence Olivier, John Gielgud, and Mel Gibson), but the melancholy prince has been played by older actors (John Barrymore) and younger actors (Ethan Hawke) as well. Mr. Giamatti, an acclaimed performer who won an Emmy award as Adams and was nominated for an Oscar for the 2005 film ''Cinderella Man,'' will be 45 when his Hamlet returns to Elsinore during the Yale Rep run, scheduled for March 15-April 13, 2013.

PALADINO--Daniel R.,of New York City, March 15, after a long struggle with Lewy Body disease. A man of enormous intellect, kindness and humor, Dan was born in the Bronx. After graduating from Stepinac High School, White Plains, he went on to earn a BS in economics from Fordham University, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He spent his junior year at Ecole Polytechnique in Paris. He earned his LLB from New York University School of Law, where he was a Root-Tilden Scholar. Dan taught legal writing at the University of Indiana Law School, Bloomington, before joining the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, New York City. He went on to become a Partner at Davis and Cox, where he handled corporate, commercial and financial transactions for Summa Corporation, the Howard Hughes holding company. Dan subsequently spent 22 years with The Seagram Company Ltd., as Executive Vice President for Legal and Environmental Affairs and General Counsel. A member of The New York State Bar, The Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the American Bar Association, he also served as board member and president of Upward, Inc., an afterschool program in Harlem. A long-time member of Gipsy Trail Club in Putnam County, Dan was always up for a friendly tennis game and loved to trap shoot. He was also a dedicated runner and enjoyed traveling the world for both business and pleasure. He leaves his wife of 40 years, Polly McCaffrey; a sister, Judith Anson, Scarsdale; brothers-in-law, William McCaffrey, Potsdam, New York, John McCaffrey, LaPorte, Texas, and Robert Casper, Oswego, New York; nieces Amy Anson, Hartsdale, New York, Stacia Harrje, Falls Church, Virginia, Julisa McCaffrey, LaPorte; and three Casper nephews, all of Oswego, Robert Jr., Ted and Ben. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Sunday, March 18, 5-8pm. Service Campbell's Chapel, Monday, March 19, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, Daniel R. Paladino Fund for Memory Disorders Research, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.
A critic's notebook article on Thursday about the jazz pianist Vijay Iyer misidentified the city where he was born. It is Albany -- not Rochester, which is where he grew up.

MF Global employees at the center of a federal investigation are expected to appear before a Congressional panel this month to shed light on the brokerage firm's misuse of roughly $1 billion in customer money, according to people briefed on the matter. One notable employee, Edith O'Brien, is expected to invoke her constitutional right against compelled self-incrimination, one of the people said. Ms. O'Brien has also declined to cooperate with federal prosecutors without first receiving immunity from criminal charges.

Mark Sanchez flew to Orlando,Fla., a few weeks ago, but not for a Disney World vacation. His objective: a face-to-face meeting with Santonio Holmes. They ate.They spoke. And, according to Sanchez, they laughed. It was, in other words, much more enjoyable than the conversations they shared toward the end of last season, when their feud consumed the Jets' locker room. ''I know it can work between us,'' Sanchez said before a charity function Thursday in Manhattan.''It's not a question of if. It's just a matter of when, and that's now. I'm thrilled about that.'' Sanchez called reports of friction between the men overblown.Their relationship appeared to bottom out during the final weekof the season, when they sparred during a receivers meeting and, the next day, when Holmes failed to attend another meeting called by Sanchez. But Sanchez did not deny that their relationship had frayed. Still, he called the rift ''ancient history.''During a 25-minute interview with reporters, Sanchez appeared relaxed and in good spirits, and he addressed a range of topics -- the Jets' underachieving,his own poor performance,the offensive coordinator BrianSchottenheimer's departure -- that he did not during the conferencecall the Jets held last Fridayto announce his new five-year contract.Before last Friday, Sanchez had not spoken publicly since theday after the season, staying silent as unnamed teammates andothers unleashed a torrent of criticism.He said he had since spoken with several teammates and ''absolutely'' felt he had their respect.''No matter what you say,whether I come back to try to defendmyself or not, it doesn't matterunless you go win games,''Sanchez said. ''That's the ultimategoal. That's the ultimate defense.Just win games.''In their search to find a backupfor Sanchez, the Jets are hostingBrady Quinn, formerly of theDenver Broncos, on Friday.BILLS SIGN TOP PRIZE The BuffaloBills rarely have the moneyand have never had the flash thathelps their rivals lure the mostsought-after free agents. Theyhave had to overcome economics,a lack of trendy nightclubs, longwinters and, lately, the absenceof success to attract players whohave other options.Mario Williams would havehad plenty of options. The formerfirst overall draft pick by theHouston Texans, Williams wasthe best defensive player availablethis year, the rare elite passrusher to hit the open market inhis prime. But the Bills made himtheir top priority in free agency,not just to shore up their anemicpass rush but also to give a boostto a franchise and a fan base desperateto be relevant again afternot making the playoffs for a dozenseasons.So when free agency beganTuesday, the Bills were therewith a private plane to whisk Williams to Buffalo, and then theydid not let him leave.He remained there for twonights -- an unusually long visitfor a free agent -- while the Billsplied him with everything fromtours of residential neighborhoodsto conversations with theformer Bills star Jim Kelly.Finally, they overwhelmed himwith an offer no team was preparedto approach -- a six-yeardeal that guarantees Williams$50 million, the biggest guaranteeever for a defensive player.That surpasses by nearly 20 percentthe $42 million guaranteegiven to Julius Peppers by theChicago Bears two years ago,and it makes Williams the thirdN.F.L. player to be guaranteed$50 million.On Thursday, Williams signed,becoming the biggest free-agentacquisition in Bills history.The Bills had been a long shotto land Williams, but now thatthey have him, a defense that hadonly 29 sacks last season -- onlytwo teams had fewer -- shouldhave one of the most dominantdefensive lines in the league. Williamswill join end Chris Kelsayand tackles Kyle Williams andMarcell Dareus in Buffalo's 4-3defense. JUDY BATTISTA

Tom Murrin, a performance artist whose frenetic shows fashioned kooky narratives out of found objects and homemade masks and made him a longtime favorite in the downtown avant-garde arts scene in New York, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 73. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Patricia Sullivan.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Wednesday about renovations to Digital Domain Park, the Mets' spring training center in Port St. Lucie, Fla., misstated the given name of the chairman of the board of commissioners in St. Lucie County. He is Chris Dzadovsky, not Chad.

6:43 p.m. | Updated Cisco Systems said on Thursday that it planned to buy the NDS Group, a provider of content streaming and security software, for about $5 billion to help expand its next-generation video services. By buying NDS, which has British Sky Broadcasting and DirecTV among its customers, Cisco is hoping to augment its Videoscape streaming platform. The company has been focusing on its video offerings as it works to bolster lagging growth in its core networks business.

HODDER--Mary, died March 10 after a long illness, her husband Peter Aaron by her side. Born 1949 to emigre parenst from England. Stufied at NYU, did her thesis on Mathew Arnold and the Bhagavad Gita at Magdalen College, Oxford. A Tibetan Buddhist, Adjunct Professor at NYU and Mary Mount, employed by Goldman Saks on 9/11. Penetrating mind, indomitable spirit, sweet soul, beloved wife, brave sister. A memorial in June will be announced.

-The Rolling Stones will not tour to celebrate their 50th anniversary, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards told Rolling Stone magazine in an item published on Wednesday. Mr. Richards, who is 68, said 2013 was a more realistic goal for the aging rockers. The band did announce on Wednesday that it would release a new documentary film about its history in September to mark the anniversary. The film is by Brett Morgen, who directed the documentary ''The Kid Stays in the Picture.''
3:44 p.m. | Updated For President Obama, the fainting spells are back. A woman listening to the president discuss his energy policy in Maryland on Thursday fainted among the standing-room-only crowd.

WASHINGTON -- On Christmas in 1980 a fifth-grade boy in Flushing, Queens, received his first computer, a Commodore VIC-20. It changed his life. A few months later, a third grader about 100 miles upstate, in Woodstock, also received his first computer, a Commodore VIC-20. It changed his life too. The kid in Queens was Chris Melissinos, curator of ''The Art of Video Games,'' the path-breaking new exhibition opening here on Friday at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. The boy in Woodstock was me.

When the old-line law firms Dewey Ballantine and LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae merged in 2007, it was the talk of the legal industry. The combination created an international behemoth poised to benefit from the booming global economy. Five years later, the corporate law world is again abuzz over the firm, Dewey & LeBoeuf, but for less auspicious reasons.

In a little over an hour, Ryan Matthew Pierson racked up $437.71 in iTunes charges for virtual currency that he could use to buy guns, nightclubs and cars in iMobster, a popular iPhone game. One problem: Mr. Pierson, a technology writer in Texas, has never played iMobster. ''This was fraud,'' said Mr. Pierson, recalling the November incident. ''I woke up, checked my e-mail, and I could see these purchases happening in real time.''

The New York State Education Department announced on Thursday that it would hire a team of investigators and lawyers to overhaul and modernize the state's handling of test tampering complaints. The announcement followed the completion of a four-month review by Henry M. Greenberg, a lawyer appointed by the Board of Regents to investigate how the department collects and reviews allegations. According to a five-page summary of the report's findings -- state officials would not release it in full -- the department ''cannot adequately receive, review and follow-up on reports of allegations in the administration and scoring of state assessments.''

The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious annual honors for historians, has been awarded to three scholars for books published last year. The winners are Anne F. Hyde for ''Empires, Nations and Families: A History of the North American West, 1800-1860'' (University of Nebraska Press); Daniel T. Rodgers for ''Age of Fracture,'' an intellectual history of 1970s and 80s America (Belknap Press/Harvard University Press); and Tomiko Brown-Nagin for ''Courage to Dissent: Atlanta and the Long History of the Civil Rights Movement'' (Oxford University Press).

A former MTV executive who helped found the E! television network has announced a gift to the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles to begin a new $100,000 artist award that has overtones of reality television, The Los Angeles Times reported. The winner will be chosen from among artists who participate in ''Made in L.A.,'' a biennial scheduled to open June 2, organized by the Hammer, Laxart and the Los Angeles Department of Cultural Affairs. After a jury of art experts narrows the field to five finalists, museumgoers who see the exhibition will pick the winner. The prize will be known as the Mohn Prize, after Jarl Mohn, the art collector and former executive who will pay for it, along with his wife, Pamela.

6:15 p.m. | Updated with additional details WASHINGTON - A federal appeals court dealt a stinging rebuke on Thursday to Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in New York, who last year rejected a Securities and Exchange Commission fraud settlement with Citigroup because the deal had allowed the company to avoid admitting any wrongdoing.
Two leaders of Moscow’s street protest movement and the husband of another were convicted, raising fears that something resembling a campaign of reprisals had begun.

10 P.M. (Sundance) LOVELY AND AMAZING (2002) Nicole Holofcener examines narcissism and its fallout in this story about two sisters, both in their 30s: Elizabeth (Emily Mortimer, above), an attractive actress who was rejected for a role in a soap opera for not being sexy enough, and Michelle (Catherine Keener), an artist who designs gift-shop tchotchkes and has anger-management issues. Brenda Blethyn plays Jane, their mother, a divorced matriarch and something of a diva who has recently adopted a black 8-year-old daughter, Annie (Raven Goodwin), whose biological mother was a crack addict. When Jane develops complications from liposuction, Elizabeth and Michelle are left to care for Annie while enduring their own crises with the men in their lives. ''As smart and observant as it is, 'Lovely and Amazing' doesn't really go anywhere,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. NOON (ESPN2 and ESPN3) 2012 WINTER X GAMES EUROPE The competition in Tignes, France, wraps up with finals in the women's and men's snowboard slopestyle and the men's skiing superpipe.

MARCUS--Henry, died yesterday at age 94. Mr. Marcus served in the U.S. Army CID in WWII. A graduate of Brooklyn College, Mr. Marcus was preceded in death by his loving wife of 52 years, Pearl Marcus, whom he met in college. In 2005, Mr. Marcus remarried and is survived by devoted wife, Kathleen Marcus; by daughter, Sherry Hatcher (Robert), granddaughters Jessamyn Hatcher and Juliet Hatcher-Ross and great-grandchildren Willa Fields and Quinn Hatcher-Ross. Mr. Marcus, an engineer, had a strong sense of social justice, a keen sense of humor and was an avid tennis player. He was beloved and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester at 1:00pm on Friday, March 16, 2012.

MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands--The art dealers wanted fireworks to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the European Fine Art Fair here. But that idea was deemed too dangerous, so instead they settled for an installation of 20,000 cascading white LED lights that shimmers at the fair's entrance. The work of the American artist Leo Villareal, ''Cylinder II'' is computer-controlled and changes over time, creating different patterns and movements of light throughout the day. Some are slow, others fast; the lights get dim and then quite bright. They also shimmer and oscillate.

HECHT--Irwin M. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the loss of Irwin ("Win") Hecht, our beloved friend and longtime employee. Win's leadership helped our company navigate a complex and ever-emerging global market. He joined the International Division of the Estee Lauder Companies in October 1970 as Regional Director for the Pacific Region and, later, Europe. He spent several years traveling the world, and building our business. In 1973, Win was named Managing Director of the Canadian affiliate, where he helped establish a firm foundation for what has become one of our most vibrant markets. After 11 years in Canada, Win spent four years as Managing Director in South Africa, mobilizing an outstanding team and instilling a strong sense of social responsibility that endures. In 1988, Win became Executive Vice President of the International Division for the Estee Lauder Companies based first in New York and then London, where he remained in this role until he retired in 1997. Win's guiding principles, both for himself and for his teams, were flexibility and focus. He was a financial genius, a compassionate mentor, and a caring human being. Win was invaluable, and his passion and generosity helped define a new generation of our international executives. He will be missed. Our thoughts are with his cherished wife, Heidi, his family and his many, many friends.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- Pat Summitt plays games and puzzles on her iPad to help her remain alert. Her sense of humor remains acute, along with her ambition to win a ninth national championship. But anyone who has been around her can sense inevitable changes seven months after Summitt revealed that she had symptoms of early onset Alzheimer's disease. Once she was so fiery that she pounded her hands on the court and had to have her rings re-rounded. As was evident at practice Wednesday, she now appears quieter, more subdued.

In an odd twist, the time change due to Daylight Savings apparently continued to depress television ratings among the networks for the fourth night in a row on Wednesday. Overall viewership in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic was down by 9 percent compared to last week and almost every show experienced a drop in ratings of some kind. Fox was the No. 1 network for the night and ''American Idol'' had 17.9 million total viewers, but that was down from the 18.7 million who tuned in for last Wednesday's episode. On ABC, ''Modern Family'' finished with season lows in the 18-to-49 category and in total viewers (10.5 million). ''Criminal Minds'' on CBS hit a series low in viewers 18-to-49 and had 11.3 million total viewers.
MIDWEST No. 2 Kansas

Eight school employees with records of behaving inappropriately around students did not receive the proper punishment in the past, and should now be fired, according to a review released Thursday by Dennis M. Walcott, New York City's schools chancellor. Four of the employees were school aides, and have already been fired, Mr. Walcott said in a letter to principals. The four others are tenured teachers, who are entitled to hearings under state law and contract rules. They have been removed from classrooms in the meantime.

An article last Friday about the Presidio Parkway construction project incorrectly rendered the name of the office that issued a 2010 report saying a public-private partnership for building highways was ''not likely to be a good fiscal deal for the state.'' It was the California Legislative Analyst's Office, not the California Legislative Office.
HINE--Peter J.,Memorial on Sunday, March 18, 10:00am at the Jacob Burns Film Center, 405 Manville Rd., Pleasantville, NY, reception to follow.

FISH--Walter, on March 15, 2012, Beloved husband of Sandra. Loving father of Mark and Dena, Kenneth and Kyoko and Jonathan and Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Maya, Boaz, Aderet, Kazumi, Keizo, Caroline and Sarah. Fond brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Funeral service Friday 1pm at Gutterman's Inc, 175 N. Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre.

WASHINGTON -- RepresentativeGary L. Ackerman, a longtime member of Congress from Queens and Long Island, announced on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, an unexpected development that brings an end to a colorful political career. Mr. Ackerman, 69, arrived at his decision even though it was quite likely that his district would be spared under the Congressional redistricting process, which the state is close to completing. New York must reduce the size of its House delegation to 27, from 29, to reflect population changes recorded in the 2010 census.

Something has got to get better, and it's got to happen fast because I'm about at the end. ARNOLD L. GALLEGOS, a struggling small business owner in Pueblo, Colo., who said his support for the Democratic Party and President Obama is wavering. [A19]

A court hearing for a woman accused of running a high-class brothel in Manhattan was upstaged Thursday by a rotating cast of defense lawyers, as two dueling lawyers were unexpectedly relieved by two others. Prosecutors and the judge, Juan M. Merchan of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, had expected a discussion on a decidedly unorthodox bond proposal from Peter Gleason, one of the two lawyers for the woman, Anna Gristina. Mr. Gleason on Monday offered up his loft in TriBeCa to help his client secure a $2 million bond to be freed from custody.

GREENBERG--Steven. A Celebratory Service in Loving Memory of STEVEN A. GREENBERG Will be held on Tuesday, March 20 at 5:30pm at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th St. (between Lexington and 3rd Avenues). Steven was a visionary creative genius who became the Nightlife King of NY. Owner of 230 Fifth, the Roxy and the Palladium. A renowned collector of Art Deco. He was a generous, charismatic and special friend to many.

SCHUHALTER--Murray. A great man, who put family above all else and who lived a life of honor, decency and integrity. Murray passed away peacefully at home on March 15, 2012, at the age of 86, surrounded by his loving family. Murray lived and loved life to the fullest. He loved tennis and golf, singing and dancing, family and friends. He leaves behind the love of his life, his beautiful wife of 62 plus years, Beverly, his three wonderful daughters, Ellen Dyner, Debbie Somoza and Robbie Karp, three loving sons-in-law, Charlie, Brad and Joe, five adoring grandchildren, Lauren, Jamie, Meredith, Arielle and David, and a legion of friends and admirers. A decorated veteran of World War II, Murray reminded us every day why his was the greatest generation. We all were blessed to know Murray; he enriched our lives and made each of us a better person. His example will guide us always. Murray Schuhalter will be forever missed. Services will be held on March 16, 2012, at 12:00pm, at Bernheim Apter, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey. Donations may be made to the National WWII Memorial (Washington, D.C.) or the cancer research/treatment organization of your choosing.

An article on March 6 about the Web site Fan Chants, which compiles soccer chants from around the world, referred incorrectly to Channel 5, which airs Europa League games in the United Kingdom. It is an over-the-air broadcast network, not a basic cable channel.

The Tony Award-winning writer Terrence McNally (''Master Class,'' ''Ragtime'') will have a world-premiere production of his new play, ''And Away We Go,'' Off Broadway next year. The play travels through time to show the similarities among chaotic theater companies in ancient Greece, Elizabethan London, Versailles and 20th-century America. The Pearl Theater Company, a New York troupe that mounts classic plays and new works dealing with classical themes, commissioned the play and said on Thursday that the production would run April 19 to May 19, 2013, at the Pearl's new home at 555 West 42nd Street, the space formerly occupied by Signature Theater Company.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- President Hamid Karzai insisted Thursday that the United States confine its troops to major bases in Afghanistan by next year as the Taliban announced that they were suspending peace talks with the Americans, both of which served to complicate the Obama administration's plans for an orderly exit from the country. Mr. Karzai's abrupt planning shift was at odds with a pledge offered just hours earlier by President Obama to stick to a 2014 withdrawal schedule for troops in Afghanistan. It also ran up against the Pentagon's stark assessment that Afghan security forces were not yet ready to take over control of the country.

There was always something artistically sinister about Damien Demento, the loony thug who thrilled World Wrestling Federation fans in the early 1990s with his stringy Fu Manchu beard-mustache combo, bear-claw poncho and bad-guy persona A Salvador Dalí on steroids, equally adept at revving up bloodthirsty fans or body-slamming foes, Demento was the brainchild of the fertile and somewhat twisted mind of one Phillip Thies, who grew up a tough street kid in Brooklyn and on Staten Island with an outsize personality to match his physique.

A chart on Wednesday with the Economic Scene column, about the many tax breaks in the United States tax code, included erroneous calculations of average federal benefits per family because the data was not adjusted for family size. A corrected version of the chart can be found at nytimes.com/economy.

SILVERSTEIN--Murray (Mike) The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Murray (Mike) Silverstein, a respected member of the Jewish community and a widely admired entrepreneur in the shoe industry where he and his brother, Stanley Siverstein were co-founders and co-chairmen of the Nina Footwear Corp. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Renee and his children, Scott, Baron, Nanci and Neil and to his beloved brother Stanley (and Raine) Silverstein, Yeshiva University Benefactors who established the Raine and Stanley Silverstein Chair in Professional Ethics and Values at the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration, and to the entire Silverstein family. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. YESHIVA UNIVERSITY Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

5:23 p.m. | Updated The weekly public radio program ''This American Life'' said on Friday that it was retracting a critical report about Apple's suppliers in China because the storyteller, Mike Daisey, had embellished details in the narrative. The program's host, Ira Glass, said in a statement that Mr. Daisey ''lied'' to him and to Brian Reed, a producer of the program, about details related to injured workers Mr. Daisey had described meeting at Foxconn, a factory in China where Apple products are made.

LONDON - Hector Sants, the chief executive of Britain's financial regulator, will step down at the end of June, as part of a major overhaul to the country's policing of financial markets. The announcement comes a year before the Financial Services Authority will be split up in early 2013, with the majority of its powers to be given to the Bank of England, the country's central bank.

The Broadway director and choreographer Rob Ashford (''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'') has been hired for a stage musical adaptation of Tim Burton's 2010 film version of ''Alice in Wonderland,'' according to Variety. A spokesman for the producer, Disney Theatrical Productions, declined to comment on Friday, and Mr. Ashford did not return a phone call seeking comment. The musical is still considered several years away from reaching the stage, and no songwriters have been hired. Mr. Burton is widely known to be involved in creating the ''Alice'' musical; the Variety report said that Linda Woolverton is writing the musical's book based on her screenplay for the film, and Richard D. Zanuck, one of the film's producers, would be an executive producer of the musical. (The Disney spokesman declined to confirm those details.) The film version of ''Alice,'' which starred Johnny Depp and Mia Wasikowska, brought in more than $1 billion worldwide in spite of mixed reviews and won Academy Awards for art direction and costume design; the musical will be based on the movie's designs.

HECHT--Irwin M. 'Win', passed away peacefully in Scottsdale, Arizona on March 13th, 2012 after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's. He was 83 years old. He will be sadly missed by his loving wife, Heidi, his two sons, Daniel and Jonathan, his step-daughter Renata, her husband Dave and their two children, Camden and Sophia. He was pre-deceased by his dear sister, Lottie. Win was born on December 9, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Georgia Tech as an Engineer and promptly went into the Cosmetic and Perfume industry. He joined Estee Lauder International in 1970 and travelled the world. He made many friends as well as being a mentor and leader to many. He touched so many people in so many places in such a wonderful and profound way. On his retirement in 1999 as Executive Vice-President, he spent his time between his home in Greenwich, CT and The Boulders in Carefree, AZ. A service will be held Monday, March 19th, 12 noon, at Gallagher's Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06830 (203-869-1513) followed by a burial at the historic Putnam Cemetery, 35 Parsonage Rd. Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers and in remembrance of Win's life, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America in his name (1-866-232-8484, web: Alzfdn.org).

The actor George Clooney, his father, Nick Clooney, and Representative James P. Moran of Virginia were among more than a dozen protesters arrested Friday outside the Sudanese Embassy in Washington. The arrests were confirmed by a spokeswoman for the congressman and a spokesman for the Secret Service, which made the arrests. The protesters were demonstrating to bring attention to accusations that Sudan's president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, is using military force to block food and humanitarian aid intended for civilians in Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile in a mountainous region on the country's shared border with South Sudan. South Sudan split from northern Sudan in July.

BERLIN- Germany's leading historical museum must return a collection of more than 4,250 rare posters seized by the Nazis to the American son of a Jewish dentist who fled Germany, the country's highest court for civil affairs in Karlsruhe ruled on Friday. The collection, which includes prewar advertisements for movies and cabaret shows as well as political propaganda by artists including Wassily Kandinsky, Max Pechstein and Otto Dix was taken from Hans Sachs, a Jewish dentist, when he was sent to a concentration camp in 1938. Sachs later escaped with his family to Boston and his collection eventually became property of the Deutsches Historisches Museum in Berlin.

Maybe absence really does lead to fondness: The return of NBC's cult-favorite ''Community'' on Thursday night generated the show's best ratings for this season by far, and the best entertainment numbers for NBC in that time period in 14 months. An article on Friday about the American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers misstated the details of the relocation of the sergeant's family. They moved from their home onto Joint Base Lewis-McChord; their home was not located at the base. And because of an editing error, the article misstated at one point the number of times the soldier served in Iraq. It is three, not two.

ALBERT--Jerome Lewis, fformer owner and President of Coney Island's Astroland Park died at the age of 74 on Thursday, March 15, 2012 from complications resulting from Parkinson's Disease. He died at home surrounded by his loving family and friends. He is survived by his wife, of 35 years, Carol Hill, of New York, son Bradley, daughter-in-law Amy and grandson Tosh, all of Maui, as well as several nieces and nephews. Jerome graduated from PolyPrep, attended Syracuse University and graduated from New York University. Jerome Albert, along with his father Dewey, founded Coney Island's Astroland Park in 1961. Astroland took up the banner for reviving and maintaining Coney Island's amusement area after the collapse of the renowned Steeplechase Park. Throughout the sixties, Jerome Albert traveled the world for new and revolutionary rides and designs that had never been seen in Coney Island, as well as many that were completely new to the East Coast. These included the Astro Tower observation ride, one of the first giant Water Flumes and the first aerial tramway, the Sky ride, which stretched across the three acre park from Surf Ave. to the Boardwalk. Jerome Albert was also known for his extensive charitiy work including his work for children of Special needs- The Community Mayors Association--and the Police Anchor club, for widows and orphans of Police officers, as well as being the original sponsor for Coney Island's Friday night fireworks, the Air Shows, and many other community events. He was the recipient of the Mayor's Humanitarian Award from Mayor Giuliani for his work with the Community Mayors. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday March 18, 2012 at l0am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam Ave. and 91st St. to be followed by interment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations many be sent to the American Parkinson Association 135 Parkinson Ave. Staten Island, New York 10305.

OTTAWA -- Bell Canada, Canada's largest telecommunications company, extended its move into the media business on Friday by agreeing to pay 3.38 billion Canadian dollars (about $3.4 billion) for Astral Media, the owner of several prominent cable television channels including HBO Canada. The move follows Bell's acquisition of CTV, Canada's largest private-sector broadcaster, about a year and a half ago, as well as its participation last year in a joint venture that will own all of Toronto's professional sports teams, including hockey's Toronto Maple Leafs.

Reading and theater-going are largely separate activities. Though they walk side by side through my life, occupying more waking hours than any other activities, the lines between them seldom blur. Reading is private, even in a subway car; theater is a collective experience, in which you're always on the same page (literally if not figuratively) with a lot of other people. Or so I thought until ''Gatz'' walked into my life two years ago. Elevator Repair Service's epic-length adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby,'' which is back at the Public Theater for a limited run, is centered on the inspired notion of making you, dear reader, the main character.

Reverse mortgages have always been viewed as a last resort -- something that older retirees could turn to when they desperately needed to supplement their dwindling incomes. But in the wake of the housing market's collapse and high unemployment, a new study has found that people are using reverse mortgages to alleviate more urgent financial pressures, like paying off debt. And homeowners are applying for these loans at much younger ages than they have in the past. Reverse mortgages allow people age 62 and older to tap what may be their biggest asset, the equity in their home, without having to make any payments. Instead, the bank pays the borrowers, though they continue to be responsible for paying property taxes and homeowner's insurance. When borrowers are ready to sell (or when they die), the bank takes its share of the proceeds from the sale, and borrowers (or their heirs) receive whatever is left.

College students and their advocates are increasingly concerned about student loans, both those administered by the federal government and those made by private lenders. On Tuesday, students rallied on Capitol Hill to protest a pending interest rate increase in subsidized loans made to low- and moderate-income undergraduates under the federal Stafford program. The rate is scheduled to increase to 6.8 percent from 3.4 percent for new loans made after June 30.

9 P.M. (Starz) FRIENDS WITH BENEFITS (2011) Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis, above, play Dylan and Jamie, New York singles with battered hearts and eager bodies -- she's a corporate headhunter; he's the art director she places at a men's magazine -- who try to keep things light in this ''breezy, speedy and (no kidding) funny comedy'' about ''love and sex in the age of social networking,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The director, Will Gluck (''Easy A''), ''largely distinguishes himself in this movie by the casting (Woody Harrelson plays a randy gay colleague of Dylan's, and Patricia Clarkson shows up as Jamie's mom) and by directing the actors to talk at warp speed,'' Ms. Dargis said. Mr. Gluck ''doesn't just want to have his romantic comedy cake and eat it too, he also wants to throw it in your face and make you laugh as you lick the icing off your lips,'' she added. ''The results are about as naughty as that sounds (not very), but it also makes for a fairly giggling good time.'' 3 P.M. (21) CLANNAD LIVE AT CHRIST CHURCH CATHEDRAL, DUBLIN This Grammy-winning Irish-crossover ensemble celebrates its 40th anniversary with this special taped in January 2011, in which the five original members came together for their first full concert in 20 years. Recorded at the cathedral, which dates back to the 11th century, as part of the Temple Bar Tradfest, the program includes works like ''Theme From Harry's Game,'' the first Top 10 hit in the Gaelic language in Britain; ''Newgrange''; and ''I Will Find You.'' The guests include Anuna, Ireland's National Choir, and Brian Kennedy, who was the lead singer in ''Riverdance'' on Broadway. The program will be rebroadcast at 10.

Take one good, long last look at St. Patrick's Cathedral, a defining landmark of New York City. It is about to disappear for two or three years under a cocoon of scaffolding, inside and out, that will permit a $177 million rehabilitation project to unfold, the most extensive work at the cathedral in generations. Come to think of it, don't take too good a look. You may see the growing cracks in the marble facade and the patchwork of repairs up and down the buttresses, the dimness of the stained-glass windows and smoke-darkened walls, the zebra striping caused by lathing behind the plaster ceiling vaults, jerry-built vents poking out of the triforium arches along the nave, the jury-rigged cooling plant sitting in a giant plywood shed on 51st Street and the climbing-ivy accumulation of wiring and conduits around the column bases. You may even spot a chunk of stone on the cathedral grounds that has fallen from a wall above.

An article on Friday about social media's effect on keeping the raucous spring break gatherings in check referred incorrectly to the open-container laws in Key West, Fla. LONDON - Deutsche Bank announced changes to its management team on Friday, a sign that the incoming co-chief executives of the German bank are looking to put their stamp on the group before they assume joint control. Anshu Jain and Jürgen Fitschen, who are set to take over the company on June 1, named Henry Ritchotte to become Deutsche Bank's chief operating officer, while Stuart Lewis will take over as the company's chief risk officer. Stephan Leithner will lead the bank's human resources, legal and compliance division.

The Federal Reserve made an error in its stress test of Citigroup that led it to overstate a crucial measurement of losses on the bank's mortgages, the central bank acknowledged on Friday. The Fed also issued corrections for Bank of America, Ally Financial, MetLife and Wells Fargo. It said the corrections did not change the capital ratios projected by the stress tests, which estimated the losses that a bank could bear amid situations that include a severe recession and a market meltdown.

CLARKE--Richard V. Richard V. Clarke, one of the pioneers in the field of African-American business recruitment, and a generous and wise counselor to New York arts institutions, passed away on Friday, March 9, 2012, after a brief illness. He was born in New York City on June 11, 1927, the son of Emelda Clarke Mills and La Roi Mills. He spent his childhood and teenage years in D'Abadie, Trinidad and Tobago before returning to New York City. Shortly after his return, he enlisted in the New York National Guard. In 1957, he founded Hallmark Employment Agency, the precursor to Richard Clarke & Associates, the nation's first diversity recruitment firm with offices in New York and Chicago. In the early 1960 he created the Job Opportunity Centers, the equivalent to what is now known as job fairs. The firm closed its doors upon his retirement in 2004. In the 1970's, he published Contact Magazine, one of the first for an African American business audience. A longtime resident of the Upper West Side, he had a keen interest in the visual arts and he was an avid collector of African and African American art, autographs, and books. His true passion was spending time with family and friends, often on the deck of his former home in the Ninevah section of Sag Harbor, NY. Clarke was very active in the New York business and arts communities. He sat on many boards, including the New York Chapter of 100 Black Men of America, the New York Council on the Arts, the Studio Museum in Harlem, and as a Trustee, and later, Trustee Emeritus at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was a member of the External Affairs Committee, and was a founder and member of the Museum's Multicultural Audience Development Advisory Committee. He is survived by his children, Tracy Clarke and Richard C. Clarke, his daughter-in-law Shena Clarke, two granddaughters, Maya and Ava, his brother, Dr. Steven Mills, and many loving relatives and friends. A private memorial service will be held later.

GUITON--Margaret (Peggy), died peacefully at her home in New York City on Saturday, March 10, 2012 at the age of 94. She held degrees from Bryn Mawr, the University of Chicago and Radcliffe, where she was awarded a Ph.D. in political theory. During World War II and the immediate postwar years, she worked for the State Department and in the press section of the U.S. Embassy in Paris where she met her future husband, Jacques Guiton, with whom she enjoyed a long and happy marriage. He died in 2007. French literature was always Peggy's passion. Her published writings include a co-authored work on the French novel, a book on the fables of La Fontaine and most recently a collaboration on a translation of poems by Francis Ponge. She is survived by her daughter Nicolette, son John, daughter-in-law Linda Chesis and granddaughter Sophie Guiton. Her eldest daughter Jacqueline died in 2001.

WASSERMAN--Germaine. December 4, 1923 - January 10, 2012. Born NYC to Anna/ Nathan Podolsky. Germaine was a devoted daughter, sister, mother and provider who gave generously with a concerned and loving spirit for family, friends and those in need. She labored tirelessly for working people during a 50 year career in the Labor Movement. Worked for the creation of Medicare, battled for Civil Rights, Women's Rights and World Peace. Survived by twin sister Louise, son Eric (Joan) grandson Evan, granddaughter Shanna (Jarrett) greatgrandson Jack, nephews, nieces, and cousins. Preceded in death by husband John Moran and Leonard Wasserman(husband of 53 years), sister Sylvia and twin brothers Jack/Oscar. Memorial Sunday, March 25, 2:30, Riverside 76/Amsterdam.

Hugo Pratt's swashbuckling baddie Corto Maltese is huge in Europe and largely unknown in the United States, which makes him something like the Nutella of comic book heroes. Corto's reputation here could improve, however, with this month's publication of ''Corto Maltese: The Ballad of the Salt Sea'' (Universe, $25), one of the first major English translations of the classic Italian graphic novel from 1967. Set in a hyper-realistic, World War I-era slice of the South Seas, the book's exoticism might recall the travels of a certain Belgian boy reporter. But actually Corto Maltese is the anti-Tintin: he's a gruff pirate, the love child of an English seaman and an Andalusian sorceress-prostitute. He'd have no use for a little white dog, unless it could pour him rum. ''You'll take me as I am,'' he says early in the book, ''or go to hell.'' Corto's bravado struck a chord with the designer Joseph Altuzarra, who themed his latest fall-winter collection around the seafaring rake. ''My aunt gave me the comic books as a teenager, and I loved them,'' said Altuzarra, who grew up in France, where these books are canonical. ''Corto Maltese was everything I wasn't as a 13-year-old: elegant, confident, charismatic and mysterious.'' He says that a double-breasted navy peacoat from his collection - modeled by Joan Smalls during the February runway show in New York (below, center) - was ''a play on a classic Corto look,'' complete with a huge upturned collar. Altuzarra said that Gypsy references elsewhere in the collection were a nod to Corto's mixed heritage.

MARGULIES--Harriett W.,on March 11, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Ned, adored mother of Alan (Gale), and Alissa (Emily). Although a child of a broken home, she finished high school at 15, graduated from the Traphagen School of Design and became chief designer and manager of a major fashion house in NYC. She married Ned in 1949, and raised her family on Long Island, creating an atmosphere rich in culture, music, art and travel. Whether helping with school papers, driving lessons or Little League practice, Mom was there for us. That, and her dry sense of humor, kept the travail of childhood in perspective. She was knowledgeable on almost any subject, well read, inquisitive, cool in a crisis, always logical; she was our Mr. Spock before we knew of Star Trek. Her Sunday Times crossword was finished in under 90 minutes- in ink, no less. Mom nurtured our independence and took pride in our accomplishments, yet was modest about her own. She taught herself to play the piano and violin, to paint and sculpt, to photograph, to knit and do needlepoint. She designed furniture, helped decorate our homes, mapped out gardens. Afraid of flying, she still managed to accompany our father to six continents. She mastered computers long before we did, and spent afternoons doing research on anything and everything, just because she could. She loved cooking and faxed us recipes that she had discovered, after trying them out first on a grateful husband. Cared for at the end by Veviene, Paula, Robinann and Grace, Mom was always the heart of her home. She was one of a kind, and we knew it, and we'll miss her always. And her pot roast.

Forty or so miles north of Venice, on the slopes of Cartizze -- prime prosecco country -- is a charming stone house called Osteria Senz' Oste. Depending on whom you ask, the name translates to ''Tavern Without Host'' or ''Bar Without Barkeep,'' and the place is exactly that. There for the taking are fresh bread, cheese, artisanal salami, chestnuts, cookies and many varieties of sparkling wine, all on the honor system -- or, as the proprietor, Cesare De Stefani, phrases it, ''trust in the people.'' De Stefani, who produces the salami and prosecco nearby, asks that visitors simply leave money for what they eat and drink in a locked box on site. ''I thought how nice it could be for a tourist or friend to arrive here and discover my vineyard and the old house,'' he says, ''finding fresh prosecco wine to be tasted in the absence of the landlord

DEMMON--Roy Earl, Jr. 1927-2012. On March 8, 2012, Roy E. Demmon Jr. passed away peacefully in his beloved Harbour Island, Bahamas surrounded by his wife and children. He was preceded in death by his father, Roy Earl Demmon and mother, Betty Lucille Demmon. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Nina; his four children, Linda, Terry, Charlie, Nancy and their spouses, Tom Walsh, Myn Demmon, Barbara Demmon, John Clifford; and his grandchildren, Scott Walsh, Jamie Walsh, Bryan Walsh, Kathy Demmon, Case Demmon, Liz Demmon, Bailey Fowlkes, Lucy Fowlkes, George Fowlkes, Emily Demmon, Sarah Demmon and Troy Demmon. Roy was born in Houston, TX on February 3, 1927 and grew up in Bronxville, NY. He attended Riverdale Country Day and graduated from The Taft School of Watertown, CT, in 1945, Yale University with a B.A. in 1948 and Harvard University Graduate School of Business with an M.B.A. in 1957. He served his country from 1950 - 1953 during the Korean War. In 1955 Roy married Nina Hardenbergh in Bronxville, NY. Upon graduating from Harvard, Roy moved to California where he began his 50-year career in the Real Estate business. He started his career with Derk Hunter forming Demmon-Hunter in 1960. In 1981, as a long time supporter of the Republican Party, he took time off from business to work in Washington, D.C. for the Reagan Administration as Executive Assistant in the U.S. Department of H.U.D. and Director of Operations and Marketing for the Federal Home Loan Board. After Washington, he returned to California to resume his career in Real Estate partnering with his son-in-law, Tom Walsh, and his sons, Terry and Charlie Demmon. Roy led the partnership through years of expansion and played an active role in the partnership until his untimely death. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Boys and Girls Club of the Peninsula (www.bgcp.org)

Scott Holman didn't think too much before he bought a lighthouse. In the fall of 1999, a local radio station announced that the Granite Island lighthouse, built in 1868, and the 2.5-acre island on which it sits were being auctioned off by the federal government. Without mentioning anything to his wife, Martine, he put in a bid for $86,003. She found out about it when a local newspaper called to ask how it felt to own a lighthouse. Holman, a 70-year-old Michigan entrepreneur, hadn't inspected the lighthouse before purchasing it. He saw the island in 1963, when he was a student at Northern Michigan University in Marquette, and even then the place was abandoned. The island is five miles off the coast of Michigan's Upper Peninsula in Lake Superior and 10 miles from the nearest marina. He and Martine arrived on a beautiful April day in 2000 to look at the house. ''It was a disaster,'' Martine says. They found snow in the basement: there were holes in the roof and in the floors above. ''Normal contractors didn't want anything to do with it,'' Scott Holman says. For two summers he would bring a local carpenter and his crew to the island on Monday mornings and pick them up again Thursday evenings. The workers lived in a tent, and when weather was bad, they had to stay until the storm and waves subsided. Holman logged more than 4,000 miles on his boat in those two years. ''You really get a sense of what it must have been like to be a lighthouse keeper in the 1800s with no communication, no mail, no fresh food,'' he says. Wildflowers grow across the island and thousands of seagulls nest there in the summer. The island's rocks are covered in lichen that glows yellow and orange in the evening light. ''At night you can just sit out on the deck and watch the northern lights,'' he says. ''It's a thrill every time I go out there.''

Nyjah Huston, 17, makes flying down a stairway railing on a skateboard look easy, as if anyone could flip the board under his feet in midair, then land on it, bones intact. ''But you have no idea how much time and pain went into that,'' says Huston, who lives in Laguna Beach, Calif., where his dad taught him to skate at age 5. He's been skating professionally since he was 11 and last year won gold at the X Games in L.A. Home-schooled his whole life, Huston spends a few hours a day at the skate park and travels three months a year to compete in places like Australia, Spain and Costa Rica. Between competitions, he tools around Laguna listening to Wiz Khalifa in his Mercedes CLS 63 AMG (his deals with brands like Element and D.C. Shoes are lucrative) and fuels up on his mom's vegan tacos. Only last year did he finally lop off the dreadlocks he'd had since childhood. ''The back of my head feels lighter now when I skate,'' he says.

Finnegan -- not Ingrid Saunders Jones, Sean Combs and Joseph R. Perella, who were last year's honorees.

GENERAL MOTORS has retrained its focus on technology destined for outer space. Those awaiting the world's first galaxy-hopping private aircraft, however, may be disappointed. The company's current space mission is focused on the design of a robotic glove that would assist astronauts and down-to-earth workers on G.M. assembly lines. Working with NASA to develop the device, G.M. said in a news release Tuesday that the glove would help autoworkers and astronauts perform their jobs with lowered risk of repetitive-task stress injuries.

I write this after having eaten six and a half eggs in the last 24 hours. Breakfast yesterday: Salad with two fried eggs. Lunch: Many things, including an egg-enriched corn bread (that's the half-egg). Dinner: Pasta carbonara. And breakfast today, my favorite of all: Grits with two eggs cooked therein. I did happen to be visiting friends who raise hens, but that only made things easier. You know that eggs are simple, almost infinitely useful; these are clichés I can barely bring myself to repeat. That people have trouble embracing them -- this is perpetually baffling. Part of this perception problem comes from the cholesterol scare of a generation ago, from which we've barely recovered. (Six eggs every 24 hours may be a bit much, but they're hardly among the worst foods in our diet.) Part comes from a general fear of food: for many of us, the natural state of the egg is a McMuffin; a raw egg demands more of a commitment. The egg-combination generator is a way of dealing with some of these issues. (I also devote a bit of space to this very subject in my new book, ''How to Cook Everything: The Basics.'')

Saturday night. We're cruising up North Chester on our way to a Basque feast at Noriega's, when something catches our eye across the median. Bryce hangs a U-ie so we can get to the source: a makeshift church in an empty warehouse. ''Sinners Welcome'' reads the gothic script banner hung on a rolled up metal grate, and a young man with a shaved head and vacant eyes asks if we know the Lord. Bryce and I nod reflexively. Inside, past rows of folding chairs, another man is at the lectern, trying to strangle salvation out of an electric guitar. It's not pretty, though maybe it isn't supposed to be. A few yards away, on the sidewalk, three teenage girls furiously suck on cigarettes, like there are nutrients or redemption in them. A heavyset woman on a scooter motors toward us. Nashville of the West, they used to call Bakersfield. Surely this is not what they meant.

MELNIKER--Charles, a business affairs executive at Creative Artists Agency, died March 13 after a battle with lung cancer. He died at home surrounded by family. Melniker was 60. Melniker started his legal career at the United Artists Corporation as associate counsel; he then transitioned to RCTV/The Entertainment Channel. In 1983, Melniker moved with his family to Los Angeles to work at ICM and later Columbia Pictures. In 1990, Melniker opened his own management firm, Melniker Management, representing writers, directors, actors and producers. He joined CAA in 2001. According to the CAA partners, he was a beloved figure in the halls of the agency. "We have lost a dear friend who was beloved by all who had the great fortune to know him," the partners said in a statement. "Charles was not merely a remarkably talented and widely admired colleague, but an inspiration as well. His relentless optimism, passion for his work, and devotion to his family and friends were regular reminders to us all of what it means to embrace and enjoy life. Our hearts go out to Charles' loving family at this incredibly difficult time. he will be deeply missed." Melniker is survived by his wife, Nadine; his daughter Avital and her husband, David Berman; his daughter Sophie and her husband, Matthew Shuman; his daughter Lara; his granddaughter Zoe Berman; his brother Harvey; and his parents Benjamin and Shirley. He is further survived by adoring nieces, nephews, other relatives and many friends.

It's as true as ever: American fashion is dominated by comfort. The first definitive fashion trend of spring is the flat ballet slipper. It was everywhere on last week's first springlike day, when the trees in parks were bursting open. Even the horses were grazing on the first fresh blades of grass. But don't be deceived by the flat shoes: many women carry their high heels in their bags for the office or social engagements.
The arc of a neighborhood from artist haven to international destination can be steep. A newer anointed hotspot might follow the same path.

Antonio Lacertosa had wanted to see what was going on when an argument broke out outside a restaurant on Staten Island where he and his fiancée were celebrating their recent engagement with friends and relatives early Saturday, one of his sisters said. But just after the 27-year-old bridegroom-to-be stepped outside, a man with a knife suddenly emerged from the restaurant and plunged the weapon into Mr. Lacertosa's torso, fatally wounding him.

The first thing you are meant to see when you arrive in Tongeren, which bills itself as the oldest town in Belgium, is a statue of Ambiorix, the leader of the Eburones, the hometown tribe that defeated the Romans circa 55 B.C. But for some reason I miss this landmark in favor of a humongous branch of H&M dominating the village square. But no matter! I am not in town to discover the ancient roots of this little city (though there is an adorable medieval area called the Béguinage). The reason for my visit to this burg - an hour or so from both the Dries Van Noten shop in Antwerp and Neuhaus in Brussels - is that every Sunday the town turns into a giant flea market, an extravaganza reportedly stuffed with incredible bargains. It's a dealers' destination that many of the most assiduous market fanatics know nothing about (including me, until very recently). Booths line two squares and crowd the old streets, others colonize a warehouse and a parking garage, and a fair number are ensconced directly opposite that town's Roman wall.

The government guarantees a free education, but public school parents in New York City know that education is rarely free. For an article on the real cost of public education, SchoolBook is asking parents how much they spend on their children's schooling. After five years of cuts to school budgets, many PTAs have multiplied the number of fund-raisers, and many teachers have longer mandatory supply lists. Add expenses for ambitious enrichment programs, field trips, events, sports and extras like school pictures and yearbooks, and the dollars mount. With your help, we can document the specifics and get a citywide picture of how much public education really costs in different neighborhoods. To participate:

In efforts to rejuvenate Atlantic City, casinos and resorts have leaned on celebrity chef-run restaurants, sprawling spas and mega-nightclubs. The latest opening adds a new dimension: a smoke-free environment. Casinos are exempt from New Jersey's nonsmoking law, but when the 1,800-room Revel (revelresorts.com) opens in stages starting April 2, it will be Atlantic City's only nonsmoking casino resort, intended to appeal to the 81 percent of American adults who do not smoke. The 47-story boardwalk newcomer will house a 150,000-square-foot casino plus three pools, a rooftop garden, a burlesque stage, a 31,000-square-foot spa and restaurants run by the chefs Marc Forgione, Jose Garces and Michel Richard.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''North Carolina Penalized,'' March 13: After a two-year investigation, University of North Carolina football has been barred from playing in any postseason games during the coming season, docked 15 football scholarships over the next three years and placed on three years' probation starting next season.

PALADINO--Daniel R.,of New York City, March 15, after a long struggle with Lewy Body disease. A man of enormous intellect, kindness and humor, Dan was born in the Bronx. After graduating from Stepinac High School, White Plains, he went on to earn a BS in economics from Fordham University, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He spent his junior year at Ecole Polytechnique in Paris. He earned his LLB from New York University School of Law, where he was a Root-Tilden Scholar. Dan taught legal writing at the University of Indiana Law School, Bloomington, before joining the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, New York City. He went on to become a Partner at Davis and Cox, where he handled corporate, commercial and financial transactions for Summa Corporation, the Howard Hughes holding company. Dan subsequently spent 22 years with The Seagram Company Ltd., as Executive Vice President for Legal and Environmental Affairs and General Counsel. A member of The New York State Bar, The Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the American Bar Association, he also served as board member and president of Upward, Inc., an afterschool program in Harlem. A long-time member of Gipsy Trail Club in Putnam County, Dan was always up for a friendly tennis game and loved to trap shoot. He was also a dedicated runner and enjoyed traveling the world for both business and pleasure. He leaves his wife of 40 years, Polly McCaffrey; a sister, Judith Anson, Scarsdale; brothers-in-law, William McCaffrey, Potsdam, New York, John McCaffrey, LaPorte, Texas, and Robert Casper, Oswego, New York; nieces Amy Anson, Hartsdale, New York, Stacia Harrje, Falls Church, Virginia, Julisa McCaffrey, LaPorte; and three Casper nephews, all of Oswego, Robert Jr., Ted and Ben. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Sunday, March 18, 5-8pm. Service Campbell's Chapel, Monday, March 19, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, Daniel R. Paladino Fund for Memory Disorders Research, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Kentucky should at least be susceptible to some anxiety in a close game, something that exposes its youthfulness and hinders its blur of talent. The Wildcats have a senior, Darius Miller, who comes off the bench, but they start three freshmen and two sophomores, and they should show some cracks when pressured. No. 1 Kentucky did not crack Saturday night. It rolled.

RECENTLY inspired by pagan symbols and Robert Mapplethorpe's little-known frame installations, the jewelry designer Eddie Borgo decided to construct his own three-dimensional pentagram frame (not to be confused with a standard picture frame) to hang in his downtown New York studio. Enlisting the help of Ryan O'Connor, a sculptor, Mr. Borgo set up shop at 3rd Ward, the popular Brooklyn workshop. ''I won't lie, I was kind of terrified to start from scratch because it's so different from jewelry,'' Mr. Borgo said. Beginning with corner techniques, Mr. Borgo soon moved on to learn aspects of metal and wood masonry. Deciding on a Swedish pistol-and-mortar joint method for the frame's corners, he and Mr. O'Connor added a base made of double-sided mirrors that reflect a kaleidoscope of one's image. ''The geometry was especially challenging,'' Mr. Borgo said. ''It was like a puzzle.'' Now on display at the designer's studio, the frame is a perfect complement to his spring collection's pavé rings, ribbon-collared necklaces and lacquered cuffs. Eddie Borgo ring, $395. Go to net-a-porter.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

ON Wednesday, the Maryland Senate passed a bill that would prohibit smoking in vehicles when transporting a child under 8 years old, a move to protect children from secondhand smoke. If the bill is approved by the House and eventually enacted into law, Maryland would join a number of other states to ban smoking in vehicles when children are inside.

A THREE-APARTMENT penthouse combination that sold for $17.07 million in the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. ''The buyer needed a large, elegant and well-appointed home, complimented by the Laureate's long list of amenities and services,'' said Shlomi Reuveni, who is leading the sales team at the building for Brown Harris Stevens Select.

A FEW hours before ''ONCE'' had its official Off Broadway opening at New York Theater Workshop in December, the producers of this musical about a complicated romance between two musicians -- a Dublin busker (played by Steve Kazee) and a Czech immigrant (Cristin Milioti) -- announced that the show would move to Broadway in the spring. (It opens Sunday at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater.) It was a bold move, since critics had to yet to weigh in, but it was also well suited to a production based on an independent film with a small budget but a big impact. Onstage the combined effort of the director John Tiffany and the choreographer Steven Hoggett, reason enough to see ''Once,'' has led to empathetic and imaginative staging. As Mr. Hoggett did in his work on the Broadway production of ''American Idiot'' -- in which lurching, stomping movement evoked characters' angst -- he has here created emotive, nontraditional choreography to express feelings of longing in the people of ''Once.'' The book is by Enda Walsh, and the music and lyrics by Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, who starred in the 2007 film version. Their song ''Falling Slowly,'' which won an Oscar, is a highlight of the stage version too. 242 West 45th Street, Manhattan; (212) 239-6200, oncemusical.com; $26.50 to $124.

When it comes to hedonistic pleasures - clothing-optional beaches, mega-yachts - St. Bart's isn't exactly lacking. But until recently, the island had one curious deficiency: a scarcity of high-end spas. (Hôtel Guanahani's Clarins center was the only game in town.) Then last fall the Isle de France spa overhauled its treatments with the help of Natura Bissé, a company known for its anti-aging technology. Le Sereno added a Christian Liaigre-designed spa with an indoor-outdoor waterfront pavilion (above) and a menu heavy on products from the local brand Ligne St. Barth. And the Hotel Christopher just opened a spa with sea-facing treatment rooms and 15 different massages. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

IN addition to many landmarks of world cinema, Rialto Pictures, the distributor founded in 1997 by Bruce Goldstein (later joined by Adrienne Halpern) has released masterpieces previously unseen in American theaters like Jean-Pierre Melville's ''Army of Shadows,'' and Alberto Lattuada's ''Mafioso.'' For the company's 15th anniversary the Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting ''15 FOR 15,'' a weekday series (Monday through March 29) of Rialto films at the Walter Reade Theater. In the opening film, ''Mafioso'' (1962), resurrected five years ago at the New York Film Festival, Alberto Sordi plays Nino, a factory supervisor in Milan who takes his wife and two children to meet his family in Sicily. A local mobster pays him a visit and pressures him to return a favor from long ago. The payback, which involves being stuffed into a crate and flown to New York City in a plane's cargo hold, is an offer he can't refuse. Other lesser-known films shown in the series include ''Went the Day Well?,'' Alberto Cavalcanti's 1942 thriller, adapted from a Graham Greene story (Wednesday), and Jacques Becker's 1954 French crime classic, ''Touchez Pas au Grisbi'' (March 27). 165 West 65th Street; (212) 875-5600, filmlinc.com.

When Mike Krzyzewski takes a seat on the United States men's basketball bench during the London Olympics this summer, he could well be joined by two unemployed assistants but no coaches with N.B.A. jobs on a team full of N.B.A. players. The former Knicks coach Mike D'Antoni and the former Portland Trail Blazers coach Nate McMillan are the two coaches with N.B.A. experience on the national team's staff. The other assistant is Syracuse's Jim Boeheim. Krzyzewski is Duke's coach.

FALICK--Charles H.,at his Manhattan home on March 15, 2012. Beloved husband of 31 years to Evelyn, loving father of Gloria and Jimmy, devoted stepfather of Sloan, Kenneth and Valarie and proud grandfather of seven. From Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn to Patton's 3d Army, where he helped to liberate Ohrdruf concentration camp in Germany in April 1945, he served his country proudly, raised a family in the boom of post-war America and built a profitable furniture business in northern New Jersey. His unflagging labor, strength of will and considerable personal charm made him the epitome of a successful salesman. Together with Evelyn, he headed a second family to which he brought as much love and devotion as his first. Charlie embraced life, wore his optomism with pride and firmly believed that "man will not merely endure: he will prevail."

The first week of N.F.L. free agency is often described as a feeding frenzy, but that metaphor does not really fit. Schools of mackerel do not swim away from tiger sharks with $42.5 million contracts. ''Shopping spree'' is more appropriate. Teams jostled one another for door-buster values the moment the free-agency superstore opened last Tuesday. Some teams loaded their carts indiscriminately and threw budgetary restraint to the wind. A few were too caught up in the splurge to notice that they were overpaying for damaged merchandise or buying duplicates.

Though he was a genius of the intellectual high wire, the 19th-century philosopher Soren Kierkegaard wrote from experience. And that experience included considerable acquaintance with the chronic, disquieting feeling that something not so good was about to happen. ''All existence makes me anxious,'' he wrote in one journal entry, ''from the smallest fly to the mysteries of the Incarnation; the whole thing is inexplicable, I most of all; to me all existence is infected, I most of all. My distress is enormous, boundless; no one knows it except God in heaven, and he will not console me.'' Is there any doubt that were he alive today he would be supplied with a refillable prescription for Xanax?

For Yodit Eklund, the 26-year-old designer behind Bantu swimwear, the beaches along Africa's West Coast are a source of inspiration - so she photographed her recent collection there (including the suits above, on the road to Assinie-Mafia in Ivory Coast). She wonders why ''some of the best beaches in the world'' are surfed only by locals. Here, Eklund's favorite spots. Dakar, Senegal The beaches in and around Senegal's capital are a boater and surfer's paradise. From the city it's only a 10-minute ferry ride to Île de N'Gor, an island with world-class breaks. (It was one of the stops in ''The Endless Summer.'') For lessons, check out the N'Gor Island Surf Camp, a rustic inn popular with surfers.

That Tokyo's subway system is one of the most efficient in the world hasn't slowed a recent two-wheel invasion of the city's streets. An aboveground alternative to the rush-hour crunch, bicycles also proved to be one of the more reliable forms of transportation after the 2011 earthquake; with trains halted and taxis in gridlock, desperate commuters bought out local bike shops. The city's many flat roads are ideal for cruising, even if the numerous unnamed streets pose a challenge. Local riders swear by the navigation-meets-social-networking app Navinko, available on iTunes, but if you've left the iPhone at home, consider joining the Tokyo Great Cycling Tour, a guided one-day ride that includes rentals. Tokyo has yet to adopt a citywide bike-share program, but visitors who don't mind applying for a membership card can rent a bike through Cogicogi, an upstart service with 20 ports dotting the city; quick jaunts (less than 30 minutes) around Omotesando and Shibuya are free.

In the film version of ''All the President's Men,'' when Robert Redford, playing the journalist Bob Woodward, is struggling to unravel the Watergate conspiracy, an anonymous source advises him to ''follow the money.'' It's a good rule of thumb for understanding the behavior of politicians. But following the money leads you astray if you're trying to understand voters. Self-interest, political scientists have found, is a surprisingly weak predictor of people's views on specific issues. Parents of children in public school are not more supportive of government aid to schools than other citizens. People without health insurance are not more likely to favor government-provided health insurance than are people who are fully insured.

REDDY--Paul, died on March 9, 2012 at the age of 62 following complications from surgery. He retired as a Senior Vice President at AON Corporation, which he helped rebuild after their New York City offices were destroyed on September 11, 2001. He lost many friends that day. He was a man of integrity and great humor, an avid reader and a wonderful storyteller. He traveled over six continents with Clifton Campbell, his beloved partner of thirteen years who survives him. He is also survived by his sons, Rob of Brooklyn, Christopher of Providence, RI, two grandchildren, Eamonn and Zoey, his brother John of Rochester, NH, two sisters, Mary Kay of Quincy, MA and Jeanne Flight of Marion, MA. A memorial mass will be celebrated at the Church of Saint Francis Xavier, West 16th Street, New York on April 13 at 6:30pm.
