If there's a barometer of the rise of urban cycling, it's the proliferation of bike-share programs. Just ask Alison Cohen, president of Alta Bicycle Share, which is opening New York's 10,000-bike system this summer. ''Right now most New Yorkers think, 'Should I take the subway? Should I take a cab? Should I walk?' '' Cohen says. ''We want to make cycling the fourth option.'' It's already an option in Milan, home to the designer Marta Ferri, pictured here on one of the elegant bikes from that city's program and in clothes from her namesake label. For two and a half euros, visitors can buy a daily subscription to Milan's BikeMi program on its Web site, where a station map locates available bicycles and parking spots, updated in real time. Milan is flush with bike shops as well. Ferri recommends Rossignoli, for a selection of traditional Italian bikes, and Turbolento, for an expert tuneup. She also suggests cruising the bike lane that surrounds the 95-acre Parco Sempione. ''Don't forget to explore narrow streets and alleys for glimpses of private gardens,'' Ferris adds. ''Milan is a secret city. Most of her beauty is hidden.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Julie Ho and Nicholas Andersen of ConfettiSystem transform simple materials like tissue paper and foil into something unexpected. For this issue's T, ''Golden Ticket'' (Page 85), the duo created a ''lush, textural landscape from which the T would subtly emerge,'' Ho says. ConfettiSystem began as a rock band but found designing backdrops for their shows even more rewarding. They've since collaborated with fashion lines like Creatures of the Wind and nightspots like Candeleria, in Paris. Kava Gorna

1:09 a.m. | Updated Scores of Occupy Wall Street protesters were arrested on Saturday night as police officers swept Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan and closed it. Dozens of demonstrators sat down and locked arms as officers moved in about 11:30 p.m. The protesters chanted ''we are not afraid'' as the police began pulling people from the crowd, one by one, and leading them out of the park in handcuffs.

All roads lead to Rome, but chief among them was the Via Appia, a storied path from the capital to the heel of Italy traveled by everyone from Cicero to Monty Python. Robert A. Kaster traces their footsteps in ''The Appian Way'' (University of Chicago Press, $23). In ''Desert Terroir'' (University of Texas Press, $25), Gary Paul Nabhan forages in the borderlands, where he connects dishes like capirotada, a Mexican bread pudding, to the Levantine cuisine of his Arab ancestors. ''High Street'' (V&A Publishing, $35) is a facsimile of a rare book, published in Britain in 1938, that included gorgeous woodcut illustrations of many shops of the day, from an oyster bar in the Strand to an undertaker who preferred to be called a ''funeral director'' (he said there are too many jokes about undertakers). ''Traveler of the Century'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30), the prize-winning Spanish novel by Andrés Neuman, is about an itinerant romantic who holes up between Saxony and Prussia, joins a local literary salon and falls for a minor noblewoman: delicious philosophical debates ensue.

The landscape of Washington appears fixed, iconic. The Capitol building, the monuments -- Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln -- are all instantly recognizable and they are illuminated each evening. But this spring the skyline is changing. The Hirshhorn Museum has commissioned a groundbreaking work of what's being billed as ''liquid architecture'' from the artist Doug Aitken, a site-specific installation that will envelope the Hirshhorn's spherical building with 11 high-definition screens and alter the cityscape of the National Mall from March 22 to May 16. In Mr. Aitken's installation -- called ''SONG 1'' -- 360 degrees of projections will encourage visitors to walk the perimeter of the museum; each viewing point offers a different vision, and perspective. From sunset to midnight, the screens will light up the night. SONG 1 is based around musical and cinematic interpretations of the song ''I Only Have Eyes for You.'' Some of the covers come from musicians -- Beck, James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem, Mountains, High Places, No Age, Lucky Dragons -- but some are spoken word, some simply recitations by actors.

Noble Fleming, who for nearly 50 years sipped and sniffed from teaspoons and fine china cups to ensure the quality of tea for millions of Americans, died on Feb. 24 at a nursing home in Saint-Vaast-la-Hougue, France. He was 92. His daughter, Anne Fleming-Smith, confirmed his death.

If the British economy is flagging, it's no worse than it was in 1948, when London's last Summer Olympics earned the nickname the ''Austerity Games'' - an irony that hasn't gone unnoticed. Luckily the city's museums are stepping in to burnish its brand: two exhibitions focused on postwar British design are making the case that the country's economic tribulations have always coincided with periods of creative ascendancy. ''British Design 1948 to 2012,'' opening March 31 at the Victoria and Albert Museum, charts artistic upticks after the war, during the oil crisis in the '70s and after the recession in the '80s, when the ''creative salvage'' movement spurred the careers of designers like Tom Dixon. ''Designing Women,'' at the Fashion and Textile Museum, which opened March 16, focuses on the midcentury modern textile designs of Lucienne Day, Jacqueline Groag and Marian Mahler, and plays up a heroic moment of British ingenuity: three women inspired by the Bauhaus and the Secessionists rejected the chintzes and florals of the '30s and '40s and helped democratize modernism. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

GROGAN--John "Jack," (June 3rd, 1932 - March 16, 2012). Loving brother to Maureen Kenny (nee Grogan) and Charles Grogan (dec.). Beloved husband of Margaret Finn, loving father of John, Neil, Kieran, Thomas, Timothy, Margaret Ann, and Gregory, devoted "Poppy" of Sean, Brendan, Ryan, Seamus, John, Kieran Jr., Tessa, Ciara, Michael, Kaitlyn, Jacqueline, Daniel, Christopher, Owen, Abaigeal, and Jack. Graduate of the LaSalle Academy NYC and Manhattan College. Army veteran. Former treasurer of Cushman & Wakefield, and founder of John J. Grogan & Associates Real Estate Management Company. Well-respected member of Holy Family Church in New Rochelle, NY, and Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church in Point Lookout, NY. The wake will be held at Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Monday from 6-9pm and Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. The Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday at 10am at Holy Family Church in New Rochelle, NY.

MENELL--Norman Jules, 80, passed away of pneumonia on Friday, March 16th in Sarasota, FL. He was born in Bayonne, NJ and attended Syracuse University where he received both his undergraduate and law degrees. He practiced law in New York City as a corporate and securities partner at Golenbock and Barrell for twenty-five years. In 1981, at the urging of his good friend and client, Lou Nicastro, Norman became an executive officer of WMS Industries (NYSE), serving as its chief operating officer for fourteen years, including three years as President. He was a member of WMS Board of Directors for sixteen years, including six years as Vice-Chairman. While at WMS, Norman was instrumental in guiding the company's investments in the El San Juan, Conquistador and Condado Plaza hotels in Puerto Rico. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of Midway Games, Inc. After moving to Sarasota in 1990, Norman served on the boards of the Sarasota Ballet of Florida, the Asolo Repertory Theater and the YMCA Foundation of Sarasota. He was chairman of the YMCA Foundation for four years. He is survived by his devoted wife, Betty Burge, and his five children: Scott Menell, Roger Menell and Cathy Menell Slater as well as Robert Burge and Lisa Burge Swotes. He also is survived by nine loving grandchildren as well as his brother Howard Menell and sister-in-law Phyllis. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his honor to the YMCA Foundation of Sarasota, One South School Ave., Sarasota, Fl., 342387, would be appreciated.

Amelia Forman was only 3 when her mother, the photographer Robin Schwartz, took her along to a photo shoot with a chimp. Schwartz was astonished by what happened. ''I went to photograph the chimp, and they kissed,'' Schwartz said. ''It was sort of odd.'' That set off nearly a decade of mother-daughter trips to photograph Amelia with animals. Now 12, Amelia projects a near-mystical calm into the camera: gazing into the eyes of kangaroos, nuzzling a capuchin monkey, staying still while a cotton-top tamarin paws through her hair. The animals are owned privately across the country, and Schwartz sounds out the owners in advance to ensure the situation is safe. She did have one scare, but says Amelia wasn't involved. Amelia plans to be a primatologist; Jane Goodall is a hero. She insists she has never been frightened around an animal. ''It's like being with a very little kid, except better,'' Amelia said. ''You can really understand them. You can almost talk to them.'' approximate number of rolls of film used on the amelia project: 3,000 number of years photographing animals: 31 number of years photographing animals with her daughter: 9 number of pets at home: 5

8 P.M. (TCM) WHAT'S ON TONIGHT: EXOTIC PETS This Virginia McKenna-Bill Travers double bill begins with ''Born Free'' (1966), James Hill's drama, based on the 1960 autobiographic best seller by Joy Adamson, in which the married actors, above, play a game warden in Kenya and his wife who face a heartrending decision after Elsa, the orphaned lion club they have raised, becomes too big to keep. The composer John Barry won the Oscar for best original score and, with Don Black, for best original song for ''Born Free.'' Vincent Canby, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''a poignant but happy reminder of the beauty and mystery of the life cycle.'' In ''Ring of Bright Water'' (1969), at 10, Mr. Travers portrays a London civil service clerk whose life is changed when he decides to move Mij, his rambunctious pet-shop otter, to a village along the west Scottish coast. Ms. McKenna plays the doctor who, with her spaniel, captures the pair's attention. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Rick Santorum discusses his campaign for the Republican nomination. Mr. Santorum also appears on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Timothy Doner, a teenager in Manhattan who taught himself more than a dozen languages and found a subculture of polyglots on YouTube, misstated the role of Richard Simcott in an online language forum to which he introduced some videos of Timothy speaking. Mr. Simcott participates in the online forum How to Learn Any Language; he does not run it.

SCHUHALTER--Murray. A great man, who put family above all else and who lived a life of honor, decency and integrity. Murray passed away peacefully at home on March 15, 2012, at the age of 86, surrounded by his loving family. Murray lived and loved life to the fullest. He loved tennis and golf, singing and dancing, family and friends. He leaves behind the love of his life, his beautiful wife of 62 plus years, Beverly, his three wonderful daughters, Ellen Dyner, Debbie Somoza and Robbie Karp, three loving sons-in-law, Charlie, Brad and Joe, five adoring grandchildren, Lauren, Jamie, Meredith, Arielle and David, and a legion of friends and admirers. A decorated veteran of World War II, Murray reminded us every day why his was the greatest generation. We all were blessed to know Murray; he enriched our lives and made each of us a better person. His example will guide us always. Murray Schuhalter will be forever missed. Donations may be made to the National WWII Memorial (Washington, D.C.) or the cancer research/treatment organization of your choosing.

WOLF--Barry. He died at home in the loving arms of his wife on March 6, age 78. A vivid man rich in courage and resource, he was a bold entrepreneur, an avid art collector, a loyal friend, an endless seeker of experiences, a mentor to many, a providing father and husband. Survived by his wife, Jivan, and his sons, David, Steven, and Christopher, his stepdaughter, Sunderland, and seven grandchildren. His ashes will be spread in Saline Bay on the island of St. Bartholomew.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Everybody Wants a Piece of Nerlens Noel,'' March 11: There must be a more humane way of rescuing disadvantaged youths from lives of poverty and desperation than to conscript a handful of them into a warrior caste of elite high school athletes, groomed and ultimately commoditized for gladiatorial contests in the big-time collegiate and professional sports entertainment industry.

REEVE--Gregory. American composer Gregory Reeve died on March 11th, 2012 in Queens, New York. Mr. Reeve was born in NYC on July 18th, 1939 and was educated at Regis High School and Hunter College where he studied with Louise Talma. In 1971 he founded The Center for New Music, a vital informational clearing house for the modern music world. He also hosted an interview program on WBAI radio which featured discussions with among others such contemporary music luminaries as Elliot Carter and Pierre Boulez. Mr. Reeve was a performing percussionist with the American re-incarnation of Musica Elettronica Viva. His eclectic talents extended to the visual arts with his paintings being executed in a bold expressionist style. He was also a gifted student of the heavens who crafted his own telescopes. Mr. Reeve is survived by his daughter Rebecca Smalley, son-in-law Robert Smalley and grandchildren Sean Eisenberg and Alec Smalley. His best friend Anne Reeve, his brothers: Christopher, Joseph and Basil and sister Angela Piper. Memorials may be sent to The Children's Orchestra Society, The Gregory Reeve Scholarship Fund, 1355 Northern Boulevard Manhasset New York 11030.

SUSAN PETERSVice president, executive development, and chief learning officer at General Electric. THOMAS EDISON, the founder of General Electric, said, ''I find out what the world needs, then I proceed to invent it.'' G.E. now files an average of more than five patents per day -- 20,000 patents over the last decade.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''After Struggles, A Split: D'Antoni Resigns Amid Frustration,'' March 15: Mike D'Antoni's resignation is only the most recent chapter in a Knicks book riddled with ineptitude. The author of this book? James L. Dolan.

Pete Pin spent five months last year photographing a small Cambodian community that has settled in the Bronx. The quiet photographs - of a woman cutting green beans on the floor, of a man walking in winter's first snow - are part of a long-term project documenting Cambodian refugees in the United States. For Mr. Pin, 29, the work is intensely personal. He was born in a refugee camp in Cambodia. His parents spent years in labor camps. He doesn't know the names of his grandparents, who died, along with 1.7 million others, under the Khmer Rouge.
GROOTHUIS--Michelle Sherman. She was taken from us way before her time after an incredibly brave fight. Loved by hundreds of friends and family members.

Robert Griffin III's career statistics at Baylor were impressive: 10,366 passing yards, 78 touchdowns and only 17 interceptions. He also rushed for 2,254 yards and 33 touchdowns. But there is one number in particular that has raised his profile. Griffin, the 2011 Heisman Trophy winner, ran the 40-yard dash in 4.41 seconds last month at the scouting combine. N.F.L. teams are not the only ones that have to re-evaluate his talents, either. The producers of EA Sports video games may have to speed up the virtual Griffin to keep up with the living version.

Savvy hotels across the country are riding the urban-cycling trend, offering two wheels to guests at no additional charge. THE BOWERY HOTEL, NEW YORK A fleet of red cruisers, complete with front baskets, stands ready at this boutique property in the East Village (above). Bring your own helmet. Doubles from $325.

GOODWIN--Dr. Peter. Compassion & Choices honors the life and legacy of our dear friend Dr. Peter Goodwin of Portland, OR. He died peacefully at home on March 11, 2012, surrounded by his four children and their spouses. Peter began medical practice as a surgeon. He ended it as a role model and educator in family practice, promoting healing and growth from the beginning of life to its end. Peter called his accomplishments as chair of the committee to pass the Oregon Death with Dignity Act in the mid 1990s "the most gratifying of my entire life." His principled and passionate leadership laid the groundwork for expansion of end-of-life choice across the nation. We shall miss our dear friend. We draw comfort knowing his life was filled with love and that he died on his own terms with courage, grace and dignity. None of us could ask for more. With sincere gratitude we honor a true pioneer for end-of-life liberty, Dr. Peter Goodwin. Learn more about Peter and Compassion & Choices at: CompassionAndChoices.org/ Goodwin

STERNBERG--Ilsa. Remarkable, sister, aunt, cousin, and friend to many, especially Gwen McCalla. An inspiration to all who knew her. Ilsa lived an extraordinary life being afflicted early by Kugelberg-Welander disease which took away the use of her limbs and ultimately her life; but never her spirit, drive or humor. Armed with a souped up multipurpose wheel chair and specialty vehicles she traveled the country side and accomplished what many with able bodies never dare to dream of. Now she's Free and will soar! Service, Sunday 11am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

''In his mind, this was the only way that he could change the culture of the firm.'' Lex Bayer, talking about his friend Greg Smith, who publicly resigned as an executive director from Goldman Sachs, saying the firm puts its own financial interests above those of its clients. ''He is completely toast in terms of Wall Street, no question about that.'' The author William Cohan, speaking on Bloomberg Television about Mr. Smith.

An article last Sunday about the figure skaters Meryl Davis and Charlie White referred incorrectly to the skater Michelle Kwan. She won silver and bronze medals in the Olympic Games; she was not an ''Olympic champion.'' The article also referred incorrectly to the skater Kristi Yamaguchi. She was not part of the United States Olympic team in the late 1990s, by which time she had retired from the Winter Games.

In ''Adventures of a Teenage Polyglot,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, John Leland profiled Timothy Doner, 16, who taught himself more than a dozen languages and found a community of other hyperpolyglots online. A selection of reader comments from NYTimes.com is below. Whew -- just to think I struggle with speaking and writing English correctly. May the powers that be continue to make your life interesting.

FIONA APPLE has made herself scarce. Beyond appearances in Los Angeles, where she lives, she all but vanishes between album releases, and there have been only three of those: in 1996, 1999 and 2005. But Ms. Apple is now gearing up for her fourth album, due in late June and titled ''The Idler Wheel Is Wiser Than the Driver of the Screw, and Whipping Cords Will Serve You More Than Ropes Will Ever Do.'' She has re-emerged, and this week she returns to perform in New York City. Her old songs would be reason enough to see her. Ms. Apple's low, dusky, bluesy contralto and her measured piano backup are ideal for her songs about obsession, self-destruction and self-invention. On her three albums she traversed sorrow, desperation, questioning and, on ''Extraordinary Machine'' in 2005, a new, more grown-up wryness. Seven years later, with songs that have been in the works for some time, she's likely to have some new insights. And she could disappear again at any moment. Friday at 9 p.m., Music Hall of Williamsburg, 66 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn; (718) 486-5400; sold out. March 26 at 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side; (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; sold out.
TSOU--Gordon. Former Managing Director Of Chase Manhattan Bank. Died on March 12, 2012. He is survived by his wife Frances, brother Ed Tsou, sister Carolyn Flugger.
BLADE--Erna, on March 6, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Werner. Survived by her daughter Linda Diesso and son-in-law Arthur Kutcher.
BATTERY PARK CITY CONDO $1,550,000

FOR Anna Plunkett and Luke Sales, the Australian duo behind the label Romance Was Born, the decision to work off the fashion grid has been planned and purposeful. After graduating from East Sydney Technical College, they were offered internships at John Galliano. They turned them down. ''We had never been to Europe, had no money and couldn't speak a word of French, so we decided to stay home and start our own thing,'' Ms. Plunkett said. Their first show, Regional Australia, celebrated small-town Aussie culture -- the designers held it at their local pub in Sydney and served barbecued sausages. Their spring 2012 collection, Happy Campers, was inspired by Girl Guides, 1970s camping equipment, Moroccan wedding rugs and German Scheurich ceramics, and will be available in the United States at Tenoversix in Los Angeles. But that doesn't mean that the designers are headed for the mainstream anytime soon. Remoteness, it seems, is also a state of mind. Says Ms. Plunkett, ''We are pretty much in our own bubble.'' NANCY MacDONELL

It is counterintuitive that Paris, the host city of the Tour de France finish line, was ever not a bicycling capital, but until it got a bike-share program - and an expanded network of bike lanes - cycling was not a mainstream mode of transportation there. Now it's de rigueur, thanks to the Vélib' system's more than 20,000 bikes at 1,800 stations. The Vélib' app, available on iTunes, tells you where to find the nearest station and the number of bikes there. And at a little more than $2 a day, the price is hard to beat. (Bring your American Express card, though; Vélib' machines are not compatible with Visas and MasterCards that do not have a European chip.) For a slightly less bulky ride, the day trips at Fat Tire Bike Tours (011-33-1-56-58-10-54) come with a city cruiser. A charming, 1980s-inspired store in the 18th Arrondissement, Vélo Vintage (011-33-6-13-13-42-27) refurbishes yesteryear's beauties plucked from the French countryside. And there is no shortage of high-end shops: the museumlike biCyCle Store Paris (011-33-9-51-61-68-29) stocks everything from California cruisers to lowriders; Cyclope (011-33-1-43-55-47-34) is for the fixie-obsessed; and Bicloune (011-33-1-42-77-58-06) is packed with bikes of all shapes.

IN college, I used to underline sentences that struck me, that made me look up from the page. They were not necessarily the same sentences the professors pointed out, which would turn up for further explication on an exam. I noted them for their clarity, their rhythm, their beauty and their enchantment. For surely it is a magical thing for a handful of words, artfully arranged, to stop time. To conjure a place, a person, a situation, in all its specificity and dimensions. To affect us and alter us, as profoundly as real people and things do. I remember reading a sentence by Joyce, in the short story ''Araby.'' It appears toward the beginning. ''The cold air stung us and we played till our bodies glowed.'' I have never forgotten it. This seems to me as perfect as a sentence can be. It is measured, unguarded, direct and transcendent, all at once. It is full of movement, of imagery. It distills a precise mood. It radiates with meaning and yet its sensibility is discreet.

GARRETT--Carolyn Holmes, born August 27, 1933 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, daughter of Henry and Helen Holmes passed away in New York City surrounded by her family on August 14, 2011. She is survived by her husband Dr. Michael Garrett, her children Nina Voci, Leah Paterson, Kate Ramirez and Ivan Ramirez, her sons-in-law David Voci and Robert Paterson, her daughter-in-law Alisa Sims, her grandchildren Sebastian and Zachary Ramirez-Brunner, Sofia and Max Voci and Francis Lie, her sister Elizabeth Webb, her nieces Lisa Howe, Nina Cullen, Pam Serra, Pat Spicer, Ada Puches, her nephews Charlie Webb, Hank Holmes, Edmund and Russell Puches and her dog Cyd. Carolyn attended the Baldwin School in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania and Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, NY. She received a Masters Degree in Art Therapy from New York University and an MSW from The Hunter College School of Social Work. Credentialed as an ACSW, she maintained a clinical practice of art therapy and psychotherapy in NYC for thirty years. Carolyn will be remembered by those who miss her desperately everyday for her keen sense of humor and her artistic eye.

The cover article last Sunday, ''Boldface Buildings in the Cold Light of Now,'' reported on whether the ''starchitect'' pedigree held up when apartments were resold in those buildings. Following are edited excerpts of comments from nytimes.com: A lot of these ''starchitect'' condos strike me as ridiculous examples of gilded shoebox construction, but their one saving grace is that they are condos and not co-ops. At least you actually own the apartment and don't have to put up with a snobbish co-op board that can try to have you evicted as an ''undesirable tenant'' when prices are rising and you no longer fit the ''image.'' Such is the price of living on that designer treadmill that is today's Manhattan. Grossness54West Palm Beach, Fla.

New York isn't the only major American city to go the way of the bicycle. Chicago is getting a public bike share this summer and 100 miles of new protected bike lanes by 2015, all part of Mayor Rahm Emanuel's plan to make his city the most cyclist-friendly in the country. For now try Chicago B-Cycle, a bike share with a few stations near the Lakefront Trail, an 18-mile path along Lake Michigan. Cruisers, hybrids and more can be rented at the McDonald's Cycle Center (312-729-1000), a state-of-the-art facility for commuters. Or buy your own: Working Bikes Cooperative (773-847-5440) sells restored discarded bikes on the cheap; J. C. Lind Bike Company (312-643-1670) and Copenhagen Cyclery (773-456-0024) carry the best Danish cargo bikes; Method Bicycle (312-965-8635) makes bespoke steel frames. Nothing heralds the city's status as a cycling stronghold quite like the newly opened Heritage Bicycles General Store (above; 773-245-3005), a bike shop-cafe where you can order a custom bike, get a tuneup, scarf a soup-and-salad lunch and tank up on Stumptown coffee, an export from that other great bike town, Portland, Ore. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KOBY--Richard H. Hartman & Craven LLP mourns the untimely passing of its long-time partner, Richard H. Koby, on March 15, 2012. Richard's bravery during his long illness was an inspiration to all who knew him. He will be greatly missed by colleagues and clients, family and friends. Richard is survived by his loving daughter, Jessica, also of New York. A memorial service will be held Sunday, March 18 at 11am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue NY, NY 10024.

An article last Sunday about states that are rethinking the use of long-term solitary confinement misidentified the office held by Christopher B. Epps, Mississippi's commissioner of corrections, in the American Correctional Association. He is president-elect, not president. (Daron Hall is the current president; Mr. Epps takes over in 2013.)

Ruth Barcan Marcus, a philosopher esteemed for her advances in logic, a traditionally male-dominated subset of a traditionally male-dominated field, died on Feb. 19 at her home in New Haven. She was 90. Her death was announced by Yale University, from which she retired in 1992 as the Reuben Post Halleck professor of philosophy.
'It's an unfortunate situation.' CARMELO ANTHONY,

THERE may be more facial hair in ''DUCK DYNASTY'' than there was in ''Whisker Wars,'' a show that was actually about facial hair. It belongs to the men of the Robertson family of Louisiana, a clan that makes duck calls. The family has built the quack makers into a substantial business via some decidedly unbusinesslike practices. The series, which begins Wednesday night at 10 on A&E, follows the goings-on at Duck Commander, the family business, which sells handmade duck calls and other merchandise, as well as an image. The family has already had some television exposure on the Outdoor Channel with a series called ''Duck Commander,'' and everyone is pretty comfortable on camera, working the bayou-chic thing. In the premiere Willie Robertson, the chief executive, is exasperated because an order needs filling, but others in the clan seem more interested in trolling for catfish and hunting beavers than in replenishing the duck call supply. ''That's how you do it: You sell stuff, you make more stuff,'' he vents to the one unfortunate worker who is still at his post. ''You can't just sell stuff, run out of stuff and say, 'O.K., I guess it's over.' ''

An article on March 4 about Yahoo's unveiling of its first season of scripted comedy shows online misstated the connection the actress and writer Alison Becker has to a satire of ''The Hunger Games.'' She is starring in the spoof, not directing it.

DAN SATTERTHWAITEThe head of human resources at DreamWorks Animation. WE feel it is critical to empower employees to take risks, move boundaries and test the limits of their imagination. Simply put: individuals must be allowed to fail in order to innovate.

Three new voices clamor for a place in the expat canon. ''A Family in Paris'' (Lantern, Penguin Group Australia, $40) When her businessman husband is transferred to Paris, Jane Paech, a former Australian nurse, struggles to become more than just ''the trailing spouse.'' She rents a sprawling - and showerless -Haussmannian apartment in bourgeois Passy, sends her two daughters to dance classes and Le Cordon Bleu cooking lessons, and smiles in the face of frosty locals, including one woman at a dinner party who tells her, ''We have enough friends, thank you.''

In honor of the long-awaited return of ''Mad Men'' on March 25, the Big City Book Club is getting in the spirit of 1960s Manhattan. Our next selection is James Baldwin's 1962 novel, ''Another Country,'' which chronicles the descent of the jazz drummer Rufus Scott. Baldwin recreates the world of Greenwich Village bohemians for an examination of race, emotional denial, professional rivalry, tortured marriages and other subjects that the AMC series has mined so well. Join us for an online conversation April 4 at a new time, from 7 to 10 p.m.

KORAL--Frances Gertrude, born November 10, 1925, died peacefully in upstate New York on February 19, 2012. She was a beloved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, educator, stained glass artist, painter, activist, union member and champion scrabble player, and will be missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by her husband Richard, son Joshua and daughter Harriet; grandchildren Alex Koral, Eli Koral, Jacob Vestergaard, Hannah Vestergaard and Katrine Vestergaard; daughter-in-law Marilyn Koral and son-in-law Niels Vestergaard; and nephew Jonah Goldsmith. A memorial will be held at 1:00pm on Saturday March 24th at 140 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn NY, 2nd floor.

CLUETT--Virginia Ashcraft, died peacefully at her home in Westwood, MA on March 6, 2012. The youngest child of the late Edwin M. Ashcraft II and Anna Strawbridge Ashcraft, she was born in Chicago, IL on June 21, 1915. Following the death of her first husband, Gerald H. Smith, she married George A. Cluett, Jr. in 1957 in Princeton, NJ where they resided for many years. In 1994, she moved to Fox Hill Village in Westwood, MA. She was also a long time summer resident of Blue Hill, ME where her family gathered every summer. A graduate of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, Ginny was active in the Princeton Garden Club and as a volunteer at the Princeton Hospital. She was predeceased by her two children, Ann A. Smith and Ralph O. Smith, her stepson A. Tucker Cluett, her sisters Barbara Ashcraft and Ann A. Mitchell, and her brother Edwin M. Ashcraft III. She is survived by her stepson Mark S. Cluett of Savannah, GA, her granddaughters Amanda C. Stanton of Pennington, NJ, Elizabeth C. Thors of Brookline, MA, and Julia S. Cluett of S. Egremont, MA, six great-grandchildren, and many nephews, nieces, grandnephews, and grandnieces. A family service is planned for a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Historic Deerfield in Deerfield, MA.
DAVID LAWEE Vice president for corporate development at Google.

BLOG Pete Pin spent five months last year photographing a small Cambodian community that has settled in the Bronx. The quiet photographs -- of a woman cutting green beans on the floor, of a man walking in winter's first snow -- are part of a long-term project documenting Cambodian refugees in the United States. www.nytimes.com/lens

YASGUR--Marvin, passed away peacefully at his winter home in Boynton Beach, Florida on Friday, March 16, 2012 at the age of 82. Dee, his beloved wife of 60 years was by his side. He is survived by his loving children and grandchildren. Services will be held at KTI Synagogue located at 575 King Street, Port Chester, NY on Monday morning at 10am.

Mark Bittman's column last Sunday on a vegetarian alternative to chicken misidentified an organization. It is the Vegetarian Resource Group, not the Vegetarian Research Group.

THE dance and drum company NIMBAYA! is daring. When it was founded in 1998 as Amazones Women Master Drummers of Guinea, it dared to allow women to play the djembe, a traditional West African drum that had been an exclusively male instrument. For breaking this taboo some of its members were disowned by their families. More recently the company has stirred up fresh excitement with works, to be performed in its evening programs in New York this week, reflecting the plight of women who have experienced female genital mutilation, a practice rooted in the traditions of several societies worldwide. Also to be presented during the company's visit is a children's matinee intended to introduce youngsters to the beauty of world dance and music. Appropriately enough the company takes its name from the Nimba mask, which symbolizes a woman at the height of her power and beauty, the embodiment of fertility and the joy of living. 8 p.m. Friday and 11 a.m. (Childernâ s show) and 8 p.m. next Saturday, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 545-7536, worldmusicinstitute.org; evenings, $40, $30, $20 for students; matinee, $25, $15 for children.

THE virtuoso mandolinist Chris Thile is one of the most versatile musicians of his generation. Frontman of the irresistible Punch Brothers, a progressive bluegrass band, he also composes and plays Bach. On Sunday at Galapagos Art Space, Mr. Thile performs his arrangements of traditional fiddle tunes with Orpheus, the adventurous conductorless orchestra; the program also includes Copland's ''Appalachian Spring'' Suite and selections from John Adams's ''Book of Alleged Dances.'' Next Saturday at Carnegie Hall, Orpheus and Mr. Thile offer the New York premiere of his Mandolin Concerto, Paul Chihara's arrangement of Bernstein's ''Trouble in Tahiti'' and the premiere of Clint Needham's ''When We Forget.'' 8 p.m. Sunday, 16 Main Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn; (718) 222-8500, galapagosartspace.com; $20 and $35. 7 p.m. next Saturday, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $14.50 to $110. Judging by the passionate, poetic interpretations of Chopin, Liszt and Ravel on his recent Decca release, Benjamin Grosvenor's concert on Sunday at the Frick Collection should be exciting. Mr. Grosvenor, a 19-year-old British pianist, makes his New York recital debut with a program including Bach's Partita No. 4, Chopin's Sonata No. 3, Ravel's ''Gaspard de la Nuit,'' Scriabin's Sonata No. 2 and selections by Rachmaninoff. 5 p.m., 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan; (212) 547-0715, frick.org; sold out, but returned tickets may be available at the box office.

HECHT--Irwin M. 'Win', passed away peacefully in Scottsdale, Arizona on March 13th, 2012 after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's. He was 83 years old. He will be sadly missed by his loving wife, Heidi, his two sons, Daniel and Jonathan, his step-daughter Renata, her husband Dave and their two children, Camden and Sophia. He was pre-deceased by his dear sister, Lottie. Win was born on December 9, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from Georgia Tech as an Engineer and promptly went into the Cosmetic and Perfume industry. He joined Estee Lauder International in 1970 and travelled the world. He made many friends as well as being a mentor and leader to many. He touched so many people in so many places in such a wonderful and profound way. On his retirement in 1999 as Executive Vice-President, he spent his time between his home in Greenwich, CT and The Boulders in Carefree, AZ. A service will be held Monday, March 19th, 12 noon, at Gallagher's Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06830 (203-869-1513) followed by a burial at the historic Putnam Cemetery, 35 Parsonage Rd. Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers and in remembrance of Win's life, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America in his name (1-866-232-8484, web: Alzfdn.org).

To the Editor: Regarding the Frugal Traveler blog post ''Tips From the Times Travel Show'' (March 6), as a native Mainer, I would agree that the coast can be more expensive but it's still worth it. For a good inland spot, check out Baxter State Park in Millinocket, home to the state's highest peak, Mount Katahdin, and cheap camping. It's worth the drive to see the moose and the nature-carved, stone water slides. Jenn Beard

GOING into the nominating process for the annual fashion awards presented by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, there was a lot of debate as to which celebrity or cultural figure would be singled out for their style. After awards have been handed out to Michelle Obama, Iman and Lady Gaga in recent years, there was a bit of a feeling of who's left? Johnny Depp was a surprise choice, if not an inspired one. Among the special awards announced by the council on Wednesday, Mr. Depp was the first male recipient of the Fashion Icon Award, given ''for his personal and eclectic sense of style,'' which presumably is a euphemism for man mascara and shlumpy chic. In that regard, he is certainly one of the most deserving recipients in years. Other special awards, to be presented at Lincoln Center on June 4, will go to Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garçons for international design, Andrew Rosen for the Founders Award and Tommy Hilfiger for lifetime achievement. Scott Schuman and Garance Doré, the street-style photographers, who are a couple off the clock, will be given the Media Award.

ROCKETT--Laurie R.,died on March 12, 2012 in Valhalla, NY. Wife of the late Fredrick C. Rockett, mother of Nat (Courtney Rohan) and CJ, grandmother of Declan, Patrick and Maclain Rockett, sister of Charles and Jons Rogers and step mother of Grant and Abigail. Mrs. Rockett was raised in Danbury, CT, graduated from Barnard College with Honors in 1964, and from Columbia Law School magna cum laude in 1970. She began her career at the Hudson Institute, but worked most of her life as an attorney in New York City specializing in non-profit corporate advisory and author representation. She was also a pioneer in the field of women's health services and related legal rights. She raised her family in Bronxville, NY and was a resident there until 2010. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church, 180 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY at 2pm on Saturday March 24, 2012.

AT a glance, the photographs on view in ''Matt Ducklo & Matthew Monteith: Mind's Eye,'' which opened Friday at the Gallery at Hermès, appear to be relatively straightforward shots of people looking at art. But for both photographers, there is an element of blind faith at work here. For the last six years, Mr. Ducklo has documented visually impaired visitors interacting with sculptures on touch tours at museums like MoMA and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Monteith spent the better part of a year at the American Academy in Rome, where he captured tourists looking at the city's many monumental attractions (below right), seeking the precise moment when the artwork infiltrates the viewers' imagination and the act of looking becomes an act of seeing. ''You don't know how they are experiencing the work, but you know how it looks like they are experiencing it,'' Mr. Ducklo said regarding the slippery nature of perception. At the very least, says Cory Jacobs, who curated the show, ''the photos make you slow down and take notice of how quickly we tend to pass things by.'' Gallery at Hermès, 691 Madison Avenue, through April 28. ALIX BROWNE

BERLINERS love to complain about the transformation of Mitte, the central district in the city's former East. Once a post-Wall petri dish for Berlin's creative innovators, the area has gradually gone commercial, welcoming international chains, four-star hotels and, on sunny days, seemingly half the under-40 population of Western Europe. Yet there's still no place in the city richer with high-end homegrown fashion boutiques, as neighborhood trailblazers hold their ground and each year a different cobblestone back alley comes of age as the new-style strasse of the moment. The after-hours action may be elsewhere, but Mitte is where Berlin's singular gestalt is minted into high fashion. CHARLY WILDER

IN one of the season's more colorful collaborations, the designer Thakoon Panichgul of Thakoon has made a limited-edition series of lacquers for Nars based on the brights from his spring runway. ''The prints in that collection were inspired by the rich color palette of India -- the spices, the holy festivals,'' Mr. Panichgul said. According to the designer, when the Nars team, who did the makeup for the show, saw the color boards, ''it made so much sense that we should do a nail project together.'' The Thakoon for Nars polishes ($18) will be available May 1. Go to narscosmetics.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

THE Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden's striking but bunkerlike circular Washington building, designed by Gordon Bunshaft, has prompted many an artist and designer to dream of intervention. Next year, if things stay on track, the museum will realize a long-planned project to cover its interior courtyard with a temporary inflatable bubble, an architectural soufflé that will meld the outside and inside of the museum and provide space for installations and performances. But in the nearer term the doughnut-shaped structure will become the plaything of the artist Doug Aitken, who is turning it into a movie in the round. Between sunset and midnight from Thursday to May 13 visitors to the National Mall will be able to see ''SONG 1,'' a projected video work that will cover the building, transforming it into ''a turntable of contemporary life,'' as Kerry Brougher, the museum's chief curator, puts it. Mr. Aitken, who created a similar building-size video in 2007 for the Museum of Modern Art in New York, has structured the new work around the sentimental 1934 standard and perennial contender for perfect pop song, ''I Only Have Eyes for You,'' by Al Dubin and Harry Warren. For nearly eight weeks this spring the Hirshhorn will have the eyes of tens of thousands. 700 Independence Avenue SW; (202) 633-1000, hirshhorn.si.edu.

In Far Rockaway, a Queens neighborhood on the slender peninsula east of Coney Island, the beach bungalow is having a surprising revival. What was once thought of as a desolate stretch near the last stop on the A train is now home, at least on weekends, to urban pioneers drawn by quiet beaches, decent surfing and the unlikely chance to own a seaside house in the city. The tiny Rockaway bungalows are refugees from another era. They were constructed in waves of speculation beginning in 1905. The low rents allowed regular New Yorkers -- butchers, bookkeepers, clerks -- to have a modest vacation home near the beach. ''Far Rockaway was the working-class Riviera,'' says Barbara Bleier-Schlachet, who spent many summers of her childhood in a rented bungalow.

In bike-mad cities like Amsterdam and Copenhagen, cargo bicycles -- the station wagons of the bike lane -- are staples. Usually equipped with storage cabs in the front or back of the frame, cargo bikes are used to haul groceries, yard-sale finds, even small children. Now they're showing up stateside in cities like Portland, Ore., where this hybrid of sorts, called the Fremont, is produced. Conceived by the design firm Ziba and Signal Cycles, the bike features a small side trailer that holds an expandable, Filson-like canvas satchel. Go to ziba.com/thefremont.

An article last Sunday about child actors in art-house movies described incorrectly the time period in which the events of ''The Tin Drum,'' Volker Schlöndorff's 1979 adaptation of the Gunter Grass novel, took place. It was prewar Germany, not postwar.

WECHSLER--Lawrence (Larry), on March 15th at the age of 86, beloved husband of Jan (Dean) for 37 years, adoring father of Brad (Patty), loving grandfather of Samantha, Robert and David. Uncle to Betty (Chris) Connolly and Stephen Wechsler. Resident of NYC, Boca Grande, Florida and Millbrook, NY. Larry loved life. Born in Brooklyn, he rose to become a cosmetic industry leader, serving Revlon for 30 years. Following retirement from Revlon, he taught at Parsons School of Design in addition to serving as a consultant to Christian Dior Cosmetics and Fragrances. He served on the board of CTFA and was affiliated with The New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. Larry enjoyed playing the saxophone and was a determined athlete in spite of his affliction from a neurological disease CharcotMarieTooth. He will be greatly missed. A service will be held on Monday, March 19th at 4pm at Frank E. Campbell- 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC.

Known for sharp tailoring and custom leathers (Rooney Mara wore one of their jackets in ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo''), the designers behind Cerre find inspiration wherever they go. ''We're as fascinated by huge structures, like the pyramids, as we are by tiny patterns we see in New York bridges or alleyways,'' says Clayton, who's half Danish. Former models, the pair met in 2000 on a train from Paris to Cologne. ''I chased her all around France and Spain for three months before she would even go out with me,'' Clayton says. Flavie quips: ''I'm French -- I'm difficult.'' Since then, they've traversed Europe, Senegal, Morocco and Egypt. Their new Los Angeles boutique (a celebrity magnet) has served to tame their nomadic tendencies, but they compensate by seeking creative mojo closer to home. ''We drive deep into the desert,'' Clayton says. ''We love finding abandoned buildings completely overtaken by nature.''

Earl Blumenauer (above), who represents most of Portland, Ore., in Congress, insists that Washington, D.C., is a bikeable town. But then, Blumenauer would insist every city is a bikeable town. A passionate advocate of cycling, he founded the 170-member Congressional Bike Caucus and led a successful charge to put bike lanes up the middle of Pennsylvania Avenue. He bikes to work on Capitol Hill most days, and to the White House, occasionally confusing security guards. Blumenauer suggests visitors make good use of the city's bike-share program, Capital Bikeshare, or rent a bike from the Bikestation at Union Station. He also recommends riding on the Capital Crescent Trail; along the C&O Canal; on the upper Rock Creek Trail; and at the National Arboretum, ''a secret gem.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Mumbai suburb of Bandra, long a refuge for the city's Catholics, feels more like an expat playground these days. And with a flurry of new galleries, shops and bars, the district is officially rivaling South Mumbai as the city's style hub. Hakkasan The design team Gilles & Boissier lent just enough chinoiserie to the minimalist interiors at this new branch of the Michelin-starred London restaurant. The Chinese-centric menu includes dishes like stir-fried lotus root and duck salad with pomelo and pine nuts. Krystal, 206 Waterfield Road; 011-91-22-2644-4444.

AVRETT--Rosalind Case, died March 12, 2012 in New York City. Born in Upper Montclair, NJ, she was predeceased by her husbands, William Reynolds and Jack Avrett, and is survived by her son, Gerald Reynolds and her sister Paula Lewis. Legendary in advertising circles, Roz was the first female creative director of BBDO. She carried her talents into writing novels which included "My Turn" and "72 and Rodeo Drive" as well as a mystery game called "Crack the Case", created with her friend Marty Everds. A beautiful woman, Roz epitomized a breed of hostesses who had parties for any occasion or no occasion. Her legion of friends will miss her generosity, her parties, those elegant clothes and the bon mots. Most of all, we will miss her. She was the party and what a swell party it was. Anyone wishing to remember her might contribute to the A.S.P.C.A.

HODDER--Mary, died March 10 after a long illness, her husband Peter Aaron by her side. Born 1949 to emigre parenst from England. Stufied at NYU, did her thesis on Mathew Arnold and the Bhagavad Gita at Magdalen College, Oxford. A Tibetan Buddhist, Adjunct Professor at NYU and Mary Mount, employed by Goldman Saks on 9/11. Penetrating mind, indomitable spirit, sweet soul, beloved wife, brave sister. A memorial in June will be announced.

GREISSMAN--Judith Sue, died suddenly in her sleep on February 25th. She was 72. Born in Brooklyn, she went to James Madison High School and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1960. She worked as an editor for all of her professional life, first at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and later at Basic Books and the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation. She impressed everyone who met her with her boundless energy, rapid delivery, and inexhaustible curiosity about all aspects of her world. She leaves her loving friend Gwendolyn Kerr and many friends and colleagues who will experience a large hole in the universe with her passing.

HECHT--Irwin M. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the loss of Irwin ("Win") Hecht, our beloved friend and longtime employee. Win's leadership helped our company navigate a complex and ever-emerging global market. He joined the International Division of the Estee Lauder Companies in October 1970 as Regional Director for the Pacific Region and, later, Europe. He spent several years traveling the world, and building our business. In 1973, Win was named Managing Director of the Canadian affiliate, where he helped establish a firm foundation for what has become one of our most vibrant markets. After 11 years in Canada, Win spent four years as Managing Director in South Africa, mobilizing an outstanding team and instilling a strong sense of social responsibility that endures. In 1988, Win became Executive Vice President of the International Division for the Estee Lauder Companies based first in New York and then London, where he remained in this role until he retired in 1997. Win's guiding principles, both for himself and for his teams, were flexibility and focus. He was a financial genius, a compassionate mentor, and a caring human being. Win was invaluable, and his passion and generosity helped define a new generation of our international executives. He will be missed. Our thoughts are with his cherished wife, Heidi, his family and his many, many friends.

SCHERMER--Marie A.,nee Mastrangelo, died March 13, at 91. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Schermer, survived by her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. She worked in public relations at the New York Hospital Association and Roosevelt Hospital, beginning the latter's patient advocacy program. After the death of her husband, she was an executive assistant at Morgan Stanley. There will be no memorial service. Contributions in her name may be made to New York Public Library or the ALS Association of Greater New York.

With the opening of the Jacques Garcia-designed NoMad Hotel (thenomadhotel.com), on the once-bleak corner of Broadway and 28th Street, the transformation of New York's old ''Tin Pan Alley'' hits a peak. Dror Benshetrit (left), the sought-after designer behind Dror, is no stranger to travel. He is constantly touring cities like Istanbul, Paris, New Delhi and Tokyo to show off his innovative building systems, like QuaDror, a ''space-truss geometry'' sleek enough to be confused with art and strong enough to apply to table trestles, houses and even bridges. So when the luggage maker Tumi approached him to create its latest -- and his fi rst -- line of travel bags, he thought, How complex can it be? Very, it turned out. Nevertheless, Benshetrit pushed the boundaries of what a suitcase can be, with a collection of chic, multifunctional bags: totes that become backpacks, reversible briefcases, expandable satchels and a hard-shell carry-on that, with two pulls of a hinge, doubles in size. ''Static objects do not work for me,'' he says. Go to tumi.com.

Magazine groups rely on sister publications to support weaker ones. So, Power & Motoryacht, which was up 29 percent from 2010 to 2011, offset other glossies and put Source Interlink up almost 4 percent in a year where 17 of 23 groups had ad page declines. Architectural Digest, Vogue and Wired each gained 9 percent, keeping losses by Condé Nast to 1 percent overall. One magazine in a small group carries a lot of weight: Intermedia Outdoors gained on the strength of Handguns, up almost 26 percent, and Departures, from American Express, was up 43 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GREENBERG Will be held on Tuesday, March 20 at 5:30pm at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th St. (between Lexington and 3rd Avenues). Steven was a visionary creative genius who became the Nightlife King of NY. Owner of 230 Fifth, the Roxy and the Palladium. A renowned collector of Art Deco. He was a generous, charismatic and special friend to many.

YASGUR--Marvin, passed away peacefully at his winter home in Boynton Beach, Florida on Friday, March 16, 2012 at the age of 82. Dee, his beloved wife of 60 years was by his side. He is survived by his loving children and grandchildren. Services will be held at KTI Synagogue located at 575 King Street, Port Chester, NY on Monday morning at 10am.

FULLERTON--Reginald H. Jr.,"Pete", passed away March 15, 2012 at his home in Watch Hill, RI. He was born on June 15, 1933 in New York, NY and was the son of the late Reginald H. Fullerton & Gwendolyn Graves Fullerton. He attended Westminster School and Philips Andover Academy and graduated from Yale University in 1957. Pete was a Vice President of Bankers Trust Company in New York for several years before retiring to Rhode Island. He was a member of The Links Club and The Knickerbocker Club in New York and The Misquamicut Club and Watch Hill Yacht Club in Watch Hill, RI. Pete was, for many years, the Treasurer of the Misquamicut Club and was a former Trustee of the Watch Hill Chapel Society. He was a passionate supporter of Stand Up For Animals in Westerly, RI and The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust in Kenya. He was also a long time supporter of The Westerly Hospital and Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation, as well as numerous other organizations. Pete is survived by his sister, Nan Fullerton Shupe, Atherton, California, two daughters, Kirsten Stephens (Eric Stephens), Owings Mills, Maryland, and Kimberly Anderson (Robert Anderson), Watch Hill, RI, and their mother, Pete's former wife, Kathleen Knudson Wattles, as well as three grandsons, Isaiah Stephens, Spencer Stephens and Sam Anderson and two dogs, Smokey and Scout. He is further survived by his niece and two nephews, other relatives and many friends. His funeral service will be held Saturday, March 24 at 11am at Calvary Episcopal Church, 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. His family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Stand Up for Animals, P.O. Box 1706, Westerly, RI.

PERELSTEIN--Michael, 56, Rye, NY, beloved husband of Liz, adored father of Sarah and Daniel, died on Saturday, March 17, biking among friends on a beautiful day. Michael received a BA in Economics from Brandeis University in 1976 and an MBA from the University of Chicago in 1986. He left a long career in international finance in 2004 and found his true calling teaching at Columbia and NYU business schools. Michael was born to Zofia and Yasha Perelstein in Haifa, Israel, and moved at age five with his family to Cologne, Germany. They immigrated to Boston in 1967. His peripatetic childhood left him with a love of travel that he shared with his wife and children. He and Liz met working at a summer camp at age 16, and would have celebrated their 33rd wedding anniversary next week. Funeral services will be held at the Friends Meeting House at Purchase and Lake Streets, Purchase, NY on Monday, March 19th at 1:30pm. Guests may arrive after 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

LEWY--Rudolf, 93, died peacefully on Friday, March 16, 2012 in Boynton Beach, Florida. Born in Germany, Rudy emigrated to the United States in 1939. He enlisted in the US Army, fought in North Africa and Italy, and was awarded a Purple Heart and Bronze Star. He owned and developed, together with his brother-in law, a gift import business that he ran successfully for many years. Before retiring to Boynton Beach, he lived in Bergen County, New Jersey, with Esther, his wonderful wife of 65 years, who passed away in 2008. He is survived by his children, Rhonda (and Joel) Koss and Glen (and Cheryl) Lewy, five grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and his brother, Frank (and Irma) Lewy. Rudy was an avid tennis player, a world traveler, and a man of great dignity, wisdom and integrity. He will be greatly missed by all of us. Contributions may be made to the Anti-defamation League, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158.

Rosie O'Donnell's 7 p.m. talk show on OWN, Oprah Winfrey's struggling cable network, is being canceled after just five months. ''The Rosie Show'' will tape its final episode on Tuesday, the network said in a news release on Friday night, after weeks of speculation about its fate.

HOFFMAN--Harold M.,82. Died March 17, 2012 at home, leaving his devoted wife of 60 years Lillian, loving children Steven, Jane (Kevin), and Carol (David), and cherished grandchildren Jeremy, Rachel, Daniel, and Claire. Born in The Bronx, 1929. Graduated City College of New York and Yale Law School. Retired from distinguished legal career as partner, Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman. Proudly served as Justice for Village of Great Neck Estates. Loved and respected for his compassion, clear-headedness, negotiating skills, and wise counsel. Avid supporter and donor to his alma maters. Funeral Services at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, Thursday, March 22, at 11:00am.

GoMo, with apologies to the Energizer Bunny, keeps going and going. GoMo, as in ''Go Mobile,'' is an effort sponsored by Google to encourage businesses to offer Web sites that are mobile-enabled - that is, that work well on mobile devices. The effort, which began in November, is being extended and expanded.

Movies based on television shows often lead to box-office disaster (''Bewitched'' in 2005, ''Land of the Lost'' in 2009), which makes the ones that do succeed quite impressive: Over the weekend, a comedic remake of ''21 Jump Street'' was a big No. 1 at North American theaters, selling an estimated $35 million in tickets. ''21 Jump Street,'' starring Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum and released by Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, cost about $42 million to make and succeeded because -- brace yourselves -- it was actually funny. It received strong reviews, and moviegoers under age 25, the target audience, gave the film an A score in exit polls. ''Dr. Seuss' The Lorax'' (Universal Pictures) was second, taking in about $22.8 million for a three-week total of $158.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. ''John Carter'' (Walt Disney Studios) slumped to third place in its second weekend, selling an estimated $13.5 million for a new total of $53.2 million. Coming in fourth with about $4 million in ticket sales was ''Project X'' (Warner Brothers), for a three-week total of $48.1 million. ''A Thousand Words,'' starring Eddie Murphy and released by Paramount Pictures, rounded out the top five, taking in about $3.8 million for a two-week total of $12.1 million.

Nielsen says it is ready to sell what many advertisers have been clamoring for: a system that standardizes ratings for television and online ads. The new system, given the name ''cross-platform campaign ratings,'' will combine Nielsen's existing television ratings, which measure the reach and frequency of ads on TV, with Nielsen's new online campaign ratings, which apply the same measurements to the Web.

Peter Novick, a history professor at the University of Chicago who stirred controversy in 1999 with a book contending that the legacy of the Holocaust had come to unduly dominate American Jewish identity, died on Feb. 17 at his home in Chicago. He was 77. The cause was lung cancer, his wife, Joan, said.

For months, Mitt Romney has tried to deflect attention from his rivals' accusations that his health care plan was the inspiration for President Obama's overhaul. That task will be harder in the coming days. This week is the two-year anniversary of Mr. Obama's health care law, and Republicans in Washington are planning to celebrate with a series of attacks. Next week, the Supreme Court will hear three days of arguments about whether the law is constitutional. The hoopla will be enormous.

Someday soon, the Federal Reserve may be dead, at least for economic information. Blame it on, or credit it to, cloud computing. I recently visited the Oakland, Calif., headquarters of GT Nexus, a company that monitors supply chain information - things like ordering, payment, manufacture and logistics - for 100 major companies. Think of GT Nexus as a Facebook for corporate behavior: business partners are friends, and the completion of tasks are status updates.

Three of Cisco's top engineers with a strong record in building some of the company's most important products are in negotiations to create a new type of network switch for data centers, according to people with knowledge of the talks. The product they are discussing, called Insiemi, would be designed to work in high-end computer centers that use ''software-defined networking.'' This type of data center, increasingly used in cloud computing, typically carries out much of its computing with cheaper off-the-shelf semiconductors, while complex software handles tasks that were previously done using expensive machines full of custom semiconductors.

She was 87. Her death was confirmed by her son, David Hyman.

Every so often, a new mobile gaming craze sweeps across smartphone screens around the world -- think Angry Birds, Words with Friends, Tiny Tower. Over the past few weeks, Draw Something has become the new sensation.

SAN FRANCISCO -- On Monday morning I'm going to drive to the airport, check in for my flight to New York, then head to the airport bookstore for a stack of magazines to read on the plane. I'll do this reluctantly because I will carry both an Amazon Kindle and an Apple iPad packed full of reading material in my bag. I need the paper products because Federal Aviation Administration rules state that I cannot use these digital reading devices on an airplane during taxi, take-off or landing.

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- After President Obama selected North Carolina State to advance to the Round of 16, Wolfpack Coach Mark Gottfried sought to explain the pick as simply a move to curry favor among the state's voters in the coming presidential election. But 11th-seeded North Carolina State's 66-63 victory over No. 3 Georgetown on Sunday showed that Obama might have been relying on more than political guile when he made such a bold prediction about a team that nearly missed making the N.C.A.A. tournament.

WALTCHER--Irving, died March 17, 2012 at the age of 95. He was the husband of the late Azelle Waltcher, loving father of Jeffrey and Dan (Barri), grandfather of Genevieve, Thomas, Sarah and David. A Professor of Chemistry at City College for 30 years, Irv attended the University of Rhode Island, Duke (Masters) and Ohio State (PhD). Irv was a supporter of educational and other causes, and a lover of the arts and Newport, RI, where he was born. We will miss his keen intellect, deep voice, political rants and stock tips. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, www.vnsny.org.

Franklin is classified on Facebook as a public figure in Brooklyn, N.Y. His ''likes'' include ''Babe: Pig in the City'' and Crest Hardware and Urban Garden Center, a plug for the store in Williamsburg where he can often be found rooting through mulch. He has blue eyes, the inspiration for his name -- as in Frankie Blue Eyes -- and mellows out while listening to classic rock radio. One recent chilly day, Franklin, a pot-bellied pig, was dressed in a black sweater with a stretched-out neck, his wiggling tail showing his joy at having free rein of the 5,000-square-foot garden at the hardware store. Soon, his world will shrink.

The Pew Research Center's latest accounting of the news industry pairs good news - big audiences hungry for more news and information - with bad news - less revenue to pay for news production. The nonprofit group will release its ninth annual State of the News Media report on Monday morning.

Our thoughts are with her sons, David and Jonathan, but they can rest assured that their mother's good works and beautiful, nurturing soul will live on in the hearts of our members. The Executive Board of NELA/NY.

Proud Papa to Jacqueline Jurik and Rachel and Alison Walensky. Adored brother to five wonderful sisters. Daddy-You did it your way!

United Parcel Service is near a deal to buy TNT Express, a Dutch shipping company, for about 5 billion euros, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. The deal, months in the making and worth roughly $6.6 billion, was sealed after U.P.S. raised its takeover bid to about 9.50 euros a share from 9 euros a share. A deal could be announced as soon as Monday, one of these people said, cautioning that the talks might still fall apart.

If you are a movie buff, this Knicks season has probably looked eerily familiar to you. The Knicks have followed the plot of the 1990 Academy Award nominee ''Awakenings'' so closely that James L. Dolan could be accused of plagiarizing Penny Marshall. If you never noticed the resemblance between Mike D'Antoni and Robin Williams's Dr. Malcolm Sayer, or cannot picture Robert De Niro method-acting Jeremy Lin the way he inhabited the character of Leonard Lowe, this point-by-point comparison will show just how carefully the Knicks straddled the line between basketball disappointment and copyright infringement this year. CHARNEY--Geraldine. A passionate teacher, Geri passed away on March 17th, at age 82. Devoted wife of the late Robert Charney, she leaves her children, Scott and Pamela, five grandchildren (Christina, Kevin, Dylan, Ashley, and Zachary), her close friend Mort, devoted nephews and nieces, and a long list of lifetime friends, bridge partners, and political club members who will miss her dearly. Services will be held on Tuesday at 2:15pm, Riverside Memorial (Amsterdam and 76th St). In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

Jean Giraud, a French comic-book artist whose dark, intricately drawn fantasy worlds exerted a profound influence on graphic novels worldwide and on American science fiction films like ''Alien,'' ''Tron'' ''The Fifth Element,'' and ''Avatar,'' died on Saturday at his home outside Paris. He was 73. The cause was cancer, according to a statement by his publisher, Éditions Dargaud.

Four days of noon-to-midnight basketball in the N.C.A.A. men's tournament have whittled 64 teams to a field of 16, setting the stage for the weekend between the opening of the tournament and the Final Four. Teams will head to Boston, Atlanta, St. Louis and Phoenix this week, with the goal of cutting down the nets and advancing to New Orleans.

REDDY--Paul, died on March 9, 2012 at the age of 62 following complications from surgery. He retired as a Senior Vice President at AON Corporation, which he helped rebuild after their New York City offices were destroyed on September 11, 2001. He lost many friends that day. He was a man of integrity and great humor, an avid reader and a wonderful storyteller. He traveled over six continents with Clifton Campbell, his beloved partner of thirteen years who survives him. He is also survived by his sons, Rob of Brooklyn, Christopher of Providence, RI, two grandchildren, Eamonn and Zoey, his brother John of Rochester, NH, two sisters, Mary Kay of Quincy, MA and Jeanne Flight of Marion, MA. A memorial mass will be celebrated at the Church of Saint Francis Xavier, West 16th Street, New York on April 13 at 6:30pm.

MELMAN--Rosemarie, 90 years old, died on March 17, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted sister of Anne Abeles and John and Jean Lesser. Cherished aunt of John, Susan, Robert and Ellen. Loving great-aunt. Also loved by her caretaker Jean Gholson. Proud veteran of the US Navy in World War II. Services Monday, March 19, 2012, 11am at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

Cooper put on a transcendent performance in the N.C.A.A. tournament, they are showered with adulation and publicity that is usually lacking for lower-profile programs. Magazine groups rely on sister publications to support weaker ones. So, Power & Motoryacht, which was up 29 percent from 2010 to 2011, offset other glossies and put Source Interlink up almost 4 percent in a year where 17 of 23 groups had ad page declines. Architectural Digest, Vogue and Wired each gained 9 percent, keeping losses by Condé Nast to 1 percent overall. One magazine in a small group carries a lot of weight: Intermedia Outdoors gained on the strength of Handguns, up almost 26 percent, and Departures, from American Express, was up 43 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

NASHVILLE -- CBS slotted Florida State and Cincinnati as the late game on Sunday night, with tip-off coming at nearly 10 p.m. Eastern. Being cast in a time slot when the game would finish when many in America had gone to bed was a subtle way for CBS to acknowledge the obvious -- this game would not be pretty. And the instincts of the network executives proved correct, as Florida State and Cincinnati did not put on an aesthetic display of basketball in the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 32. With big bodies colliding into one another, sixth-seeded Cincinnati outmuscled third-seeded Florida State, 62-56.

REMES--Carol, (June 22, 1921 - March 14, 2012). An English professor at Fashion Institute of Technology for many years, Carol loved the arts and letters, philosophy and language, and social and political thought. She is survived by a loving family--her sister, Ruth Levine; her children, David and Emily Remes; her daughter-in-law, Naomi Remes and her son-in-law, Craig Stewart; and her grandchildren, Katie and Nick Stewart and Betsy and Sarah Remes. We will cherish her memory.

It's been a busy week for Cody Simpson. The tween dream from Australia released a new single, ''So Listen,'' a collaboration with the hip-hop star T-Pain, and is in the studio wrapping up his first album. And he announced plans to join Big Time Rush on its summer tour. Next on the 15-year-old Simpson's ascension to pop idol: the cover of a Toys ''R'' Us catalog. In addition to being a popular singer with millions of fans, and one who's helped sell millions of copies of conventional magazines like Teen Beat, Bop and J-14, Cody Simpson is a popular brand as well, with 16 licensing deals for a wide array of products. Toys ''R'' Us is putting his face of on the cover of its annual catalog, which comes out on Friday, to promote an exclusive line of dolls, clothing and accessories.

WECHSLER--Lawrence (Larry), on March 15th at the age of 86, beloved husband of Jan (Dean) for 37 years, adoring father of Brad (Patty), loving grandfather of Samantha, Robert and David. Uncle to Betty (Chris) Connolly and Stephen Wechsler. Resident of NYC, Boca Grande, Florida and Millbrook, NY. Larry loved life. Born in Brooklyn, he rose to become a cosmetic industry leader, serving Revlon for 30 years. Following retirement from Revlon, he taught at Parsons School of Design in addition to serving as a consultant to Christian Dior Cosmetics and Fragrances. He served on the board of CTFA and was affiliated with The New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. Larry enjoyed playing the saxophone and was a determined athlete in spite of his affliction from a neurological disease CharcotMarieTooth. He will be greatly missed. A service will be held on Monday, March 19th at 4pm at Frank E. Campbell- 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC.

KAUFMAN--Melvyn, 87, of Mamaroneck, died peacefully at his home with his wife Liz at his side on Sunday March 18, 2012. Beloved husband of Elizabeth H. Atwood. He was born to the late William and Esther Kaufman, (d. respectively 1976 and 1984). His older brother, Bennett, who died in 1980, predeceased him. His younger brother, Robert, survives him. Together with his brother, Robert, they advanced The William Kaufman Organization and Sage Realty Corporation, started by their father William, to the level of one of most respected and honored real estate ventures in New York City and the entire country. As a young man Melvyn learned the construction business "the hard way", by working for his father as a day laborer. lt was from this early experience that he realized that he had found his true love - architecture and construction. Melvyn attended New York University and Long Island University. This was interrupted by his military service as an infantry soldier in Europe in World War II. After the war ended Melvyn did not return to school. Instead, he went to work for his father. He started his career as a builder of shopping centers and small commercial buildings, but the company's and his attention soon turned to bigger things in the booming postwar economy of New York City -the high rise office building. In the early 1950's WKO built its' First New York City buildings, 711 Third Avenue and 405 Park Avenue. Several years later 777 Third Avenue followed and over the next several decades continued to develop large New York City office building projects. These include 437 Madison Avenue, 767 Third Avenue, 747 Third Avenue, 127 John Street, 77 Water Street and 17 State Street. Melvyn was a guest professor at Cooper Union and at Pratt School of Architecture. He lectured at McGill University, Ohio University, New York University and many other architectural schools. He spoke before the American Institute of Architects and the Architectural League of New York. Melvyn was Chairman of the Stoneyard Institute of The Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. His first wife and mother of their children, Claire, who died in 1987, predeceased Melvyn. Melvyn is survived by three children: Jerian Franco and Kim Kaufman, of New York City and Karin Kaufman of Pound Ridge. Four grandchildren also survive him: Samantha, Daniel, William and James. Two stepchildren survive Melvyn: Richard Metz Jr. of New York City and Jane Robinson of West Hartford, CT. He is also survived by three step-grandchildren: Courtney, John, and Thomas. Many nieces and nephews as well as many great-nieces and great-nephews also survive Melvyn. ln lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made out to Berwick Boys Foundation, 335 West Street, West Bridgewater, MA 02379 or www.berwick.org. Family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue New York, NY 10028, Wednesday March 21, 2012 3pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. A service will be held Thursday March 22, 2012 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am followed with burial later that afternoon at Kensico Cemetery. SCHAFFER--Loretta Wolff, on March 18, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Larry Schaffer, devoted mother of Roni Greer, cherished grandmother of Jamie and Jocelyn Greer.
