If the two-week Peyton Manning Derby felt like a whirlwind to fans, imagine how it must have felt for Manning. The life of an in-demand millionaire may appear glamorous on the surface, but a closer look reveals a long succession of endless meetings, carefully choreographed flights, and long rides in suspicious-looking vehicles. Here is a recap of the major events of a 15-day turning point in N.F.L. history. MARCH 4 With a final decision on Manning's future with the Colts still a few days away, 27 seconds of grainy, distant cellphone footage of Manning throwing footballs at Duke University goes viral. A confused Dan Snyder of the Redskins offers three future first-round draft picks for the monster from Cloverfield.
Tim Tebow appeals to the Jets because of his familiarity with the Wildcat formation.

New York's much delayed redistricting process came to a partial end on Monday when a panel of federal judges in Brooklyn ordered the state to put into place a new map of Congressional districts drawn up by a court-appointed magistrate. The court-imposed plan will reduce the number of districts in New York to 27, from 29, as Congressional seats are shifted to faster-growing parts of the nation in the wake of the 2010 census. The state plans to hold a Congressional primary on June 26 and a general election on Nov. 6.

In September they began to gather, their encampment growing by the week. The police, confronted with a populist movement that put down roots in the financial district, were unsure of how to respond to Occupy Wall Street. At some marches, protesters were arrested for veering off the sidewalk into the street; at others, the police ordered protesters off the sidewalk. Tents were banned early on, then tolerated, then banned again. The mayor said he was going to clear the encampment in October to clean up Zuccotti Park, then balked before finally going through with it a month later, when he sent the police in to clear the camp, in the middle of the night, with little warning.

Despite declining ratings - to say nothing of declining civilization - and the pregnancy of a cast member, MTV isn't ready to say goodbye to ''Jersey Shore'' just yet. On Monday the cable channel announced that it had ordered a sixth season of the reality series that gave the world Michael Sorrentino (better known as the Situation) and Nicole Polizzi (a k a Snooki), who in turn will be giving the world a Snooki Jr. in the months to come. MTV has already announced ''Jersey Shore'' spinoffs featuring Paul DelVecchio (Pauly D) as well as Ms. Polizzi and Jennifer Farley (nom de shore JWoww), and ratings for the original series tumbled to fewer than 5 million viewers for some of the final episodes of Season 5. Even so, ''Jersey Shore'' remains one of MTV's - and basic cable's - most popular shows with younger viewers.

BEIJING -- Communist Party leaders sacked Bo Xilai, the powerful party chief of metropolitan Chongqing, after being told that he had schemed to remove his police chief and impede a corruption investigation involving his family, according to a preliminary report on Mr. Bo's actions circulated among government officials. A version of the report, posted on a Chinese Web site and verified independently, provides a rare glimpse of the government's internal efforts to manage one of its biggest political earthquakes in years. Some officials are worried that the purge of Mr. Bo could upset plans for a transfer of power to a new generation of party leaders this fall.

KAUFMAN--Melvyn. The partners and staff of Berdon LLP mourn the passing of a truly unique and dynamic figure in real estate, our good friend and client Mel Kaufman. A man of vision and drive, Mel's influence on the real estate scene will be a lasting legacy. Our fondest thoughts go out to Mel's wife Liz Atwood, his children, his brother Robert, and the entire Kaufman family. We will all miss him dearly.

When courting new business, Wall Street's deal makers often point to their long client lists as proof of deep industry knowledge. Three Ocean Partners takes the opposite approach. The three-month-old boutique firm pitches clients on the promise of exclusivity, pledging to take just one account per industry.

SAN FRANCISCO -- When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory. In the seven years since it was introduced, Google's offering of street maps, satellite photos and street-level views has become the dominant player in the world of online mapping, displacing earlier entrants like AOL's MapQuest. According to comScore, 71 percent of the 91.7 million people in the United States who looked at maps online in February used Google Maps.

HOFFMAN--Harold. The City College of New York mourns the loss of devoted alumnus Harold Hoffman, Class of 1949. Harold's City College education was a bridge that took him from modest beginnings in the Bronx to Yale Law School and a career as a prominent corporate attorney. He and his wife, Lillian, a member of the CCNY Class of 1951, gave back to their alma mater by providing scholarships for students in our Honors Program and by endowing the Harold and Lillian Hoffman Student Center, the Hoffman Forum and the Hoffman Game Room. On behalf of our students, faculty and staff, our sincerest condolences to Lillian, their children and grandchildren. Lisa S. Coico President

Monreal was a well known painter with over 30 solo exhibits in New York, Paris, Santiago and Ibiza. Monreal is survived by his two sons the filmmaker: Nick Gomez and the painter: Rodrigo Monreal.

The Board remembers with deep appreciation his wise and warm counsel, his guidance and his dedication to the ideals of the City College of New York and its commitment to access and excellence. Martin Cohen, President of the Board Rachelle Butler, Executive Director

An article on Saturday about Rick Santorum's loss of his Senate seat in the 2006 election, using information from a political scientist, described the significance of Mr. Santorum's defeat incorrectly. It was the biggest loss for an incumbent senator from Pennsylvania since the 17th Amendment to the Constitution in 1913, which required that senators be popularly elected instead of appointed. His loss, by 17.4 percentage points, was not the biggest for any incumbent senator in Pennsylvania ''since at least the Civil War.''

KAUFMAN--Melvyn. The Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy extend our condolences to fellow Trustee and dear friend Liz Atwood on the loss of her beloved husband Melvyn Kaufman. Doug Blonsky President and CEO of the Central Park Conservancy Administrator of Central Park Thomas L. Kempner, Jr. Chairman Board of Trustees

The ''Popular Demand'' listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday included several errors. The 2011 advertising pages are in thousands, not millions. In the data for Hearst/Hachette magazine group, there were 22,460 pages, not 23,040, and the change from 2010 was minus 2.20 percent, not minus 2.04. The listing also misstated the number of magazines published in 2011 by the magazine group of the National Geographic Association. It was three, not one. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/media.

KONOPKO--Abraham Marvin, 86, of Manhattan. Beloved husband of the late Lea, devoted father of Elliot and Deborah and the late Peninah, loving and beloved grandfather of Charlotte and Oliver. Born in Poland and came to the United States at the age of 12. Proud member of the US Navy Seabees with service on Saipan during WW II. BS in Pharmacy from Fordham University. Worked in and owned pharmacies in The Bronx and Manhattan for five decades. Member of Congregation Ansche Chesed. Funeral services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, 11am, Tuesday, March 20th. Donations may be made to Jewish Theological Seminary, Women's League Torah Fund, 3080 Broadway, New York, NY 10027.

Mr. Lewy and his late wife, Esther, perpetuated a family tradition of selfless philanthropy, which has had a profound impact on the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and beyond. We extend our condolences to his children, Glen (and Cheryl) Lewy and Rhonda (and Joel) Koss; his five grandchildren; his three great-grandchildren; and his brother, Frank. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

The Jets bolstered their depleted safety ranks Monday by signing LaRon Landry, who spent the previous five seasons with Washington. Landry, the Redskins' first-round pick in 2007, joins the starter Eric Smith and Tracy Wilson as the only safeties under contract for the Jets. Known for his tackling skills and his awareness near the line of scrimmage, Landry does not satisfy the Jets' true need at safety - a dynamic playmaker who can assist in covering tight ends, a major shortcoming last season. But if he can remain healthy, Landry is a genuine asset. An Achilles' tendon injury, which he has tried to heal without surgery, has limited him to 17 games over the past two seasons.

An Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on Monday about the teams that received No. 1 seeds in the N.C.A.A. men's hockey tournament misstated the day the event will begin. It is Friday, not Saturday.
McQUISTON--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John McQuiston associated with The New York Times from August 31, 1959 until retiring on June 1, 2000.

A picture caption on March 9 with a review of ''Hora,'' performed by the Batsheva Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misidentified a dancer. He is Doug Letheren -- not Matan David, another member of the company.

SCHIFFER--Harvey, born in New York, on April 3, 1926, died peacefully on March 17, 2012 at age 85. Devoted son of Dorothy and Morris, brother of the late Gertrude (Fieldston), beloved husband of Ruth for 62 years, loving father of Mark (Stephanie Gertler) and Joan (Les Levinson), cherished grandfather of David, Elyena (Lawrence Brotherton), Benjamin, Dana and Cara. Lived in Plainfield, NJ, and later Palm Beach Gardens, FL. A founding sportswriter for the NCAA, and later president of The Wearever Shirt Company. Dedicated golfer, great friend and family man with a wry sense of humor, he was a man of keen intellect, warmth, sensitivity, and respected and loved by all. Funeral services at 11:00am on March 21 at Congregation Beth Israel, Scotch Plains, NJ, and interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the charity of your choice.

Mick Taylor, the guitarist best known for his work with the Rolling Stones during the early 1970s, will perform six shows at the Iridium in May, the club announced on Monday. Mr. Taylor joined the Stones in 1969 at the age of 20 after playing with John Mayall's Bluesbreakers for several years. He brought smooth, lyrical guitar style to the band's often jagged sound and is credited with helping shape some of the Stone's best albums, among them ''Let It Bleed,'' ''Sticky Fingers'' and ''Exile on Main Street.'' At the Iridium, Mr. Taylor will play two shows a night from May 9 through May 14 with a band of seasoned studio professionals from the jazz and funk realms: keyboardist Max Middleton, bassist Wilbur Bascomb, drummer Bernard Purdie and guitarist Jon Paris. On the last night of the series, he will be joined by the Les Paul Trio.

BlackRock is helping to determine how much capital Greece’s banks will need to raise in the coming months, a crucial step as Greece tries to fix its banking industry and its broader economy, but a risky one.

COWLES--John, Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Walker Art Center mourn the passing of their former Trustee, whose steadfast commitment to the Walker and the entire cultural community in Minnesota were deeply appreciated. In addition to serving as a Walker Trustee and making Cowles Conservatory possible in the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden, John along with his wife Sage, was a longtime member of the Patrons' Circle and one of the founding members of the Walker Producers' Council, which supports its performing arts program. He was a greatly respected civic leader and a beloved friend. The Walker extends heartfelt condolences to Sage, their children Jay, Fuller, Tessa, and Jane, his brother Russell and sister Sarah, and extended family and friends.
The contrast in North Carolina basketball loyalties — pro versus college — is starkly apparent, particularly with the seven-win Bobcats and the state’s N.C.A.A. tournament teams.

The new Disney stage musical ''Newsies'' got off to a strong start on Broadway last week, grossing $735,991 for its first six preview performances at the Nederlander Theater - or about $123,000 per performance, more than the musical ''Rent'' grossed when it set the Nederlander house record of $864,321 for eight performances in 2008. The new box office data was released on Monday at the same time that Disney Theatrical Productions - which mounts the film studio's properties on Broadway - announced that ''Newsies'' would run through August 19, instead of closing as originally planned on June 10. ''Newsies'' was always likely to be extended, and no one in New York theater circles will be surprised if Disney ultimately announces that the musical will have an open-ended run. Disney executives have been gaming expectations low for ''Newsies,'' as indicated by the limited run and the relatively modest roll-out (by Disney standards) of the musical. The reality is, ''Newsies'' already has strong buzz after its critically praised tryout run in suburban New Jersey last fall, and Broadway has few new family-oriented shows like ''Newsies'' this spring.

ALLEN--Phillip R.,passed March 1, 2012. Actor of stage, screen and television. Studied at Neighborhood Playhouse and starred in Pulitzer Prize winning play "That Championship Season" and Albee's "Zoo Story", both of which he won best acting awards. He also performed in the controversial award-winning theatrical performance dealing with AIDS, "The Normal Heart." Phillip went on to do "Are You Now or Have You Ever Been?". The entire New York cast won an ensemble acting award. Recurring roles in television series: "The Mary Tyler Moore Show", "Bad News Bears", "Happy Days" and with Tom Hanks in "Bosom Buddies" - IMDB and many more. An actor's actor who always left the audience smiling. Phillip was the brilliant raconteur and will be remembered by his friends as a gifted chameleon on stage and screen. Phillip's films included "Onion Fields", "Star Trek III", "Mommie Dearest" and "Midway" to name a few. Survivors include Joanie, his wife, muse and soulmate of 40 years, and devoted son Keegan who follows in his father's footsteps presently starring in the hit television series "Pretty Little Liars".

In a television interview on Sunday and a Web video released on Monday, Mitt Romney said that President Obama has sought higher gasoline and energy prices and called on the president to dismiss three cabinet officers Mr. Romney claims have abetted him. But the assertion, which echoes charges from other Republicans, is largely unsubstantiated or misleading.

Americans are having a passionate love affair with something they cannot see, hear, feel, touch or taste. That something is calories, billions upon billions of which are consumed every day, often unwittingly, at and between meals. Certainly calories are talked about constantly, and information about them appears with increasing frequency on food labels, menus, recipes and Web sites. But few people understand what they are and how they work - especially how they have worked to create a population in which 64 percent of adults and a third of children are overweight or obese, or how they thwart the efforts of so many people to shed those unwanted pounds and keep them off once and for all.

For the first time since giving birth, Beyoncé plans to return to the stage in May with a series of concerts at a new resort in Atlantic City, her publicist, Yvette Noel-Schure, said on Monday. Beyoncé, a Grammy-winning singer, will appear over the Memorial Day weekend - on May 25, 26 and 27 - to inaugurate a 5,000-seat hall at Revel Resorts, a casino scheduled to open in April. The concerts will be the first time Beyoncé has performed since she appeared at the Roseland Ballroom in August. In early January she gave birth to her first child, a girl named Blue Ivy Carter, and she has kept a low profile since then, though last week she showed up with her husband, the rapper Jay-Z, to hear The-Dream perform at S.O.B.'s in Manhattan.

A picture caption on Monday with articles about Sunday's action in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, using information from Reuters, misidentified the North Carolina State player shown colliding with Henry Sims of Georgetown. He is C. J. Leslie, not C. J. Williams.

MBIA did not award bonuses to its top executives in 2011, but only after its regulator pressured the beleaguered bond insurer to withhold the payouts, people briefed on the matter said. Jay Brown, the company's chief executive, and three other senior executives, did not receive any cash bonus or long-term stock awards for 2011, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

Mike Daisey, the theater monologist who has come under criticism for embellishing details about a Chinese factory for his one-man show about Apple, ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' changed some of the disputed language during the show's final performances at the Public Theater over the weekend, according to a spokesman for Mr. Daisey and executives at the Public. Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public, said on Monday that he and Mr. Daisey had spoken at length about the content of the show after the weekly radio program ''This American Life'' on Friday retracted a report based on Mr. Daisey's visit to the Foxconn factory, which makes Apple products, after finding evidence that Mr. Daisey had invented damning details about life and work there. Mr. Eustis said that Mr. Daisey had decided on his own to change language, and to add a new prologue in which he acknowledged the controversy and said that he stood behind the content of the newly altered show. Mr. Eustis estimated that the changes amount to ''2 percent or less'' of the monologue.

GOULD--Arthur P. Beloved husband, best friend, and companion on all the trails and tides to his dear wife Julia; beloved father of David, Andy and Vicky and father-in-law of Laura, May, and Dave; supremely and ceaselessly devoted grandfather of Nathan, Ezra, Sonya, and Abby; loving brother and brother-in-law to Sam, Susan, and the late Helen, Bea, Hilda, Dan, Eli, Jules, and Henry; loving and caring son of the late Manya and Isidore; supportive cousin, uncle and friend to many too numerous to name but whose love remains in our hearts. His four years of naval combat service in World War II shaped and informed his determination to live every moment of every day, and to share with his children and grandchildren both the spirit and optimism with which he faced life, and the respect for the hazard and contingency upon which we all breathe but can never fully understand. We will all miss him terribly. Shiva Tuesday, March 20 2:00 9:00pm at Arthur's home. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will be appreciated.

Mark Thompson, who has overseen the British Broadcasting Corporation's television channels, radio stations and Web sites since 2004, will depart the public broadcaster later this year, he said Monday. In anticipation of such an announcement, the corporation, which is financed in large part by a license fee paid by British households with televisions, has already started to talk about planning for a successor. Mr. Thompson, who is 54, said on Monday that he would depart some time after the Summer Olympic games in London in July and August.

Warning: this post contains spoilers about the ''Walking Dead'' season finale. Today's case study in contrasts is AMC, the cable-television home of shows including ''The Walking Dead'' and ''Mad Men,'' and which has already been circulating advance copies of the Sunday ''Mad Men'' premiere to reporters and critics, along with a letter from that show's creator, Matthew Weiner, warning these writers not to spoil plot details for their readers. ''My goal every season is first and foremost to entertain the audience,'' Mr. Weiner writes, ''and I know that this is best accomplished when key story lines are not revealed in advance.''
The microbes have been at this a lot longer than us. DR. L. CLIFFORD MCDONALD,

Mistaken identity is an occupational hazard for people who are mentioned even fleetingly on the Internet. Still, consider Peter Agree's shock when he searched the Web for references to his mother. ''The references I turned up were to 'Rose Agree, geriatric porn star,' '' said Mr. Agree, the editor in chief of the University of Pennsylvania Press. ''Wikipedia had a biographical entry for this person, and to my horror it fused elements of my mother's biography, including her having been a librarian on Long Island.''

An article on Saturday about 15th-seeded Norfolk State's victory over second-seeded Missouri in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament misstated, in some editions, the last time a No. 15 seed defeated a No. 2 seed in the tournament. As a picture caption with the article correctly noted, it was 2001, not 1991.

THE FACTS Health experts advise Americans to exercise moderately for at least two and a half hours a week. But for those who are overweight, overheating can be a major hurdle to staying active. For some, the extra fat prevents the body from dissipating heat, causing a steep rise in core temperature that leads to quicker exhaustion.

TIRANA, Albania -- Rising above the dingy backstreets here in the Albanian capital, the instantly recognizable silhouette shines like a promise: the Statue of Liberty. This version is part of the logo of the University of New York, Tirana, where students pay more than $32,500 for what a sign in the lobby describes as ''the only real European and American education'' in the country.

I ran my first marathon this month. It went well, and despite my fears, I had fun. I met my goals - qualified for the Boston Marathon with nearly half an hour to spare and came in second in my age group. But the big surprise was my coach's advice the next day. It will take four weeks to fully recover, he told me. That seemed like an awfully long time.

Amazon.com is buying an army of robots. The online retailer announced on Monday that it is acquiring Kiva Systems, a maker of robots that service warehouses, for $775 million in cash. Amazon, a customer of Kiva's, is buying the robotics company as it builds out its vast network of warehouses and tries to improve its margins.

EXCLUSIVE TALKS Viterra, the Canadian grain marketing and shipping company, run by Mayo Schmidt, left, confirmed on Monday that it was in ''exclusive negotiations'' with a potential buyer. It did not name the likely purchaser, but speculation points to Glencore International, the large Swiss commodities trading company, in a consortium with two Canadian firms. IAN AUSTEN

For nearly three generations, women have been taught that annual Pap smears, mammograms and visits with their doctor were essential to good health. Now all that is changing. National guidelines are urging less frequent screening for breast and cervical cancer. The declining use of menopause hormones means that older women no longer need to check in with their doctors to obtain annual refills. Women are delaying childbirth, and some birth control methods are effective for five years, giving women even less incentive to schedule a regular appointment.

8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER The eight remaining contestants head to Hawaii to challenge the myth that people can't lose weight while on vacation. After a luau in Oahu, they compete in a trivia game for a cash prize before embarking on a challenge for immunity. Then they take to the waves with Bethany Hamilton (above, flanked by Bob Harper, left, and Dolvett Quince), the competitive surfer who lost an arm in a shark attack at 13 while on a board off Tunnels Beach on Kauai. ''Soul Surfer,'' the movie about the efforts of Ms. Hamilton, played by AnnaSophia Robb, to resume competition and find comfort through Christianity, will be shown at 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. on Starz. 9 A.M. (HBO2) GEORGE HARRISON: LIVING IN THE MATERIAL WORLD (2011) Martin Scorsese uses interviews, music, film clips, photos and memorabilia to document Harrison's cultural trajectory from the Beatles to his later incarnation as a Renaissance man. The three-hour film ''is an argument for Harrison's essential role in the culture'' and ''for the continuing relevance of his explorations of Eastern thought,'' Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. But, he added, it's Paul McCartney, ''even after all these years -- and even in Harrison's own film'' who ''still steals the show, every chance he gets.'' In ''My Life Without Me,'' at 2:45 p.m., Sarah Polley plays Ann, a 23-year-old working-class mother and wife who tries to turn the diagnosis that she has only a few months to live into the best thing that has ever happened to her. So she makes a list of things to do before dying: find a new wife for her husband (Scott Speedman), sleep with other people and make someone fall in love with her. Mark Ruffalo is the scruffy man who becomes enchanted, and Deborah Harry is Ann's embittered mother.

When the Andrew Freedman Home opened in the Bronx in 1924, it looked like a limestone luxury liner sailing up the Grand Concourse, a grandiosity that advertised its odd function: a privately endowed retirement home for the formerly well-to-do, those who might have lost their money but not their manners or manorial tastes. ''They were expected to have attained a state of reasonable culture,'' commented an article in The New Yorker at the time, ''and not to eat peas with their knives.'' Freedman, who died in 1915, had been an owner of the New York Giants baseball team and a financier of New York's first subway lines, and his unusual will created a retirement home as palazzo, with plush carpets, plentiful servants and formal dress required at dinner.

Times Square may be the place hardened New Yorkers go out of their way to avoid, but its importance as a magnet for commerce as well as tourists has risen rapidly in the last few years, according to a study to be released this week. The Times Square district directly and indirectly contributes one-tenth of all of the jobs in the city and $1 of every $9 of economic activity, says the study, which was commissioned by the Times Square Alliance, the de facto chamber of commerce for the district. That amounts to $110 billion in annual economic activity - about equal to the output of Portland, Ore. - emanating from the district, which the report defines as roughly a block on each side of Broadway between 40th and 53rd Streets.

When Fred Wilpon returns to Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Tuesday, feeling triumphant, he will encounter a Mets team that has played poorly this spring and done little to dispel the notion that the 2012 season will be long and difficult. The Mets currently have a $90 million roster - down from $140 million just a year ago - that lacks veteran talent and depth and looks overmatched in a formidable National League East.

If New York City Opera is to have any success in its new manifestation as a scaled-down, roving company, then every production will have to be a must-see event. It finally has one, with the director Christopher Alden's new production of Mozart's ''Così Fan Tutte,'' which opened at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College on Sunday afternoon. This is the third of only four productions in the company's modest season. And despite some confounding and heavy-handed touches in Mr. Alden's libidinous, darkly contemporary and bitterly comic staging, neither veteran opera buffs nor curious newcomers will want to miss this ''Così.'' It is performed by an appealing young cast in an intimate auditorium of about 600 seats, ideal for Mozart, with Christian Curnyn conducting a vibrant and stylish, if occasionally scrappy, performance.

The About New York column on Friday, about the muted response of the Bloomberg administration to the forced hospitalization of an officer who uncovered wrongdoing by his supervisors at the 81st Precinct, misidentified the precinct where officers in 1997 assaulted Abner Louima at a station house. KAUFMAN--Melvyn, set only the highest standards for NYC's built environment when he designed and constructed his buildings. His goal of bringing award-winning architecture to the millions who work in or pass by his properties will be one of his lasting legacies. With his beloved wife, Liz Atwood, his reach increased into our city's parks, public plazas and streetscapes. We send Liz, our devoted Board Member, and her family our deepest sympathy and love. We will continue to emulate Melvyn's standards, and be inspired by his lasting contributions as we complete the park's rebuilding in the Downtown neighborhood he so cherished. The Board of Directors of The Battery Conservancy William C. Rudin, Chairman Warrie Price, President

BUKSBAUM--Susan. The Dalton School is saddened by the loss of Susan Buksbaum '56. A valued member of our community for over 20 years, Susan was a Trustee, parent, grandparent, gifted faculty member, mentor and advisor. She shared her passion for American History, politics and journalism with thousands of Dalton students and colleagues. We extend our love and condolences to her husband, David, daughter, Jennifer '85, grandson, Alexander '25 and brother and former Chairman of our Board of Trustees, Richard Ravitch. Ellen C. Stein Head of School

KAUFMAN--Melvyn, 87, of Mamaroneck, died peacefully at his home with his wife Liz at his side on Sunday March 18, 2012. Beloved husband of Elizabeth H. Atwood. He was born to the late William and Esther Kaufman, (d. respectively 1976 and 1984). His older brother, Bennett, who died in 1980, predeceased him. His younger brother, Robert, survives him. Together with his brother, Robert, they advanced The William Kaufman Organization and Sage Realty Corporation, started by their father William, to the level of one of most respected and honored real estate ventures in New York City and the entire country. As a young man Melvyn learned the construction business "the hard way", by working for his father as a day laborer. lt was from this early experience that he realized that he had found his true love - architecture and construction. Melvyn attended New York University and Long Island University. This was interrupted by his military service as an infantry soldier in Europe in World War II. After the war ended Melvyn did not return to school. Instead, he went to work for his father. He started his career as a builder of shopping centers and small commercial buildings, but the company's and his attention soon turned to bigger things in the booming postwar economy of New York City -the high rise office building. In the early 1950's WKO built its' First New York City buildings, 711 Third Avenue and 405 Park Avenue. Several years later 777 Third Avenue followed and over the next several decades continued to develop large New York City office building projects. These include 437 Madison Avenue, 767 Third Avenue, 747 Third Avenue, 127 John Street, 77 Water Street and 17 State Street. Melvyn was a guest professor at Cooper Union and at Pratt School of Architecture. He lectured at McGill University, Ohio University, New York University and many other architectural schools. He spoke before the American Institute of Architects and the Architectural League of New York. Melvyn was Chairman of the Stoneyard Institute of The Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. His first wife and mother of their children, Claire, who died in 1987, predeceased Melvyn. Melvyn is survived by three children: Jerian Franco and Kim Kaufman, of New York City and Karin Kaufman of Pound Ridge. Four grandchildren also survive him: Samantha, Daniel, William and James. Two stepchildren survive Melvyn: Richard Metz Jr. of New York City and Jane Robinson of West Hartford, CT. He is also survived by three step-grandchildren: Courtney, John, and Thomas. Many nieces and nephews as well as many great-nieces and great-nephews also survive Melvyn. ln lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made out to Berwick Boys Foundation, 335 West Street, West Bridgewater, MA 02379 or www.berwick.org. Family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue New York, NY 10028, Wednesday March 21, 2012 3pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. A service will be held Thursday March 22, 2012 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 11:30am followed with burial later that afternoon at Kensico Cemetery. When someone you love becomes a memory, the memory becomes a treasure.

The police search for a middle-aged woman suspected of starting 15 trash-can fires in Midtown on Monday ended Tuesday with the arrest of a man, not a woman, who has been living on the streets outside Pennsylvania Station, the Fire Department said. The suspect, Armando Calderon, 56, was arrested at 1 p.m., and told fire marshals he was homeless and angry about his circumstances and the people around him, a Fire Department spokesman said.

A physical education teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested on Tuesday after the police said he grabbed the buttocks of a 16-year-old female student. He is at least the sixth New York City school worker charged in two months with a sexual offense against a student. The teacher, Esran Boothe, 49, of the Brooklyn Academy of Science and the Environment in Crown Heights, was charged with forcible touching and third-degree sexual abuse, both misdemeanors, the police said, adding that the charges arose from a single episode.

The Tony winners Linda Lavin (''Broadway Bound''), top, LaChanze (''The Color Purple''), center, and Shuler Hensley (''Oklahoma!''), bottom, will be part of the 12-person cast singing material from shows created by the Broadway producer and director Harold Prince in ''Prince of Broadway,'' a musical tribute set to open in New York in November. Producers on Tuesday announced the complete cast, which also includes Daniel Breaker, Sebastian Arcelus and Emily Skinner. Susan Stroman will choreograph and direct with Mr. Prince, the winner of Tony awards for productions including ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' ''Cabaret,'' ''Company,'' ''Follies'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' David Thompson is writing the book; the lead producers are Aubrey Dan, Martyn Hayes and Peter W. Lamb for Dancap Productions. Also in the cast is Sierra Boggess, who had been scheduled to play the lead role in ''Rebecca,'' a musical that had been postponed. Producers for that show, based on the Daphne du Maurier novel, recently confirmed that they had raised the money for the $12 million musical and expect it to open at the Broadhurst Theater in the fall. A spokesman said on Tuesday that ''Rebecca'' would go on without Ms. Boggess, and that casting and an opening date would be announced in the coming weeks.

The councilman is Ydanis Rodriguez, shown to the right of George E. Packard, a retired bishop -- not George Martinez, a Congressional candidate.

ETKIN--Joyce, of Hollywood, Fl, formerly Woodmere, NY, on March 20, 2012. Loving wife, life partner and inspiration to Hal for 62 years. Beloved Mama to Emily, Jessica, Jennifer, Madeline, Erica, Ben, Zach, Hannah, Sam and Samantha. A woman whose personality, wit and will were only surpassed by her heart, love of family and friends, and character. She left her mark on the world and in our hearts. Services March 22 in Florida. In lieu of contributions, hug your children, family and friends and tell them you love them.

REVIVING TALKS Just one month after deal talks between Yahoo and its Asian partners collapsed, the sides are coming together once again. Alibaba's chief financial officer and lead deal negotiator, Joe Tsai, flew to Silicon Valley last week to meet with Yahoo's chief executive, Scott Thompson, left, according to two people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Ronald Fisher, a managing partner of SoftBank Capital, the largest owner of Yahoo Japan, also attended the meetings. EVELYN M. RUSLI

LONDON - After months of economic uncertainty caused by the European debt crisis, investors are starting to venture back into the Continent's financial markets. In the latest signs of life, two European companies, DKSH, a Swiss trade and marketing company, and Ziggo, a Dutch cable operator, raised a combined $2 billion through initial public offerings this week.

Buddy Guy and Neko Case will be the headliners at the second annual Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, which will be held July 11 and 12 in a plaza outside the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan, organizers said. Buddy Guy, who is 74, is considered one of the most influential blues guitarists of modern times, having influenced everyone from Stevie Ray Vaughn to Jimi Hendrix. Other acts on the bill include Charles Bradley, the Brooklyn born R&B singer, and John Mayall, the elder statesman of British blues whose 1960s band was a launching pad for guitarists like Eric Clapton and Mick Taylor. The festival is free to the public and is presented by Brookfield Office Properties, which owns the World Financial Center. The concerts will run from 6 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It was summer 1999, and a meeting between the leadership of the Bonanno and Colombo crime families was under way in an apartment off Third Avenue, in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. But something was amiss: the seat that should have been taken by William Cutolo Sr., a Colombo underboss, was empty, a former Bonanno underboss testified on Tuesday.

KONOPKO--Abraham Marvin, 86, of Manhattan. Beloved husband of the late Lea, devoted father of Elliot and Deborah and the late Peninah, loving and beloved grandfather of Charlotte and Oliver. Born in Poland and came to the United States at the age of 12. Proud member of the US Navy Seabees with service on Saipan during WW II. BS in Pharmacy from Fordham University. Worked in and owned pharmacies in The Bronx and Manhattan for five decades. Member of Congregation Ansche Chesed. Funeral services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, 11am, Tuesday, March 20th. Donations may be made to Jewish Theological Seminary, Women's League Torah Fund, 3080 Broadway, New York, NY 10027.

GOULD--Arthur P. Beloved husband, best friend, and companion on all the trails and tides to his dear wife Julia; beloved father of David, Andy and Vicky and father-in-law of Laura, May, and Dave; supremely and ceaselessly devoted grandfather of Nathan, Ezra, Sonya, and Abby; loving brother and brother-in-law to Sam, Susan, and the late Helen, Bea, Hilda, Dan, Eli, Jules, and Henry; loving and caring son of the late Manya and Isidore; supportive cousin, uncle and friend to many too numerous to name but whose love remains in our hearts. His four years of naval combat service in World War II shaped and informed his determination to live every moment of every day, and to share with his children and grandchildren both the spirit and optimism with which he faced life, and the respect for the hazard and contingency upon which we all breathe but can never fully understand. We will all miss him terribly. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will be appreciated.

10:12 a.m. | Updated One year after The New York Times Company introduced a pay wall on the Web site of its flagship newspaper, the company said Tuesday it would now require visitors to the site to pay for access after reading 10 free articles, down from the threshold of 20 that was established when the system was initiated. The new policy will take effect in April.

Four former Merce Cunningham company dancers have received fellowships to teach some of the choreographer's works this spring and summer. The fellowships, $6,000 each, represent the latest effort to keep the Cunningham flame alive after his death in 2009 and the company's dissolution last year. The company's successor, the Merce Cunningham Trust, made the announcement on Tuesday, saying that ''pre-professional students'' had auditioned for the chance to take part in workshop rehearsals. A spokeswoman said they would not be paid, and that no performances are scheduled, although they have not been ruled out. ''It's sort of like an educational experience,'' said the spokeswoman, Leah Sandals. Most of the selected dancers are in university programs, she said.

In a deal that could signal the arrival of a prominent new player in digital music, Beats Electronics, the company that has transformed the high-end headphone market with its Beats by Dr. Dre line, is in the process of buying MOG, an online music service. The deal has not closed, but negotiations are in their final stages, according to three people briefed on the deal who were not authorized to speak about it publicly. The price was not known.

FOR the past few years, the Breslin and the John Dory Oyster Bar in the Ace Hotel have made a good case for heading to the largely commercial wedge of Midtown Manhattan between Madison Square and Herald Square. A new restaurant called the NoMad, set to open on Monday in the hotel and the neighborhood of the same name, clinches the argument. The area's cobbled-together nickname (it means North of Madison Square Park) might even stick. Daniel Humm, the chef of Eleven Madison Park, and its manager, Will Guidara, are partners in this hotel restaurant, which is little more than a hop across the park from their home base. With a group of investors last fall, they bought Eleven Madison Park from their boss, Danny Meyer, and his Union Square Hospitality Group. The NoMad, the restaurant project that prompted Mr. Meyer to sell -- he says he did not want to keep Eleven Madison if the two were competing with him at a nearby restaurant -- is the second property for their company, Made Nice.

8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: ONE WORLD The old saying ''no pain, no gain'' will be tested this week as the competition for $1 million continues. (Above, Greg Smith, left, and Jay Byars during an immunity challenge.) With both tribes living on the same site, drama runs high as the tribal council makes an unexpected decision. 1:30 P.M. (Sundance) GRIZZLY MAN (2005) Timothy Treadwell, who spent many of his summers living with and filming grizzly bears in the Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska, below, was killed in a bear attack in 2003, along with his girlfriend, Amie Huguenard. The director Werner Herzog combed through their footage to create this documentary, which casts an unsentimental eye on Treadwell's mission to protect the grizzlies and questions his preparation for life in the wilderness. Interviews with family members and friends shed light on Treadwell's past as an actor who struggled with addiction. And those who last saw him, including the medical examiner who performed his autopsy, depict him as a man who failed to appreciate the power and danger of nature. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Treadwell's adventures with grizzlies amounted to ''a kind of performance, built on lies and truth and played out on the stage of celebrity.'' She added, ''Even though his choices were dangerous and finally fatal, he traveled a familiar American path shaped by boundless optimism and an almost religious belief in the self.''

An article on Thursday about the challenges of raising money for museums named after wealthy patrons misspelled the name of a well-known art museum that Craig Robins, a museum trustee and Miami art collector, said he supported. It is the Hirshhorn, not the Hirschorn.

It was a van Gogh, then it wasn't a van Gogh and now it's a van Gogh again, maybe this time for good. New research has shown that a still life painting of a vase brimming with flowers, bought in 1974 by the Kröller-Müller Museum in the central Netherlands, was executed directly over a painting of two wrestlers that matches a description of an image that a young van Gogh once mentioned in a letter to his brother, Theo, as a work in progress.

Wackiness turned to nastiness and back again in the short but bitter special election in South Brooklyn to replace a state senator who had pleaded guilty to corruption charges. But the biggest twist of the race was its outcome -- or lack thereof when election night ended. With all precincts reporting, according to unofficial results received by the New York City Board of Elections, the Republican upstart candidate, David Storobin, 33, held a tenuous 120-vote lead over Lewis A. Fidler, 55, the Democratic city councilman for the 27th District seat. But there were still at least 757 paper ballots outstanding, and those would not be counted until Tuesday, said Valerie Vazquez, a spokeswoman for the board of elections. The entire legal process, which also will include a random audit and the counting of emergency ballots, could take at least 10 days.

In his performances as Vincent Crabbe in the ''Harry Potter'' movies Jamie Waylett is known for his physical menace and mischief making, but these real-life qualities have seen the actor sentenced to two years in jail for his involvement in the 2011 London riots, BBC News reported. Mr. Waylett, 22, who played the all-around Hogwarts bully Crabbe in six ''Harry Potter'' films, was found guilty of violent disorder during the July riots by a London court on Tuesday, but cleared of intending to destroy or damage property, after video footage showed him holding a gas bomb.

11:54 a.m. | Updated What's in a name? And what's in a code name that a man running for president chooses for himself? Mitt Romney's Secret Service code name is Javelin, Marc Ambinder reports in GQ, an apparent reference to a muscle car produced in the late 1960s and early '70s by American Motors, the company Mr. Romney's father ran.

DAVIES--David L. The American Folk Art Museum mourns the passing of longtime friend and trustee David L. Davies, who served on the board from 1990 to 2010. A celebrated collector, Mr. Davies generously donated important American weathervanes to the museum collection, as well as the iconic c. 1899 "Man on a Bicycle Trade Sign," and Morris Hirshfield's 1945 masterwork "The Artist and His Model." A bon vivant of the old school, Mr. Davies will be deeply missed. Heartfelt sympathies go to his devoted partner, Jack Weeden.

Here is a breakdown on what a Tebow trade could mean for each N.F.L. team. OTTAWA - Glencore International, the Swiss commodities trader, entered the North American agriculture market on Tuesday with a widely anticipated deal to acquire Viterra, the largest Canadian grain company, for $6.2 billion.

Gloria Sachs, a fashion designer who tapped into a growing market of women seeking understated elegance in clothes as they rose to new heights in the workplace in the 1970s and '80s, died on Monday, March 12 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85. Her daughter, Nancy Sachs, confirmed her death.

KNAPP--Miriam H.,a renowned sculptor, died on March 20, 2012, at age 77, after a courageous battle with cancer. She leaves behind her husband of 56 years, Dr. Robert C. Knapp, her children, Louise Iyengar, Jennifer Crawford and Michael Knapp, her grandchildren, Charles, Sarah, Jacob, Benjamin and Roger, and her brother Robert Levy Hermanos. Miriam was born in Paris, France to the late Selma and Maxime Levy Hermanos. She resided in New York City and Palm Beach. She was a graduate of the Dalton School, Bennington College, and Columbia University where she received a Master of Arts in French literature. During her career as a sculptor, Miriam created forms inspired by the figure. Highlights of her career include three large-scale sculptures, called "Hygeia", located at the State University of New York in Brooklyn, the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Palm Beach. Miriam had a passion for ballet since childhood and was a long standing supporter of the Miami City Ballet. She proudly served on the Company's Palm Beach Board of Trustees since 2002 and tirelessly championed the ballet's mission amongst her friends and the community at large. Services will be held Thursday, March 22, 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. In lieu of flowers, her family requests donations be made in her loving memory to Miami City Ballet, 2200 Liberty Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139.

ROCKETT--Laurie R.,died on March 12, 2012 in Valhalla, NY. Wife of the late Fredrick C. Rockett, mother of Nat (Courtney Rohan) and CJ, grandmother of Declan, Patrick and Maclain Rockett, sister of Charles and Jons Rogers and step mother of Grant and Abigail. Mrs. Rockett was raised in Danbury, CT, graduated from Barnard College with Honors in 1964, and from Columbia Law School magna cum laude in 1970. She began her career at the Hudson Institute, but worked most of her life as an attorney in New York City specializing in non-profit corporate advisory and author representation. She was also a pioneer in the field of women's health services and related legal rights. She raised her family in Bronxville, NY and was a resident there until 2010. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church, 180 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY at 2pm on Saturday March 24, 2012.

BEGUELIN--Natalie Pickering died March 15. Mrs. Beguelin was born in New Haven, CT December 10, 1924 to Amy Hyacinth Drury Pickering and Captain Nelson Winslow Pickering. Married for 44 years to the late Dayton Beguelin, she is survived by two sons, Robert Dayton Beguelin, and Winslow Drury Beguelin; daughters-in-law, Susanna Jones and Sarah Pierce Beguelin and six grandchildren. Very active in her community she served on the Boards of the Riverside Drive Association, Visiting Homemakers Association, Monmouth County Organization of Social Services, The Monmouth County Historical Association, where she served as Secretary of the Board. She was also very involved in the Monmouth Conservation Foundation, most recently serving on their Advisory Committee. An avid gardener and flower arranger, Mrs. Beguelin was a member of the Rumson Garden Club where an annual award was created in her honor. A memorial service at St. George's by-the-River, Rumson, NJ will be held this Friday, March 23 at 11:30am. A reception will follow at the Rumson Country Club. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Monmouth County Historical Association.

WELKER--John Ralvan (Ral), of Southampton, NY, died March 13, 2012, at Flagler Hospital in St. Augustine, Fla., surrounded by his family. Ral was one of the founding faculty members establishing the Marine Science Program at Southampton College on Long Island, serving as director of Marine Operations and Research from 1965-1993. The Marine Science Program became world renowned for its excellence. He retired as Professor Emeritus, Marine Science-Biology in 1993. He was greatly honored to receive the 2004 Long Island University Environmental Leadership Award for his lifelong commitment to Southampton College and its Marine Science Program. In his life's work, he impacted the hearts and lives of many, but also made tremendous contributions to the preservation of open space on the East End of Long Island, and the health and quality of many bodies of water, especially the Peconic Bay Estuary System. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Mary Meagher Welker; daughter Ann Elizabeth Welker, sons, William Ralvan Welker, and his wife, Jessica Miller Welker and John Timothy Welker. If anyone wishes to make a contribution in Ral's memory, he had an abiding interest in each of the following: QuogueWildLifeRefuge.org, PeconicLandTrust.org, PeconicBaykeeper.org.

A picture in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday with a report about the guitarist Mick Taylor's performances at the Iridium in Manhattan scheduled for May was published in error. It showed Mick Jones of the Clash, not Mr. Taylor.

Hundreds of leading gay donors will travel to Washington in late April to plan strategies and marshal financial commitments for state and federal elections around the country, according to people with knowledge of the meeting. The conference, one of the largest ever gatherings of gay donors, is being organized by the Gill Action Fund, one of the country's leading gay political organizations, which has played a quiet but pivotal role at the state level in recent years on gay marriage and other issues, including working to defeat lawmakers who oppose gay marriage. The fund is keeping quiet the details of the gathering, hoping to shield potential donors from unwanted scrutiny or attacks from opponents, and a spokesman for the fund declined to comment on the plan on Tuesday.

LAURICELLA--Thomas A. March 16, 2012, age 79, leaves wife Juliet, children Tom & Debby, five grandchildren. Proud of his family, artist, active lifelong in politics. True mensch. Cared deeply about the world and always fought for what he felt right and just. "Ave"

There is no shortage of restaurants along Columbus Avenue in the West 80s where you can pick up or arrange delivery of a pizza, a container of dumplings or some mac and cheese. Still, Nicole Ahronee (above), a former jewelry designer who lives in the neighborhood, felt a need for a market and cafe dedicated to those who enjoy fine dining at home. So on Wednesday, she plans to open Gastronomie 491, offering well-prepared Mediterranean-style food, as well as good cheeses, cured meats, breads, olive oils, spices, dairy products and produce that is often organic. The meats and cheeses are curated by Martin Johnson, who runs The Joy of Cheese, a company that offers classes. The chef, Steven Gutterman, handles the breakfast quiches; lemon-ricotta pancakes; vegetable dishes like chickpea and eggplant tagine; and rotisserie chicken. His inventive array of pan bagnats takes the niçoise sandwich on tour to places like Athens with lamb and feta, and several of his desserts are Middle Eastern.

WORTH--Tobia Lessler. Died at age 88 on Sunday, March 18, 2012 in Bryn Mawr hospital with her family by her side. Tobia was born in NYC on August 22, 1923, and moved to Philadelphia in 1964. She had a passion for life, a love of good things, a brilliant mind and a sharp wit. Beloved wife of the late Sol Worth; loving mother of Debora Worth and mother-in-law of Robert Hymes; adoring grandmother of Saul Hymes and Ilana Harwayne-Gidansky and great-grandmother of Samuel Zev Harwayne-Hymes; devoted sister of Phyllis Schimel; loving aunt of David, Joshua and Elizabeth Schimel and great-aunt of Kate and Anna Schimel and Jacob and Adam Zhu; and cherished friend and colleague of many. She will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held Thursday March 22 at 4pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

Gmail users who cut and paste email messages from the Gmail Web site into text documents for printing may want to try out the optional ''Create a Document'' feature that lets you quickly create a Google Doc from a message. To turn on the ''Create a Document'' option, log into your Gmail account on the Web. Click the gear icon on the right side of the screen and choose Settings form the menu. On the Setting screen, click on the Labs tab and scroll down the list of Available Labs. Click the Enable button next to ''Create a Document'' and click the Save Change button.

A Congressional subcommittee voted on Wednesday to subpoena an MF Global executive at the center of a federal investigation into wrongdoing at the firm. The subpoena came despite Ms. O'Brien's assertion that she would not answer questions from lawmakers; she was expected to invoke her constitutional right against self-incrimination.

MILLER--Dr. Arthur, a physician for 70 years and clinical professor of OB/GYN at NYU Medical School, passed away from natural causes on Monday evening March 19th at the age of 93. He is survived by his wife of 63 years Hope Simon, sons Lane and Lloyd, daughters-in-law Anne and Heather, and granddaughter Ruth. He was preceded in death by his son Scott. Funeral services will be held at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, March 22nd at 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The NYU Langone School of Medicine.

KNAPP--Miriam H.,a renowned sculptor, died on March 20, 2012, at age 77, after a courageous battle with cancer. She leaves behind her husband of 56 years, Dr. Robert C. Knapp, her children, Louise Iyengar, Jennifer Crawford and Michael Knapp, her grandchildren, Charles, Sarah, Jacob, Benjamin and Roger, and her brother Robert Levy Hermanos. Miriam was born in Paris, France to the late Selma and Maxime Levy Hermanos. She resided in New York City and Palm Beach. She was a graduate of the Dalton School, Bennington College, and Columbia University where she received a Master of Arts in French literature. During her career as a sculptor, Miriam created forms inspired by the figure. Highlights of her career include three large-scale sculptures, called "Hygeia", located at the State University of New York in Brooklyn, the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Palm Beach. Miriam had a passion for ballet since childhood and was a long standing supporter of the Miami City Ballet. She proudly served on the Company's Palm Beach Board of Trustees since 2002 and tirelessly championed the ballet's mission amongst her friends and the community at large. Services will be held Thursday, March 22, 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. In lieu of flowers, her family requests donations be made in her loving memory to Miami City Ballet, 2200 Liberty Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139.

Looking at the back of a modern television is like looking at a map of Eastern Europe in the mid-'90s -- it's adapted to work with the older inputs, those features have to stick around for a while. The new ones can be baffling, always in flux. New connectors pop up, rendering older jacks obsolete. But since plenty of devices could be if only because many do the same things as the old connectors. Here's a map to navigating which cables go where.

MAURIELLO--Joseph A.,Ph.D., CPA, Professor Emeritus of Accounting, New York University Graduate School of Business peacefully died at the age of 94 on March 20, 2012. Joe Mauriello was an academic scholar, educator, public accountant, entrepreneur and devoted family man his entire life. Until his death, he presented academic papers at meetings of the American Accounting Association and was completing his seminal work on a Specially Designed Chart of Accounts for Recording and Learning Financial Accounting. He was the author of numerous major accounting textbooks and articles and the recipient of multiple distinguished awards. He was also elected to many honorary scholastic societies. Born to Italian immigrants in 1917, Joe was one of six brothers who grew up in East Orange, NJ. He and his wife, Alba, married in 1944, had three children, and lived in NJ their entire lives. He graduated Summa Cum Laude from the New York University School of Commerce in 1939. Professor Mauriello achieved the highest scholastic average ever attained according to his Profile published in the Accounting Ledger, published in February, 1953, authored by Joseph Silvermintz. Awarded a PhD in accounting in 1944, he quickly rose to the academic rank of Full Professor of Accounting at the New York University Stern School of Business, where he continued to teach for 35 years and subsequently for a number of years Seton Hall University, NJ He also had a full time public accounting practice. Joe Mauriello displayed warmth, charm, generosity of spirit, steadfastness, and an abounding love of nature and music throughout his life. He is survived by his brother, Michael M. Mauriello, two of his three children, Janet M. Simon and Joseph A. Mauriello, Jr., MD, nine grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. His devoted wife, Alba, passed away in 1988 and his oldest daughter Lynda M. Franklin, in 2002. He is also survived by his longtime companion, Dorothy G. Hanscom. A funeral mass will be held 10:00am, Friday, March 23rd at the Church of Christ the King, 16 Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations in memory of Joseph A. Mauriello to: NYU Stern School of Business, Suite 10-53, New York, NY, 10012, 212-998-4161. Services by Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ. To leave the family a message of condolence or for further information, visit www.bradleyfuneralhomes. com.

A NEW breed of social shopping start-ups -- basically online curators of fancy things to buy from all corners of the Web -- has been popping up with head-spinning frequency. There are too many to count, as if all the venture capitalists of the world had collectively responded to an e-mail that promised that you, too, could make $25 an hour just by sitting at home and picking out things for other people to buy. Most follow a basic, low-overhead business plan: A prominent socialite or stylish magazine editor posts links to her favorite looks from online retailers (like Barneys New York, Net-a-Porter or Saks Fifth Avenue), customers buy, the site gets a commission. It may sound like a bubble, but some of the sites are actually worth a browse.

LOEWY--Anneliese, 89, died on March 20, 2012. Beloved wife to the late Paul, devoted mother of Mark (Iwona) and John (Joi), cherished grandmother of Laura, Katheryn and Melania. Anneliese was a tortured survivor of Nazi Germany. She came to the U.S. after WWII, sent for Paul one year later and married. She was the best mother two sons could ever have. Funeral service will be conducted at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Friday March 23 at 2:15pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC, would be deeply appreciated.

8:45 P.M. (Sundance) WORDPLAY (2006) This documentary from Patrick Creadon examines crosswords and the people who love them, highlighting the creations edited by Will Shortz, above, for The New York Times. Puzzle constructors muse on their methods and inspiration, and several notable solvers, including Bill Clinton, Bob Dole and Jon Stewart, discuss their fondness for the puzzles in The Times. The documentary crew also follows competitors at the annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, where a solitary obsession becomes a reason to socialize. 3:45 P.M. (IFC) MORNING LIGHT (2008) The experienced sailors who test their mettle in the Transpacific Yacht Race battle the unpredictable winds of the Pacific Ocean on a thrilling journey to Hawaii from Los Angeles. The race is usually the domain of professionals, but here 15 rookies -- the oldest is 23 -- are followed as they vie for a spot aboard the sloop Morning Light. The director Mark Monroe captures the joy and the struggles of the 11 sailors who make the cut. ''For all its sparkling seascapes and shiny, happy faces,'' Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The Times, '' 'Morning Light' is sunny-side-up filmmaking that sacrifices dramatic focus for generic observations on teamwork and character building.''

For all celebrants of Johann Sebastian Bach's 327th birthday (and all Bach lovers, for that matter), on Wednesday, a record label is offering a promotional gift: nine hours of Bach's music for 99 cents on Amazon, available through Friday. The company, eOne Music - the label formerly known as Koch - says it is selling the downloads to publicize its plans to reissue recordings by the Bach Guild, a label started in 1948 to make the composer's works more widely available. EOne Music said it also planned new recordings. The promotional issue covers 120 tracks, and includes the B minor Mass, harpsichord and flute works, the ''Italian Concerto,'' orchestral suites and the ''Brandenburg'' Concertos. Many of the versions hail from an earlier era of Bach interpretation, before a tendency to reduce the size of choruses and orchestras and play with a sharp eye toward period practice had set in, and they may sound dated to some ears. After Friday, the price goes up to $9.99 on digital retailers, eOne said.

ROBARDS--Lois O'Connor, 75, died peacefully at home in New York City on March 17. Before her marriage in 1970 to actor Jason Robards, she was one of the first women hired in television production at both Talent Associates and Filmways Productions, and worked on shows including Playhouse 90, The Patty Duke Show, Get Smart, The Steve Allen Show, The David Susskind Show, and Good Company with F. Lee Bailey, where the last featured such notable guests as Ernest Hemingway, J. Paul Getty, and Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. In Hollywood she worked with director Sam Peckinpah on films including Noon Wine, where she first met her future husband. Behind the scenes, she was a foundation for Mr. Robards' personal and professional success, which included his iconic roles in Moon for the Misbegotten and All the President's Men. Lois will be remembered for her elegance, intelligence, and above all, generosity. She was devoted to her children, Shannon and Jake, and her large extended family. She was an active supporter of the Westport Country Playhouse, the Brain Tumor Foundation, the American Classical Orchestra, and the Roundabout Theater Company, which gives an award in her husband's name each year. Lois lived in Southport, CT, for 30 years and subsequently in New York City. In addition to her two children, she is survived by four grandchildren and four stepchildren. A funeral mass will be held on Monday, March 26, at 3:00pm at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her name to the American Classical Orchestra or the Inner-City Foundation of Bridgeport, CT.

HUMPHREY--Louise. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Louise Humphrey, who was the first woman to serve as President of our board of directors, a post she held from 1986 to 1991. A board member for 40 years, she became President at a time when effective leadership was crucial, and the Met's success today is in part a tribute to her tireless efforts. She was cheerful, elegant, and indefatigable in her work, and a friend to many artists and backstage staff members. We offer our sincerest condolences to her sons George and Watts, her seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Ann Ziff, Chairman Kevin Kennedy, President Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera

The men of the Fulton Fish Market along South Street did not suffer outsiders gladly. In the early 1980s, however, they warmed to a newcomer from Brooklyn named Barbara Mensch. She was a photographer. She had just moved into an old salting house a block away on Water Street. They let her see the living market in its predawn hours and capture their words and faces: a loader named Philly, a retailer named Heschy, a journeyman named Sweet Pea and a fillet man named Vinny the Bone. What resulted were ''The Last Waterfront: The People of South Street'' (1984) and ''South Street'' (2007), portraits and oral histories collected by Ms. Mensch while the Fulton Fish Market was still vibrant. The fishmongers left for Hunts Point in the Bronx in 2005. Ms. Mensch stayed behind, in a loft she had restored by hand to preserve the large rings on the oak floors left by the brine barrels that once were stored there. Hers is an artist's loft and an artists' loft: the sculptural piping under the sink was installed by an assistant to Mark di Suvero, the desk was created from discarded woodwork by an assistant to Richard Serra.

MINTZ--Walter. Peacefully on March 20th. Lived a wonderful fulfilling 82 years. Survived by his beloved wife, Sandra. Loving father of Richard (Helaine), Peter (Leslie) and Carol (Bill). Cherished grandfather of Jake, Abby, Johanna, Talia, Charlotte, Samantha and Elsa. We will love and remember you always.

HINE--Peter J.,age 58, died March 8, 2012 in Ossining, NY. A transplanted Clevelander, he came to Manhattan in 1976 and later joined the Metropolitan Transit Authority, becoming a senior real estate manager. He was an inveterate booster of his adoptive city, student of its rail systems, and superlative raconteur, giving impromptu tours that often led to abandoned subway stations, rail yards, or private rail cars. He organized a trip on the private NYC3 rail car attached to the last Amtrak train out of Grand Central Station in 1991, and was recently busy with arrangements for the 2013 Grand Central Centennial. He helped the late Peter Obletz save the elevated High Line from destruction, making possible its redevelopment as a pedestrian park. He promoted MTA efforts to turn the long-closed Delancey Street-Essex Street trolley station into an underground park or development. He conducted a lively video tour of the space, explaining how the baseball team Brooklyn has never forgotten was named after the borough's "trolley dodgers," and spotlighted the decrepit dispatch tower as a potential future DJ booth for a nightclub. The video was a smash on YouTube and the New York Observer declared Mr. Hine an "MTA superstar." He was known for irreverent humor and extravagant acts of kindness, including saving a fallen sparrow on Sixth Avenue in 2003, captured in a front-page Times photo showing him balanced precariously on a utility pole returning the chick to its nest. He was born April 4, 1954 in Cleveland, OH, to Jeanne and John Hine. He resided with his family in Pleasantville, NY. He leaves a wife, Diane Diamond, sons Nicholas and Casey, his sister Carol, brothers William and Thomas, nephews William, Robert and Lucas and a niece, Emily.

May Michael's memory forever be a blessing. Richard Altman, CEO Arthur Maslow, President

8:15 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES - Michael Lynton, the chairman and chief executive of Sony's filmed entertainment unit, will soon take charge of the Japan-based company's United States operations in an expanded role as chief executive of Sony Corporation of America, according to people who were briefed on the expected change. Under the realignment, Nicole Seligman, a general counsel and executive vice president of Sony, will add the title president of Sony Corporation of America, those people said. They spoke on condition of anonymity because Sony has not yet formalized the appointments.

From the Olympics to Lincoln Center: A three-play cycle by the major Irish dramatist Tom Murphy will be offered at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer, after performances in Galway, Ireland, and the Cultural Olympiad in London, Lincoln Center said on Wednesday in announcing its 2012 program. The cycle, called DruidMurphy, is being presented by the Druid Theater Company of Galway and is directed by Garry Hynes. It will be the company's third visit to the festival. Other theatrical productions include a Sydney Theater Company presentation of ''Uncle Vanya,'' directed by Tamas Ascher. The cast includes Cate Blanchett. Mikhail Baryshnikov will star in a new play, ''In Paris,'' and Alan Cumming will appear in a one-person production of ''Macbeth'' by the National Theater of Scotland. As previously announced, the Paris Opera Ballet will have a run of performances at the festival. Tao Ye, a modern dance choreographer from China, will bring his company with two works. The festival will celebrate the music of the R&B performer Curtis Mayfield, and John Adams, the composer, will lead the Royal Academy Orchestra of London and the Juilliard Orchestra in a concert that includes the pianist Imogen Cooper as soloist. In addition, the soprano Elizabeth Futral will sing the title role of ''Emilie,'' an opera by the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho and the Lebanese librettist Amin Malouf, which received its first United States performance last spring at the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C.

TOULOUSE, France -- A 23-year-old Frenchman of Algerian descent claimed responsibility on Wednesday for the methodical killings of four men and three children in this region over the past 10 days, officials said, after barricading himself in a small apartment building in Toulouse surrounded by hundreds of police officers. The suspect was identified as Mohammed Merah, 23, a former garage mechanic who had made trips to Afghanistan and Pakistan, and said that he had been trained by Al Qaeda. Mr. Merah remained retrenched in an apartment building in the quiet neighborhood of Côte Pavée into the early hours of Thursday morning, in a standoff that had gone on for nearly a day. Several explosions and gunshots could be heard just before 2 a.m. Thursday, a few hours after three blasts rattled the area in what French news media reported was an attempt to destroy a window at the suspect's apartment, as the police tried to let in the night cold in the hope that Mr. Merah might surrender peacefully.

A federal judge has ordered Joseph F. Skowron, a onetime star hedge fund manager now serving jail time for insider trading, to pay $10.2 million to his former employer, Morgan Stanley. Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that Mr. Skowron, who was a portfolio manager at FrontPoint Partners, which is owned by Morgan Stanley, owed the bank $3.8 million in legal fees as a result of Mr. Skowron's crimes.

In the space of a blog post we couldn't possibly summarize the story to date of R. Kelly's musical serial ''Trapped in the Closet,'' the continuing narrative of a homewrecker named Sylvester; Cathy, the married woman with whom he had an affair; her cuckolded husband, Rufus; and such dramatis personae as Roxanne, Twan, Pimp Lucius and Rosie the Nosy Neighbor. It's 22 chapters long (so far), and boy is it confusing, even if you've seen it. But R. Kelly will have further opportunities to untangle this narrative -- or to complicate it even more -- in a new series of ''Trapped in the Closet'' episodes that have been ordered by the IFC cable channel. IFC said it would begin showing new installments of R. Kelly's ''hip hopera'' later this year, as part of a programming lineup that emphasizes new comedy shows. The channel said it was also ordering a new series tentatively titled ''Maron,'' starring the comedian and podcaster Marc Maron in a fictionalized version of his life, and a new animated program called ''Out There,'' chronicling the lives of three small-town adolescent boys and created by Ryan Quincy, a former animation director for ''South Park.'' Both shows are planned for 2013.

''Next stop Dow 57,757? Don't count on it but Tuesday's bullish session is in the books.'' That dash of market analysis on Twitter wasn't an impromptu thought from an investor. It was a prewritten post, taken from a library of 140-character messages that had been approved by the compliance department of Morgan Stanley and sent out by financial advisers at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney.

The Associated Press, tapping a longtime newspaper executive for one of the pre-eminent jobs in journalism, said late Wednesday that Gary Pruitt would be its next chief executive, succeeding Tom Curley, who is retiring. WE can say it confidently: a trench coat, reimagined with playful new tweaks, is the season's must-have wardrobe essential. Trench tinkering may have begun with Burberry, where Christopher Bailey has subjected its iconic coat to all manner of cheeky transformations. His spring trenches with hand-crafted raffia collars were coveted from the moment they appeared on the runway. Aimee Cho, who designs Gryphon, another label offering modernized trench coats, is of similar mind. ''Sometimes the straightforward version is not enough,'' she said. For spring, Ms. Cho added geometric embroidery to a crinkled khaki coat. Other styles have sequins and studs. ''Sometimes a woman wants more fashion from her reliable basic,'' she said, ''and a trench can be a good blank canvas for doing something fun.'' Clockwise from top left:Erdem cotton trench with houndstooth tweed embroidery, $4,830 at Barneys New York; barneys.com. Dsquared gabardine trench with contrast colors, $1,190 at Saks Fifth Avenue; saksfifthavenue.com. Gryphon embroidered cotton trench, $760 at Bergdorf Goodman; bergdorfgoodman.com. Sonia by Sonia Rykiel leopard-print trench, $630 at Kirna Zabête; kirnazabete.com. Terra New York waterproof trench, $295 at Gap 1969, 513 Broadway; gap.com. Burberry striped trench with raffia collar, $2,995 at Burberry; burberry.com. Topshop trench with camel storm flaps and collar, $250 at Topshop; topshop.com.

Wendy Nichol canteen bags (small, $695; large, $850) at Wendy Nichol, 147 Sullivan Street; (212) 431-4171; wendynicholnyc.com.

As the founders of Houzz.com, Adi Tatarko and Alon Cohen have become the first couple of home renovation. The site grew out of their own difficult renovation of a 1950s ranch house in Palo Alto, Calif. They passed along a few pieces of hard-won wisdom. TAKE A DEEP BREATH Ms. Tatarko and Mr. Cohen have worked together and remodeled together, they said, and remodeling is much harder. Ms. Tatarko suggests new homeowners go slowly and ''live in the house a while before you make decisions. Because you discover many things after you live in the house.''
