Seeking to become the next hip-hop artist turned audiophile, the rapper 50 Cent recently unveiled a line of high-end headphones and accessories from SMS Audio. The line features two styles of headphones, the wired Street by 50 and the wireless Sync by 50, both with a sleek design and a high price: the Sync by 50 headphones will set you back about $400.

An article last Thursday about the growing popularity of mixed martial arts misstated a portion of a cheer that some fans shout during matches and the reason they do so. It is ''Get the mount!,'' not ''mouth,'' and it is shouted for specific moves, not injuries. The article and a picture caption also misstated the surname of a 19-year-old Florida student who is a fan of the sport. He is Chris Groves, not Jones. The article also misstated the number of fights that the Ultimate Fighting Championship, the sport's dominant brand, has a year in the United States. It is about 21, not 15. And because of an editing error, the article also referred incompletely to the U.F.C. title held by Georges St-Pierre. While he is considered the current welterweight champion, an interim champion was determined in a fight in February because Mr. St-Pierre was not able to defend his title because of an injury. (The interim title was won by Carlos Condit; they are expected to face each other in a title fight at a date to be announced.)

In the book ''How to Survive the Titanic'' -- an elegant account of the infamy that hounded J. Bruce Ismay, the chairman of the company that owned the ship, after he fled in a lifeboat -- Frances Wilson writes, ''The need felt by survivors to tell their tales was, from the start, overwhelming and the need of those who were not on board to read their accounts, to see the films, to repeat the experience and work it through, to raise the Titanic and watch her go down again and again is one of the shipwreck's most peculiar effects.'' The centennial of the Titanic disaster is April 14, and publishers appear to be hoping readers maintain an appetite for it. The number of Titanic-related books that have crossed my desk recently borders on the comical. But to dip into almost any of them is to be riveted by a story that remains eerie, dramatic and heartbreaking.

For its latest collection of trays, the Italian housewares company Alessi enlisted the help of eight Chinese architects. ''We're used to working with different industrial designers and cultural backgrounds,'' said Alberto Alessi, the company's managing director, noting that Alessi frequently collaborates with American, European and Japanese designers. ''But we were missing the Chinese, so I thought it was time to extend our scouting.'' The result is (Un)Forbidden City, a line of eight strikingly different trays. Chang Yung Ho of Atelier FCJZ, for instance, created A Lotus Leaf ($240), a stainless steel tray that looks exactly like its name, and Liu Jiakun of Jiakun Architects developed Jane ($410), pictured, a tray made from anodized aluminum sticks that can roll up for storage. Information: (212) 941-7300 or alessi-shop.com.

When Cisco Systems said it would stop making its popular Flip video cameras, it also announced that it would eventually shut down its FlipShare video sharing and storage service. Last May it put a 30-day expiration date on videos and photos stored there. Anything more than 30 days old would be erased. FlipShare gave users a reprieve, never making good on the policy. But 30 days from now it will, partly because it has cut a deal with another site, Givit, where FlipShare users can transfer their videos.

When Senator Barbara A. Mikulski was sworn into the Senate in 1987, there was no ''dean of women'' to mentor female lawmakers. One of two women in the Senate at the time, Ms. Mikulski wasn't even allowed in the Senate gym, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky said Wednesday. The Senate has come pretty far, with 17 women now serving, Mr. McConnell, the minority leader, said.

When you are an essentially immortal being from another planet who can traverse space and time, you don't always pick up on changes great and small. But a momentous transition is coming for ''Doctor Who,'' the popular BBC science-fiction series (shown in the United States on BBC America) and the enigmatic Doctor of its title: in its upcoming season, the Doctor, played by Matt Smith, will get a new companion, to be played by Jenna-Louise Coleman, the show's producers said on Wednesday. Ms. Coleman, a 25-year-old actress who has appeared on the British television series ''Emmerdale'' and ''Waterloo Road,'' will replace Karen Gillan and Arthur Darvill, who have played a married couple, Amy Pond and Rory Williams, who shared in the Doctor's adventures. The BBC said in a statement that Ms. Gillan and Mr. Darvill will ''bow out of the show in a heartbreaking departure after one final series of rollercoaster voyages.''

GAINES--Ludwell Ebersole, Jr.,died peacefully in San Francisco on March 15, 2012. He was known fondly as "Eb" by his wide circle of friends and associates in his government and business careers. He was born April 21, 1927, in West Virginia, educated at the Lawrenceville School and graduated from Princeton University in 1951. He served in the Navy aboard LST 636 between 1944-1946. In his business career, he worked with the American Arbitration Association, Plax Corp. and Continental Can Co. In 1981, Eb was appointed by President Reagan as executive vice president of Overseas Private Investment Corp., an agency of the State Department, and later was appointed by President George H.W. Bush to be American consul general to Bermuda, where he served from 1989 until 1992. In 1956, he married Sheila Kellogg of Libertyville, Ill., and they raised four children while living in New Jersey, Connecticut, Ohio, Illinois and Ketchum, Idaho, before moving to Washington, D.C. Sheila predeceased him in November 1995. Their children, Eb III, Leith, Kelly and Audrey, their respective spouses and three grandchildren, Riley, Chilton and Simmons, survive him, as does his longtime close friend Ann Caen. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, Friday, March 30, 2012 at St. Luke's Church, 1755 Clay St., San Francisco, CA. Reception to follow at the church. Parking will be available.

There have been two Odd Future sagas unfolding over the last year and a half. In full public view this Los Angeles hip-hop collective has become an unlikely mini-juggernaut of the post-record age, creating a significant touring and merchandise business with only the Internet behind it - not radio or video - and redefining narrow ideas about the hip-hop underground. And then there's been Earl Sweatshirt, the most promising rapper in the crew, who was nowhere to be seen, the gaping wound at the center of the body.

The Great Recession may have officially ended in June 2009, but its effects continue to weigh on many aspects of consumers' financial lives. The economy has not fully regained its footing,and many families are still struggling with joblessness, depressed home values and declining wages. But there are some signs of improvement, detailed in the chart below. Not only has the stock market rebounded from the plunge of 2008 to 2009, but it has also increased from the end of July 2006 -- the point at which housing prices peaked. Several other important economic measures have also turned a corner, including consumer confidence.

As consumers use their mobile devices more and more to enjoy music, television and movies, they are facing a capacity crunch as those devices quickly fill up. For instance, I can't fit even half of my iTunes library on my iPhone, and my iPad is near capacity with movies and TV shows. Cloud services from Apple, Amazon and others help alleviate the storage problem, but they come with annual fees. The services from iTunes and Amazon are free for lower capacity storage, but then jump to $25 a year and up.

Local broadcasters, by law, have to disclose the identities of those who buy political advertisements, as well as detailed information about the purchases. They print out the data and store it at their offices for the public to see, theoretically. But few members of the public ever get a chance to. The existence of the so-called public file is little more than a quirk of broadcasting - and the broadcasters seem to prefer that it stay that way.

Samuel Glazer, a co-founder of the company that gave the world Mr. Coffee, one of the first and most popular automatic drip coffee makers to appear on American kitchen counters, died on March 12 in Cleveland. He was 89. The cause was complications of leukemia, his wife, Jeanne, said.

The executive reshuffling and air of uncertainty that have lately dominated Dunder Mifflin are now a behind-the-scenes reality at ''The Office'' as well. Paul Lieberstein, the show runner on that NBC sitcom (who also plays the twitchy human resources officer, Toby Flenderson), is preparing to leave the series to work on an ''Office'' spinoff, The Hollywood Reporter said. The new series would feature Dwight Schrute, the despotic ''Office'' employee played by Rainn Wilson, and though it does not have a debut date NBC is seeking a replacement for Mr. Lieberstein as a growing number of the show's staff members appear to be in flux. James Spader, who joined ''The Office'' in a recurring role this year, will not be back next season; veteran cast members like John Krasinski, Ed Helms and Jenna Fischer have not signed deals for future episodes; and Mindy Kaling, a performer and producer on the show, is preparing a sitcom pilot for Fox.

Undoubtedly with some sense of relief and satisfaction, NBC announced Thursday it would bring back ''Smash'' for a second season. The Broadway-based drama, on which the network lavished attention and promotion, has performed reasonably well in its 10 p.m. Monday slot - and far better than anything NBC has tried in that time period in many years. It is by far the top-rated drama now on NBC.

MIDLAND, Tex. -- The desolate stretch of West Texas desert known as the Permian Basin is still the lonely domain of scurrying roadrunners by day and howling coyotes by night. But the roar of scores of new oil rigs and the distinctive acrid fumes of drilling equipment are unmistakable signs that crude is gushing again. And not just here. Across the country, the oil and gas industry is vastly increasing production, reversing two decades of decline. Using new technology and spurred by rising oil prices since the mid-2000s, the industry is extracting millions of barrels more a week, from the deepest waters of the Gulf of Mexico to the prairies of North Dakota.

An article on March 3 about Rick Santorum's wooing Ohio voters ahead of the Super Tuesday nominating contests referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of voters in Washington State. There are about 3.7 million registered voters -- not that many registered Republicans. (Voters in Washington State do not register by party.)

SEEKING ACTION Barney Frank, below, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the co-author of the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory overhaul, is questioning how regulators will enforce a central provision in his law. In a statement on Thursday, Mr. Frank said that regulators should swiftly complete and simplify the so-called Volcker Rule, which bars banks from trading for their own account, rather than for clients. BEN PROTESS

After a six-month search for a new artistic director, the Royal Shakespeare Company has chosen Gregory Doran, who has been affiliated with the ensemble, first as an actor and then as a stage director, since 1987. Mr. Doran has also written three Shakespeare-themed books, including the ''Shakespeare Almanac'' in 2009, and contributed to several programs about Shakespeare for the BBC and the British Library, activities that were cited Thursday in the formal announcement of his selection. Most recently, Mr. Doran has been the company's chief associate director, though he has also directed other works for companies in Britain and elsewhere. He will succeed Michael Boyd, who announced in September that he and Vikki Heywood, the company's executive director, would step down in September of this year.

The series premiere of ''Bent'' on NBC could only muster 2.6 million viewers. In the 18-to-49 category, it was NBC's lowest-rated in-season comedy premiere ever. Meanwhile, it was business as usual for ''American Idol'' on Fox: dominant in all ratings categories in comparison to the other broadcast network offerings and yet its own numbers fell once again. The singing show averaged 16.6 million total viewers - down from 18.4 million last week - to go with a 9 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

5:12 p.m. | Updated Etch A Sketch, a toy known to generations of children, makes it easy to wipe away the past. There is an investor who might wish he or she could use it to void a trade made Thursday. Ohio Art, the maker of Etch A Sketch, used to be a public company, but it took advantage of a provision in the law to force most public shareholders to go away. Now it rarely trades on the over-the-counter market, and it no longer files public disclosures with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MAYERSON--Manuel D. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family mourns the death of Manuel Mayerson, z"l, innovative business leader and philanthropist. A devoted member of our Board Governors, he was devoted to perpetuating the values, teaching and ethics of Judaism. His wide ranging generosity spanned the Jewish and secular world as well as causes in the United States and Israel. His love of Torah and Jewish learning and his deep devotion to his family were manifested in all his endeavors. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife, Rhoda, and their children and grandchildren. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Irwin Engelman, Chairman Board of Governors

Bank of America said Thursday that it would offer a small number of customers facing foreclosure the option to remain in their homes and rent the property instead. The program highlights how investors are increasingly interested in becoming landlords on troubled properties. Under the terms of the pilot program, which will be offered initially to about 1,000 consumers only in New York, Nevada and Arizona, homeowners will give up the title to their property in exchange for bank forgiveness of their mortgage debt. They would then be able to rent the property for up to three years.

KINGSBURY--Peggy, Died March 21st in Greenport, NY. Right from the start, there was something special about Peggy. She was born on July 4, 1938, in German-occupied Vienna, and grew up all over the world. She and her adoring husband Jim, who were married for 50 years, had three children, Anne, Heather and James, Jr. After they were born, she got a masters in Urban Affairs and Policy Analysis from the New School and worked as deputy director of the city's Office of Management and Budget under Mayor Ed Koch. She later ran her own conference-planning firm, then earned her MSW from Smith College. She was a natural at being in charge. She loved the beach at Point O'Woods where she and Jim built a house, and she took great pleasure and pride in their five grandchildren. The service is Sunday, March 25, 2pm at Holy Trinity Church in Greenport. In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Church at Point O' Woods and CAST, Inc., Southold, NY.

DALY--Margaret (Maggie), 91, at home Fairfield, CT, March 20. Her many accomplishments included Broadway actress at age 22, founder and director for 20 years of a Fairfield landscape design firm and an honored personal gardener. Sanford Miller Jr., Blair Miller, Deirdre M. Daly, and Michael W. Daly. Funeral service, Saturday March 24, 10am Cathedral of St. Augustine, 359 Washington Avenue, Bridgeport, CT.

ST. LOUIS - North Carolina's standout point guard Kendall Marshall (right wrist surgery) did not practice Thursday and still does not know if he can play against Ohio in the Round of 16 on Friday night. The left-handed Marshall broke the scaphoid bone in his right wrist in Carolina's rugged 87-73 victory over Creighton on Sunday in the third round. He underwent surgery to insert a screw Monday and had his cast removed Wednesday. Marshall said the wrist still hurt but continued to improve, though he had not dribbled or shot a ball since Sunday.

After reading about Tesla Motors' new electric sedan three years ago, Rob Stelling drove 100 miles to the carmaker's showroom in Menlo Park, Calif., and put down $40,000 in cash to make an early reservation for the Model S. ''It took them 20 minutes to count it,'' said Mr. Stelling, a clinical laboratory scientist from St. Helena, Calif., who expects the car to be delivered this summer. ''Tesla's the only company that makes a premium, no-compromise electric car.''

In 2008 Dubai announced plans to build a series of cultural projects including libraries, theaters, museums and an opera house. But when the global economic crisis hit that year, the projects stalled. Now, despite its continued economic woes, including debt that is believed to exceed $100 billion, the government of Dubai has announced that it plans to build an opera house and a modern art museum after all, according to Agence France-Presse.

POLANSKY--Susan. A beautiful light has been dimmed. You will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to Harris, Michelle and Tracey and your beautiful grandchildren. You have provided such wonderful moments to our lives. Barbara and Phillip

The American International Group said on Thursday that it had repaid an additional $1.5 billion owed to the Treasury Department, further reducing the bailed-out insurer's government lifeline. Under the terms of this latest agreement, A.I.G. paid off preferred shares that the government owned in a special entity that holds shares in the AIA Group, an Asian insurer spun off in the fall of 2010.

A construction worker died Thursday after a century-old, two-story warehouse under demolition as part of Columbia University's expansion collapsed in a hail of concrete, bricks and steel that engulfed three workers. Cries for help could be heard as firefighters and other rescuers converged on the crushed remains of the building at 604-606 West 131st Street in West Harlem and began picking through the rubble to free the three workers who were trapped.

8 P.M. (NBC) WHO DO YOU THINK YOU ARE? Each week on this series a celebrity embarks on a personal genealogical journey. In this installment Helen Hunt (above, with Prof. Marc Dollinger) sets out to learn more about her paternal ancestors, a side of the family whose history had been largely forgotten. Ms. Hunt's search leads to some surprising discoveries, including the revelation that her great-great-grandfather helped to start Wells Fargo and that her great-great-grandmother was a pioneering women's rights activist. 11 A.M. (FLIX) CELEBRITY (1998) This Woody Allen film pokes fun at celebrities by wondering what they ever did to attain their status and what they do to keep it. Mr. Allen's avatar in this film is the neurotic writer Lee Simon (Kenneth Branagh), a struggling celebrity journalist who keeps brushing up against fame without having it rub off on him. His ex-wife, Robin (Judy Davis), finds her star rising when a romance with a television producer leads to a gig in the spotlight. Leonardo DiCaprio, Melanie Griffith and Charlize Theron all make appearances. But the film, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, ''has plenty of opportunity to bog down between star turns.''
A music review last Friday about a performance by the ensemble L'Arpeggiata, at Zankel Hall in Manhattan, misstated the given name of the double bass player. He is Boris Schmidt, not Bruno.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Thursday about the Rangers' 2-1 overtime victory over the Detroit Red Wings misstated the surname of the player who assisted on Ryan Callahan's winning goal. He is Michael Del Zotto, not Zotto.

Steven Millhauser won the Story Prize on Wednesday for his collection ''We Others,'' a book that the judges called ''a powerful and intriguing collection of stories, marked by page after page of beautifully written, intelligent and sensitive prose.'' The award, which is given annually to the author of an outstanding collection of short fiction, is accompanied by a $20,000 prize. Mr. Millhauser, who teaches at Skidmore College, is the author of several short story collections and seven novels, including ''Martin Dressler,'' for which he won a Pulitzer Prize in 1997. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
MARTIN--Sebastian J.,Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sebastian J. Martin, Jr. associated with The New York Times from November 1, 1971 until retiring on August 1, 1989.

ROBARDS--Lois O. With great sadness we mourn the passing of our cherished friend, Lois Robards. Lois was a kind, loving, generous, classy and beautiful woman who will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt condolence to the entire family. Michael S. Shedler, CPA Shedler & Cohen, LLP

Because of editing errors, an article on Thursday about the admission by a gunman in Toulouse, France, that he was responsible for the methodical killing of seven people in the region over the last 10 days misstated at one point, and in some editions, the number of children killed and the location of funeral services for three soldiers who were among those who died. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, three children -- not four -- died and the funerals were held in Montauban, not in Toulouse. Also because of an editing error, the article omitted the given name of the French interior minister, who insisted that the killing of the soldiers was not linked to their ethnic backgrounds. He is Claude Guéant.
Amid a challenging time in the legal industry, a growing chorus of law-school graduates are bemoaning the lack of job opportunities. One judge does not want them complaining in his courtroom.

YATSU--Dr. Frank M.,79, died unexpectedly but peacefully March 9, 2012 at home, leaving devoted wife of 56 years, Michiko; loving daughter Libby (Ben); grandchildren Katie, Sophia. Born 1932 Los Angeles. Graduated Phillips Academy, Brown University, CWRU, Neurological Institute of New York. Career at UCSF, Chairs of Neurology at Oregon HSC and UTHSC, Houston. Over 25 years, as one of New York's official photographers of mayors, Ed Reed has shadowed four. They have struck contrasting poses and projected divergent personalities. He has photographed them from every angle. But he is the kind of guy who doesn't volunteer a negative word about any of them. ''I never see their bad sides,'' Mr. Reed said.

NUSSBAUM--Adolph (Eddie). We are deeply saddened with the passing of Eddie Nussbaum, a brilliant man who had an incredible journey through life. He was a loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather who will be sorely missed. We want to extend our deepest sympathy to our dearest friends David, Sandi and family. We are blessed to have known Eddie and know this world is a better place because of him. Jane, Stanley, Robyn, Margot and Ron

A previously unpublished novella by Kurt Vonnegut will be released on Friday by RosettaBooks, close to 60 years after it was written, the publisher said on Thursday. The 22,000-word novella, ''Basic Training,'' was rejected by the Saturday Evening Post in the late 1940's, long before Mr. Vonnegut had become famous through works such as ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' and ''Cat's Cradle.'' After Mr. Vonnegut died in 2007, a trove of his unpublished work remained in Indiana, where he was born. RosettaBooks chose the novella from hundreds of other works that Mr. Vonnegut's literary executor had made available. A statement by RosettaBooks described the novella as a book that demonstrates Mr. Vonnegut's ''trademark grand themes: the lunacy of kings, the improbability of existence, the yearling hero's struggle with duty and love and the meaning of heroism.''

The European Commission said Friday that it had moved into the second phase of its review of Universal's $1.9 billion bid for the recorded-music division of EMI, a move that was expected but could still cause problems for the Universal Music Group. Acting on the last day of its self-imposed deadline, the commission said it would begin an in-depth investigation of the deal and the effect that the consolidation could have on the music market. Universal, already the largest music company in the world, would control about 40 percent of the global market as a result of the deal, and in some European countries the proportion could be greater than 50 percent.

Two days after the N.F.L. suspended him for the 2012 season, New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton issued a statement Friday in which he never used the word ''bounty'' while saying that he was sorry ''for what has happened.'' Payton will lose about $6 million in salary, and his suspension starts April 1. Before that, he, General Manager Mickey Loomis -- who has been suspended eight games -- and the owner Tom Benson must select an interim head coach.

Record Store Day, the annual retail promotion started in 2008 to help struggling independent record stores, has to a great degree been about the fetish of collecting vinyl records. If you're interested in that Pavement or Big Star record available only on that day you better get in line early, because there may be 500 collectors ahead of you trying to get one of the 300 copies available (and then put it on eBay). This year's Record Store Day is April 21, and it continues an odd trend in that fetishization. For true believers it's no longer enough simply to buy a 33 1/3- or 45-rpm record; the only way to go is 78. Yes, 10-inch records playing at 78 revolutions per minute, a format that was largely extinct by 1960.

LONDON - Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of the Swiss financial giant Credit Suisse, experience a 54 percent cut in his compensation last year after the firm reported its first quarterly loss in three years. Mr. Dougan received a pay package worth 5.8 million Swiss francs ($6.4 million), including a 2.5 million franc salary and Credit Suisse shares worth 3 million francs, according to the company's annual reported published on Friday. His total compensation package in 2010 was 12.8 million francs.

MITCHELL--Ruth Sterling. January 29, 1916 - March 23, 2012. Ruth Sterling Mitchell passed away peacefully in her home in Cliffside Park, NJ. She was 96. Born in New York City, she was the daughter of Fannie and Edward Marshall. She is survived by her daughter, Doreen Sterling, son-in-law, Ben Smith, grandchildren, Sarah and Jonathan Lim and Abigail Smith, nephew Lance Halperin and great-nephews David and Josh Halperin. She was predeceased by her sister, Rose Trepel and husbands, Paul Sterling and Stanley Mitchell. She was involved throughout her life in the business world. She started out as an executive secretary to a large real estate corporation in Manhattan. Later, she became part owner in Trepel Flowers where she managed the business. After the death of her husband, Paul Sterling, she took over the management of his business, Dependable Newspaper Delivery, in Manhattan where she worked until her 80s. Service Sunday, March 25, 2012 11:30am at Gutterman and Musicant Hackensack, NJ. Family will return to Ruth's residence after the Funeral.

When Todd W. Goings travels from his home in Ohio to tend to his patients in New York City, he knows he faces a heavy lift. Many are centenarians, with creaky limbs, unsteady gaits and wan complexions. Some are missing their tails. Mr. Goings is a carousel doctor. His latest house call was to the merry-go-round in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, which turns 100 this year. He was there the other day bent over a wooden horse, carefully repairing damage to its belly with dowels and glue. It was among 10 horses that needed a tune-up before the carousel reopens for the season on March 31.

Drew Stanton's tenure as Mark Sanchez's backup lasted precisely one week, and it was a successful turn. He did not throw an incompletion or turn the ball over or create locker-room disharmony. For his troubles he received a nice consolation prize: a $500,000 signing bonus. After acquiring Tim Tebow, the Jets were left with little choice but to trade Stanton on Friday. He was sent to Indianapolis in a move that completes a bizarre quarterback circle that began two weeks ago, with the Colts' release of Peyton Manning. When he signed with Denver, Tebow, whom the Jets will introduce at a news conference Monday afternoon, became expendable.

And the money came rolling in: ''The Hunger Games'' took in about $19.7 million at 12:01 a.m. shows on Friday - the highest midnight screenings total ever for a nonsequel, not accounting for inflation, according to Paul Dergarabedian, a box office analyst for Hollywood.com. ''The Hunger Games,'' Lionsgate's PG-13 movie adaptation of Suzanne Collins's best-selling novel, ranked seventh on Mr. Dergarabedian's overall list of ''top midnight and preview screenings,'' with only movies from the Twilight and Harry Potter franchises performing better. (No. 1 on the list with $43.5 million in midnight sales is ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2.'')

As taglines go, ''All of the above'' is not exactly phenomenal, lacking the sex appeal of its energy-policy sister, ''Drill, baby, drill,'' and the historic resonance of, say, ''Where's the beef?'' It conjures a standardized test more than economic stimulus. -But President Obama's use of the phrase to describe his current energy policy leanings - signaling yes to a combination of domestic drilling, alternative energy and conservation -- is driving Republicans nuts, because the phrase has been a product of their party's energy platform for years.

Despite recent improvements in the economy, Americans are divided about whether the upswing will continue for the rest of this year, In fact, Americans are split about evenly, a new survey shows. About half of those surveyed are confident that the recovery will last through 2012, and half are not, according to Bankrate's Financial Security Index survey for March.

A small Atlanta aid organization that works mainly in North Korea wants to bring an orchestra from the isolated dictatorship to the United States, but comments from the State Department indicate that it won't be happening soon. A State Department press official on Friday referred all questions on the proposed tour to the organization, Global Resource Services, but when asked if the United States government would approve such a visit responded, ''Decisions regarding North Korean visits to the U.S. are made in the context of the overall relationship.'' And that relationship has turned sour for now with North Korea's announcement a week ago that it would launch a rocket next month to release a satellite, which is in violation of United Nations resolutions and an agreement last month with Washington.

The stock market claimed an unlikely victim on Friday: one of its own. Just as its shares started selling to the public for the first time, BATS Global Markets, one of the nation's newest and largest electronic exchanges, halted trading on its own stock, after a series of technical glitches and errors in its system that also affected the shares of Apple and other companies.

An article on Thursday about the increasing calls for the resignation of Nancy G. Brinker, the founder and chief executive of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, the breast cancer charity, misidentified, in some copies, the Web site where more than 1,000 people have signed a petition calling for her to step down. It is change.org, not change.com.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about NBC's renewal of the show ''Smash'' for a second season carried an erroneous credit. It was by Bill Carter, not by Noam Cohen.

She was the widow of the late Bay Area author and fellow psychoanalyst, Allen Wheelis MD. Joan Wheelis MD joan.wheelis@twobrattle.com

Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has put more distance between the theater and the monologist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' which just finished a hugely successful run at the Public. In remarks offered Thursday night before a panel discussion on the fallout from the revelations, Mr. Eustis was more critical of Mr. Daisey than he had been after the radio show ''This American Life'' first disclosed that incidents recounted in the stage production, about Apple's labor practices in China, had been invented or embellished. The radio show had run a lengthy excerpt of ''The Agony and the Ecstasy,'' only to retract it after discovering the inaccuracies.

In this weekend's Your Money column, I look at the many insurance questions that come up about the burgeoning peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. The basic question is this: If you turn your car into a Zipcar, in effect, what are the odds that you could end up in some sort of trouble if someone rents your car and then crashes it and hurts someone? I raise three questions in the piece. First, whether you could be on the hook for an enormous judgment, beyond the $1 million in coverage that a company like RelayRides provides. Second, whether your failure to maintain the car properly could leave you exposed if someone rents it and gets in an accident because of, say, your bald tires.
If I had a son, he'd look like Trayvon. PRESIDENT OBAMA, on the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, 17, in Florida [A1].

St. Augustine Church in the Bronx long sat atop a slight hill, like a beacon to the surrounding African-American community for whom it was home and haven. Today, the cavernous church is silent, closed down earlier this year after mounting costs and dwindling resources. Yet its spiritual life persists - face it, prayerful resolve is a special gift in Morrisania. Most of the parish's 300 members now trek a mile away to Our Lady of Victory. Others staff the food pantry, which feeds more than 400 people each week. And a core of devoted church ladies still gathers at a small chapel for weekly Bible study.

The Acquavella Family and Acquavella Galleries

More than a month ago, the federal government and 49 states announced a $25 billion settlement with the five biggest mortgage servicers to provide help to borrowers who lost their home in a foreclosure or who are having trouble making their mortgage payments. Many details of the settlement are still being worked out. But the Center for Responsible Lending, a nonprofit group that advocates for borrowers, has published a summary and a preliminary guidebook to help consumers figure out if they may be eligible for help under the settlement.

Consider the competition slate for the Cannes Film Festival officially scrambled. Or, you know, maybe not: on Thursday, Warner Brothers announced that it was preparing a third installment in the ''Hangover'' series, its bawdy, billion-dollar grossing comedy franchise about three friends whose travels invariably result in collective memory loss followed by farcical efforts to retrace their troublemaking steps. Warner Brothers said in a news release that the series stars Bradley Cooper, Ed Helms and Zach Galifianakis would reprise their roles as the three friends, Phil, Stu and Alan, in ''The Hangover Part III,'' which is planned for release on May 24, 2013. Todd Phillips, who directed the two previous films, is once again on board as director. He will also produce ''Part III'' and write the script with Craig Mazin, his screenwriting collaborator on ''Part II.''

YATSU--Dr. Frank M.,79, died unexpectedly but peacefully March 9, 2012 at home, leaving devoted wife of 56 years, Michiko; loving daughter Libby (Ben); grandchildren Katie, Sophia. Born 1932 Los Angeles. Graduated Phillips Academy, Brown University, CWRU, Neurological Institute of New York. Career at UCSF, Chairs of Neurology at Oregon HSC and UTHSC, Houston. World renowned Neurologist, leader in stroke awareness. Memorial services: Rothko Chapel, Houston, Sunday, March 25, 1pm. Visit Frank's website: www.earthmanbellaire.com

A cover article this weekend about the Argentine actress Elena Roger, who is starring in a Broadway revival of ''Evita,'' misstates her age and misquotes her when she refers to a song from the show ''What's New, Buenos Aires?'' She is 37, not 39. And in quoting the lyrics during an interview, Ms. Roger correctly said, ''Rio de la Plata, Florida, Corrientes, Nueve de Julio.'' -- not ''Rio de la Plata, Florida, Nuevo de Corrientes.'' Because of an editing error, the article also misidentifies the actress who originated the role of Fantine in the Broadway production of ''Les Misérables.'' She is Randy Graff, not Patti LuPone.

SUTNER--Robert F. May 16, 1930-March 22, 2012. Robert Sutner, 81, of Irvington, died peacefully on Thursday night in White Plains Hospital surrounded by his children. He was an Army veteran of the Korean War era. He earned an MBA from Baruch College and attended the London School of Economics. He later lived in and worked in the financial services industry in Europe, Mexico, Canada and in Manhattan. His wife, Charlotte, died in 1995. He leaves his beloved partner of 15 years, Karen Ganz, of Irvington; four children, Adam, of Vail, CO, Arianne, of Portland, OR, Joshua, of Vail, and Shaun, of Worcester, MA; four grandchildren; and Karen's children, David, of Montclair, NJ, and Beth, of Denver. The funeral service is Sunday, March 25 at 9:45am, at Riverside Chapel, 21 Broad Street West, Mount Vernon, NY. Burial is at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation or other charities.

Six partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf resigned on Friday, the latest in a series of defections at the embattled New York law firm. The lawyers, who are leaving to join Sutherland Asbill & Brennan, focus on insurance regulation and advise on corporate transactions involving insurance companies.
